HEADLINE: For an Avant-Garde Center, An End and a Beginning

BYLINE: By DULCIE LEIMBACH 

 BODY:
Martha Wilson was sitting in her sister's kitchen in Olympia, Wash., two summers ago when she experienced an epiphany. That is how Ms. Wilson, the founding director of Franklin Furnace, the performance art and gallery space in TriBeCa, recalls the moment. She was looking out the kitchen window at Mount Rainier, which had the effect of "centering" her, she said. Then it hit her: she was about to embark upon renovating the 19th-century Italianate Franklin Furnace loft space, but renovation was not what she wanted the gallery to be remembered for.
"I realized the money was going toward something that had no future," she said. "I wanted to kill myself." 
 What she wanted Franklin Furnace to be remembered for, she suddenly knew, was its success at championing art -- artists' books, performance art -- overlooked by mainstream institutions. "I knew I had to come up with something," she said recently about her Olympian moment, and it meant new plans.
If she has used this anecdote frequently in the last year to justify to friends, artists and foundations her decision to close Franklin Furnace, to put its 20-year history into an electronic archive and to go on line with live performance art next spring, Ms. Wilson is not ashamed. After all, it is an anecdote that proves she can operate both in the then and in the now.
Ms. Wilson is no stranger to risk-taking. You see it in her appearance: orange-red spiky hair. ("I love being called Red on the street," she said.) In her personal life: she gave birth to her only child, Comly, eight years ago, when she was 41, with no expectations of marrying the boy's father. And in what she has accomplished in the arts.
Through Franklin Furnace, she has nurtured the artists Willie Cole, Jenny Holzer, Barbara Kruger and Ida Applebroog, among others, and introduced Eric Bogosian, Karen Finley, Annie Sprinkle and Paul Zaloom to the New York City performance art scene.
Ms. Wilson describes her next big risk by borrowing a line from her friend and fellow performance artist Spalding Gray: "Life boils down to getting the next hot dog."
To get her next hot dog, she is selling the Franklin Furnace loft space in TriBeCa for nearly $500,000. With that money, she will meet a challenge grant from the National Endowment for the Arts and begin archiving the reams of Franklin Furnace material, about 25,000 slides and hundreds of videos, which will tell the story of the last 20 years in the world of avant-garde art.
Other Government and private grants for her archiving have given her a big cushion. Indeed, after she pays off the mortgage at Franklin Furnace, hers will be, she said, "the only in-your-face arts organization with a cash reserve."
The paradox of having these grants is not lost on her. "They've been hammering at me for years," she said, referring to Government agencies. And now they have given her money to preserve the very activities that might have contributed to the arts endowment's undoing.
Who will want information on the history of Franklin Furnace? Documentary filmmakers, schools, electronic and print publishers, critics, Ms. Wilson said. "I get inquiries every day for the Karen Finley material," she said, referring to slides and tapes of the performance artist's work.
By looking at the last 20 years, the public can see that performance art didn't operate in a vacuum. "It tells the story of AIDS, feminism and Government financing," she said. "It's a social lens on the value of performance art in politics and economics."
Ms. Wilson's enthusiasm gives way to regret when she discusses actually closing Franklin Furnace. "My installation artists are unhappy," she said, but she had to face the fact that free-standing arts organizations can no longer pay their expenses.
Ms. Wilson, who was born in Philadelphia in 1947, attended Wilmington College in Wilmington, Ohio, and did graduate work in English literature at Dalhousie University in Halifax, Nova Scotia. In the mid-1970's, after teaching English to the art students at the Nova Scotia College of Art and Design, she came to New York, where she opened Franklin Furnace in 1976. From the beginning, the gallery, a former chandlery, was shaped to realize her ambition to meld the two worlds of art and words she had always longed to inhabit.
A performance artist whose impersonations of Barbara Bush and Nancy Reagan are legendary, she is also subject to bouts of sentimentality. "When I first started Franklin Furnace, we were all groping in a fog," she said, tears collecting in her eyes. "We had potlucks there; I lived on the mezzanine; my kitchen was in the back. And there was this hole in the art world, no one else was collecting artists' books."
So she did, and subsequently sold the collection to the Museum of Modern Art for $350,000, about the same amount, she said, it cost the gallery to preserve and catalogue the books. "But now artists are terrified," she said. "There is no support."
No wonder, then, that the World Wide Web seems to be performance art's savior. The computer screen can be used as a backdrop to provide far more variety, innovation and dimension to performances than was possible at Franklin Furnace, and with the Web, Ms. Wilson can do what she does best: cultivate talent, explore a new medium and go beyond the mainstream.
Cathay Che, a young performance artist who has appeared in New York at P.S. 122 and Exit Art, is eager to leap onto Ms. Wilson's Web bandwagon. "I like the stop-motion of cyber," she said. "It gives everything a science fiction feel."
More experienced performance artists are more circumspect. "I expect diversity in the medium just as in the others," Ms. Finley said. "And the reality is, do I have any other choice?"
Ms. Wilson plans to pair unknown artists with well-established or prominent ones, like Laurie Anderson. Their performances will be cybercast from Thinking Pictures, a studio and multimedia company in Chelsea that is already producing live rock group performances at http://www.rock.com. (These can be seen on computers equipped with cable modems and broad-band lines.)
Live performance on the Web is not new, but the necessary technical skills and production equipment are still out of reach for many arts groups. At this stage, too, the technology is imperfect: frames move robotically, and audio and visual components need to mesh better.
Exit Art, the SoHo gallery, used the Internet last year for broadcasting live theater performances inside its space. "We got responses from all over the world," said Jeanette Ingberman, the co-founder and director.
Right now, the Web's strongest feature is its air of great expectations. "The Web will introduce a new dimension to performance art," said John Hanhardt, the senior curator for film and media arts at the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. "You have to develop your languages, your understanding of the medium, how it affects your performance, how you see it, how it moves. This is where I wait and see what artists will do with it."
"Martha's idea of taking so much a part of performance art history and putting into a digital archive will make it available to artists who should know that history," he added. "Scholars and critics should know that history, too."
Ms. Wilson, of course, has gone beyond waiting, but she can't help feeling ambivalent about shutting down the Furnace. If only, she seems to want to say, the art world were more appreciative of what she did. Her voice ringing with pain, she added, "Not every artist realizes the debts we paid."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Martha Wilson, the founder of Franklin Furnace, with posters of its presentations. (Jack Manning/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Pay Attention

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
In mid-July a Saudi Arabian aircraft secretly took off from Syria for Saudi Arabia, carrying one passenger and several guards. And therein lies an intriguing tale of shifting geopolitics in the Middle East.
The passenger, a Saudi Shiite Muslim code-named "Khassab," was one of five key suspects initially sought by Saudi Arabia for the June 25, 1996, bombing of the U.S. Khobar Towers barracks in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, which left 19 Americans dead. Of those five suspects, Jaafar Chueikhat "committed suicide" in a Syrian prison; Hani al-Sayegh fled to Canada and has been turned over to the U.S.; and Ahmed al-Mughassil and Ali al-Khuri remain at large, suspected of being in Iran. Khassab was apparently tracked down by the Syrians in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Officials familiar with the inner workings in Syria (which initially resisted helping the Saudis) say the Syrians simply telephoned the Saudis one day and told them to send a plane, because they had "someone" for them. Presto: a key suspect was handed over. 
 Pay attention to this newfound Syrian cooperation: The Syrians' arrest of Khassab followed by just a few weeks a visit to Syria by Saudi Arabia's Crown Prince Abdullah. Abdullah has always been the most pro-Syrian of the Saudi leaders and he had been embarrassed at home by Syria's lack of cooperation on Khobar. In late June, Abdullah spent a week in Syria and Lebanon, accompanied by a 172-member official delegation.
The Saudis have apparently decided to deal with Khobar in their own, Middle Eastern way. The Saudis seem to feel that by leaking information from their own investigation that points to a possible Iranian involvement in Khobar they have effectively deterred Iran from mounting any more mischief in Saudi Arabia. The Iranians are on notice that anything that goes "boom" in Saudi Arabia will now be blamed on them. That is all the deterrence the Saudis need or want. The last thing the Saudis desire now is for the U.S. to start shooting up Iran, with Saudi Arabia then left to deal with Iran's wrath. I believe the Saudis don't trust the U.S. to handle Iran or Syria, so they are doing it their own way. Through quiet diplomacy the Saudis are getting Syria to roll up the anti-Saudi forces in Lebanon, and they have signaled Iran's new President, Mohammed Khatami, that they are ready to have good relations with him, if he reciprocates. If not, the Saudis can always summon the U.S.
The Syrians are using their rapprochement with Saudi Arabia to help construct a new regional coalition. In the wake of the U.S.-led victory over Iraq in the gulf war a de facto "American coalition" arose in the Middle East, comprising Israel, Turkey, Egypt, Jordan, Saudi Arabia, Qatar, Morocco and Kuwait. This American coalition was going to settle the Arab-Israeli conflict, forge a new Middle East economic order and establish a regional system in which the U.S. and its friends were predominant. The attack on U.S. troops at Khobar was an attack by one (or several) of those parties left out of the U.S. coalition -- Iran, Iraq, Syria, Hezbollah or Islamic Jihad -- in order to halt its momentum.
In many ways, it worked. Those who want to deconstruct American dominance are now on the rise, energized by the collapse of the peace process, a new regime in Iran ready to have better Arab relations and the chilling aftermath of Khobar. So Syria has patched up ties with Saudi Arabia, Syria is pressing for a new Arab summit with Iraq included, Syria has reopened trade and borders with Iraq, and President Hafez al-Assad, who rarely travels, recently visited Iran, where he mediated between Iran and Saudi Arabia. The Syrian goal is to blunt U.S.-Israeli pressure to make peace on their terms and to counter a growing Israel-Turkey alliance.
The symbol of the American coalition has been the annual Middle East economic summit, held for the past three years, at which Israelis, Americans and Arabs mix openly and cut deals in an Arab capital. Syria has been trying to organize a boycott of this year's economic summit set for Doha, Qatar, in late November, and as part of the Saudi-Syrian rapprochement, the Saudis will likely join that boycott. By coincidence, an Islamic summit is set to be held Dec. 9, just after Doha, and it will be interesting to see how many Arab leaders attend that, instead of Doha.
That Islamic summit will be held in Teheran.

HEADLINE: New Voice in Drug Debate Seeks to Lower the Volume;
Group Calls for Moderation and Pragmatism

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER S. WREN 

 BODY:
When Robert MacCoun, a psychologist at the University of California at Berkeley, set out to analyze American perceptions about illegal drug use, he found himself treading a political minefield.
"I was stunned at how emotional the debate is," Professor MacCoun said. "The emotions are very understandable -- drugs can cause a lot of serious harm to society. But I think the emotions have made it hard to talk about solutions in an effective way." 
 Now a group of 34 scientists, drug policy experts and public officials, Professor MacCoun among them, is moving to stake out the middle ground in the drug debate by asserting that while drugs should not be made legal, the policies adopted to prevent their use have sometimes done more harm than good.
The polarized words of the debate have upset drug researchers and policy experts who find themselves caught in a crossfire between those who say the war against drugs has failed and should be abandoned in favor of more liberal policies and those who believe that reconsideration of existing policies is tantamount to a sellout.
"It's impossible to talk about any other alternatives without one side accusing you of being a traitor and having a hidden agenda," Professor MacCoun said.
The polarization has been illustrated by the refusal of Senator Jesse Helms to let the Foreign Relations Committee that he leads consider the nomination of William F. Weld as United States Ambassador to Mexico. Senator Helms, Republican of North Carolina, accuses Mr. Weld, the former Massachusetts Governor, of being soft on drugs because he favors making medicinal marijuana available for seriously ill people. In fact, Mr. Weld, as a Federal prosecutor, put drug traffickers behind bars.
The 34 professionals advocating a new look at drug policy plan to announce 14 "principles for practical drug policies" at a news conference in Washington on Tuesday. Their move constitutes the first attempt in years to bring pragmatism as well as civility to what has degenerated into a shouting match.
"It's being done to make clear to people that the argument between the legalizers and the drug warriors isn't where the action is, if what you're really trying to do is reduce the damage that drugs do to American society," said Mark A. R. Kleiman, a professor of public policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. "What we'd like to do is make it politically safe to say something sensible about drug policy."
Though the people who have signed the statement are generally known for their work on issues like drug addiction, most have not publicly spoken out about drug policy before. To avoid partisanship, none of the prominent personalities on either side of the drug debate were invited to sign the declaration, which also avoids much of the language of the current heated debate. For example, it speaks of reducing the damage of drugs to society rather than "harm reduction," a phrase that connotes cutting down on the harm addicts do to themselves.
The signers said: "The current drug policy debate is marked by polarization into two positions stereotyped as 'drug warrior' and 'legalizer.' This creates the false impression that 'ending prohibition' is the only alternative to an unrestricted 'war on drugs,' effectively disenfranchising citizens who find both of those options unsatisfactory."
In such a climate, the statement continued, "every idea, research finding or proposal put forth is scrutinized to determine which agenda it advances, and the partisans on each side are quick to brand anyone who deviates from their 'party line' as an agent of the opposing side."
The signers included the former New York City Police Commissioner, William Bratton; Detroit's prosecuting attorney, John O'Hair; criminal justice experts like John J. Dilulio Jr. of Princeton and Francis X. Hartmann, Mark H. Moore and David McLean Kennedy of Harvard and economists like Glenn Loury of Boston University and Philip Jackson Cook of Duke.
The signers known for their scientific research into drugs included Avram Goldstein of Stanford, George Vaillant of Harvard, George E. Bigelow and Solomon H. Snyder of Johns Hopkins, Lewis Seiden of the University of Chicago and Marian W. Fischman of Columbia.
"I oftentimes think that elected officials never hear from those of us who espouse moderate principles," said one of the document's signers, Charles R. Schuster, a former director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush.
"It's very important to have spokespeople for the moderate positions," said Dr. Schuster, who directs clinical research on drug abuse at the Wayne State University School of Medicine. "All they're hearing from are the two other extremes."
Several of the signers said that they had begun drafting the principles after voters in California and Arizona approved the ballot initiatives endorsing marijuana for medical purposes last November. Those referendums triggered heated exchanges between government officials and supporters of more liberal availability of marijuana.
Jonathan P. Caulkins, a drug policy analyst at Carnegie-Mellon University, said he signed the statement because he favored a "smarter prohibition" of illegal drugs. His recent analysis of mandatory minimum sentences for drug offenses, published by the Rand Corporation, concluded that tax money would be more effectively spent on treating minor offenders for drug abuse than on locking them up for long periods.
"One of my frustrations is that the drug legalization groups are intellectually irresponsible in a lot of their thinking, except they raise valid criticisms of the current regime," Professor Caulkins said. "And the current regime is intolerant of criticism. It feels that even constructive criticism is an act of treason."
The signers said: "We cannot escape our current predicament by 'ending prohibition' or 'legalizing drugs.' " Lifting controls, they contended, could increase drug use. But they said that law enforcement and punishment should be designed to minimize overall damage. "The use of disproportionate punishments to express social norms is neither just nor a prudent use of public funds or scarce prison capacity," they said.
Other principles make these points:
*Policies to curtail drugs should be judged by the results they produce, and not by their intentions.
*Social disapproval, while a powerful, economical means of reducing drug use, should not breed indiscriminate hostility toward drug users. But people who violate the rights of others while under the influence of drugs or while trying to obtain them should be held responsible.
*Policies should be tailored for different drugs because every drug carries its own risks and has its own patterns of use.
*Treatment that reduces drug use but fails to produce lasting abstinence should be considered an incomplete success, not a failure.
*Drug prevention messages should reflect accurately what is known about specific drugs.
Several signers expressed hope that their statement would provide a cover for politicians who have been reluctant to discuss the nation's drug problem more openly for fear of sounding soft on drugs.
"A lot of politicians have avoided talking about drug policy because there is no articulated middle ground, so they just stay silent on the issue," Professor MacCoun said. "We want to make clear to them that there's a whole palette of choices, and any criticism of the status quo doesn't have to imply endorsement of drug use."

HEADLINE: In Labor Day Bonus, U.S. Raises Minimum Wage

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
Millions of Americans have a little extra something to celebrate this Labor Day: a pay raise of 40 cents an hour.
On Monday, the Federal minimum wage will rise to $5.15 an hour in the second phase of an increase approved by Congress in the summer of 1996. In the first phase, last fall, the wage for hourly workers was lifted to $4.75 from $4.25, where it had been for more than five years. 
 The change will affect more than just the estimated 6.4 million workers who make less than $5.15 an hour; many employers plan to raise all wages to preserve pay scales.
"We can't pay a crew leader the same" as a regular employee, said Ed Guerra, who runs Dairy Queen restaurants in West Texas.
About 10 million minimum-wage workers will have benefited from either last fall's increase or Monday's increase, the Labor Department said. Some workers got raises last fall that pushed them above the new $5.15 minimum, the agency said.
Supporters say the wages are well deserved.
"Corporate profits and earnings for the average worker are rising," Labor Secretary Alexis M. Herman said. "This minimum wage increase will help insure that the lowest-paid Americans also share in this prosperity."
The increase comes at a time when the booming economy has pulled unemployment down to 4.8 percent.
And Jared Bernstein, an economist with the Economic Policy Institute, said that raising the minimum wage "had no job-loss effect," despite earlier fears that it would.
But critics who had warned that there would be consequences, like reductions in the number of jobs or in working hours, say the strong economy has simply delayed problems.
The wage increase could, for example, make private companies less likely to hire welfare recipients who are losing benefits, said Jeffrey H. Joseph of the United States Chamber of Commerce.
"I think you'll start seeing the movement from welfare to work will slow down," he said. "You're now digging deeper into the welfare ranks to people who have fewer skills, yet what we're doing now is increasing the price people have to pay for them."
Monday's increase is the 25th since the minimum was instituted in 1938 at 25 cents an hour. At the new rate, yearly earnings for full-time work at minimum wage will be about $10,700.
In contrast, the Government said the poverty level for 1995 -- the latest year for which figures are available -- was about $15,600 for a family of four.

HEADLINE: Profits From Casino Help an Indian Tribe Reclaim Its History

BYLINE: By JUDITH H. DOBRZYNSKI 

DATELINE: LEDYARD, Conn.

 BODY:
History books may now have to acknowledge what Theresa H. Bell, a member of the Mashantucket Pequot Tribal Nation, has always felt in her heart: The Pequots did not disappear in the 17th century when, ravaged by the combination of a war with the colonists and smallpox, measles and other European diseases, the tribe supposedly succumbed to European culture and was assimilated.
That is what the gently rolling woodlands of southeastern Connecticut seem to say. And the secrets archeologists are unraveling here bring vindication to a group that was sometimes derided in the 1970's for seeking Federal recognition as a tribe, the purest Pequot being a one-eighth Pequot, and the accompanying right to operate a casino. 
 Now, profits from Foxwoods, the Pequots' 24-hour-a-day casino, are paying for a $135 million museum and research center to house evidence found mere footsteps away from the conspicuously turquoise-and-purple gambling hall. More than $1 million has been spent on the dig itself.
The findings unearthed by archeologists suggest that the Pequots not only endured but also maintained many native practices -- what they ate, how they cooked, how many family members lived together and more -- through at least the 18th century.
"We knew there had to be a story underneath the ground that hadn't been told," said Ms. Bell, granddaughter of Elizabeth George Plouffe, who pressed the dispersed tribe to reunite a quarter-century ago and was the founder of the modern Pequot nation. "This just proves what our oral history says."
The evidence backing Ms. Bell comes from the discovery of the trace remnants of a fortified Pequot village, probably built in 1670 and abandoned in 1675, and several 18th-century dwellings.
There are fragments of wampum, nuts, flint, tools, the oldest peach pit in the Northeast (probably) and much else. The biggest treasure is an earthenware cooking pot, as big as a pumpkin, pieced together from shards. Together, these clues tell how the Pequots hung on after they began their long slide in 1637. That year, after a series of raids by English colonists intent on taking the Pequots' land and taking over their fur trade, soldiers killed about half of the tribe in a battle at Mystic that lasted less than an hour. Then they burned down the Pequots' homes.
There is much work to do to before history could actually be revised, but many experts agree it should be. "This archeology is really going to be important," said Kathleen J. Bragdon, an anthropology professor at the College of William and Mary in Williamsburg, Va., who has visited the sites and is the author of "Native Peoples of Southern New England."
Kevin A. McBride, an associate professor of archeology at the University of Connecticut at Storrs who is the director of research for the Pequots, said: "We now understand how they survived and maintained their cultural integrity. After all this is done, we will know, in terms of the Pequots, more about natives after their contact with the Europeans than has ever been known before."
And he sees further ramifications. "I believe that what we're finding here is not unique, that this has broader implications" for other Indians of New England, he said. "The individual decisions that each tribe made were different. But they made decisions that would assure and maintain their culture." He said the findings supported his belief that the tribes "were not passive," as the colonists had said.
In addition to traces of the Pequots' staying power, Mr. McBride has also found material that places their ancestors backward in time: vestiges of a prehistoric camp site dating back 10,000 years, with hints, as yet unproven, of evidence from 11,000 years ago.
"Ten thousand years is very old for a documented site in New England," Dr. Bragdon said. "There are others of that period in other parts of North America, but this is one of the first that shows continuous occupation in New England."
Next June 1, the 361st anniversary of the massacre at Mystic, the tribe plans to open its museum complex, with Ms. Bell as executive director. It will devote 85,000 square feet to telling the tribe's story and 5,000 square feet to galleries for special exhibitions about the culture of other American Indians. It will also house a research center and library.
The complex, conceived 30 years ago, was one reason the tribe built Foxwoods, whose annual gross revenues approach $1 billion. Some of the profits, which have not been disclosed, have been invested in fisheries and a shipyard and used to make an annual payment to all 400 tribe members and pay fees to Connecticut. But some have always been earmarked for the research and the museum.
"We realized we'd need to generate a lot of money because we wanted to understand and find parts of our history and culture that had been lost for so many years," said Ms. Bell, whose own hopes were reinforced by memories of the bottles and arrowheads and other trinkets she found on the reservation as a child on her personal "treasure hunts."
 
Presumed Lost, Accidentally Found
Professor McBride, who is not an Indian, had no such hopes rooted in his background when he set out in 1983 to study the Pequots' native grounds. "I didn't think much would be here," he said recently. "Most of the archeological record has been destroyed."
Laurence M. Hauptman, a history professor at the State University College at New Paltz, N.Y., and a co-author of "The Pequots in Southern New England: The Fall and Rise of An American Indian Nation," explained why. "Village sites are hard to find because most are now other towns, like New London," he said. "We Europeans didn't discover the geopolitical or economic importance of certain sites."
While the Pequots once presided over a 250-square-mile territory, Mr. McBride's most important finds are taking place on the 214 acres that, saved from encroachment, eventually were established as a reservation.
Many finds have simply emerged accidentally. Early this year, for example, the contractor for a parking garage wanted to move some soil on a small south-facing slope nearby. "He cut in, and we saw some of this," Mr. McBride said, pointing to thin, dark stains that look like chocolate frosting in a sandy-colored layer cake.
These blotches teem with the residue of a 10,000-year-old civilization: pit houses, probably made of wood pieces and beams, maybe covered with hide or sod, for perhaps 5 to 15 people.
Since winter, graduate and undergraduate archeology students from the University of Connecticut and other colleges have been digging, separating soil samples into plastic bags, sifting some to find artifacts and storing others.
The alternating layers of dark and light suggest that a family returned to this site each winter to enjoy its southern exposure but left for a less tethered life for the rest of the year.
 
Two Black Lines Add Up to a Fort
"The fort is the coolest thing we've found," Mr. McBride said. Although nothing but tiny fragments has been uncovered, he gets little argument from other experts.
"To find something like this fort, from this time period, is unique," Dr. Hauptman said. "Here, in Esopus country," he added, naming a Delaware Indian tribe, "we know there was an Indian fort, and we've never found it. Archeologists have been looking for it for a century."
As Mr. McBride tells the story, discovery of the Pequot fort was serendipitous. Stopping his red Toyota Land Cruiser on a bumpy dirt road leading to it, he said the modern Pequots planned a maintenance building on the site.
Because the Pequots send in the archeologists whenever they plan to build, Professor McBride and his staff members explored. With some core drilling, they found some stone tools, English flint and other "bits and pieces that told us there was a historic site here," he said. That was in 1986, and it was enough to stop the construction.
More intense work followed in the early 1990's. The crews found artifacts from the 1780's: some brass, some beads. "We thought it was a 1780's farmhouse," Mr. McBride said. "But slowly it began to dawn on us that we might have found something from the 1670's. We found Pequot pottery that doesn't date after 1680," judging by its style. They have also tested their findings with radioactive carbon dating.
Then came the revelation. The archeologists had found one long black stain of material and another long black line perpendicular to it. "It came to me on Block Island," where he had gone for some respite, Mr. McBride said. "I woke up at 3 A.M. and said, 'God, it's a fort.' I called back and said: 'Connect the dots. Extend the two lines and dig and see if you get a corner."
His colleagues did.
Eventually, diggers discovered a square fort, with bastions at the corners. The design demonstrates that the Pequots, who sided with the English in King Philip's War, an Indian uprising to turn back the Puritans that engulfed New England in the 1670's, learned from them. Records show that a previous Pequot fort, from 1637, was circular, not square, and lacked bastions. A forge, meanwhile, demonstrates that the natives used European technology in gun smithing.
Inside the fort is a village of 8 to 10 houses, yielding a trove of fragments from iron kettles, pothooks, pottery pots with Pequot marks, pipes stamped with English makers' marks, wampum, musket balls, gun flints, arrow points, spear points and decorative objects.
"We also found two garbage dumps," Mr. McBride said, "one in which everyone threw everything and one in a wigwam with incredible food remains." These included indications of nuts, corn, beans, squash, peach pits, pig, deer, raccoon, duck, turkey, geese, and fish from both the coast and local ponds.
Clearly, the Pequots interacted with the English colonists in many ways at least as early as the 1670's. Sites where wampum was manufactured and stored suggests, too, that they "were probably getting rich, though not rich in the European sense," said Professor Bragdon of William and Mary.
Sifting through all the information, Mr. McBride can surmise much else about Pequot life. The presence of more than one fire in a household, for example, suggests that extended families lived together, possibly siblings as well as grandparents, parents and children.
The food wastes tell a tale that differs from colonial records, which are heavy on the improvements Europeans brought to Indian meals. The Pequots apparently did eat domesticated animals like pigs, but they also continued to fish, hunt and gather food from nature.
"When you look at all the food remains, you'll find, with a few exceptions, an overwhelming native eating pattern," Mr. McBride said. The Pequots also continued to cook outdoors in pits.
The existence of the Pequot fort itself provides another example of divergence from accepted wisdom. "History says they were not well-organized, but this shows they were well-organized, with an organization that allowed them to maintain their own practices and take advantage of the fur trade," Professor Bragdon said.
"What Kevin has," she added, "documents their active participation in the fur trade and shows that they were real players in the economy, not pawns of the Europeans."
Professor McBride sums up what he has learned so far this way: "We are finding European cultural influences, but also native culture underlying it." Instead of assimilating, the Pequots made some strategic retreats.
To Ms. Bell, remembering her grandmother's tales, the discoveries ring true. "I am glad we started this," she said. "We don't need an archeological site to learn a lot of this; my grandmother still cooked outside, and I have a fire pit, too. But other people do. Outside people have to have proof to change the history books."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Archeologists digging for artifacts at the remains of a fort built in the 1670's on the Mashantucket Pequot reservation in Connecticut. The Pequots sided with the English in other tribes' war against the Puritans. (Ruby Washington/The New York Times)(pg. B4)

HEADLINE: Western Senators Are Pushing to Break Up Circuit Court

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 31

 BODY:
For more than a decade, a group of senators from the Northwest has been trying with little success to break up the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, complaining that it was too large and, more important, was dominated by judges from California who issue liberal environmental rulings.
But this summer, the lawmakers, all Republicans, managed to insert a little-noticed rider into an appropriations bill that would split the circuit. It passed the Senate days before the August recess. The House has approved a different measure, one that would authorize only a study of the issue, and it is likely to balk at the Senate's swifter approach. 
 Nonetheless, the Senate action is the high watermark of the effort to dismantle the Ninth Circuit, which decides Federal appeals from nine Western states and two territories, making it by far the nation's largest appellate court.
The Senate vote also comes almost 60 years to the month after President Franklin D. Roosevelt tried and failed in his famous "court packing" scheme to enlarge the Supreme Court because he was angered at its rulings on his New Deal programs.
Critics of the latest effort in the Senate, including some usually reticent Federal judges, describe the effort to split the Ninth Circuit as similarly motivated, a kind of "court unpacking" plan in response to unpopular judicial decisions.
Chief Judge Procter Hug Jr. of the Ninth Circuit said in an interview that the primary motivation behind the divide-the-court effort was that many of the court's decisions had been unpopular and had caused political problems in the Northwest.
"If there are a few high-profile cases that are decided in such a way as to be unpopular, there is a remedy for that through the Supreme Court," he said. "My sense is that this is a wholly inappropriate reason to suddenly decide on changing the entire structure of a court."
Albert T. Goodwin, a former chief judge of the circuit, has been more explicit, once telling reporters that the effort was a reflection of the frustration that timber and mining interests felt about the Ninth Circuit's ruling in favor of preserving habitats of the spotted owl.
Judge Hug and Judge James R. Browning, also a former chief of the circuit, have even arranged to come to Washington next week to lobby House members to resist the move.
But not all of the court's judges agree with Judge Hug. Judge Andrew J. Kleinfeld, who sits in Fairbanks, said he thought it was absolutely necessary to divide the circuit and its workload. He said that with a complement of 28 judges, the court was too large, too unwieldy and too unmanageable.
"It's impossible for a judge on our court to keep up with all the rulings of the other judges," he said. "This has resulted in a far less coherent and disciplined body of law from this circuit."
The Federal appellate courts, the level just below the Supreme Court, are organized into 11 regional circuits and one in the District of Columbia. The new legislation would leave just California and Nevada in the Ninth Circuit while creating a new Twelfth Circuit composed of what's left: Alaska, Arizona, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, Washington and the Pacific Territories (Guam and the Northern Mariana Islands).
The legislation is opposed by the White House, the majority of judges on the Ninth Circuit, including the last three chief judges, the American Bar Association, the California Bar Association and Gov. Pete Wilson of California, who has called it "judicial gerrymandering."
The reason this effort was successful in the Senate earlier in the summer appears to be that the Ninth Circuit recently aroused the ire of Senator Ted Stevens, the Alaska Republican who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee. Senator Stevens had previously been a steady but lukewarm advocate of dividing the circuit, but he seemed energized by a decision last year in which a panel of the circuit's appellate judges, none from Alaska, decided a tax case involving Alaskan Indian tribes. After that, he declared it was time for a change.
Mr. Stevens inserted the provision about the Ninth Circuit into the appropriations bill for the Departments of Justice and State. The rider, an often used way of effecting policy, passed with no hearings and no consideration by the Senate Judiciary Committee, which would usually deal with such an issue.
The Alaska case involved a Ninth Circuit ruling in December that two Indian villages in the state had the same broad sovereignty rights, including taxing power, as Indian villages in the lower 48 states. Senator Stevens denounced the ruling as upsetting the state's economy and told The Anchorage Daily News that he would raise anew the effort to split the circuit. "That court has too much to do to even learn about Alaska," he said. "I don't think any of those judges ever have been to Alaska and yet we have them issuing an opinion like this which has so much to do with our future."
Senator Stevens's comments mirror those of the more aggressive sponsors of the effort to split the court. Senator Conrad Burns, Republican of Montana, has said that his state needed judges who grew up in the region who would be more sensitive to "how we manage our own resources."
But the senators in the Northwest have emphasized instead the issue of the court's size, arguing that it makes judicial administration unwieldy. The court was set up in 1891, before California grew into the most populous state.
In 1996, 8,502 appeals were filed with the Ninth Circuit, according to the Administrative Office of the Courts. The next busiest circuit was the Fifth, in the Southeast, which had 7,546 cases filed.
A Senate study in 1975 recommended splitting the circuit and doing so by dividing California down the middle.
But the executive director of that study, Prof. Arthur Hellman of the University of Pittsburgh Law School, now says the division may be unnecessary. He said there was little doubt that the motivation behind the effort to divide the court was a misguided belief that it would produce more conservative rulings.
He said critics mistakenly think that the judges in California are, as a whole, more liberal than those in the other states. "Essentially, these people want to secede from a circuit that includes California," he said.

HEADLINE: GAINS PUT UNIONS AT TURNING POINT, MANY EXPERTS SAY

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With the United Parcel Service settlement seen as a major triumph and an omen of future success, union leaders and many experts say the labor movement is in its strongest position in nearly a generation and is poised to increase its membership after a two-decade decline.
This Labor Day might be a watershed moment for unions, some experts say, because the 15-day U.P.S. strike created a surge of sympathy for unions as many of the efforts at revitalization pushed by John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, have taken root. 
 The labor federation, with 13 million members, is spending $20 million a year on organizing new members, up from $2.5 million a year in the early 1990's, and several unions that had essentially stopped organizing have started pumping money and staff into recruiting new members. Hundreds of college graduates are signing on as union organizers, while a new generation of labor leaders in their 40's has emerged, far more interested in shaking up and expanding the labor movement than were the crusty old leaders who dominated labor in the 1980's.
"Things are better for labor than they've been in a very long time," said Tom Juravich, director of the Labor Relations and Research Center at the University of Massachusetts. "The mood is fundamentally different from just two or three years ago, when there was a sense of hopelessness."
As part of Mr. Sweeney's push to reverse labor's slide, there is a surge in union organizing, including campaigns to unionize 16,000 teachers and school aides in Dallas, 20,000 strawberry workers in California, 55,000 apple workers in Washington State, 70,000 home health care workers in the Los Angeles area and 110,000 employees at Federal Express.
Labor has recently scored some of its biggest victories in two decades, among them unionizing 5,000 mechanics at Continental Airlines and 30,000 government workers in Maryland.
There have, of course, been major defeats, too, most notably losing an election two weeks ago to represent more than 5,000 textile workers at a dozen North Carolina factories owned by Fieldcrest Cannon. And despite the new confidence within labor, some critics assert that all the activity aimed at reversing labor's decline has generated little but sound and fury because it has failed to increase labor's bottom line: the number of Americans belonging to unions. In 1996, the first full year after Mr. Sweeney was elected president, union membership declined by 92,000 and the percentage of American workers belonging to unions slid to 14.5 percent, down from 35 percent in the 1950's.
"Unions have become much better at communicating," said Thomas J. Donohue, the new president of the United States Chamber of Commerce. "They're spending a lot of money. But they still seem to be flailing around trying to find something that works."
The decline in membership as labor tries to expand its ranks is due to numerous persistent forces like retirements, plant closings and downsizing. In addition, labor must contend with expensive campaigns by employers to keep out unions and the hostility felt by many Americans who see some officials driving Cadillacs or using union money to attend conferences in Hawaii or Italy.
Mr. Sweeney predicted in an interview that in the next few years, his big organizing push would begin raising labor's overall numbers. He said the decline in labor's ranks last year was understandable because he had only begun putting his organizing plans into place and because the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s focus in 1996 had been on the Congressional and Presidential elections, not on organizing.
"The bottom line is, nobody has any unrealistic dreams of doubling our membership in one year," he said. "We're going to get on a modest growth pattern of 2 or 3 percent a year. We're going to get results as more newly trained organizers get involved and more unions step up their efforts."
Under Mr. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has provided many unions with matching grants to encourage them to do more organizing. The labor federation has also reorganized dozens of city labor councils to make them focus on recruiting. It has also set up a program in many cities, called Street Heat, in which hundreds of union supporters hold raucous protest marches at companies that dismiss workers who back unionization drives.
To extend labor's reach, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. has sponsored teach-ins with academics and has established alliances with members of the clergy, environmentalists, women's groups and ethnic groups. One of these alliances is bearing fruit on Labor Day weekend -- hundreds of pro-union priests, ministers and rabbis invited workers and union leaders to deliver sermons to their congregations about the values shared by labor and religious faiths.
"A lot of what we're doing is for the long term," Mr. Sweeney said. "We're just beginning to see the payoffs." He said he believed the strike by 185,000 U.P.S. workers, the biggest strike in the nation since an AT&T walkout in 1983, would attract more Americans to unions because the public saw what the teamsters were able to accomplish by standing together. The U.P.S. workers won most of their demands, including converting 10,000 part-time positions to full-time jobs and restrictions on subcontracting.
Richard Bensinger, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s new director of organizing, said that the day after the strike ended, he had been on an airplane, wearing a T-shirt with large letters saying, "Union Yes!"
"The woman sitting next to me started talking to me and said she's never been for unions her whole life," Mr. Bensinger said. "She told me her husband is a part-time worker, and she said she started thinking a lot better toward unions when she saw what the teamsters had won for the part-timers at U.P.S."
The emergence of dozens of younger leaders like Mr. Bensinger, 46, is one of the most important factors driving labor's renaissance. Mr. Bensinger is an inspiring speaker who began climbing labor's ladder after successfully organizing the ski and tennis racquet factory he worked at in Colorado.
Among the new leaders in their 40's are Karen Nussbaum, 47, the director of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s women's division and founder of 9 to 5, an organization that represents secretaries. John Wilhelm, 49, the secretary-treasurer of the hotel workers' union, has masterminded an innovative drive over the past decade that has unionized 27,000 hotel maids, cocktail waitresses and other workers in Las Vegas, Nev. Andrew Stern, 45, president of the Service Employees International Union, has, more than any other labor leader, focused on recruiting, moving many headquarters staff members out to the field to organize. With this new strategy, the service employees have, in the first six months of this year, organized 23,000 janitors, nursing home employees and other workers.
Douglas McCarron, 46, president of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, has also refocused his union on organizing and has led the way in showing that unions should serve their members more than union officials. To make sure that money from dues is used more efficiently, he has merged dozens of locals, a move that left dozens of local business representatives complaining that they had lost their $90,000-a-year jobs.
Despite all these changes, many things are still not going labor's way. Last year, unions won only 47.3 percent of elections in which workers voted whether to join unions, the lowest percentage in five years. The number of such elections held last year, 2,792, was less than half the number in the early 1980's, when labor was thrown on the defensive by a recession, rising imports and President Ronald Reagan's dismissal of 11,500 striking air traffic controllers in 1981.
Mr. Bensinger said that labor's victory rate in representation elections had not risen because employers had grown more aggressive in fighting unions and because, in his view, the nation's labor laws were skewed against organizing drives. He nonetheless predicted that labor's new unionization push would soon pay off in larger numbers because labor unions were seeking to organize larger units and because many Americans were frustrated with stagnant wages.
Some labor experts predict that the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s expansion efforts will be to no avail because of powerful countervailing forces.
Leo Troy, an economics professor at Rutgers University, said labor's advances would be checked by business owners' need to hold down costs in the face of increased global competition and by the transformation of the workplace, with more people working at home, part time or as temporary workers or independent contractors. Noting that unions traditionally focus on full-time, permanent employees working at one site, Mr. Troy said, "The nature of unionism is at odds with the nature of the new work force."
He added: "Despite the rhetoric, the flamboyance and the fireworks, nothing has changed for the good for unions, and it's not going to in the private sector, where just 1 in 10 workers belongs to a union."
But many labor leaders say these forces may bode well for unionization drives because, in their view, these trends point to increased exploitation by employers and increased unhappiness among employees. These trends, labor leaders say, explain why the public overwhelmingly supported the U.P.S. strikers, while in walkouts in the 1980's, the public generally supported management. "The public's sympathies are different from 10 years ago," said Harry Katz, a professor of labor relations at Cornell University. "The 90's have produced huge skepticism about the motives of management, about stagnant wages and the astronomic rise in C.E.O. pay. That has made a lot of people think maybe unions aren't such a bad idea compared with corporate executives."

HEADLINE: Saving the Whales' Hearing;
Some Fear That Fleets of Watchers May Harm Mammals

BYLINE: By JANE FRITSCH 

DATELINE: MONTAUK POINT, N.Y.

 BODY:
It was nearly three hours before the first, tentative shout rose from the squinting crew. It could be a whale. It looked like a whale. "We have the animal off the bow at 11 o'clock!"
Within minutes, two more boats carrying hundreds of passengers arrived, alerted by radio that a whale had finally been spotted. Engines idled, cameras snapped and the lone minke whale dove deep and disappeared. 
 Off the Atlantic and Pacific coasts and, increasingly, around the world, such scenes are a cause of gratification and concern for whale researchers. While whale watching offers a greater appreciation of the animals, which could help save them from extinction, the din caused by such scenes and other noise made by humans could be damaging their hearing. And that, some researchers theorize, might be fatal.
"A deaf whale is a dead whale," said Peter M. Scheifele, a bioacoustic researcher at the University of Connecticut. "If you're in the ocean and you rely on hearing for navigation, and to avoid predators and to find your mate, I don't think nature's going to let you live too long deaf."
Because little is known about whale hearing, Mr. Scheifele and researchers from several institutions are planning a project to determine the effect of the huge increase in underwater noise created by engine-driven vessels over the last century.
The greatest share of ocean noise is created by supertankers and other merchant ships that send sound waves miles ahead of their location, Mr. Scheifele said. "But whale watching and fishing boats figure in," he said, "not because one of them is very loud, but because a lot of them can be around at one time."
And the benign activity of whale-watching boats could be having another unintended effect, Mr. Scheifele added. "We have to worry," he said. "We are conditioning animals not to be afraid of ships." Still, Mr. Scheifele said he believes whale watching is valuable and should not be stopped.
A chance to see earth's largest mammal frolicking in the sea, sometimes only yards away, is a mighty lure that has led to tremendous demand for whale-watching tours over the last decade. An estimated 5.4 million people in 65 countries or territories went on whale-watching expeditions in 1994 and the numbers grow by as much as 10 percent each year, according to statistics compiled by the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society, based in Bath, England.
Two-thirds of organized whale watching is done in the United States, where it was started in 1955, according to the society. The activity now generates more than $500 million in revenue around the world.
On the East Coast, whale watching began in earnest in 1975, when Al Avellar, a fisherman in Provincetown, Mass., began taking tourists aboard his boat. He eventually built his whale-watching business into the highly successful Dolphin Fleet. Now, dozens of companies along the Atlantic coast offer whale-watching tours.
Customarily, crews now radio each other, even if they are from competing fleets, when they spot a whale. This explains why three or more vessels may suddenly converge on the same whale.
Recognizing the potential for harm to the whales, the National Marine Fisheries Service has set guidelines recommending that boats stay at least 100 yards from whales, that they not charge or pursue whales and that they travel parallel to them.
But sometimes, to the delight of passengers, close encounters cannot be avoided. Once a boat cuts its engine, it may stay in its position even if whales approach, which often happens, according to Robbins Barstow, the founder of the Cetacean Society International, a volunteer organization that promotes whale watching.
Some whales seem to enjoy the encounters, Dr. Barstow said. "They breach and show off their calves." Many have become well known to observers over the last 20 years and have been given names, he said.
"Occasionally, you'll get a wild guy in an outboard motor," he added. "He'll tear over to where a whale is and really harass it."
But over all, whale watching has been beneficial for whales, he said, helping to turn public sentiment against the whaling industry. And as whale watching becomes a major tourist attraction, it may become an economic alternative to whaling, he said.
Several whale-watching expedition operators now offer space on their boats to researchers, who use the trips to observe whale behavior and to track the population. At Montauk Harbor, the Viking Line offers space to the Riverhead Foundation for Marine Research, whose staff runs an education program for whale watchers on board.
Dr. Barstow said he has seen no evidence that whale watching has affected the hearing of whales. "There is a much greater threat from tankers, oil ships and military ships," he said. "Whale watching is very incidental."
Mr. Scheifele first became concerned about excessive noise four years ago during a trip to Tadoussac Harbor, in the St. Lawrence Seaway. At about 11 P.M. one day that summer, he was struck by the amount of noise in the surrounding water and tossed a hydrophone overboard to measure the level, he said. "It was party loud."
At the height of the summer tourist season, he said, it is not uncommon to see one whale surrounded by 25 boats, all jockeying for position. "What I suspect," he said, "is that in the St. Lawrence there are times of the year, days and sites that are potentially dangerous to the hearing of whales."
Mr. Scheifele, director of bioacoustic research at the National Undersea Research Center at the University of Connecticut, is planning a three-year study with a team of researchers who will set out to answer some basic questions about noise levels and what whales hear.
But studying whale hearing is fraught with difficulties. Simple observation of whale behavior may be meaningless, he said, because it is not necessarily true that a whale will flee from damaging sounds. Humans, for example, may endure repeated loud sounds or generally high noise levels without realizing that their hearing is being damaged. The same could be true for whales, he said.
And because most whales travel thousands of miles in a year, it is difficult to know where or how their hearing might have been damaged. Further, as in humans, whale hearing declines with age, so the age of the whale must somehow be taken into account. "We don't know what a whale hears," Mr. Scheifele said. "For whales there are no hearing standards."
The first step will be to define standards of whale hearing, he said. The second will be to examine the ears of dead whales for damage to the hair-like cilia inside the ears to see whether they are broken or bent, signs of damage from loud or prolonged noise. The study will focus on the 700 or so beluga whales that inhabit the St. Lawrence Seaway. Because they never leave the waterway, it should be easier to determine the level of noise they have been exposed to in their lifetimes, he said. And the belugas may be in greater danger from noise because they cannot flee from it, he added.
"It's a very complex problem," Mr. Scheifele said, "not one that will be solved in the next year."
But Mr. Scheifele said he believes whale watching should continue. "Whale watchers are good people," he said. "They want to do what's right for the whale. And we need good scientific proof."
"The object is not to put somebody out of business," he said, but rather to find a way to live with other animals.

HEADLINE: 1997 U.S. OPEN;
Haas Shows Potential As the Last German Out

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY 

 BODY:
Early last week, a German television station, DSF, sent its reporters into the field to conduct an informal poll. Eighty people were interviewed and 40 of them said they believed that Boris Becker had a good chance to win the United States Open.
Becker must have appreciated the support, particularly because he was not playing in this United States Open. 
 As it turns out, no German has a chance to win at Flushing Meadows. For the first time since 1982, no singles player from Becker's once tennis-mad land has advanced to the fourth round.
Anke Huber, who has sting but little strategy in her ground strokes, became the last German woman to lose on Friday night. Yesterday, the last German man, Tommy Haas, lost to the No. 10-seeded Marcelo Rios of Chile, 6-4, 3-6, 6-3, 1-6, 6-1.
At a time when the United States Tennis Association is clearly concerned about the future of player development, the German Tennis Federation is in a similarly edgy frame of mind. Becker and the former Wimbledon champion Michael Stich have announced their retirements from Grand Slam singles play. Steffi Graf, who has won 21 Grand Slam singles titles, is recovering after major knee surgery and is now 28 years old.
Germany has been tennis's economic engine throughout this decade, and the dearth of successors to its stars is not simply of concern to 82 million Germans. It is also of concern to tennis administrators such as Mark Miles, the ATP Tour chief executive officer, who rely on German corporations and German television contracts for major chunks of their operating budgets.
Nick Bollettieri, the American coach with the dark shades and the bright smile, believes Haas could be part of the solution. At 19 years 5 months, he is the youngest men's player in the top 100, and yesterday he very nearly became the youngest men's player in the fourth round.
"I think, the next couple years, we should see him potentially become the top player in the world," Bollettieri said. "I think he needs more experience and a little bit more maturity mentally and continued physical work because he's grown up so quick. But he's got all the shots."
Haas has lived at Bollettieri's Academy in Bradenton, Fla., since he was 11 when he and his father, Peter, a tennis teacher, decided that the road to Grand Slams passed through Bollettieri. Haas now lives in his coach's house.
When the teen-ager reached the semifinals at a major ATP event in Hamburg, Germany, this spring on clay, Germans were quick to leap to conclusions: "Our New Boris" read one headline in one newspaper. But while Haas is clearly a gifted prospect with his big frame, increasingly effective serve and powerful, if somewhat mechanical, ground strokes, he remains prone to misjudgments under pressure. He also is prone to leg cramps, which he began experiencing after losing the third set yesterday.
"That was my first five-setter," Haas said.
His opponent had physical problems of his own. Before this tournament began, Rios's sponsor, Nike, provided him with a custom-made pair of shoes to match his clothing line. Unfortunately, the custom-made shoes left him with a badly irritated tendon on top of his right foot. He survived a five-setter in the second round against Kenneth Carlsen of Denmark and went back to his old footwear, but he could only practice briefly on Saturday and received treatment throughout the match yesterday. Afterward, he complained of numbness in his lower right leg.
"He can't push off with his right foot on his serve," his coach, Larry Stefanki, said. "The good news is he toughed something out."
Rios, one of the most gifted shot makers on tour, has a reputation for folding when adversity strikes, but he has now won seven five-set matches in a row. Germany could use him. Instead, it will have to rely on Haas and a five-player development team sponsored by Mercedes and coached, in part, by Becker.

HEADLINE: California Draws Newspaper Chains Eager to Cluster

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: MONTEREY, Calif.

 BODY:
Stroll down the sunny side of Alvarado Street in this old seaside city until you reach Bonifacio Plaza and you will all but bump into the competitive reality of today's newspaper business: a miniature Stonehenge of sidewalk news boxes selling eight different daily papers.
Each of the papers -- including three published from the East Coast -- are vying for the attention of readers in the prosperous San Francisco region. 
 And yes, the only local paper, The Monterey County Herald, which has a weekday circulation of 36,000, still sells more copies here than any of the others. But like local papers in many big states, The Herald is feeling rising pressure from bigger papers with statewide or national ambitions.
Now, though, The Herald may be in a better position to fight back. On Aug. 24, the paper became part of the Knight-Ridder Inc. chain, which already owned six other dailies in the Bay Area.
It is the latest example of an expanding trend that newspaper industry executives call clustering. The concept is playing out in various markets, including New Jersey, where the Gannett Company earlier this month acquired the 156,500-circulation Asbury Park Press and the 86,000-circulation Home News and Tribune of East Brunswick. The deals raised Gannett's presence in the state to five papers with a total circulation of 553,000.
By assembling collections of dailies within a region, called clusters, newspaper chains can achieve savings on administration, production and distribution costs. Most importantly, they can also strengthen their defenses against competition by offering special cluster-wide advertising deals to big advertisers.
The affluent San Francisco region has become a particularly popular place to cluster, as Knight-Ridder's recent deal demonstrates.
Knight-Ridder already owned The San Jose Mercury News (daily circulation, 290,000) in Silicon Valley, north of here. And in October 1995, it acquired five daily newspapers in Contra Costa County, east of San Francisco Bay, that now offer clustered advertising deals for major retailers and in classified ads for the East Bay area.
Knight-Ridder, though, has stressed only its expectation of growth for its new California papers, and has not yet suggested that The Herald might begin to cooperate with its other properties in the area.
Just the same, the Herald acquisition now gives Knight-Ridder a reach farther south in the region. Monterey is about 90 miles south of San Francisco, and about 50 miles south of San Jose.
"It enlarges the footprint," said John Morton, a newspaper analyst and head of Morton Research Inc.
Clustering lets a handful of smaller regional papers act like one big-city daily, said William Dean Singleton, president and chief executive of the Media News Group, a pioneer in the practice -- and with a big presence itself in the San Francisco area.
"If you're one 40,000-circulation regional daily, it's pretty hard to get the big advertisers to take you seriously," Mr. Singleton said. "But if you can sell space in five 40,000 regionals, then the advertisers start to treat you like a 200,000-circulation metropolitan paper."
It was precisely such thinking that prompted E. W. Scripps to make its recent swap with Knight-Ridder. In exchange for the Monterey paper and The Telegraph-Tribune in San Luis Obispo, down the California coast about 180 miles north of Los Angeles, Scripps received The Boulder Daily Camera in Colorado.
The Scripps flagship newspaper, The Rocky Mountain News in Denver, is close enough to the chain's new Boulder paper to offer both the operating efficiencies and advertiser incentives that should greatly strengthen Scripps's hand in its fight for survival with its archrival in Denver -- which happens to be Mr. Singleton's Denver Post.
Mr. Singleton, meanwhile, is competing for ad dollars in the Bay Area with the Knight-Ridder papers, as well as the region's biggest daily, The San Francisco Chronicle, which has a weekday circulation of 500,000.
In Oakland and Alameda Counties, Mr. Singleton controls the four papers jointly produced by the East Bay Alameda Newspapers Group; they have a total circulation of nearly 200,000. The Alameda group's fifth and newest member, The San Mateo County Times (37,000 daily circulation) is just to the south, on the neck of the San Francisco Peninsula.
However attractive clustered ownership may be for management, changes in ownership can present a rough ride for newspaper employees, as the staff of The Monterey County Herald found out. A few days after announcing Knight-Ridder's deal with Scripps in late July, P. Anthony Ridder, the company's chairman and chief executive, visited The Herald and said that the new owners planned to invoke a condition of the Federal law governing asset swaps and set aside all union contracts at the paper.
This is the first time Knight-Ridder has adopted the tactic, but the wholesale dismissal and re-hiring of staffs is a legal -- though seldom used -- way for new owners in various industries to sweep away union contracts.
The law's provision enabled Knight-Ridder to dismiss the entire Herald staff of 235 full- and part-time employees. All were then invited to reapply for their jobs at their same base pay -- but without the fringe benefits, night differentials and job security of their existing contracts.
Mr. Ridder said that the labor contract was "not suitable" but that the new owners would recognize the union and commence bargaining at some point. The paper's staff, represented by three unions, promptly took strike votes and authorized walkouts if the company failed to treat the workers "fairly."
"I can't see that any company would benefit from demoralizing 200 people like this," said Bonnie Gartshore, who has worked at The Herald off and on for 30 years as an editor and columnist.
"I assume they have consulted psychologists and know what they are doing," Ms. Gartshore said. "But it just baffles me what good it can do to the company to treat people this way."
The company said that The Herald's contract was simply too lush.
"The working terms and salaries are out of line with the size of the market and the size of the newspaper," said Lee Ann Schlatter, a spokeswoman for Knight-Ridder. "They are much more in line with a newspaper in a major market."
Through the years there has been little turnover among the reporters and editors, pressmen and circulation workers at The Herald, because people tend to stay put in Monterey, satisfied that they already live in paradise, tucked between the crescent of ocean bay and the tawny hills of the Coast Range mountains. So news of the mass dismissals was particularly jarring to the staff -- and dismaying to many townspeople who consider the paper a central institution of the community.
"I think the thing that's distressing to me was this meat-cleaver approach," said Dan Albert, the city's Mayor.
Mr. Albert, already aware that Knight-Ridder has not yet quite shaken off the effects of an acrid, sometimes violent strike at its Detroit paper, The Free Press, said he wondered if Monterey should start worrying, too.
"I have to ask, what is going to happen with that kind of disruption?" he asked. "Are there going to be labor problems here? Are people's lives going to be disrupted? It just doesn't seem right to me."
The Mayor expressed puzzlement that no one from Knight-Ridder had called to introduce themselves and discuss the labor and economic impact of such sweeping change at the Monterey Peninsula's sixth-largest commercial employer.
Mindi Keirnan, a corporate vice president at Knight-Ridder who is supervising the transition at The Herald, did not respond to a request for an interview. But on Aug. 21, Knight-Ridder took out a full-page ad in the paper over the signature of Patricia T. Keil, who will be the new publisher of The Herald, to try to explain things.
"This is not exactly the way I wanted to start my new job," Ms. Keil began. Farther down she wrote, "Undeniably, the transition process here is painful, but it is something we must get through in order to move forward."
In a radio interview that same day, Ms. Kiernan and Ms. Keil said that Knight-Ridder wanted more flexibility to hire part-timers or stringers, instead of using staff reporters for every story, and to change work assignments when the need arose.
Eventually, Knight-Ridder rehired 90 percent of the Herald employees who reapplied for their jobs; however, 24 did not do so.
Those rehired, as Ms. Gartshore was, were taken back at their base pay, which averages about $42,000 for a reporter with more than six years' tenure.
Non-Herald people would start at lower scales, the company has told its employees.
Knight-Ridder has made no statements about the future relationship between The Herald and its new cousin, The San Jose Mercury News. But other chains have learned to tread lightly when they try to link papers under common ownership.
Mr. Singleton recalled, for example, that when he began forming the Alameda Group in the early 1990's, he had his papers share editors and even entire news pages as a money-saving move. But after readers quickly came to suspect that they were not getting their own, locally tailored paper and responded angrily, the publications cut back, sharing only special sections and features.
Still, the lesson was not perfectly learned. There was another backlash two years ago when The San Mateo County Times, on the West Bay, joined the Alameda Group, and its readers rebelled against the group's East Bay point of view.
"We started losing readers, so we had some focus groups to find out why," Mr. Singleton said. "We found out they thought we were giving them an East Bay paper with coverage of the Oakland Raiders and the Oakland A's. Their focus was on the 49ers and the Giants."
