HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: The Face of The Future In Japan;
Economic Threat Of Aging Populace

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The year is 2025. The nation has twice as many old people as it has children; its economy is groaning under the weight of heavy taxes; its population is shrinking, and the Government's reserve of social security funds has run dry. 
 America in the next generation? Not exactly. For unless things change, this is the not-too-distant future of Japan, once the fastest-growing economy on the globe and now the world's most rapidly aging industrial society. With one person in six already older than 65, the challenge of how Japan will support its aging society grows more bedeviling with each passing year.
Not that the United States will be exempt from some of the same hardships. But Japan will be the world's guinea pig: No nation has ever had experience with such an elderly society and Japan is graying faster than the rest of the industrial world in North America and Europe. So how it faces the quandaries presented by a rapidly aging society is likely to serve as a model -- or a warning -- to other nations that will eventually undergo the same transformation.
The lessons from Japan so far are not encouraging, for it seems that the only way that Tokyo will be able to finance the nation's wrinkled future will be with significantly higher taxes and considerably smaller benefits.
"There is no golden egg," Atsushi Seike, an economics professor at Keio University, said. "So we have to get money from somewhere and that is only from the people or an increase in their productivity."
A declining birth rate and a graying society -- rather than exchange rates and trade surpluses -- are likely to be the key factors during the next several decades in shaping the economies of Japan and other rapidly aging industrial countries.
Unless policies change substantially, high payments will exhaust Japan's pension reserve fund sometime before the year 2025. By that time, the total social welfare burden -- much of it retirement and health care costs for the elderly -- could reach as high as 73 percent of national income, according to an official forecast. Taxpayers, of course, will have to pick up much of the swollen tab, and higher tax rates could lead to a flight of talent -- even among the famously loyal Japanese.
"Who's going to work?" asked Robert Alan Feldman, chief economist at Salomon Brothers Inc. in Tokyo. "The most productive guys will go somewhere else."
A simulation analysis by Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's advisory council forecast that unless the Government's finances are overhauled, the burden from social welfare and fiscal debt will balloon. For 2025, it projects an overall national debt of 153 percent of gross domestic product, compared with just 11.5 percent of the overall economic output in 1995.
As a result, the analysis concluded with perhaps a touch of typical Japanese alarmism, if the current system is not changed, the "economy will collapse."
"We don't have any concrete direction," Junichi Sakamoto, an official at the Health and Welfare Ministry, said. "But I think that many people think a cut in the benefits is inevitable."
The future strains on society are evident in the reaction of those unlucky workers, like Atsuto Hayahara, who have already suffered pension cuts for other reasons. A 55-year-old employee at Seishoku Kohyo, Mr. Hayahara saw his benefits cut when the pension fund at the troubled textile firm was bankrupted by the ailing economy and a stifling regulatory climate. Mr. Hayahara had been anticipating a lump-sum pension payment of 2.21 million yen -- or roughly $18,300 -- but that has been cut by more than half, to 880,000 yen, or $7,285.
"I'm just infuriated," Mr. Hayahara said. "I believed in the system, and look how it turned out. I've been betrayed.
"I wanted to do something good for my wife, who has had a harsh life, but now that the pension will be reduced, my dream has evaporated," he added. "We were putting in our own money. What we thought would be for our retired life has disappeared."
Japan's experience is relevant precisely because it is not unique, just ahead of its time. Many experts say that the United States and other countries face similarly difficult outlooks, as the populations born after World War II all begin to age at about the same time.
Still, America is aging more slowly than Japan, and -- at least for now -- its Social Security program is running decent surpluses. Elderly Americans will make up only 20 percent of the population in the year 2030; in Japan, they will account for 25 percent of the population by 2015.
By the year 2029, though, America's Social Security program could be technically bankrupt, too. Unless the Government restructures the system, argues Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist who served for a while as President Ronald Reagan's chief economic adviser, it will become a "bad deal" for participants in the program who stand to receive less and less in benefits.
In some respects, Japan is better off than America. For starters, 55 percent of Japanese older than 65 still live with their children, compared with less than 20 percent in other industrialized countries. That means that even if pension checks do not come on time, someone will look after most of the elderly here.
The Japanese are also legendary savers, and worries about their future have already driven them to accumulate an average of 9.6 million yen, about $79,500, in savings for each man, woman and child.
But even this tendency to save may be in jeopardy. In general, most people save money in middle age and then spend it after retirement, so that an elderly population is expected to have a much lower savings rate.
For the rest of the world, that means that Japan may no longer be the source of excess savings that are channeled into investments abroad, helping to prop up foreign bond markets.
"The savings rate could be zero or negative by 2010," said Charles Horioka, an economist at Osaka University who has analyzed the savings habits of the elderly. "Japan will have less savings, less money to finance investment and the economy won't grow as fast."
In any case, since the United States and other countries are not far behind in their own aging process, Japan will be forging a plan from which others may learn.
That is, if it develops a plan. Many economists say that the Government has been slow to revamp the nation's archaic pension system, a pay-as-you-go arrangement like the United States' Social Security system and most others in the industrial world.
The Government pension system has generally tried to provide enough money to cover all of a retiree's daily expenses. Every Japanese worker is now required to join the national pension system, and some also join supplementary corporate plans. Most workers pay at least the basic fixed monthly amount, around 12,700 yen, or $105, into the national system regardless of how much they earn.
But many individuals, mainly the self-employed, are not making their contributions to the national pension system because they no longer trust it. Failure to contribute is technically illegal but quietly tolerated.
Japan's complex social security system embraces a network of public, corporate and individual pension plan with numerous quirks and peculiarities that have developed over the years.
As in Mr. Hayahara's case, many employees join company pension plans to supplement the national program, and the troubles of the economy since the stock market collapsed in the early 1990's have plunged numerous pension funds into bankruptcy. Interest rates are at rock bottom in Japan, with the benchmark overnight lending rate at half a percent. The conservatively managed pension funds have been able to get returns of only 2 percent to 3 percent, which could cut deeply into future payments.
In the meantime, pensioners are making out well, for many of them joined pension plans later in their working lives but collect full benefits now. The result is that young and middle-aged workers are effectively subsidizing the elderly.
"If we keep the structure of the present system unchanged, then there will be intergenerational inequities," Mr. Horioka said. "The younger are getting less than they paid, losing out to the older people who are making out like bandits."
Many company pensions do not have enough money in reserve to cover their future payouts comfortably, and collectively, publicly listed companies could be underfinanced by as much as 40 trillion yen, roughly $331 billion, according to estimates by Watson Wyatt, a pension consulting firm in Tokyo. Official statistics show that 53 percent of the nation's 1,873 pension funds are running deficits or just breaking even.
This year, even the Honda Motor Company, which is flush with profits, said that for the third consecutive year, it had set aside extra money, about 25 billion yen, or $207 million, to bolster its skimpy pension reserve. Honda may be well able to afford it, but for most companies, such moves come at the cost of missing important business opportunities.
"It's a big deal for corporations," Mr. Feldman of Salomon said. "You can't build capacity for expansion. If you normally make a hundred bucks and buy a machine to build your business, now you've got to put that into a pension fund."
So far, the Government's remedies, like the actions taken in Washington, amount to little more than tinkering. Starting in 2001, Tokyo plans to gradually push the age at which pensions begin to 65 from the current 60. The Government has also suggested that pension benefits will have to be cut by one-fifth.
Government projections show that by 2025 workers' monthly contributions at corporations will have to be raised to about 35 percent of the average salary from an average of 17 percent now. But many experts say that the Government's fiscal system must be overhauled along with the social security system.
"Japan's scheme will not bring success," Kiyoshi Murakami, a prominent pension specialist in Tokyo, said. "There must be fundamental change."
Any solution is likely to include proposals to extend the employment of the aged, cut benefits to the wealthy and rebalance the system's benefits and burdens among the different generations. For the first time, the Government is also considering shifting part of the pension system to the private sector, an idea that is also under discussion in the United States.
But these considerations have increased mistrust of the public system among the Japanese. In a recent survey, more than 70 percent of those polled said that their biggest worry about retirement was whether their Government pensions would continue. Like aging baby boomers in the United States, many individuals here are setting up their own retirement funds in what has become one of the fastest-growing areas in pension management.
"One housewife in her 20's or 30's said she couldn't count on the public pension in the future," said Junichi Nezu, who monitors a hotline on old-age financial matters at the Japan Institute of Life Insurance. "So she said, 'I would like to stop paying the premium for the public pension and solely invest in an individual pension.' "

HEADLINE: Driving Increases, as Do Gas Prices

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
With demand surging this summer, the price of gasoline at the pump just took one of its biggest monthly jumps ever. Even running their refineries full tilt, oil companies have barely kept up with the nation's drivers, who increasingly favor hefty, less efficient vehicles.
And the industry will pocket much of the cash from the higher prices, since the price of its raw material, crude oil, has remained fairly steady. 
 The jump in prices, which rose as much as 15 cents a gallon for regular unleaded fuel at some stations in the New York area, represents a confluence of several long-term trends, analysts say. These trends are likely to continue, though the end of summer driving is expected to bring some relief.
One trend is the popularity of sport utility vehicles, which burn more gasoline per mile and have become the staple of many households for vacations and commuting to work. On top of that, Americans have driven more this summer, some to escape rising air fares and others because a strong economy has given them the money to take more elaborate vacations.
"People feel they have the ability to take the vacation they want to take," said Mike Morrissey, a spokesman for the American Automobile Association, which predicted that Labor Day weekend travel would be at record levels.
The result has been an unexpectedly big rise in gasoline consumption, which in recent weeks has been running about 3 percent higher than around this time last year. The demand has caused the nation's refiners to operate at a record 99.4 percent of capacity.
"The industry is straining to keep up with demand," said Frederick P. Leuffer, an oil analyst for Bear, Stearns, who has concentrated on the trends in refining for the last several years.
The last time drivers experienced such a big run-up in prices was in the spring of 1996, when gasoline rose 18 cents a gallon, but that was spread over four months. At the time, the oil industry was accused of price gouging, but it could point to a surge in crude oil prices as justifying the increases at the pump.
In recent months, though, crude oil has remained in a range around $19 to $21 a barrel. In contrast, retail prices in Connecticut -- which just cut its gasoline tax -- have risen 11 cents a gallon.
According to the Energy Information Administration, a part of the Energy Department that keeps track of prices, the average nationwide cost of regular unleaded gas rose to roughly $1.24 a gallon on Aug. 25 from a little less than $1.18 a gallon on July 21. The increases have been greater in the Northeast. In New England, regular unleaded jumped to $1.33 from $1.22. In the Middle Atlantic states, which include New York and New Jersey, the average price rose to $1.29 from $1.20.
After years of overcapacity that kept refining margins thin and profit lower than now, the major producers and independent refiners are in a strong position to increase prices, analysts say. Frustrated for years by often-low profit from refining -- except in a crisis like the Persian Gulf war -- the industry has sought to bring capacity more in line with demand.
It has not built new refineries since the 1970's, but has invested billions of dollars to upgrade existing refineries to produce the cleaner-burning fuel now required. The big surpluses in refining capacity that in years past could be called on to meet spikes in demand have disappeared. In addition, many refiners, to cut costs, are keeping lower supplies on hand, and this has increased uncertainty.
"The balance between demand and supply has become fragile," Mr. Leuffer of Bear, Stearns said. "Anything can tip the scales. Any interruption of supply has an exaggerated impact on prices."
Thus when the Tosco Refining Company shut down parts of its Bayway refinery in Linden, N.J., for maintenance early in August, spot prices shot up in the futures markets as traders became nervous about supplies.
Victor J. Cino, president of the Pyramid Oil Company, which leases six stations in New Jersey, stressed in an interview in his office in Tenafly that the current price rise could not be attributed to costlier crude oil. Instead, he said, it showed what happens when strong demand pushes up against refineries' running at nearly full capacity.
"Bayway has this tremendous power," he said. "It's not something that Tosco sought to gain deliberately. It's something that has evolved, that the marketplace gave them."
Bill Strobel, an assistant manager at a Mobil station in Northvale, N.J., pointed to bills from a refinery that showed that the price he was charged had risen to $1.19 a gallon for unleaded regular gasoline last Thursday from $1.05 in mid-July. For retail customers, that translated to an increase to $1.28 from $1.15. The station is set among a string of gas stations along Route 303, all of which had similar increases.
"People want to know what's going on," he said.
None of the half-dozen customers interviewed while filling up expressed any anger at the oil industry. Nor have they cut back their driving, and few shop for a better price. Even at current levels, the price at the pump is about the same as it was last year, when strong demand and rising crude oil prices kept the price up for most of the summer.
Thus, there has not been the kind of outcry among elected officials and consumer advocates as there was in the spring of 1996, when rising prices became a political issue, leading to an investigation by the Energy Department. In an analysis issued in June 1996, the department found that the main culprit was the run-up in the price of crude oil.
On the East Coast, one alternative at times of peak demand has been to import gasoline, but the latest price spike came so quickly that European refiners, whose tankers take about 30 days to reach United States ports, could not have an impact.
Mr. Leuffer said, however, that European refiners had stepped up their shipments, and that this, combined with a seasonal downturn in driving, would tend to bring prices down.
"Relief for the consumer is on its way," he said.

HEADLINE: With Markets Closed in U.S., Dollar Is Mostly Flat in Europe

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 1

 BODY:
The dollar was relatively flat in overseas trading today, underpinned by a general weakness in the yen amid persisting concern about the health of the Japanese economy.
Profit taking kept the dollar below 121 yen, after it rose from its trading level late Friday in New York, but dealers said that bearish sentiment about the Japanese currency was likely to remain. 
 "The market has been wary of selling the yen too aggressively because of the perceived official resistance to a further sharp weakening beyond 120," said Paul Meggyesi, senior currency economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell here. "But so far," he added, "there has been no attempt to prevent, let alone reverse, the latest downdraft on the yen."
Late in London today, the dollar traded at 120.85 yen, up from 120.80 in New York on Friday. The dollar fetched 1.8045 German marks, down from 1.8095 on Friday.
Financial markets were closed in the United States for Labor Day.
Japanese retail sales for July, due for release Tuesday, are expected to show a drop of 3.5 percent, which would re-emphasize the lack of a rebound in domestic demand, analysts said. "The Japanese economic situation is not looking encouraging in the near term," said Neil MacKinnon of Citibank, "and investors feel encouraged to push the dollar up against the yen."
The faltering Japanese recovery has been further burdened by the prospect of a Southeast Asian slowdown. Currency and stock losses there, and a possibly resulting slowdown, could damage Japanese competitiveness. But some economists say the impact on Japanese trade will be limited in the near term.
The dollar traded in a narrow range against the mark today in Europe, with attention fixed on Tuesday's setting of the tender for weekly securities-repurchase agreements by the German central bank. This will be followed by a bank council meeting on Thursday.
Traders say both events seem likely to evoke nervousness on a German interest-rate rise, helping the mark against the dollar. "Now that the Bundesbank has successfully talked the dollar down, it need worry no more, as the underlying inflation trend is stable at 1.5 percent," said Gottfried Hoerich, interest-rate analyst at J. P. Morgan in Frankfurt.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
U.S. Bull Nears Age When Japan's Stumbled

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
Countries, like companies, take pride in rising stock prices. So it is no surprise that both corporate and government officials see the prolonged rise in stock prices -- to a level about 10 times where they were just over 15 years ago, when the bull market began -- as proof of the superiority of the nation's economic system. And it is no surprise that they are freely advising other countries that success will come from emulation.
That description applies to the American market today, including the belief that the country's economic success stems in part from the ruthless efficiency that comes from giving companies flexibility to hire and fire when they wish even while Europe, with greater protections against layoffs, has lagged behind. 
 But the situation above was equally true of Japan in late 1989. That stock market rose by an almost exactly equal amount, over almost exactly the same period of time. And books abounded on Japanese management theory. The unique combination of Government economic management and a tradition of lifetime employment, we were told, had produced the greatest economic success story ever.
Emulating Japan was fashionable in business circles around the world, and many Japanese officials, both corporate and government, were quite willing to explain other countries' failures by contrasting those countries' systems with the superior Japanese ones.
That bull market ended badly, and is now almost universally seen as having been a bubble. It damaged Japan's economy because banks were left with huge quantities of bad loans that had been based on inflated asset valuations.
But while the bull market was going on, few worried about possible problems in Japan. Those who talked about valuations being far too high began doing so years too soon, and had been largely discredited well before the actual peak in stock prices, at the end of 1989. Japan's notions of value were different from those of other countries, it was said, and were justified by the very success of the market and the economy. The Japanese public eagerly bought stocks recommended by Japan's Big Four securities firms, which were widely suspected of being able to control prices to assure that there would rarely, if ever, be any losses.
In this country, some old-fashioned valuation measures -- like the dividend yield on stocks -- flashed warning signals years ago. But anyone who got out of stocks on the basis of such measures has lost out on a lot of profits, and those who cited them have been forced to change their tune or be dismissed as irrelevant in the new era that has dawned. The public has embraced stock mutual funds, perhaps more than individual stocks, and has put its faith in fund managers who in some cases have become well-known celebrities.
There were similarities in attitudes as well when the two bull markets began. Japan's stock market bottomed in October 1974, when worldwide recession brought on by soaring oil prices had depressed investors. Japan, it was said, was an island nation largely devoid of natural resources. How could it hope to compete in a new world of rising prices for such resources? In less than a year, the Nikkei 225 had fallen almost 25 percent.
The American stock market suffered then as well, and for some of the same reasons. But it took years for the American market -- and for America's economic psyche -- to begin to recover. By the late 1970's, amid a new round of rising oil prices, Japan seemed to be coping while the United States talked of a national malaise and seemed unable to deal with soaring inflation.
The American stock market hit bottom on Aug. 12, 1982, with the Dow Jones industrial average at 777.92 points, down nearly 25 percent in about a year. There was widespread pessimism and a belief that the recession the country was then in would continue indefinitely.
In the years that followed, the revivals of both stock markets were greeted first by skepticism and then by growing acceptance. Only after the bull markets had persisted for more than a decade -- and clearly outpaced those of other major countries -- did most economic commentators find evidence of superiority in the system of the country that had produced soaring stock prices.
There are, of course, significant differences between the Japanese bull market of 1974 through 1989 and the American one that began in 1982. Even now, the valuations accorded American stocks are nowhere near as high as the peak Japanese valuations. While the two bull markets produced very similar returns in their first 15 years -- Japan was up 903 percent during the period, and in the United States the Dow gained 925 percent -- they showed some significant divergences along the way.
The Japanese bull market ended just over 11 weeks after its 15th birthday, with the Nikkei 225 up 1,008 percent from its 1974 low. Were the United States bull market to similarly end, the Dow would peak on Oct. 30, at 8,605.90.
No current piece of economic news would clearly explain why stocks should stop climbing, just as there were no obvious economic problems in Japan in 1989. The economy is growing, and corporate profits continue to rise at a rapid pace.
Still, it may be worth recalling that things can change, and that widespread expectations can be wrong. In an article published in this newspaper on Aug. 15, 1982, it was noted that brokerage firms were reeling because the public had largely abandoned the stock market over the previous year. Nearly everyone on Wall Street expected stock prices to continue falling, the article added, citing as reasons the following:
"The economic upturn is nowhere in sight. It did not appear in the second quarter of the year, as many people had hoped. It does not seem to be appearing in the third quarter, either. 'My analysts come back from visiting companies,' said John R. Groome, senior vice president in charge of equity research at the U.S. Trust Company, 'and everybody's despondent. No orders. No sign of an upturn.'
"Corporate profits are continuing to slide, increasing the likelihood that companies will have to cut their dividends. A recent Standard & Poor's survey of 885 companies found that corporate earnings sank 16 percent in the second quarter following an 11 percent drop in the preceding three months."
It only goes to show how easy it is to be dead wrong about the future. In fact, the bear market had ended a few days before, and the economy was soon to enter a prolonged boom as well.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES;
Stephen Foster's World Truly Was Sad and Dreary

BYLINE: By KARAL ANN MARLING; Karal Ann Marling teaches popular culture at the University of Minnesota and is the author of "Graceland: Going Home With Elvis."

 BODY:

DOO-DAH!
Stephen Foster and the Rise of American Popular Culture
By Ken Emerson
Illustrated. 400 pages. Simon & Schuster. $30.
 It's a real feat to write an engaging biography of a person about whom almost nothing is known for certain. Thanks to a judicious pruning of family records on the part of his mortified descendants, the facts surrounding the short life and the squalid death of the American composer Stephen Foster are exceedingly sparse.
He was born in 1826 on the outskirts of Pittsburgh, a booming industrial city on the edge of the American wilderness, to a large, musical and often impecunious clan. With documented stays in Cincinnati and New York City, and a presumptive visit to Bardstown, Ky., Foster lived in Pittsburgh for most of his life. There, he wrote songs suggesting that the singer was languishing in painful exile from a lovely and almost wholly imaginary South. ("My Old Kentucky Home," published in 1853, is a case in point.) 
 Stephen Foster married in 1850. The union was marred by Foster's chronic inability to support a family on the proceeds from the sale of sheet music containing a growing library of minstrel songs that would someday become American standards, including "Camptown Races," "Oh! Susanna," "Old Folks at Home" and "Jeanie With the Light Brown Hair." The latter, copyrighted in 1854, may be a tribute to his long-suffering wife, Jane, written at the end of one of their frequent separations.
Foster, it seems, drank to excess, much to her horror. In his book about Foster, Ken Emerson suggests that Mrs. Foster may have had other causes for complaint, too. Their daughter was probably conceived on the couple's wedding night, he argues, and thereafter "they might never have had sex again." In any case, she was not present when Stephen Foster died of dissipation and drink in Bellevue Hospital in Manhattan in 1864. America's greatest composer had spent the final months of his life alone, picking out melodies on an old piano in the shabby back room of a German grocery store on the Bowery.
All this might amount to so much tragic trivia, however, were it not for Mr. Emerson's determination to use Foster to trace the rise of popular culture in the United States back to the 1840's and 50's and to industrial cities, like Pittsburgh, where a song first became a commodity, like an iron ingot or a bale of cotton.
In common with the manufactured goods that moved up and down the rivers from the Five Points district of Pittsburgh, songs passed through many hands before they finally reached a mass audience. Composers, lyricists, famous performers who introduced numbers and lent their images to the covers of sheet music, publishers and printers all played roles in the creation and distribution of the cultural products of the Industrial Revolution. They each took their cut of the profits, too, leaving Foster and other composers as underpaid junior partners in the business of songwriting.
It is not surprising, then, that machinery, modern industry, and the calamities associated with entrepreneurship are often the themes of Foster songs that seem wholly bucolic. The second verse of "Oh! Susanna," for instance, has the singer jumping aboard one of two fast steamboats that held the record for the run from Cincinnati to Louisville (it promptly explodes), sending a telegram, and finally riding a new railroad locomotive (it breaks down, of course), all in the space of five short lines.
Most of Foster's output fell into a recognized category of minstrel songs, music performed by white artists in blackface that purported to describe a Southern slave culture neither Foster nor his Pittsburgh friends knew anything about. The reasons for the widespread popularity of minstrelsy in the decades before the Civil War are closely related to the sense of loss experienced by those who lived in Pittsburgh and other burgeoning industrial centers.
Mr. Emerson sees blackface as a nostalgic lament for a natural world overrun by progress. The imaginary primitivism of blackface music was a form of consolation for white Americans suddenly cut off from their pioneer roots, buttoned into business suits and locked into offices or factories. However bad the lot of the wage slave, there was always someone worse off than himself: the interlocutor of a typical Stephen Foster number, toiling in the make-believe cotton fields back home.
In their own era, Foster's songs were highly topical productions. Mr. Emerson says the famous "Doo-dah!" refrain in "Camptown Races" may have been the cry of a hooker, plying her trade at illegal, nighttime contests of speed held in shantytowns on the fringes of respectable communities. The songs often drew on well-known source material from the theater and serial fiction, as when Foster recast the titular theme of Harriet Beecher Stowe's abolitionist novel, "Uncle Tom's Cabin," as his own "Old Kentucky Home."
Although Stowe's tract seemed to reviewers to condemn blackface high jinks, she had a great deal in common with Foster. Both, in their respective fields, were media stars; like Foster, Stowe had written a best seller about a South she had never seen. Yet the novel and the songs (however inadvertently, in Foster's case) both also promoted a new understanding of the human character of people of color on the eve of the Civil War. The African-American singers of Stephen Foster's plaintive melodies love their families, work hard and pine for the peace and serenity of home. They are, in short, a lot like white entrepreneurs from Pittsburgh.
With "Doo-Dah!," Mr. Emerson, who has written about popular music for 30 years, has made an impressive contribution to a growing body of analytic literature on popular culture. Perhaps because the incidents of his subject's life are lost to history, he has looked to the social, cultural, economic and artistic milieu in which Foster operated. The result is a readable, fascinating book that seems particularly pertinent to an understanding of American culture in the 1990's, a culture driven by many of the same forces and prejudices that first found expression in Stephen Foster's music of the antebellum era.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Is Up on Stock Rally And German Rate Stability

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar rose against major currencies yesterday, setting a nearly two-week high versus the German mark. Its rise was helped by a stock market rebound and by a German central bank decision to leave a money market rate alone.
The demand for dollars was fueled by the stock rally, which pushed the Dow Jones industrials to their biggest one-day point gain. The rally, in turn, was driven by doubts that the Federal Reserve would soon raise interest rates. 
 The dollar was also helped by a weak Japanese retail sales report, which added to pessimism about Japan's economic recovery. The Japanese Finance Minister suggested that interest rates there would remain low and said that the yen's recent weakness was in line with economic fundamentals.
"The dollar looks set to move higher during the rest of the month," said Roger Chapin, foreign-exchange manager at Banc One International in Columbus, Ohio.
Late in New York yesterday, the dollar was quoted at 1.8335 marks, up from 1.8095 late Friday. The dollar traded at 121.47 Japanese yen, up from 120.80 on Friday. The British pound fetched $1.5920, down from $1.62. American financial markets were closed Monday for Labor Day.
The stock market got a push from a report by the National Association of Purchasing Management showing that growth in manufacturing slowed in August. That eased fear of inflation and of higher interest rates; such concerns had scared stock buyers.
The dollar was also aided by remarks by a member of the Bundesbank's policy council, Olaf Sievert, that it was premature to think German inflation was strong enough to require a rate increase soon.
Against the yen, the dollar continued a strong rally as Japan reported that retail sales at department stores and supermarkets fell in July, adding to a spate of recently sluggish economic data.
The dollar's current level above 120 yen, which until Friday had not been seen since early in May, has been cited as the benchmark for inciting trade tension between the United States and Japan. A weak yen makes Japanese goods more affordable in the United States, increasing the American trade deficit.

HEADLINE: Bronx and Queens Endorsements

 BODY:
Next Tuesday's primaries will be more important than the November finale in many parts of New York City with overwhelming Democratic majorities. These are our endorsements for some of the more competitive races in the Bronx and Queens.
 
Bronx Borough President
 Today's Bronx is a far different place than it was when Fernando Ferrer first became Borough President in 1987. The images of that old, bad era have begun to fade -- burned-out buildings, shuttered businesses, "Fort Apache" frontier lawlessness and a bumbling, corrupt government epitomized by Mr. Ferrer's predecessor, Stanley Simon. New housing, economic development, lower crime and more efficient government have begun to turn the borough around. The Bronx, of course, is still plagued by problems, and Mr. Ferrer can hardly take all the credit for progress. But good things have happened on his watch. Unlike previous Bronx leaders, he has pushed forward. 
 The City Council member Israel Ruiz Jr. is an energetic but eccentric politician whose agenda has never been entirely clear. In this race, despite a well-financed campaign, Mr. Ruiz's explanation of what he would do is incredibly fuzzy, focusing on a promise that his "leadership" will somehow reduce the number of dysfunctional families in poor neighborhoods. His attacks on the incumbent have ranged from unfair to outrageous. There is no question that Fernando Ferrer deserves re-election.
 
Bronx City Council
12th District (Co-op City and northeast Bronx): For the week preceding the passage of the city's budget, the incumbent, Lawrence Warden, lobbies fairly effectively for projects in his district. The rest of the year he is all but missing in action. His challenger, Shirley Saunders, is an aide to Representative Eliot Engel who shows commendable enthusiasm but seems familiar only with her home base at Co-op City. In a near toss-up, our endorsement goes to Mr. Warden for his close ties to all parts of his district.
14th District (west Bronx): The departing incumbent, Israel Ruiz, is supporting Richard Soto, a process server who was once the Councilman's chief of staff. The Bronx Democratic organization is backing Adolfo Carrion Jr., a former city planner and community board manager. The party has used its familiar tactic of trying to win the election by throwing opponents off the ballot in court challenges. It would be tempting to back Mr. Soto, the only survivor, out of protest if Mr. Carrion were not so clearly the better candidate. But Mr. Soto, like his mentor Mr. Ruiz, seems to be off in a political world all his own, with no agenda beyond vague talk about accountability. Mr. Carrion is familiar with the district's problems and has good ideas about economic development. We endorse Mr. Carrion.
 
Queens City Council
20th District (Flushing, parts of Fresh Meadows and Whitestone): Flushing is booming, but is strained by an influx of immigrant families. It needs a Council member who can ease the effects of overcrowding, help bring newcomers into the community and soothe the feelings of disrupted longtime residents. Julia Harrison, the veteran incumbent, no longer provides either inclusiveness or initiative. Her opponents are the district school board president, Pauline Chu; a community activist, Debra Markell, and John Liu, an actuary who is vice president of a civic association.
All offer more energy and good will than the incumbent. Mr. Liu shows real promise, but has relatively little experience in community affairs. Ms. Markell has a long resume of volunteer work, from leading protests against low-flying planes at La Guardia Airport to an anti-litter program in downtown Flushing. But Ms. Chu's work on education issues and aggressive campaign organization may give her a better chance of winning the nomination. Our endorsement goes to Pauline Chu.

HEADLINE: Commercial Real Estate;
Nonprofits' Wall St. Home Filling Up

BYLINE: By MERVYN ROTHSTEIN

 BODY:
The Association Center, opened five years ago at 120 Wall Street to help keep national and international nonprofit organizations from leaving New York City because of high rents, is about to become 100 percent occupied.
Roger A. Silverstein, a vice president of Silverstein Properties, which runs the Association Center building, said that a lease for 50,000 square feet was expected to be signed this month. He would not identify the new tenant. The center, created in cooperation with the city's Economic Development Corporation, occupies 400,000 square feet, 20 floors of the 34-story building at South Street, which was built in 1929. 
 Because of incentives from the city's Industrial Development Agency, nonprofit organizations that rent offices in the building are exempt from city real estate taxes, which are usually passed through by landlords to tenants as part of the rent. (The Economic Development Corporation runs the agency.)
Except for tenants of the Association Center, nonprofit groups must own and occupy property in New York City to qualify for a real estate tax exemption. Exemptions for nonprofits are also available at office buildings set up as condominiums, like the former B. Altman store at 34th Street and Madison Avenue, now home to the Graduate Center of the City University of New York, Oxford University Press and the Science, Industry and Business branch of the New York Public Library.
The 38 nonprofits in the Association Center include the National Urban League, the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International, the Alan Guttmacher Institute and the International Planned Parenthood Federation/Western Hemisphere Region.
Mr. Silverstein said he was in discussions with the Economic Development Corporation to incorporate into the center the building's remaining 200,000 square feet, which are leased to for-profit organizations. "The first of those leases is up in early 1999, and we hope within four or five years to have the 200,000 square feet available," he said.
Charles Millard, the president of the Economic Development Corporation, said that "expanding the initiative within that building is a particularly good option, though nothing is final." The leasing of the center, Mr. Millard said, is "a column of strength in the fulfillment of the Mayor's Downtown Revitalization Plan -- a building that had substantial vacant space now hardly has any."
Mr. Silverstein said that under its contract with the city, Silverstein Properties charges nonprofits an average annual rent of $19.74 a square foot over 15 years -- an average of $16.74 for the first five years, $19.74 for the next five and $22.74 for the final five. The rents reflect an annual tax exemption of $5.26 a square foot, which was the tax rate when the program began. It has since dropped to $3.05, a rate that would be reflected in any lease renewal, Mr. Silverstein said. Market-rate rentals in a similar downtown building would be about $25 a square foot a year, he said.
"Not-for-profits are required to make a lease commitment for 15 years in exchange for the tax benefit," he said. "The lease also includes free rent for the first year and a $35-a-square-foot landlord contribution for renovation work."
The real estate recession of the late 80's and early 90's, which hit downtown especially hard, played a significant role in the length of time it took to fill the center, Mr. Silverstein said. But now that downtown is picking up, with several empty office buildings converted to residential use and commercial tenants again leasing space, the center is reaping the benefits.
"When the Juvenile Diabetes Foundation came aboard in 1995, it gave us a strong identity, and not-for-profits started to take notice of the building," Mr. Silverstein said. "Our leasing program started to accelerate, and this year the National Urban League became another strong anchor tenant. In a few short months, we jumped from 75 percent to near 100 percent occupancy."
The creation of the center did not immediately halt the flow of nonprofits elsewhere. In 1994, the United Negro College Fund moved its headquarters from East 62d Street to Fairfax, Va., and that year the Boys and Girls Clubs of America moved to Atlanta. In fact, between 1983 and 1994, more than 2,000 nonprofit headquarters left the city. "Because of New York's increasing tax rate, cities like Washington and Atlanta were offering rental rates far better than New York's," Mr. Silverstein said.
But as the center's identity grew, it made New York competitive with other urban areas.
"The Association Center was the beginning of the end of the exodus of not-for-profits from New York City," said Joel A. Dolci, president of the New York Society of Association Executives, a trade group. "If anything is going out of New York now, it's a rarity, and some not-for-profits are coming in and considering coming in. I believe all the tenants at the center would have left if they didn't have an affordable place in a Class A building."
According to the Economic Development Corporation, there are about 11,600 nonprofit organizations in the city, employing almost 600,000 people and paying about $1 billion in taxes a year.
When the National Urban League became the Association Center's largest tenant, it leased 48,568 square feet on two floors. Before the United Negro College Fund moved its headquarters to Virginia, it and the league had shared a 21-story building at 500 East 62d Street.
The Urban League was represented in the deal by Arlene Wysong of Newmark & Company Real Estate and David Lebenstein of Time Equities, brokers who specialize in placing nonprofits and who also recently brought the Center for Urban Community Services (12,600 square feet) and the United Negro College Fund's New York regional office (4,400 square feet) to the Association Center.
Both Ms. Wysong and Mr. Lebenstein said there could be problems in placing nonprofit organizations, especially local ones.
"With rents rising in the city, we're going to run into difficulties," Ms. Wysong said. "The Association Center is wonderful, but it's only for national and international organizations. Local not-for-profits are usually the poorest groups, and they're in the direst straits. What we need is an across-the-board solution, such as some kind of tax abatement to any landlord who rents to not-for-profits."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Roger A. Silverstein's company runs the Association Center, 120 Wall Street. Nonprofit groups that move in are exempt from real estate taxes. (Andrea Mohin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
A new Belgian carrier is modeling itself after Southwest Airlines, apparently with success.

BYLINE: By Paul Burnham Finney

 BODY:
UNDAUNTED by the demise of Sir Freddie Laker's Skytrain and other low-priced trans-Atlantic carriers over the years, City Bird -- a new Belgian airline owned by City Hotels -- began low-fare flights between Miami and Orlando, Fla., and Brussels last March and then added New York (Newark International Airport), Los Angeles and San Francisco (Oakland International Airport) in June. Today, the carrier says it is packing passengers in with a 92 percent load factor.
Right now, City Bird is offering unrestricted one-way coach tickets between Newark and Brussels for $148, good until mid-December, when they will increase to $189. Even a one-way seat in the carrier's business-class section is a relative bargain -- $699 on the Newark-Brussels run, compared with $1,900 that Delta Air Lines, Sabena and other airlines charge. City Bird will throw in a free rental car for three days for those who buy a round-trip business-class ticket -- a pretty good deal considering the high cost of renting a car in Europe. 
 "City Bird is a Southwest-type operation," said its senior vice president, Serge Barder, referring to Southwest Airlines, the profitable -- and popular -- American no-frills carrier. Like Southwest, the Belgian imitator is using electronic ticketing to keep costs down.
City Bird has two wide-bodied, 371-seat MD-11's, the McDonnell Douglas successor to the DC-10. With the addition of another MD-11 and two Boeing 767's, the carrier expects to increase its current four flights a week between Newark and Brussels to daily service next spring. City Bird's 36-seat business class, called Royal Eagle, has fully reclining seats and power outlets for laptop computers, plus frills like vintage wines and amenity kits. Travelers can upgrade from coach to business class right at the airport -- if seats are available -- for only an additional $250, compared with the $699 for an advance reservation.
For leisure travelers, landing in Brussels may not be one of City Bird's strengths. But veteran business travelers know the city as the capital of the European Community and a headquarters town for American companies.
The Belgian capital has also turned into something of an air and rail hub for Europe. For example, Virgin Group's Virgin Express, which works closely with City Bird and also tickets electronically, flies between Brussels and Madrid, Barcelona, Copenhagen, Milan and Rome for around $100 and London (both Heathrow and Gatwick) for $78. Alternatively, after making the rounds in Brussels, travelers can now take the high-speed Eurostar train through the English Channel tunnel to London.
 
High Hotel Prices
Is there some relief ahead from high United States hotel prices? Maybe, considering that occupancy declined slightly in the first half of 1997 for the first time in five years, according to Smith Travel Research. But don't hold your breath waiting for rates to reflect the change. The figures are national averages, and in top business markets like New York, where the average daily rate has increased to $160 from $142 a year ago, room demand continues firm.
"The economy is doing well, and international travel is strong," said Chuck Ross, a vice president at Smith Travel Research. "Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia and San Francisco have high occupancy and high room rates similar to New York's." Where are the lower rates? "In Atlanta and Nashville, among the 25 biggest hotel markets," Mr. Ross said. "And in the Midwest and secondary cities."
 
Village Passports
The New York Passport Agency opened for business yesterday at its new, roomier offices in the West Village at 376 Hudson Street between West Houston and King Street -- a less convenient location for business travelers in midtown offices but closer to Wall Street. Travelers who need a new or renewed passport in a hurry must still have tickets indicating a departure within 14 days, or a convincing letter of explanation, to qualify for personal processing. The agency is an appointment-only operation, as it was in Rockefeller Center; the new telephone number is 212-206-3500.
 
Refurbished Ruble
Business travelers who have been fumbling with ridiculously high-denomination paper rubles in Moscow and other Russian cities will find things easier in early January when the Government plans to lop three 000's off its notes. The paper currency now comes in 1,000; 5,000; 10,000; 50,000; 100,000, and 500,000 denominations, with a 5,000 denomination note worth about $1. After the change, 10 rubles -- roughly the equivalent of $2 -- will be the lowest paper denomination available. Smaller amounts will be in coins.
In any case, the currency will still not be easily convertible. "Take dollars or Deutsche marks to Russia and exchange them there," an American Express representative said, "but you don't want to bring rubles out." Wherever possible, old Moscow hands advise, use credit cards to pay for hotel, restaurant and other travel expenditures.
 
Teeing Off at St. Andrews
Here's a hot reward for very frequent travelers: silver or gold members of British Airways' Executive Club program can use 210,000 miles (the equivalent of 30 round trips between New York and London) to play golf in Scotland at the sport's fountainhead, the Royal and Ancient Golf Club of St. Andrews. Travelers can add in AT&T True Rewards and Diners Club earnings to help qualify. The 210,000 miles will pay for trans-Atlantic business-class tickets on British Airways for two and two nights at the Old Course Hotel, plus greens fees. The offer expires on Oct. 31.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Rally After Purchasing Report

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Bonds rallied yesterday after a weaker-than-expected manufacturing report helped eased concerns that the Federal Reserve would need to raise interest rates soon to rein in the economy.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond ended the day up 20/32, to 97 21/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.55 percent, from 6.60 percent on Friday. The Treasury market was closed on Monday in observance of Labor Day. 
 Prices rose after the National Association of Purchasing Management said that its factory index fell to 56.8 last month from 58.6 in July. Some economists had expected a reading of about 59. The prices-paid component, a gauge of inflation, barely moved, rising to 53.8, up two hundredths of a percentage point. The national report relieved worries raised on Friday, when the Chicago Purchasing Management Association's report came in much stronger than expected.
The Chicago report gave a distinct impression that the economy was surging. But the two reports rarely share the same outlook. Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said the national report proved "once again that the Chicago puchasing managers index can be a serious misleading indicator on a month-to month-basis."
"Of the more important N.A.P.M. index, the bond market is rallying on the unexpected news," he said, adding, "At the same time it must be recognized that the N.A.P.M. index is still indicating broad expansion in the industrial sector, and that the prices-paid index is suggesting increasing price pressures, with a growing net differential between those reporting higher prices and those reporting lower."
Dave Shabelman, a Treasury market analyst with Standard & Poor's MMS in San Francisco, a market research and analysis firm, said: "Despite today's weak report, there are still traders who want to get out of the market given that prices are nearing the top of the range. The upside is likely limited in front of the jobs data," a reference to the August jobs report due on Friday.
Some of the buying in the Treasury market yesterday was by investors who had bet that prices would fall, and were forced to buy back securities to limit their losses.
A strong dollar in currency markets also buoyed Treasury prices.
At the Treasury's regular weekly auction, rates were moderately mixed as expected, with the three-month rate averaging 3.07 percent, down from 5.12 percent last week, and the six-month bill rate at 5.19 percent, up from 5.14 percent.
The bond market next turns its attention to data on leading indicators, due today, motor vehicle sales, construction spending, factory orders and chain store sales. But the market's chief focus will be Friday's employment statistics, which will be a primary determinant of the near-term direction of bond yields. The payroll number is expected to be depressed as a result of the United Parcel Service strike.
Following are the results of yesterday's weekly Treasury auction of new three-month and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Candidates Striving to Be Heard;
It's Uphill for 2 Trying Not to Be Also-Rans for Mayor

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

 BODY:
A man wearing a double-breasted suit and a broad smile strode amid the canned beans and Pampers at a market in Lefrak City in Queens, handing out smudgy photocopied fliers and telling shoppers, "I'm Eric Ruano-Melendez, and I'm running for mayor."
"Mayor of what?" one man asked. 
 Another man, apparently assuming that this unknown must belong to a fringe party, said: "I can't vote in your primary. I'm a Democrat." So is Mr. Ruano-Melendez.
When two checkout clerks explained in Spanish that they could not vote, Mr. Ruano-Melendez rolled his eyes, laughed and asked, "Where are the citizens?"
All year, the knock on the best-known candidates in the Sept. 9 Democratic primary, Ruth W. Messinger, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Sal F. Albanese, has been that they are second-tier material, uninspired candidates with quixotic, uncoordinated campaigns, and neither the message nor the money to topple the Republican incumbent, Rudolph W. Giuliani.
If those three are in danger of being also-rans, then what to make of Roland Rogers and Mr. Ruano-Melendez, who round out the Democratic primary field? Without renown, money, political connections or paid campaign staffs, they plod against their own obscurity, half willing to admit that they stand no chance of winning, yet trying mightily to be taken seriously. If there is a theme to their campaigns, it is the struggle to be heard.
At a candidates' forum in Harlem on Aug. 26, each candidate was promised 15 minutes, but Mr. Rogers was cut off after 7. He talked about the kind of meaty economic development issues -- the need for a railroad freight depot in the city and a rehabilitated Brooklyn waterfront -- that would gladden the heart of a city planner, but the city's news media made little mention of his performance.
Mr. Ruano-Melendez, 49, won some news coverage at an earlier debate by singing a snippet of "The Star-Spangled Banner," by his apparent inability to understand the moderator's questions and by getting the primary date wrong.
Each likes to spin elaborate scenarios for his victory. Mr. Rogers, 50, has called on Mr. Albanese, a City Councilman, and Mr. Sharpton to meet with him to unite behind one of them, a call they have ignored.
"I'm the logical unity candidate, because I'm Rudy Giuliani's worst nightmare, a credible African-American," Mr. Rogers said. According to this plan, such Sharpton and Albanese endorsements would so shock the city that media attention and money would follow, and he would be able to force Ms. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, into a runoff. "Then the momentum is with me all the way," he said.
Mr. Ruano-Melendez offers his own version. "The turnout's going to be low, see, so if I can motivate the Hispanic vote, as the only Hispanic in the race, and if we can hold Messinger under 40 percent and force a runoff, I'm poised," he said.
Mr. Rogers is a former marketing consultant and, by his own account, a failed real estate investor who is president of the New York City Birthday Committee, which was organized to celebrate the anniversary of the city's first government formed in 1653 by the Dutch. He goes at his quest with an earnestness that is almost infectious.
He hands out leaflets on the subway, talking intently about economics and race relations and exhorting riders to "help me pull off the upset of the century." He introduces a friend, John F. McHugh, a lawyer and railroad expert, as "my deputy mayor for economic development." His fax machine pumps out news releases describing in triumphant terms his performance at candidate forums and declaring that the other Democrats in the race fear him.
And he insists, at least most of the time, that he can actually win, that even in an era of mass advertising, face-to-face campaigning can prevail. All evidence to the contrary, he says it does not matter that his political experience is limited to working for a few campaigns in his native Buffalo in the 1970's. Voters, he says, want people uncorrupted by the process he is trying so hard to master.
Such faith is common to unknowns running for high office, as is the perplexed reaction that Mr. Rogers, who lives on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, generally gets as he campaigns. "They don't know who I am," he acknowledged. "But when I talk to them, their whole hearts light up. 'Here's someone that I can vote for.' "
The response was a little different on Wednesday a week ago as Mr. Rogers shook hands at the Central Brooklyn Coordinating Council, a coalition of social-service groups based in Bedford-Stuyvesant. "You're going against my man Sharpton?" asked a security guard, echoing the response from a number of black voters Mr. Rogers approached.
Asked after meeting with Mr. Rogers if he would endorse him, Charles Joshua, the Coordinating Council president, said, "I think he's a bright young person," and left it at that.
A reception for Mr. Rogers that night at 26 Hudson, a restaurant alongside the Hudson River in Manhattan, drew a few dozen people, including some who said they were friends of friends and knew nothing about Mr. Rogers, and some who said they intended to vote for Mr. Giuliani.
Mr. Rogers chafes at being lumped with Mr. Ruano-Melendez, whom he dismisses as "not a serious candidate," or with Mr. Sharpton, whom he calls divisive and unelectable.
And despite his usually brave face, a bit of desperation sometimes creeps into Mr. Rogers's talk, as when he berates newspaper and television reporters for ignoring him. His campaign is so hungry for attention that his campaign manager repeatedly tried to persuade a reporter to travel to Buffalo to cover Mr. Rogers's high school reunion.
"I can't win if I can't get the message out," Mr. Rogers said. During an interview, he told a reporter: "You can make a difference. You can make this happen. You could be my press secretary when I'm mayor."
If Mr. Rogers, as the sober novice, offers one paradigm of the shoestring candidate, Mr. Ruano-Melendez offers another: the perennial candidate who takes himself altogether less seriously.
Mr. Ruano-Melendez, a native of Guatemala who lives in Jackson Heights, Queens, ran for Congress in 1992 and 1994, and for mayor in 1993, when he got 7 percent of the Democratic primary vote against Mayor David N. Dinkins, a performance even he attributes to being the only Hispanic candidate on the ballot.
He gives a number of reasons for running again, none of them having to do with policy: "I like it." "There has to be someone Hispanic in the race." And "I feel like I'm an example for immigrants."
Mr. Ruano-Melendez, who moved to New York at age 19 and has been an engineer in the city's Environmental Protection Department for the last 20 years, goes on to say, "In Peru, Fujimori, he was an engineer, too, and he was a minority and nobody thought he could win, but he did, so why shouldn't I run?"
Buttonholing people on Queens sidewalks while a friend follows along, holding a large, badly copied picture of him, Mr. Ruano-Melendez outlines some unusual ideas about the city's problems. Drugs? Either legalize them or execute the dealers, he says. Homelessness? Set up vast fields of mobile homes. Crime? Bring in the National Guard.
"I have military experience," he said, noting that he has served in the Army. "None of the other candidates have it. That's why I'm qualified to request the National Guard."
He clearly enjoys himself more than any of his opponents, laughing frequently as he chats with prospective voters, and poking gentle fun not only at the other candidates but also at himself. When a Hispanic man looks confused by Mr. Ruano-Melendez's appeal for votes, the candidate says, "Must be my accent."
But like Mr. Rogers, he turns serious when lamenting his inability to break into the nightly television news or the morning papers. "Without that, it's very hard to get anywhere," he said. "Four years ago, I was the surprise candidate, but this time, I guess I'm old news."

HEADLINE: NEW YORK SCHOOLS OPEN WITH NEW AID AND OLD TROUBLES

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG

 BODY:
New York City's 1.1 million public-school children begin returning to their classrooms today to find a system that received an election-year infusion of new computers, textbooks, art classes and reading teachers over the summer vacation. But the system remains plagued by severe overcrowding and chronically low performance in one-third of its districts.
For the 510,000 middle school and high school students who are scheduled to take their seats today, and the more than 550,000 elementary school students who are to arrive tomorrow, this is a school opening that has drawn unusually intense attention from the adults who oversee and observe the system. 
 Much of that attention has been political -- with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican seeking re-election in November, and Ruth W. Messinger, who is seeking the Democratic nomination in next week's primary, squabbling over whether the Mayor's attention to the system has been too little too late. Mr. Giuliani has spent hundreds of millions of dollars on the schools in recent months, but only after three consecutive years in which he cut the average amount spent on each student.
But such arguments are likely to be lost on those students who will get their first look at their new classrooms today.
If they are in a middle school, they will probably find four new computers and a printer in many classrooms, and teachers who got as many as 30 hours of training over the summer -- all results of the Mayor's $123 million program to enhance technology education. If they are in an elementary school that performed among the lowest quarter on the city's reading test, they will find new reading teachers and newly stocked libraries -- a result of the Mayor's $125 million reading program.
And many students in the high schools will find teachers hired specifically to help them prepare for tougher Regents standards in mathematics and other subjects -- a result of a $40 million allocation from the State Legislature.
For all that largesse, though, there is likely to be a fair share of disruption and discomfort.
Out of the roughly 66,000 teachers in the city's 1,100 public schools, nearly 4,000 are new -- 400 of them hired only in the last week. Both the new teachers and their principals complain that cumbersome, centrally administered, random assignments have left them little opportunity to get to know if they are right for each other. [Page B4.]
As the new teachers are getting used to their classrooms, 2,500 senior teachers are still awaiting word on whether Gov. George E. Pataki will sign a bill now on his desk. It would permit them to retire this fall at age 55, rather than 62, without jeopardizing their pensions. The Governor has signaled that he is likely to veto the bill by tomorrow's deadline.
In the cafeterias, more than 1,000 newly hired school aides will be learning on the job how to supervise students when they can be at their rowdiest. The aides were hired to replace the teachers who have been relieved of that duty under the city's contract with the teachers' union.
And more than 80,000 students, especially in the Bronx and Queens, will be assigned to overcrowded classrooms, some of which will spill out into hallways and converted bathrooms, just as they did in the past. While the system, the nation's largest, has created new space for 23,000 students this year through the construction of new schools, the renovation of dozens of other schools and the installation of portable trailers, enrollment is expected to have grown by more than 18,000 students since last year.
A report released yesterday by the Citizens' Budget Commission, an independent, business-financed watchdog group, said the overcrowding was a result of a rapid rise in enrollment, fueled mainly by immigration. The system grew by 117,706 students from 1990 to 1996, compared with just 21,254 from 1983 to 1990.
But the commission faulted the Board of Education, the Giuliani administration and that of David N. Dinkins before him, for not responding adequately to the crisis. When adjusted for inflation, spending per pupil fell by 10 percent from 1990 to 1996, the commission found.
"The outlook for the future is bleak," the authors concluded.
At yesterday's dedication of a new elementary school, Public School 24 in Sunset Park, Brooklyn, the Mayor dismissed what he called the commission's "excessive entry into politics," and hinted that it was seeking to assist Ms. Messinger.
Charles Brecher, executive vice president of the commission, said that "candidate Giuliani applauded many of our ideas" four years ago.
Although it may not be apparent to the students, the system has undergone a fundamental shift in power on the neighborhood level: a sweeping new state law took effect over the summer vacation that stripped the city's 32 elected school boards of the responsibilities of hiring teachers and principals and spending money in the elementary and middle schools, transferring those powers to district superintendents. The superintendents -- a third of them new this school year -- now report to Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew, who has the enhanced authority to dismiss them if a district's performance is poor.
The Chancellor had lobbied hard for the changes as a way to hold schools accountable -- especially in 13 districts where fewer than 40 percent of students scored at grade level on last year's reading test.
But parents, teachers and principals have expressed concerns that the new law may make it harder for their voices to be heard by the empowered Chancellor, who is appointed by the Board of Education and thus not responsible to voters.
"We're just concerned that the new law will make Rudy Crew the czar of education," said Donald Singer, the president of the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, which represents the city's principals. "There's got to be checks and balances."
"Are the superintendents going to live in fear of the Chancellor?" he asked. "And if there is a problem with a reading or a math score, are they going to feel pressured to say it's the principal's fault?"
In the schools yesterday, as teachers set up their classrooms and parents registered their children, the concerns were more immediate.
Rupinder Kaur, 14, a native of India who has been in the United States for only two months, was patiently standing in line outside Newcomers High School in Long Island City, Queens, a three-year-old school intended to ease the transition of immigrants into the school system.
"My daughter doesn't speak English yet," said her father, Malkiat Singh, who was eager to secure her a spot. "She is very happy to learn."
At Louis D. Brandeis High School on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, a new teacher, Randy Abdallah, 40, was wondering what his students would be like in a school that he said he knew "absolutely nothing" about.
Mr. Abdallah taught art in Massachusetts public schools for 15 years and got a job in New York as a result of good timing: After years of whittling away art and music programs, the city is expected to spend $25 million to restore such courses this school year and the next two years.
"My fiancee lives in the city," Mr. Abdallah said, "and now that I got a job here we can get married."
But perhaps the person with the most at stake is the Chancellor himself, who, in his first full year in the system last year, saw reading test scores rise in every district in the city. For him, the challenge is to build on those gains, and he has once again focused on the third grade, in which fewer than half of the students were found to be reading at grade level last year.
At a breakfast at Gracie Mansion yesterday for several dozen elementary-school students who had taken part in a summer reading program, Dr. Crew signed autographs for nearly a half hour. When Keisha Hunt, age 7, told the Chancellor that she was entering the third grade at P.S. 114 in Canarsie, Brooklyn, Dr. Crew brightened.
"Going into third grade?" he repeated. "You and I are going to have fun this year."
He then signed her book, writing: "To Keisha. We think you are just too special for words. Keep the faith! The third grade is great! Always, Dr. Crew, Chancellor."

HEADLINE: A Resurgent California Finds All That Glitters Is Its Future

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Sept. 2

 BODY:
When demographers at the California Department of Finance finished their annual analysis of drivers' licenses last month, they found a shining nugget of good news for the Golden State: for the first time since 1991, more Americans moved to California than left it to live in other states.
Last week, the California Association of Realtors turned up another cheery statistic: sales of existing homes rose 11.2 percent in July compared with the same month last year, the highest year-to-year increase since 1989 and five times the national increase for July. 
 It is not hard to find good news these days in California, the place that once helped define national notions of the American dream but that for most of the 1990's seemed to suffer nothing but problems, from the worst recession since the Depression to riots, a devastating earthquake and the convulsive stigma of the O. J. Simpson case.
"In the 50's, 60's and 70's, people looked to see the future in California, and while that was a kind of metaphor, it's coming back again," said Stephen Levy, director of the Center for the Continuing Study of the California Economy in Palo Alto. "It's hard to name a growth industry in the world that California doesn't have a strong position in. The question should no longer be can California manage the recession, but can California manage the growth?"
That topic is so much on the public mind that last week, when The Los Angeles Times published a front-page article on expected population growth, Mr. Levy's phone was ringing off the hook with calls from news outlets around the state.
Those figures, from October 1996 projections by the Census Bureau, said California's population was expected to grow by nearly 18 million people -- the current population of the entire State of New York -- by the year 2025.
"There was nothing new in those figures," Mr. Levy said. But they touched a nerve.
The growth projections are sobering, driven by the expectation that California will continue to grow faster than any other state, with about half the expected growth coming from international immigration. By 2025, the total population is expected to reach 49.3 million, a nearly 60 percent increase from the estimated 31.6 million now.
The state's own projections call for even more growth. They are based on a slightly different methodology and include data, like drivers' license renewals, that are not used by the Census Bureau. The state's predictions do not extend as far into the future, but they estimate that by 2020 the population will be 45.5 million, about 2 million more than the bureau's estimate for the same year.
Mary Heim, a demographer with the State Department of Finance, which compiles the estimates, said: "The big difference between our projection and theirs is that they assume domestic outmigration to other states will continue to increase, and we don't. We have data that show those trends have reversed this year."
Even the state's estimated growth rates would be well below the postwar economic explosion, in which the state's population doubled from 1950 to 1970. And some experts are skeptical, cautioning about the vagaries inherent in any such predictions.
"Population projections can be so wrong," said Joel Kotkin, a fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy in Malibu. "It depends what happens, and there are constraints. I don't think this economy is going to generate a lot of jobs for less-educated people. I don't think immigration will be as great. I don't think the migration of working people from other states will be as great. Also, the number of desirable places to live, where people want or can afford to live, will go down."
Still, Mr. Kotkin and many others agree that after its period of epochal economic and natural disasters, California is at last squarely on a solid upswing, with an annual job growth rate running at nearly 3 percent, compared with about 2.3 percent nationally and 1.4 percent in the Middle Atlantic States.
The recovery is uneven, with the computer-driven economy of Silicon Valley and San Francisco Bay still doing far better than the Los Angeles area, which lost 70 percent of all the jobs lost in the state when the aerospace industry collapsed in the early 1990's.
Over all, California now has nearly half a million more jobs than it did before the recession began, many of them in high-paying fields like computers, film production and biotechnology.
What is more, the local psychological preoccupation with bad news, especially in Southern California, seems to have dissipated.
"I think people felt their personal lives were stabilizing, their personal financial situation was improving and that made itself felt on a psychological level," said G. U. Krueger, deputy chief economist for the state realtors' association. "I also think that people just got bored with gloom and it was time for a change."
Statewide, Mr. Krueger noted, the median price for sales of existing homes rose 5.7 percent last month from July 1996, to $192,810, the largest such increase since January 1990.
Not every index is splendid. Unemployment statewide is running about 6 percent, a little more than a percentage point above the national level, but well below the nearly 10 percent unemployment rate in New York City, for example.
Los Angeles County has lagged behind Northern California, still claiming about 200,000 fewer jobs than it did before the recession despite strong growth in entertainment, international trade and a garment center that for the last three years or so has surpassed New York City's in employment. In the 1980's, greater Los Angeles accounted for about one-third of the state's overall economy. Today, with California's total economy surpassing $1 trillion a year for the first time, that figure is closer to one-quarter.
"For the last couple of years the state has started to step out smartly," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Los Angeles Economic Development Corporation, a private organization that tries to foster economic growth and jobs in the region. "Los Angeles County is more like a 747 fully loaded and ready to rumble down the runway."
The state's politics reflect the turnaround. A seven-week standoff over the budget this summer was largely driven not by apportioning pain but by dividing spoils, in the form of a projected $1.3 billion surplus in tax revenue. In the end, because legislative Democrats would not agree to Gov. Pete Wilson's proposals, including a tax cut, the Governor ended the fight by unilaterally deciding to use the surplus to repay a debt owed to the state pension fund, leaving little to fight over.
Mr. Wilson is barred from seeking a third term next year, but the latest statewide Field Poll, made public last week, showed that the economy had given him a political bounce. It found that 32 percent of the 500 adults surveyed rated his job performance as good or very good, an increase from 27 percent earlier this year and the Governor's highest rating since February 1991, just after he took office. The bad news: 38 percent still rated Mr. Wilson's performance as poor or very poor. The poll's margin of sampling error was plus or minus four percentage points.
How Mr. Wilson's successor will cope with the state's expected growth is another matter. Under Gov. Edmund G. Brown in the late 1950's and 60's, the state built a network of public education institutions that was the envy of the nation, and miles of freeways and public works. But since the passage of Proposition 13, the 1978 ballot measure that capped property taxes, that legacy has crumbled substantially.
"Does the state have the will to lay down the public investment and planning that will need to take place so this growth doesn't cause a degradation in public services and the quality of life?" asked Mr. Levy, of the economic study center. "That's what we did in the 60's. Some things will be harder now -- the air and water, for example. But we'll have to build fewer schools than we did in that period.
"If the candidates are serious," Mr. Levy added, "that's what the 1998 governor's race should be about."
