HEADLINE: Federal Appeals Panel Overturns Loan-Sharking Conspiracy Conviction

BYLINE: By BENJAMIN WEISER

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court in Manhattan last week overturned the conviction of a man accused in a loan-sharking conspiracy, saying that prosecutors introduced evidence at trial that they knew was false.
Legal experts yesterday described the court's action as unusual. 
 The defendant, Charles A. Urrego, who is in a Federal prison in Otisville, N.Y., has already served about five years of an eight-year sentence for his 1995 conviction on two counts in the loan-sharking conspiracy, as well as on two lesser counts that were not overturned by the court, said his lawyer, Gerald J. DiChiara.
Mr. DiChiara said he would ask the Federal judge who presided at Mr. Urrego's trial to release his client while the Government decides whether it will retry Mr. Urrego.
"It is clear that the Government knowingly presented false evidence," Chief Judge Ralph K. Winter wrote for a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in reversing the conviction and ordering the case sent back for a new trial.
The decision, which was released on Friday, also said that other evidence was introduced at trial that was "otherwise so misleading as to amount to falsity."
A spokesman for Zachary W. Carter, the chief Federal prosecutor in Brooklyn, whose office prosecuted the case, said that office would have no comment on the matter until it had more time to review the decision. But in legal briefs to the court of appeals, prosecutors denied that they had knowingly presented false testimony, and said the evidence in question was "relatively minor when compared with the overall record."
The court did not recommend any disciplinary actions against prosecutors in Mr. Carter's office.
In briefs before the appeals court, prosecutors described Mr. Urrego as a 240-pound bodybuilder known as Charlie Arms, who charged interest of up to 253 percent and used the threat of physical violence to insure timely payment of his loans. During his trial, prosecutors contended that Mr. Urrego was involved in a conspiracy in which he lent money to associates, who in turn lent it again. At the time of his arrest in 1992, prosecutors said, Mr. Urrego had $500,000 "out on the street" in loans.
The appeals court said that important evidence in the Government's case against Mr. Urrego was records seized from Anthony Pietrosanti, who was accused of being an accomplice. The records purportedly contained lists of names, loan amounts and interest rates that prosecutors said proved a conspiracy.
But the appeals court said that prosecutors had been told by Mr. Pietrosanti that "the records seized from him were entirely fictitious and that the money he borrowed from Urrego was strictly for his personal use as a compulsive gambler."
Prosecutors checked some of the information in the records and determined that it was false, the court said. The Government later dropped similar conspiracy charges that it had brought against Mr. Pietrosanti, the appeals court said, but used the same records against Mr. Urrego, without disclosing to his lawyer what Mr. Pietrosanti had said about the material. Prosecutors in their briefs later conceded that they should have turned over the disputed material to the defense but also suggested that they did not believe they were improperly withholding evidence.
In his trial, Mr. Urrego's defense centered on his contention that there was no loan-sharking conspiracy. His lawyer argued that while Mr. Urrego did lend money at usurious rates, there were no threats of violence or harm and those who received the money did not lend it again, but rather used it for gambling and other personal expenses.
Judge Winter said that the Government, "having been told by the author of the records that they were bogus, having verified that unwelcome fact as to two names," stopped checking the rest of the information.
The court's action was joined by Appellate Judge James L. Oakes and Federal District Judge Leonard B. Sand (who was sitting by special designation).
Legal experts said the move was unusual. While defense lawyers frequently assert that prosecutors are using false evidence in a trial, "the claim is raised much more often than it succeeds," said Eric M. Freedman, professor of law at Hofstra University. When it does succeed, he said, "then one very appropriately asks the U.S. Attorney: 'What are your systems and procedures that led to this?' "
The court did not overturn two separate counts -- filing a false tax return and filing a false bank loan application -- for which Mr. Urrego was convicted.

HEADLINE: Libertarian Nominee Seeks Public Campaign Funds

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
Murray Sabrin, a college finance professor who is the Libertarian Party candidate for New Jersey governor, said today that he has raised enough money to qualify for matching taxpayer dollars under the state program that publicly finances the gubernatorial contest.
Mr. Sabrin, 50, of Leonia, would be the first third-party candidate to qualify for matching campaign funds in a general election since New Jersey imposed strict limits on campaign spending and contributions and began publicly financing the governor's race in 1977. 
 He would also be allowed to participate in two televised debates this fall with Gov. Christine Todd Whitman and State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic Party's nominee. State law requires gubernatorial candidates who receive taxpayer dollars for their campaigns to appear in at least two televised debates. The state's Election Enforcement Commission is now reviewing Mr. Sabrin's request, which it is likely to approve.
To qualify for matching funds, a candidate must raise and spend a minimum of $210,000. Mr. Sabrin, who teaches at Ramapo College in Mahwah, said he had raised $236,050 for his campaign in the last few months from supporters in New Jersey and from members of the Libertarian Party across the nation. Under state law, he would qualify for $334,100 in matching funds.
The first $69,000 that a candidate raises is not matched. But each dollar a candidate raises after $69,000 is matched with two taxpayer dollars under the state program. To qualify for the maximum of $4.6 million in public matching funds, a candidate must raise $2.3 million and agree to limit individual contributions to $2,100 and to hold total spending to $6.9 million.
For the general election, Governor Whitman has raised more than $2 million and is eligible to receive $4 million in matching funds. Mr. McGreevey is lagging behind in fund-raising, but he said that he is confident that he will be able to qualify for full matching funds. So far, he has raised about $1.1 million and has applied for about $2 million in matching funds.
It is unclear what impact Mr. Sabrin will have on the gubernatorial race. Aides to Mr. McGreevey said they believed that Mr. Sabrin's candidacy could pull support by some conservative voters from Governor Whitman. But aides to Governor Whitman said that Mr. Sabrin could also take away votes from Mr. McGreevey. There are least a half-dozen other third-party candidates running for governor, but Mr. Sabrin is the first to apply for public funds and possibly to participate in the two televised debates.
"I welcome him into the fray," Mr. McGreevey said.
Governor Whitman echoed those sentiments. "I welcome him into the race," she said.
Mr. Sabrin, who earned a doctorate in economics from Rutgers University and has taught at Ramapo College for 12 years, said the gubernatorial contest was his first bid for public office. "I am not entering this to spoil anyone's chances," he said. "I'm running this to win."
Mr. Sabrin said that Libertarian Party leaders approached him about the candidacy last spring. He said he became a member of the Libertarian Party almost two decades ago because he believes in its antigovernment philosophy. "If government has done such a good job, why do we have so many problems?" he said.
Mr. Sabrin said he opposes gun control and believes that individuals should be allowed to carry concealed weapons. He also supports the legalization of drugs. In addition, he said that, if elected, he would dismantle the state agency that oversees the protection of abused and neglected children, and give their responsibilities to nonprofit agencies. Eventually, he said, he would like to turn over the entire state social services system to nonprofit agencies. He said, however, that he would not give any state money to such agencies.
He also objected to the current public education system, saying that parents should be able to use public dollars to send their children to private schools. He also said that he would abolish the State Department of Education and leave all decisions about education up to local officials. And he promised to cut taxes and reduce the size of government.
On automobile insurance, which has emerged as the most contentious issue in this race, Mr. Sabrin said that he would support deregulation of the insurance industry. He said that rates would come down because of increased competition among insurance companies. The state's regulation of the industry, he said, has reduced competition and driven up the cost of auto insurance.

HEADLINE: Korean-Americans Assist an Ailing Envoy From the North

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Sept. 2

 BODY:
North Korea's representative at the United Nations, who has been hospitalized in New York since Aug. 12 without medical insurance or financial help from his impoverished Government, has received pledges of aid from Korean-Americans, according to Korean-language newspapers. The prospective donors, who are believed to be of varying political views, apparently fear that the envoy, Kim Hyong U, could be recalled by Pyongyang and sent home without treatment.
Mr. Kim, 62, is a patient at New York University Medical Center in Manhattan, where he is undergoing tests, hospital officials said today. They said they could not give more details about his health without his consent. 
 Korean-American newspapers first reported on Friday that the envoy, whom they described as a diabetic, had developed lung problems and had been admitted to the hospital with the help of a Korean-American clergyman and Korean-speaking American doctors.
North Korea has no hard currency to support its missions abroad, and North Korean diplomats do not have health insurance, diplomats from other countries said. Most other missions subsidize or sometimes pay fully the medical insurance of diplomats and their families, who usually face far higher health costs in New York than in their home countries.
The Korea Times, a Korean-language paper published in New York, reported on Aug. 29 that there were also concerns but no evidence that Mr. Kim was considering defection and thus was under suspicion after two other North Korean envoys -- Chang Sung Gil, Ambassador in Cairo, and his brother, Chang Sung Ho, a trade mission official in Paris -- were given asylum in the United States a week ago.
The Korea Central Daily News, another local Korean-language paper, reported on the same day that Ambassador Kim faced medical bills that could range as high as $40,000 to $50,000. The paper said that although Mr. Kim had no hope of government help, hospital officials had been told that there would be local sources of support, apparently from a number of anonymous donors who rallied to the envoy's cause.
American diplomats dealing with problems arising between foreign missions and institutions of all kinds in the United States said today that they were not aware of Mr. Kim's plight. The United States does not have diplomatic relations with North Korea, whose radical Communist Covernment is considered by Washington to have committed acts of international terrorism like assassinating South Korean Cabinet members and blowing up a passenger aircraft.
The Clinton Administration says that Pyongyang is also selling weapons to enemies of Washington, most recently missiles to Iran. Talks between the United States and North Korea on missile exports were broken off last week after the Cairo and Paris defections.
Washington, however, has been contributing to an international fund to send food to the North Koreans, who are facing severe famine after two years of floods and now a summer-long drought. The country's economy has been steadily deteriorating for decades under a nationalistic "self-reliance" system that turned its back on the outside world and left the country's farmland depleted and its treasury bare.
A diplomat at the North Korean mission who was not identified denied today that Mr. Kim was still in the hospital. "He is at home and he is fine," he said, demanding to know why a newspaper was asking questions about the envoy.
North Korea is one of the world's most secretive countries. Various people involved with Mr. Kim's case, in and out of the hospital, say that it has been very difficult to communicate with the mission to discuss the diplomat's treatment.
A Korean-speaking doctor treating Mr. Kim said that he could not disclose details of the envoy's condition because of hospital rules protecting the privacy of patients unless the envoy agreed to make the nature of his illness public. Hospital staff members say the ambassador is visited frequently by his wife and now and then by another member of the North Korean mission staff but is otherwise alone.

HEADLINE: Stocks Roar Into September, With the Dow Surging 257.36

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA

 BODY:
After suffering through a turbulent August selloff, the stock market roared back to life yesterday, posting some of the biggest gains of the decade.
The Dow Jones industrial average soared 257.36 points, or 3.38 percent, to 7,879.78 -- its largest single-day point gain ever and its biggest percentage rise in nearly six years. 
 Investors returned from the Labor Day weekend with a vengeance, snatching up many recently battered blue chips and generally doing what they have done throughout the length of this bull market: buying when stock prices fall. Analysts called it another sign that the market remains resilient.
"This tells me that there's still a lot of healthy optimism about stocks out there," said Hugh Johnson, a market analyst at the First Albany Corporation. "There's still a lot of buying power."
Broader measures also rose sharply. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surged 28.11 points, or 3.13 percent, to close at 927.58, and the technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index gained 30.77 points, or 1.94 percent, to 1,618.09.
Shares of smaller companies, which easily outperformed the blue chips last month, also rose, if not as sharply. The Russell 2000 index of small-capitalization stocks gained 4.62 points, or 1.09 percent, to 428.05, a closing high.
While the stock market has been on course for one of its best years ever, the journey has been rocky. A sharp 9.8 percent selloff in the Dow during March and April was followed by one of its strongest rallies ever through July, only to be hit by a staggering late-summer dive.
But, with yesterday's gains, the Dow halted, at least for now, a nasty downturn that saw it fall 7.7 percent from the closing high of 8,259.31 it set on Aug. 6.
No matter what happens from here on, the market is likely to remain volatile. Already this year, 30 percent of trading sessions have ended with the Dow rising or falling 1 percent or more.
Market sentiment turned optimistic early yesterday, as European markets gained and several Asian stock indexes stabilized after sharp selloffs. In addition, the dollar rose strongly against the German mark and Japanese yen, suggesting robust demand for dollars, which could translate into greater interest in American equities.
As a result, buying pushed the Dow and other indexes higher from the opening bell, even though bond prices drifted lower. Then, at 10 A.M., the National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing activity had been slower than expected in August, easing fears of inflation. Bond prices rebounded on the news, and stock prices soared even higher.
Another engine driving the rally, analysts said, was the fact that prices had been deeply depressed during the last few weeks, and on low trading volume. That created what market analysts call an "oversold" condition.
"We had a bond-friendly manufacturing number, and many people thought the market was oversold in an exaggerated way last week, and so you got a bounce," said Charles Pradilla, a market strategist at Cowen & Company.
For blue-chip issues, such as General Electric, it was the first time in weeks that they had outperformed smaller-company issues. Analysts said that the shares of many multinational corporations had been beaten down by growing concerns that they had become too expensive.
But some market watchers said that despite the sharp selloff in blue-chip stocks last month investors were quietly buying small quantities of them and positioning for more.
"This is the equivalent of playing poker with someone who complains about the stale cigars and the warm beer and then raises you 10 bucks," said Laszlo Birinyi, head of Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
Mr. Birinyi said that even while the Dow was plummeting in August, money flows into Dow stocks were rising -- meaning that the losses were masking investor interest.
"Money flows look at every single trade; they don't assume that where a stock closed is how things are," he said.
"And the money flows tell you buyers never went away. What happened today is not that buyers came in, it's that they showed their hands."
Yesterday, though, a good deal of the buying appeared to be the work of institutional investors. Birinyi tracked eight large computer-generated program trades, and traders on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange talked about an orderly march higher that had been carried along by big trades.
"There was a lot of program trading going on," Joseph Yurman, a managing director at Robertson Stephens, said from the floor of the exchange. "The boys were very active. All the stuff today is being done by machines."
Despite yesterday's enormous gains, Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley & Company, said that the market was still headed for a sharp decline later this year.
"I don't think this is the beginning of a new bull leg," he said. "The economy is going to pick up and interest rates are going to go higher. And the market can't handle that."
Still, for the session, the attitude was "Buy 'em," as Alfred Goldman, a market strategist at A. G. Edwards Inc. in St. Louis, headlined a fax sent out yesterday.
And buy they did. Of the Dow's 30 component stocks, 29 gained yesterday, led by Procter & Gamble, up 4 7/8 a share, to 138; J. P. Morgan, up 4 5/16, to 111 13/16; Merck, up 3 7/8, to 95 11/16, and G.E., up 3 5/8, to 66 3/16.

HEADLINE: Manufacturing Growth Eased In August, Purchasers Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
An important measure of manufacturing activity grew at a slower rate in August as factories contended with bulging inventories and the strike against United Parcel Service.
The National Association of Purchasing Management said yesterday that its factory index fell to 56.8 last month from 58.6 in July, reflecting a drop in orders and production. Analysts had expected an August reading of 58.3. A reading of 50 or more means manufacturing is expanding, while a reading below 50 signals a contraction. 
 Stocks and bonds rose after the release of the index, which market participants viewed as a signal that the Federal Reserve was less likely to raise interest rates to cool down the economy. Indeed, the August decline suggests that a buildup in business inventories during the second quarter has been "restraining growth in the industrial sector" during the current quarter, said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla.
Moreover, the purchasing association said that almost all of the businesses in the survey reported they had experienced difficulty getting goods from their suppliers. More than half said the strike affected deliveries to customers.
The purchasing managers reported that the rate of inventory liquidation increased during August, while the backlog of unfilled orders also remained at a high level. That, plus slower delivery times, suggested demand might remain high in the months ahead -- if the numbers were not distorted by the parcel strike.
David Wyss, an economist with DRI/McGraw-Hill in Lexington, Mass., said, "If there's a worry, it's that delivery times are getting longer, and that's a sign it's time for people to think about charging higher prices."
That concern is not shared by all analysts, however. For the Fed, which is particularly interested in delivery times, the strike "is a very important consideration," said Lyle Gramley, a former governor of the central bank and now an economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association of America.
Norbert Ore, chairman of the purchasing association's business survey committee and director of purchasing at the Sonoco Products Company, a paper maker, said that over the long haul, the effects of the strike would be short-lived.
Today's report also showed that the association's prices-paid index, considered by some an indication of the inflation rate, rose to 53.8 in August from 53.6 in July.
The employment index pointed to the sixth consecutive monthly increase in factory hiring, climbing to 52 in August from 50.7 in July. That suggests the Government's August employment report, set for release Friday, could point to a gain of 185,000 jobs, excluding the effects of the strike, said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch in New York.
The indexes do not gauge how much factories produced or how much prices rose or fell. Instead, they measure the number of manufacturers surveyed that reported increased production or higher prices for raw materials.

HEADLINE: U.S. Budget Analysis Predicts Shift to Big Surpluses in 2002

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 2

 BODY:
In the first authoritative analysis of the new tax and spending bills signed by President Clinton, the Congressional Budget Office said today that the measures would not only balance the Federal budget, but also generate substantial surpluses after 2001.
The report will set the tone for Congressional debate on Federal spending for the next six months, at least. The projected surpluses are likely to whet the appetites of members of Congress who want to spend more, or to cut taxes further. 
 The Congressional Budget Office predicts that the Federal deficit will exceed its current level in each of the next four years, but will disappear after 2001. Then, it says, the surpluses will begin, starting with $32 billion in 2002 and $13 billion in 2003, rising to $86 billion in 2007.
June E. O'Neill, director of the Congressional Budget Office, described the strong performance of the economy this year as surprising. She predicted that economic growth would continue, though at a slower rate, as inflation and unemployment crept up in coming years.
An unexpected surge of new revenue will cut the deficit for the current fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, to $34 billion, the lowest since 1974, the budget office said. The deficit last year was $107 billion, and in January the budget office was predicting that it would be $124 billion this year, while the White House was saying it would be $126 billion.
The economy has performed beyond the wildest expectations of most forecasters for a couple of years. The White House Office of Management and Budget has had marginally more optimistic economic forecasts than the Congressional Budget Office. But both substantially overestimated what the deficit would be for the current fiscal year.
The Congressional Budget Office offered a couple of remarkable statistics to explain the Government's strong fiscal condition.
Federal revenue this year will be equivalent to 19.8 percent of the nation's total economic output, or gross domestic product -- the highest level since the end of World War II. Federal outlays, by contrast, will be equivalent to 20.3 percent of economic output, the lowest level since 1979.
Another statistic shows how the just-completed budget deal may lighten the burden of Federal debt and Federal interest costs, one of the Government's few truly irrevocable commitments.
Federal debt held by the public, in the form of Treasury securities, is now close to 50 percent of the gross domestic product. But it will shrink to 40 percent in 2002 and 30 percent in 2007 under the latest projections by the Congressional Budget Office.
Under these estimates, Federal debt held by the public, which represents the accumulated total of all borrowing over the years, will peak at $4 trillion in 2001. Then it will decline, assuming that the Government posts surpluses in later years, the budget office said.
Robert D. Reischauer, former director of the Congressional Budget Office, said the projected surpluses would pose a political temptation to many lawmakers. "Surpluses burn a hole in politicians' pockets," Mr. Reischauer said. "It's never too soon to start spending money that you aren't sure you will have."
Mr. Reischauer said, for example, that revenue from auctioning the privilege of using the airwaves for commercial purposes, like broadcasting and cellular telephone service, "could prove to be pie in the sky."
The budget office said that weakness in the economy or a failure to abide by the spending limits of the budget deal could jeopardize the projected surpluses.
"In particular," it said, "the onset of a recession could push the deficit above current projections by $100 billion or more for several years."
Today's report from the Congressional Budget Office also made these points:
*The Federal deficit will rise to $57 billion next year, up $23 billion from this year's figure. It will decline in each subsequent year, to $36 billion in 2001.
*Taken together, the budget and tax bills signed by President Clinton on Aug. 5 will cut projected Federal spending by a total of $198 billion in the next five years. But the laws give away $80 billion in tax cuts, so the net savings are $118 billion.
*The loss of revenue under the new laws is "twice as big in the second five years as in the first five" -- $162 billion versus $80 billion.
But the report may ease the concerns of Democrats who predicted that the tax law would, as Mr. Clinton said, "explode the deficit" after 2007. While the revenue losses will continue beyond 2007, they will grow more slowly than the economy as a whole, the budget office said.

HEADLINE: HOSPITALS OF LAST RESORT A special report.;
Hospitals Serving the Poor Struggle to Retain Patients

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

DATELINE: EL PASO

 BODY:
On a cloudy Saturday this summer, two teen-agers gave birth in this West Texas border town.
One, a 17-year old impoverished Mexican girl, slipped across the border to have her baby boy delivered by a lay midwife here, making him an American citizen. The child, born with devastating birth defects, was sent for immediate surgery to R. E. Thomason General Hospital, the local public hospital charged with caring for the sick, regardless of their ability to pay. The surgery, plus weeks of intensive care, saved the baby's life, but it cost Thomason and taxpayers some $40,000, not a penny of which is likely to be reimbursed. 
 The other teen-ager, an 18-year-old El Pasoan, was also poor. In the past, she, too, as a Medicaid patient, would probably have used Thomason, in one of the city's grittiest neighborhoods. But these days, pregnant women on Medicaid are welcome at any hospital in town, so she chose the upscale, private Providence Hospital, where she had a trouble-free delivery.
Therein lies a profound change in the nation's health-care system. With the advent of managed care and lower fees for doctors and medical services, patients with private insurance are not as lucrative as they once were. This has pushed private hospitals and doctors to court the Medicaid patients they once shunned, mindful of the government dollars such patients bring with them.
At the same time, as Medicaid recipients turn to private care, public hospitals like Thomason are increasingly left with few patients but those nobody wants -- the uninsured, AIDS patients, drug addicts and illegal immigrants.
"Everyone wants low-risk OB cases, but no one's competing for the drug-addicted H.I.V. patient," said Christine Burch, executive director of the National Association of Public Hospitals.
For patients on Medicaid, the nation's health insurance program for the poor, this shift has created a wealth of possibilities -- including, some say, access to more comfortable hospitals and more respectful treatment. But for hospitals like Thomason, the change poses vexing problems: They must not only compete harder for the Medicaid recipients who make up the bulk of their paying patients but also fight the perception that they offer second-class care.
The change highlights the great unfinished business of the American health-care revolution: In the increasingly competitive hospital market, who will care for the poorest of the poor, and the uninsured?
The nightmare scenario, health experts say, is a downward spiral in which the desirable patients -- and then the desirable doctors -- forsake public hospitals as sinkholes of medicine. The erosion of the nation's public hospitals, exacerbated by cost-cutting by cities and states, raises special concern about the future of the uninsured, whose numbers now top 43 million.
Five years ago, President Clinton went to Washington promising to revamp the nation's health-care system, deflate medical inflation and extend coverage to the uninsured. While his Government-based plan went down in flames, the system has nonetheless been utterly reordered, mostly by the private sector. Costs are under control; that has been the why and wherefore of the managed-care revolution. But in the fury of cost-cutting and competition, the goal of caring for the uninsured has become more remote, even as their numbers increase.
According to a 1994 study by the Project Hope Center for Health Affairs, a research group based in Bethesda, Md., 33 percent of poor, uninsured people had no regular source of medical care. In the 1982 version of the study, 23 percent lacked such care.
"Everyone's moving in the direction of managed care, but the uninsured don't fit in with that," said Dennis Andrulis, president of the National Public Health and Hospital Institute, a nonprofit policy group based in Washington. "No one seems to be stepping back and saying, 'Whoa, there's more than 40 million uninsured; how do we integrate them if they're not supported by some managed-care system?' So they're increasingly marginalized as the system changes."
But public hospitals do more than just care for the uninsured. They also protect community health overall, offering important but money-losing services like trauma centers and burn units, treating public health threats like AIDS or drug-resistant tuberculosis, and creating outreach programs for high-risk pregnancies, violence prevention or immigrant health.
Across the country, from New York City, which has the nation's most ambitious network of municipal hospitals, to California, where several public hospitals have been sold, there is increasing debate about the role and financing of those that remain.
"The mood in the whole country right now is that nobody wants to increase taxes," Ms. Burch, of the public hospital association, said. "There's been a strong sentiment that business does things better than government does, and that spills over to people's attitudes toward public hospitals. Also, with low occupancy rates, because the country has too many hospitals, I think people are questioning how much we need public hospitals."
The number of public hospitals declined by more than 25 percent from 1981 to 1993, although most did not close, but simply went private, sometimes retaining their mission to the poor.
New York City's municipal hospitals are struggling to hold on to their Medicaid patients, even as the prestigious private hospitals that once shunned such patients are busily building primary care centers to compete directly with the city's 11 public hospitals and their outpatient clinics.
Across the country, many public hospitals that have so far been able to maintain their level of services, like Thomason, are increasingly hard-pressed to keep up.
And there is evidence that the private hospitals are not likely to do much to pick up the charity-care load. In a report last year, the Prospective Payment Assessment Commission, a Federal advisory panel that examines Medicare policy for Congress, cited research showing that as managed-care companies and insurers tightened their payments to hospitals, most cut back on free care. According to the report, the ones that typically provided the least free care have cut back the most.
But given current trends, health experts say, the safety-net hospitals, like Thomason, will be forced to scale back, too.
"Even hospitals with missions have limited resources, and when those resources are constrained, they do less," said Judith Feder, a professor of public policy at Georgetown University and an architect of the Clinton Administration's failed health plan.
 
The Mission
Hospital Care For the Poor
It is impossible to forget even for a moment that El Paso is a border town, with two big downtown bridges to Ciudad Juarez in Mexico, immigration officials spaced closely along the barbed wire fence that follows the Rio Grande, and a population that is 70 percent Hispanic.
If Mexico is always present in the hot dry air, so, too, is a grinding poverty. Thomason hospital serves an area where the median per capita income is just $11,300, making it the nation's third poorest community of its size. One in three El Paso residents has no health insurance, far higher than the national average.
Both the border and the poverty present special challenges for Thomason, which serves the people of El Paso, and others from West Texas, southern New Mexico and Mexico.
Since 1915, care for the needy has been the mission of Thomason. The hospital is the dominating presence in its neighborhood. Its emergency room serves 52,000 people a year, many of them lacking any other source of medical care. Its obstetric department delivers more than a third of the babies in El Paso. And its trauma center, the only one in town, cares for horrific injuries from car crashes and gunshots.
Legally, Thomason is required to care for residents of the county -- or, in a loophole wider than the Rio Grande, those who intend to become residents. In the last fiscal year, Thomason provided $40 million in charity care to the indigent; hundreds of people were billed but did not pay for an additional $37 million in care.
Many of Thomason's patients are El Paso's working people. They earn too much to qualify for Medicaid but are too stretched financially to afford private insurance. Others, like the newborn who needed extensive surgery this summer, or the woman who was hit by a car on a highway near the border and needed thousands of dollars worth of surgery and hardware to repair her leg, have just crossed from Mexico.
Thomason gets about $37 million of its $100 million operating budget from Medicaid. Another $31 million comes from local taxes, and only $3 million -- just four cents on each dollar billed -- from uninsured patients who pay out of pocket.
But as Medicaid patients abandon Thomason for other hospitals, the uninsured are coming to represent an increasing share of the patients. Medicaid patients made up 39 percent of the hospital's patients, and uninsured people 40 percent, in fiscal 1994; two years later, the Medicaid share was down to 34, and the uninsured up to 47 percent.
Another looming threat is the downsizing of the Federal aid program for hospitals that care for a disproportionate share of indigent patients, a reduction that will probably trickle down to Thomason as a multimillion-dollar cut in the $26 million the program pays.
Pete Duarte, the chief executive of Thomason, said his hospital faced a special burden for charity care after private investors had taken over all the other hospitals in El Paso -- the birthplace of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation, the nation's largest for-profit health-care chain.
Under Federal law, every hospital must stabilize any patient who shows up at the emergency room in critical condition. But they need not provide non-emergency care, and Mr. Duarte, like executives at other safety-net hospitals nationwide, said he believes that for-profit hospitals are especially quick to pass on uninsured patients.
"Providence was the last private not-for-profit hospital here, and when it was sold to Tenet, we saw a 10 percent increase in our charity care cost," he said.
Mr. Duarte identifies strongly with the patients who depend on his hospital.
"I was born in a public hospital in California," he said. "When I was 13, I had my first operation, eye surgery, in a public hospital. Two years later, I had leg reconstruction after a football injury, in a public hospital. And both my parents spent the last days of their lives in public hospitals."
When Mr. Duarte came to Thomason five years ago, he did not look like the typical hospital administrator -- and the initial reception he got was anything but executive treatment.
"I had a mohawk and an ear clip," said Mr. Duarte, who has traded the mohawk for a ponytail. "And a lot of the employees, when I said hello, they would look past me; they wouldn't respond. I was amazed at the coldness of the reception. And of course, if people don't treat the C.E.O. respectfully, you know they're not treating patients respectfully. So I started an R & D program that I hope will be my legacy -- Respect and Dignity."
Mr. Duarte argues that medically, Thomason is the best hospital in El Paso, the only one in town to be included, for the second year in a row, among the nation's top 100 hospitals, as compiled by Mercer Health Care Provider Consulting. But that is not enough.
"My frustration is that in this country, people think public hospitals are for the homeless, the people on welfare, the drug dealers and all those crazies," Mr. Duarte said. "Everybody knows the best medical care is at teaching hospitals, and in El Paso, this is it. But people who have a choice will not come here unless they are treated with respect and dignity."
 
The Competition
An Effort to Woo The Medicaid Mom
Last year, on Mother's Day, the El Paso Herald-Post ran a large advertisement listing the names, addresses and telephone numbers of 28 local obstetricians.
"Your Doctor, Your Choice," it said. "The following obstetricians in El Paso also welcome pregnant patients with Medicaid insurance to their private practice."
In the battle for Medicaid patients, obstetrics is the front line, and advertising has been the weapon of choice.
Maternity care has long been Thomason's one reliable money-maker, a cash cow that supported less profitable departments. In 1993, more than 7,000 of the 17,000 babies born in El Paso were delivered at Thomason, most paid for by Medicaid.
"Four years ago, no question, almost anyone on Medicaid having a baby would do it at Thomason," said Lydia Ramos, nurse-manager of the obstetric/gynecology clinic.
But now that the $2,002 that Medicaid pays a hospital for a delivery holds up nicely against managed-care rates, El Paso's private hospitals -- like hospitals nationwide -- are eager to appeal to Medicaid moms.
"They've got the Jacuzzi, the customized bedspread, the soft lights," Mr. Duarte said. "We have the lowest C-section rate, and great care, but Thomason can't spend public money to buy car seats to give away."
The private obstetricians, and the women choosing them over Thomason, said the amenities are beside the point.
Maria Leyva vowed four years ago never to return to Thomason after losing a six-month pregnancy there.
"They ignore you. It's crazy with so many people running around, and you never know who's going to deliver your baby," said Ms. Leyva, a Medicaid patient whose third child was born recently at Providence. "They're inhuman. The doctor didn't even talk to us when the baby died; just left it to the nurse."
"This time I knew I was high risk, and I wanted a private doctor who would take care of me through the whole pregnancy," she said. "It's been very different. I went to Providence for a test, and the nurses really talked to me, like a person. The car seat's nice, but what's important is how the doctors and nurses treat you."
Dr. Franz Theard, Ms. Leyva's doctor, said Medicaid patients make up 40 percent of his practice, compared with about 5 percent five years ago.
Thomason is feeling the change. On many days, the hospital gets fewer than half of El Paso's Medicaid-covered deliveries on a given day. Last year, the hospital delivered 5,890 babies, a 16 percent drop since 1993.
That decline has been alarming both to the hospital and to Texas Tech, the medical school that provides the hospital's doctors and runs the outpatient clinics, including the huge obstetric/gynecology clinic.
"We had 1,000 patient visits a week," Ms. Ramos, the nurse-manager, said. "Then we began dropping, down to 700-800. Women were coming here to get their lab work, and the initial Medicaid paperwork, and then going somewhere else. And we were getting paid zip."
Watching the Medicaid moms, and reimbursements, drain away to other hospitals, Texas Tech took drastic action, which has stirred tension both at Thomason and throughout the El Paso medical community.
"Last fall, we decided that if we were going to be able to keep up our patient numbers, and serve our patients, our faculty had to go out and deliver at other hospitals when women asked them to," Ms. Ramos said. "So now we're back up to 1,000 patients a week -- but 20 to 25 percent of our deliveries are at other hospitals."
Many private obstetricians are annoyed by the competition -- and by Texas Tech's extensive marketing campaign, complete with a Super Bowl advertisement and billboards recommending its doctors.
"It bothers me no end," Dr. Theard said. " If you want to chase patients, go into private practice."
But Ms. Ramos is infuriated when private doctors who welcomed women as obstetric patients send them back to the clinic if they need further gynecologic care but are no longer eligible for Medicaid.
"I've gotten so mad I've called the doctors," she said. "I say I understand you're sending me so-and-so. You delivered her baby, and now she has an abnormal Pap smear, and you won't treat her because she's not on Medicaid? And I hear the click when they hang up."
Some Texas Tech obstetricians will deliver babies only at Thomason. But others see their willingness to go elsewhere as a way both to give women on Medicaid more choices, and to keep up a high enough patient load, and revenues, to continue their care for the indigent.
Many at Thomason, though, see it simply as betrayal.
"It's bothersome, to see them abandoning ship like this," said Lisa Fisher, Thomason's post-partum nurse-manager. "I think they're trying to get their foot in the door at other hospitals, in case something happens here."
Ms. Fisher estimates, and interviews on the maternity ward confirm, that about half of Thomason's maternity patients actively chose the hospital, while the rest did not know they had a choice. Thomason is renovating its obstetric ward to impress maternity patients, moving from Pepto-Bismol pink walls to a softer peach, from double rooms to singles, and from the old system of separate rooms for labor, delivery and recovery to a setup that keeps women in the same room for all three.
Still, what began with obstetrics is spreading to other specialties. Kent Giles, the hospital's chief financial officer, said deliveries were the only major hospital service that dropped sharply last year. But in this fiscal year, there are declines in every major department: the obstetric patient count is down 21 percent compared with the same period last year, and general medicine, oncology, pulmonary medicine, general surgery, nephrology and orthopedics have all dropped more than 10 percent.
"I don't think there's less need out there," Mr. Giles said. "I think it's fewer Medicaid patients coming here. We're concerned. We haven't had cutbacks yet, but we've gotten very careful about who we replace."
 
The Future
A New Emphasis On Marketing
Thomason may already be reeling from the rapid changes in the hospital market, but the really big change -- the one by which it will live or die -- is still to come.
And soon.
Medicaid managed care will hit Texas next year. And when it does, Thomason will have to go head-to-head with other providers to get the opportunity to care for Medicaid patients.
State by state, the nation is moving toward a new system of managing Medicaid, one in which people on Medicaid will join managed-care plans that receive a set fee for each person they enroll, and take on responsibility for providing all of their care.
It is not yet clear how many providers will offer Medicaid managed-care plans in El Paso, but it is likely that Thomason and Texas Tech will put together their own offering for Medicaid recipients.
Mr. Duarte has already found out that Thomason is in an awkward position to compete, not just because of its bare-bones decor and hardscrabble neighborhood, but because of politics.
A few years ago, when it was clear that the nation was shifting to managed care, Mr. Duarte tried to put Thomason in the running for those contracts.
"We decided our best hope for the future was a hospital H.M.O., and at first everybody was very enthusiastic and supportive," he said. "But then the person developing the idea came back and said we needed to come up with another alternative because it would not be acceptable to the commissioners. We were told that the function of the hospital is not to compete."
That is political reality, Mr. Duarte said: Thomason is governed by a board of managers appointed by the County Commissioners, elected officials sensitive to the wishes of the medical community at large.
And the commissioners have not always been convinced that El Paso voters should have to pay taxes to support the hospital. Last fall, there were widespread rumors that the commissioners were looking to sell Thomason -- rumors that were denied, but not without leaving open the possibility that a sale might someday be considered.
"If we were to go out and market our services forcefully, in competition with the other hospitals, there would immediately be a political backlash," Mr. Duarte said. "Columbia and Tenet, the companies that run the for-profit hospitals, can buy tables at their fund-raisers, but we can't."
Just last year, Mr. Duarte said, he was told he could not have a marketing person in the public affairs office.
Health experts say that is a common problem in public hospitals.
"At community hospitals, nobody balks at the marketing budget, but at a public hospital, they'll question spending money on a slick brochure," said Ms. Burch, of the public hospital association. "There's not yet the understanding that this country's built on marketing, and you have to spend that money if you want to compete."
Henry Ornelas, Thomason's chief operating officer, said the commissioners were coming around as they recognized that Thomason must compete to protect its Medicaid patient base.
"We just had a meeting," he said, "and the word 'competition' has begun to flow from their mouths."
But how far that goes is still an open question. And the internal politics of any managed-care plan will be tricky.
While Thomason and Texas Tech are negotiating a closer affiliation, something akin to a merger, Mr. Duarte wants a promise that Texas Tech doctors will practice exclusively at Thomason. But Texas Tech officials see their mission more as insuring high-quality medical education than protecting Thomason's patient base, something that may mean partnerships with other hospitals as well as Thomason.
And because of Texas Tech's different mission and status, it has been able to advertise and market itself, and even to open clinics in affluent neighborhoods for patients with private insurance.
"It's tough right now," Mr. Ornelas said. "Our relationship is strained."
Whatever their differences, both institutions agree that Medicaid managed care is the key to their survival.
"We've always seen Medicaid as our market," said Dr. Jose Manuel de la Rosa, the dean of Texas Tech. "We've been good at it, and efficient enough to cost-shift from it. If we don't get into the Medicaid managed-care business successfully, we might as well just put a for-sale sign on the lawn."

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 1997, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 3 about financial pressures on hospitals that serve poor patients referred imprecisely to Dr. Manuel de la Rosa, who spoke of the problems facing the Texas Tech University School of Medicine. He is dean of the El Paso campus; Dr. Joel Kupersmith heads the overall school of medicine.

HEADLINE: Padding The Empty Nest;
Couples Build Bigger as Their Children Leave Home

BYLINE: By JULIE V. IOVINE 

 BODY:
LYNN KORDA and Jules Kroll raised four children in a 5,900-square-foot home in Rye, N.Y. But now that their children are grown, they have decided to upsize, as builders say, and are planning a new house of at least 8,000 square feet.
While Charles and Elaine Evans's three children were growing up, their country house in East Hampton, N.Y., had only one bathroom in its 980 square feet. Now that the youngest is 26 and on his own, the Evanses have more than doubled the house's size -- adding 1,000 square feet, including a second story and two bathrooms. "Our means finally caught up with our past desires," Mrs. Evans said. 
 The two couples are joining the growing ranks of empty-nesters who are rejecting the traditional image of mature homeowners as people intent on cutting back and gearing down. With the last tuition check canceled and the pounding music just a ghostly echo, more couples past the breeding age are finally asking themselves how they really want to live. And surprisingly the answer often is: big.
The building industry is feeling the effects of these expansive feathered nesters. While it is a trend primarily affecting the high end, most of the more than 40 builders and developers interviewed across the country said that these clients had altered the complexion of their businesses.
"We're beginning to see the impact of baby boomers as they enter their 50's," said Boyce Thompson, the editor in chief of Builder magazine, which devoted a special section to the housing patterns of older buyers in July. "These people have a desire for larger houses and more luxuries. It has nothing to do with the needs of their children."
Thomas Bowman, a builder in Huntington, N.Y., said that half of his business is from couples with adult or nearly adult children. "One might think that the older buyers would be thinking of consolidating and making life simpler, but no, they aren't," he said. "These are people who gave up a lot for a lot of years, and now they are looking for quality of life."
The National Association of Home Builders estimates that in the year 2000, the average American house will have 2,500 square feet, up significantly from 1,900 square feet in 1977. "Everybody wants four bedrooms when they only use two for sleeping," said Gopal Ahluwalia, the association's director of research. "And in California, every house has to have three fireplaces that never get used."
At the same time, the average number of occupants per house is dropping. "It is now at 2.6," he said.
But increasingly, occupancy is a relative term, in more ways than one. Inspiration for these big houses frequently is the hope that the family -- especially grandchildren -- will like the new surroundings enough to want to visit. Often.
Mrs. Evans said that even though her children had to make do with sharing the bathroom, she hoped that the new expanded house would "pay off with the grandchildren."
Builders of custom houses speak of being asked frequently to design special features calculated to impress youngsters, including sunken ball courts, built-in bunk beds, small video arcades and pinball parlors.
"We tell people how they can design a house to be attractive to kids," said Orren Pickell, a home builder in Chicago. "First, we suggest finishing the lower level and then putting in all the things the parents won't let them do at their own home, like video games, pool and Ping-Pong tables. It's a bribe, but so what? It works."
Builders call the houses they are designing for this powerful new market "entertainment houses," "homesteads," "quarterly houses" or "transitional homes" -- anything, it seems, but "empty nests."
"I could easily plan the perfect house for the past 26 years," said Ms. Korda, 53, who is interviewing architects. The new house will be next door to the one where she and her husband, the founder of Kroll Associates, the business investigations firm, now live. "I can only begin to think about how to plan for the next 26 years."
She is already dreaming of a larger kitchen with more counter space ("I used to need lots of floor when the kids were underfoot," she said. "Now, I need counter space for all the helping hands I'll have").
Ms. Korda said she would also like a proper library for those books that she will now have the time to read, a private sitting room, a billiards room and perhaps quarters for a live-in housekeeper. And the dining room will have to be very large for family reunions ("God willing, I hope there will be lots of people someday," she said).
David Schless, the executive director of the American Seniors Housing Association, a trade group in Washington, said: "It's a trend affecting a thin segment of the population at the well-to-do end of the market. Most people stay in the same home for as long as they possibly can."
Changes in capital-gains tax laws that took effect on July 28 (raising the exemption for selling a permanent residence to $500,000 for married homeowners and $250,000 for individual taxpayers) have meant that there should soon be more large houses on the market. Previously, older people who had bought their houses relatively cheaply decades ago were discouraged from selling at a profit because of the large tax bite.
"The tax change will definitely enable many seniors to be more inclined to move," Mr. Schless said.
The current empty-nest generation is also the first one to have so many two-career, two-income families. Furthermore, it is not a foregone conclusion that earning stops with retirement, as many older people are starting second careers late in life.
"People are beginning to catch on to the possibility of a second adulthood," said Gail Sheehy, the author of "New Passages: Mapping Your Life Across Time" (Random House, 1995). "They are retiring earlier and earlier and living longer. It used to be as life contracted, so did the living space. Now, life is opening up after 50, so why not open up your surroundings?"
Adrienne Tindall describes herself and her husband, Jack, as "barely in our 60's." The Tindalls spent 28 years raising their four daughters in what she calls "a regular 3,500-square-foot house," near Chicago. "I always thought we'd just move into a condo from there," said Mrs. Tindall, who has her own home-based sacred-music publishing business.
But Mr. Tindall, an engineer, had always nursed a dream of building his own house. When their youngest daughter reached her mid-20's, they found that the value of their old house had appreciated enough that they could afford to build a new 6,000-square-foot homestead nearby: about as far from a generic condominium as imaginable, it is a timber-framed, lodge-style affair with fieldstone walls.
Since the new house was completed eight years ago, all of their four grown daughters have lived there at various times, some with husbands and children while their own new homes were being finished. As in so many contemporary houses, the living room and dining room, fast becoming as obsolete as the vestigial appendix, have been replaced by a Great Room. This one truly fits the bill, at more than 1,100 square feet.
Need and desire have never been forced bunkmates when it comes to the high end of the housing market. And one of the enviable tasks for these affluent older buyers is to figure out what their desires are.
As a builder with a keen marketing sense, Mr. Pickell understands the whims and wants of couples who are just waking up to their newfound freedom, and he has built elaborate concept houses to whet their appetites.
"I sit them down and say, 'There's no one living with you now, so why should you live the same way?' " he said. "And they always look at me as if the thought had never occurred to them."
Mr. Pickell thinks about it plenty and has suggestions for those who, he says, have "forgotten how to live on their own."
For instance, families with children need lots of doors that can be shut to cut out noise and insure privacy. With just a spouse around, he tells them, why not dispense with a few?
Then there are quarterly rooms.
"People tell us they only use the living and dining rooms on holidays," Mr. Pickell said. "So, we call them quarterly rooms," meaning that they are used only about four times a year. "And we treat them like art on the walls -- just to be looked at," he added. There might even be two master suites, one downstairs for the owners and one upstairs for visiting children with grandchildren, possibly with a separate entrance.
For some, padding the empty nest, like empire building, starts modestly enough and then expands uncontrollably. Stephanie and Sam Lebowitz, who have a house in Clinton Hill, Brooklyn, started renovating the kitchen when their third child turned 20. ("As soon as we did it, I stopped cooking," Mrs. Lebowitz said.)
Within a year, the Lebowitzes had turned their attentions to their 2,500-square-foot country house on Shelter Island, where they are planning to add 1,200 square feet. They hope to put in an additional bedroom, double the living room size and turn another room into a home gym for what Mrs. Lebowitz calls an "older, fitter me."
"It is sort of weird that our house got bigger as soon as the kids were gone," she said. "The reason is part economics and part finally having the time. The fact is that our needs are shrinking and expanding at the same time. Our children are much bigger physically than they used to be, and when they visit they bring other big adults with them."
But as houses get bigger, isn't there a danger that even two full-size adults might find themselves rattling around?
Mrs. Tindall, of Illinois, said that she worried about just this. "I didn't want to feel like a lodge keeper in my own home," she said of her new 10-room house. So, she and her husband placed the master suite with a study on the ground floor. Since the Great Room is adjacent to the kitchen and since Mrs. Tindall keeps her grand piano and small pipe organ there, it is in constant use.
The Tindalls, who have eight grandchildren and are expecting one more, concentrated the guest rooms on the second floor, out of sight when out of use. They admit that they live in only the four or five rooms that cluster around the kitchen.
Tom Lewis, a custom builder in Florida, calls this type of floor plan "a home within a home."
"These houses aren't exactly built in separate pods," Mr. Lewis said, "but they are organized so that a couple can live in a reduced amount of it most of the time and not feel as if they are living in a mausoleum."
Sometimes, not using a space can be half the fun. Ken Alexander, a builder in Scottsdale, Ariz., recalled one couple who wanted to celebrate their liberation from years of happy if demanding servitude to their young.
"The main thing they wanted was a magnificent kitchen," Mr. Alexander said. "And they wanted it just so they could hang a sign on the door saying, KITCHEN CLOSED ."

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Faces a Suit By Writers

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The Hollywood screenwriters union says it will take the City of Los Angeles to Federal court on Monday to overturn an ordinance requiring writers and artists to get city permits before they can work out of their homes.
Two smaller writers groups said yesterday that they would file briefs supporting the suit by the Writers Guild of America, which represents movie and television screenwriters. 
 Marvin J. Wolf, a freelance journalist who is president of one of the smaller groups, the Independent Writers of Southern California, said the ordinance "is a clearly unconstitutional attempt to license journalists."
"It is very clear to us," he added, "that once the city has the power to license writers, if they write something City Hall doesn't want to hear, there is the potential for city officials to deny your license or to say: 'We'll make you pay for that. Let's audit you.' "
The Writers Guild said the ordinance recalled the "tyrannical and repressive" registration system used by the former Soviet Union and other Communist countries to regulate writers.
The ordinance does not mention writers and artists. It requires all people operating businesses out of their homes to get permits and to pay either a minimum tax or a gross receipts tax of less than one-half of 1 percent on all revenues, including reimbursed expenses.
The ordinance also provides that "the City Clerk and all of his deputies shall have the power and authority to enter, free of charge, during business hours any place of business required to be registered and taxed" and makes failure to comply a misdemeanor.
Allowing inspections in the homes of writers and artists is an unconstitutional intrusion, Mr. Wolf said.
Ramona Ripston, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California, said that the gross receipts tax "inevitably embroils city taxing authorities in investigations into the creative process that are at odds with First Amendment freedoms."
Ms. Ripston and others said that disputes were sure to arise over whether a check sent to the home of a writer or artist was for work performed at home and subject to the city tax or for work outside the city.
Deputy Mayor Stephanie Bradfield said Los Angeles was seriously considering the issues raised "by the writers, especially the screenwriters, because movies and television are such an important part of the economy of Los Angeles."
She added that the "suggestion that the city could regulate the content of what people write in their homes is ludicrous," and that in issuing permits to writers the city would never consider what they wrote.
The ordinance, passed last fall, allows office-type businesses to operate out of homes in Los Angeles provided they have little impact on the neighborhood. Businesses with a steady stream of clients and those receiving more than three deliveries a day are prohibited, as is what the law vaguely describes as "adult entertainment."
Mark Ryavec of Delphi Associates, the Writers Guild lobbyist, said the "adult entertainment" category was so broad that the city could deny permits to a writer of such works as "The English Patient," the novel and the movie, because of its erotic themes. The film won the Oscar for best picture this year.
Ms. Bradfield said that before the ordinance was adopted, it was technically illegal in Los Angeles to write in your home for money unless you did so as an employee. Thus a staff writer for a television series could write at home, but a writer working on contract for the same show could not.
"In this city, until this ordinance passed, you couldn't get a business license if you used your home address as a place of business because you couldn't do business in residential areas," she said. "If you are a tax preparer, an architect, an engineer, a business consultant, a legal researcher or a writer and if you want to do business legitimately in this city, you need a business license."
Ms. Bradfield said that "theoretically if you have been writing out of your home and making money on it you have owed city taxes all along."
The ordinance requires a permit, which costs $25 annually, to conduct business from a home and it imposes a gross receipts tax at various rates for various businesses. For a print writer making $30,000, the permit and the tax would total about $200 annually.
The Writers Guild said that a gross receipts tax on writers was an unconstitutional intrusion but that even if it were allowed the city could not tax writers at different rates depending on whether they worked in films, television or print.
Mr. Wolf said the tax would inevitably result in audits in which the city would seek documents identifying confidential sources, like a police officer who had lunch with a freelance journalist and told about corruption at City Hall with the understanding that his name would never be revealed.
The business license offices of three cities neighboring Los Angeles -- Long Beach, Pasadena and Santa Monica -- said that their ordinances required writers and artists to get licenses or permits to work from their homes. But senior officials in each city said they were unaware of any enforcement of the requirement.
West Hollywood, which is surrounded by Los Angeles, exempts "creative enterprises" like writing, painting and making handicrafts from its permit requirements, and Mr. Ryavec has asked Los Angeles to do the same.
New York City does not require writers to get permits or licenses to work in their homes. Shonna Keoghan, the spokeswoman for the City Consumer Affairs Department, said she could not imagine the city trying to license activity protected by the First Amendment.
Under an amnesty program, Los Angeles has given operators of the estimated 20,000 home businesses until tomorrow to file for a permit, after which the city says it will seek back taxes and a 40 percent penalty plus interest on those who fail to comply.
Gary Bostwick, a lawyer in Santa Monica, Calif., who was hired by the Writers Guild to sue the city, said that when the amnesty expired the guild would have a basis to take the city to court. He said he would file a lawsuit when the Federal Courthouse in downtown Los Angeles opened on Monday morning.
Mr. Wolf said the Independent Writers would file a "friend of the court" brief supporting the lawsuit. The Southern California chapter of the American Society of Journalists and Authors will also file a brief, its president, Carey Simon, said.
Martin Garbus, a New York lawyer who specializes in literary litigation, predicted that a Federal judge would strike down the ordinance.
"Writers don't have to have permits, period," Mr. Garbus said. "This is unconstitutional on its face. You cannot put any burden on creative expression even if all you have to do is get a permit that is free."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Prospect of German Rate Rise Lifts Mark and Lowers Dollar

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against most major currencies yesterday as fresh economic news from Germany and comments from the nation's central bank chief stoked fears of higher German interest rates.
Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, warned in a newspaper interview that the bank could not ignore signs of rising prices, but stressed that it was premature to speak of a general inflationary threat. 
 He also said he welcomed the mark's recent rebound against the dollar. The dollar's decline yesterday accelerated when the German economics ministry reported that German industrial production had jumped a stronger-than-expected 3.5 percent in July.
"The industrial production number was the main reason pushing the dollar lower today," said Bob Steiner, vice president and corporate trader at Mellon Bank in Pittsburgh.
While the majority of traders and economists predicted that the inflation-conscious Bundesbank would leave rates steady at its policy meeting today, many said that resilient growth could tip the scales toward a rate increase before the end of the year. Higher German rates would make dollar-denominated investments less attractive compared with those denominated in marks.
"There is now more focus on Germany again than we have seen in recent months," said John McCarthy, senior vice president at ING Barings Capital Markets, predicting that the mark would remain relatively strong in coming weeks.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 1.8203 German marks, down from 1.8335 late on Tuesday. The dollar also eased to 120.85 Japanese yen from 121.47 yen.
The dollar was bolstered by late stock market gains, but dealers called the move a "hiccup." American economic news, they added, had been largely neutral for the dollar.
A small recovery in Japanese Government bond yields and a strong showing by Tokyo stocks, following the stock rally in the United States on Tuesday, helped buoy the yen against the dollar in early trading.
The dollar had risen sharply against the yen in recent weeks, passing 120 yen on Friday, amid mounting concern about Japan's faltering economy.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Coffee Hits a 3-Month High And El Nino Gets the Blame

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Coffee futures prices jumped to a three-month high yesterday on concern that dry weather in Colombia and Central America would reduce the size and quality of the coming harvests.
"The coffee market is a weather market and everyone is trading on what may happen to the crops," said Stephen Smith, president of South Futures Ltd., a coffee trading firm in Miami. 
 July and August brought little rain to Latin America as El Nino altered normal wind and rainfall patterns, meteorologists said. The lack of rainfall came as crops matured, with harvest set to begin later this month.
As a result, Colombia's coffee crop is expected to drop to a 20-year low while output in other Latin American countries, including Costa Rica, Honduras and Guatemala, could be smaller than last year, traders said.
Coffee for December delivery rose 4.55 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $1.895 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the contract's highest price since June 9.
On other markets, wheat slid after Egypt canceled an order and copper advanced. Wheat fell after Egypt canceled a tender for American wheat, raising speculation that the country, one of the world's largest importers, may have fulfilled its immediate needs.
Egypt sought 50,000 metric tons overnight only to cancel the order a few hours later, traders said. Egypt earlier this week purchased 100,000 tons of American wheat, the Department of Agriculture said.
Wheat for December delivery fell 4 cents, or 1.0 percent, to $3.90 a bushel on the Chicago Board of Trade. Despite yesterday's decline, wheat futures are up 18 percent since July 1 on strong export demand and concern that hot, dry weather could damage the spring wheat crop, to be harvested in coming weeks.
Copper rose as reports signaling a healthy American economy -- particularly in the construction industry, the largest user of copper -- suggested that copper demand would be strong in the coming months. Strong American demand could help copper rebound from a 20 percent drop since June 16.
Yesterday, December copper rose 1.8 cents, or 1.9 percent, to 98 cents a pound on the Comex division of the New York Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Japan without a trade surplus may not be such a great idea.

BYLINE: Peter Passell 

 BODY:
HARDLY anything is going right for the Japanese economy. After a burst of growth in the first quarter, Japan is once again teetering on the brink of recession. Meanwhile, protectionist noises are beginning to emanate from America as Japan's trade surplus grows. And the Japanese economy's near-term prospects for exports of capital goods to Southeast Asia have dimmed with the collapse of the Thai baht and other regional currencies.
Japan, it seems, is trapped between the need to grow richer to pay for the retirement of its aging population and the rest of the world's ambivalence about buying the flood of Japanese goods and services needed for Japan to accumulate the necessary wealth. 
 But some economists would happily turn this conventional wisdom on its head. Without Japanese exports of capital, asks Gary Saxonhouse, who would provide the savings to develop Eastern Europe and Latin America -- or, for that matter, the capital needed to keep interest rates relatively low in the United States? "Japan is doing the world a favor," he argued.
After expanding at a phenomenal 6.6 percent rate in the first three months of the year, the Japanese economy has settled back into tepid growth -- or worse. It is hard to tell because statistics for the first half were muddled by a surge of consumption ahead of a big tax increase and then a sharp fall in retail sales as the tax increase went into effect.
What is clear is Tokyo's determination to balance the Government budget over the next few years. Mr. Saxonhouse forecasts a doubling of the national consumption tax (to 10 percent) by early in the next century. That is likely to make the road to an enduring economic recovery quite bumpy. Equally troubling, with factory capacity in Southeast Asia temporarily overbuilt, there will be more pressure on Japanese capital goods exporters to shift their sights toward American consumers.
The economically enlightened (but politically sensitive) prescription for what ails Japan from this side of the Pacific is to divert savings into domestic investment and consumption. "There's lots Japan could do to help itself" without increasing its trade surplus, argued John Makin, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute.
Specifically, deregulating agriculture would open suburban land to a building boom. Deregulating distribution and retailing would increase efficiency and spur consumption. Deregulating financial services would allow Tokyo to capture profits that now flow to New York and London.
Some of this is likely to happen. While land-use reform remains the third rail of Japanese politics, financial services and the economy's archaic distribution system are already changing for the better.
But Mr. Saxonhouse notes that Japanese labor will grow increasingly scarce as the population ages, making it ever more difficult to complement new capital formation. Hence Japan's best investment opportunities will still be overseas.
In the middle term, he estimates, 3 percent domestic economic growth in Japan is consistent with a 2 percent surplus on foreign accounts -- not very different from the current-account surplus Japan has been averaging for the last two decades. "I don't see Japan having many options," he concluded.
Is that bad? If you happen to be an employee or major shareholder in General Motors or Chrysler, probably. Among other things, Japan is very accomplished at making cars (and car factories) for export. And any world in which Japan runs a large current-account surplus is likely to be a world in which competitors to the Japanese car companies will never be allowed to relax.
But it certainly isn't bad for American consumers, who are still enjoying the fruits of the shake-up in traditional industries forced by Japanese exporters in the 1980's. More to the immediate point, Japan is the only large, rich economy around to generate savings for others.
While America and Europe supply technology to the rest of the world, they collectively import capital. And though China and India may be able to develop without net inflows of capital -- South Korea and Taiwan managed it -- Latin America and Africa are unlikely to meet their potential without vast infusions of foreign savings.
America got a whiff of life without Japanese capital a few months ago when, in a fit of pique, Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto suggested that Japan might find a repository other than dollars for its surplus, and the bond market shuddered.
The sort of "hard landing" outcome feared in the mid-1980's, in which foreign capital flees Wall Street, no longer seems plausible. By the same token, though, fat and happy Americans seem all too ready to forget that dependence on the Japanese trade surplus is mutual. We need it almost as much as they do.
