HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Lower On Treasury Securities

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities turned lower yesterday after the General Motors Corporation reported stronger car sales for August than expected, raising fears among investors that the economy might be expanding fast enough to cause inflation to heat up. G.M. said car sales and light-truck sales rose 7.4 percent.
Investors were also moving to consolidate the previous day's gains ahead of more economic data this week and a glut of corporate debt issuance. The 30-year bond dropped 17/32, to a price of 97 4/32 to yield 6.60 percent, up from 6.55 percent on Tuesday. 
 Meanwhile, a large number of issuers lined up to sell debt in the public sector led by the Ford Motor Credit Company, which priced $1 billion of five-year global bonds through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday at a price to yield 6.596 percent, or about 42 basis points more than a comparable Treasury with a similar maturity. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Traders said the heavy supply of corporate debt expected over the near term put government securities under selling pressure. Jack Ablin, executive vice president and head of fixed income for Barnett Capital Advisors Inc., said: "There is a lot of corporate supply coming, with about $40 billion already slated for sale this month. That's about double the normal amount for September, normally a heavy month for corporate issuance." Mr. Ablin said about $24 billion of corporate debt would be normal for the month.
Market participants see shorting of intermediate-term Treasury securities like 10-year notes as a result of the hedging. "I'd expect near-term pressure on rates and spreads as a result," Mr. Ablin said. Other billion- dollar sales in the days ahead are being planned by Argentina and Venezuela.
In the municipal sector, the New York State Thruway Authority tentatively priced $456 million of local highway and bridge service contract revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 5.60 percent through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers.
Sylvan G. Feldstein, municipal bond analyst at the Guardian Life Insurance Company, said the issue drew good investor interest. It was the first muni deal by New York since ratings were upgraded by Standard & Poor's last week. The general obligation debt rating of New York State was lifted to A from A- and lease obligation debt to BBB+ from BBB.
Looking ahead, Donald Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Asset Management, said: "Looming on the statistical horizon is the recent August surge in gasoline prices at both the producer and consumer level. This will likely be felt in both the P.P.I. and C.P.I., and while this may disturb some market participants, it will not be a factor in the core indices.
"There are few signs that this is the beginning of a trend, or that any increases will be permanent. Nevertheless, it will give the bond market a target to set its sight on following the labor market data."
Traders expect the market to weaken further ahead of the payroll number tomorrow, as investors demand more compensation for the risk of an unfriendly number. Besides, some investors have been looking for opportunities to move out of current positions, and every piece of good news affords them that opportunity.
Yesterday the Commerce Department reported that construction spending rose five-tenths of 1 percent in July. It was the second consecutive month to show a gain. The Conference Board's index of leading indicators, which is meant to predict growth over the next half year, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July -- the best showing since February. It increased a revised one-tenth of 1 percent in June and two-tenths of 1 percent in May. Previously, a decline of 1.1 percent was reported for June.

HEADLINE: Clinton Presses Plan to Test Pupils on Federal Standards

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: OAK BLUFFS, Mass., Sept. 3

 BODY:
Eager to press for political advantage in a legislative fight awaiting him in Washington, President Clinton interrupted his vacation to appear at an elementary school here today, promoting his plan for voluntary tests to measure pupils' performance against new national standards in reading and math.
In a 20-minute talk to about 50 teachers and staff in the library of the Oak Bluffs School on Martha's Vineyard, Mr. Clinton was at pains to justify his plan, in an effort, his aides said, to set the terms of the brewing debate on school standards. 
 "We're living increasingly in a global society as well as a global economy," Mr. Clinton said, noting that a child on Martha's Vineyard, using the Internet, could dig into Australian libraries. "Educational excellence at world-class standards is now more important than ever."
But in Washington, Republicans tried today to frame the argument differently.
"Don't be fooled," said Christina Martin, a spokeswoman for Speaker Newt Gingrich, Republican of Georgia. "This isn't a debate about standards, it's about who sets them. Republicans believe parents and teachers should have a say in their children's education, while Democrats prefer bureaucrats."
Mr. Clinton hopes that by 1999, there will be tests based on the national standards for all fourth graders in reading, and all eighth graders in math. Over the last five years, the curriculum standards have been written by academic panels, in math, science, geography and history.
As he has repeatedly done in the past, Mr. Clinton emphasized today that the tests would be voluntary, not imposed by the Federal Government. Since he announced his testing proposal in his State of the Union Message in February, six states, including Massachusetts, have pledged to use it. Fifteen big-city school districts, including New York's, have also embraced the plan.
Representative Bill Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who is chairman of the Education and Workforce Committee, is seeking to block the Department of Education from spending money on Mr. Clinton's tests. Perhaps as soon as Thursday, Mr. Goodling plans to introduce legislation that would do so by amending the appropriations bill that finances the Department of Education.
Mr. Clinton's senior aides have urged him to veto that spending bill if Mr. Goodling is successful. But the President has not made a veto decision, a White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said.
Mr. Goodling argues that the Federal Government would be intruding on state and local authority by creating the tests. Further, he says, children already must take enough tests to measure their skills.
"House Republicans and many Democrats would rather send Federal dollars to the classroom, bolster basic academics and seek ways to increase parental involvement," Mr. Goodling said today in a statement.
As they geared up today for what Mr. Clinton predicted would be "one of the major debating points of the next few weeks," White House and Congressional aides said that, after the summer recess, they were uncertain how broad Mr. Goodling's support was. But the Congressman appears to be assembling a paradoxical coalition that includes conservatives who reject an increased Federal role in education and Democrats who fervently support it.
Representative Major R. Owens, Democrat of Brooklyn, said he would support Mr. Goodling's legislation because, unless the Federal Government spends more money to supply books, build classrooms and patch leaky roofs, children in poor areas are doomed to test poorly, and then to bear the stigma of failure.
"We should not be stampeded into testing because it looks good in the headlines," Mr. Owens said. "For the White House and Administration, I'm afraid it's become, 'Let's do something and get the credit for it,' without thinking about the consequences of what they're going, or the morality."
White House aides prefer to emphasize their Republican opposition, citing public polls showing that the public trusts Mr. Clinton more than the Republicans on education issues.
"This is the party that two years ago chose to close the Department of Education," said Rahm Emanuel, senior adviser to Mr. Clinton, recalling past unpopular Republican budget-cutting maneuvers.
The Department of Education is spending $15 million developing the tests this year, and Mr. Clinton has asked for another $16 million for the tests next year.
In his remarks today, the President rejected the idea that children were already subject to enough tests, saying that many existing state tests do not measure against national standards.
"I think it would be a terrible mistake," Mr. Clinton said, "for people who are afraid our children can't measure up or who have a misguided notion that somehow the Federal Government is trying to take over the direction of education in America to persuade members of Congress not to fund the tests."

HEADLINE: Leading Index Rose at a Fast Clip in July

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 3

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators rose at the fastest rate in five months during July, and construction spending advanced -- evidence that economic growth may accelerate in the year's second half.
Investors, who had already seen evidence of strength in other economic data, did not appear overly troubled by today's reports: Stocks rose slightly and bonds fell. Some analysts said the statistics kept alive the possibility that Federal Reserve policy makers could raise interest rates later this year to prevent the growing economy from causing an acceleration in inflation. 
 "The economy is robust; leading indicators tell us it will continue on that path," said Patrick Retzer, a bond manager at Heartland Advisors in Milwaukee. "If the strong data continues, I think they'll have to raise rates later this year."
The Conference Board reported that its index of leading indicators, which is meant to predict growth over the next half year, rose three-tenths of 1 percent in July -- the best showing since February, when the economy was running at full throttle -- after having increased a revised one-tenth of 1 percent in June and two-tenths of 1 percent in May.
In a separate report, the Commerce Department said spending on new construction rose in July for the second consecutive month, increasing half a percent, to a $598.7 billion annual rate. That was the largest monthly gain since February.
The Conference Board's index of leading indicators has risen in eight of the last nine months; not since April and May 1995 have there been two consecutive months without an increase. July's increase of three-tenths of 1 percent was slightly above analysts' expectations.
The index monitors a variety of previously released economic data, including the spread between the yield on the 10-year Treasury note and the Federal funds rate, which is the rate banks charge one another for loans overnight. A widening spread between long- and short-term interest rates is viewed as an indicator that the Fed may push borrowing costs higher.
Of the 10 indicators in the index, six made a positive contribution during July. They were led by a decline in jobless claims, to a monthly average of 304,900 -- one of the lowest levels in 20 years -- from June's average of 338,900, and by an increase in stock prices, with the Dow Jones industrial average topping 8,000 for the first time during the month. The other positive contributors were increased consumer confidence; a larger money supply; slower deliveries, which is a sign of pent-up demand, and an increase in building permits.
Three components made a negative contribution, led by a narrower interest rate spread between the 10-year Treasury note and the overnight bank lending rate -- an indication that investors expected slower economic growth and, as a result, did not expect a rate rise by the Fed. The other two negative components were a drop in the manufacturing workweek, to 41.7 hours in July from 41.8 hours in June, and weaker factory orders for consumer goods. One item, factory orders for non-military capital goods, was unchanged.
The index of coincident indicators, a gauge of current economic activity like industrial production, increased two-tenths of 1 percent during July. The index of lagging indicators, including the unemployment rate, decreased four-tenths of 1 percent.
July's increase in construction spending followed a revision to June's figures that in turn pushedJuly construction to a record that exceeded analysts' expectations. June's construction spending rose a revised one-tenth of 1 percent instead of declining 1.1 percent, as the Government previously reported.
"The outlook is good for overall construction," said Evelina Tainer, chief economist at IndoSuez Carr Futures in Chicago. "Low interest rates are helping the residential and nonresidential sectors, office vacancy rates are low and the housing numbers we're seeing suggest the residential sector will at least maintain itself at a high level."
In July, spending on residential construction rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, to a $259.9 billion annual rate. Housing and other residential construction amounts to about half of all construction spending.
Spending on commercial projects like factories and warehouses increased 1.2 percent, to a $163.9 billion rate. Spending on public projects fell eight-tenths of 1 percent in July, to a $136.5 billion rate.

HEADLINE: Right to Build Over Terminal Is Up for Sale

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, hoping to cash in on the resurgence of the Times Square area, plans to sell the development rights above its Manhattan bus terminal, at 42d Street and Eighth Avenue, for a 35-story commercial building, officials said yesterday.
The plan, announced jointly by the Port Authority and the top economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki, could generate as much as $100 million from a developer who would purchase unused air rights above the 37-year-old bus terminal, real estate executives said. 
 The Port Authority said that six of New York City's largest developers have expressed interest in the proposal since it was quietly circulated late last year. The developers have now been asked to submit their bids and final building plans by Jan. 15.
The new building would include one million square feet of space -- about half the amount of space in the Pan Am building above Grand Central Terminal. It would rise over the six stories of the passenger terminal and bus lanes in the northern section of the bus depot, bounded by 41st and 42d Streets.
The authority has not put any restrictions on the type of building that could be erected, whether a hotel or apartments.
But Charles Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation and vice chairman of the Port Authority, who has championed the bus terminal proposal, said an office tower would be the most logical use of the site, with an entertainment-industry complex, perhaps including a television studio, on its lower floors.
Although the development plan comes at a time of growing interest in several sites west of Times Square -- an area long considered one of Manhattan's most forlorn urban backwaters -- it could provoke tensions with City Hall.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has repeatedly criticized the Port Authority, saying it allocates its investments in a way that shortchanges the city. One concern is that part of whatever money is raised through the bus terminal development could be used in New Jersey.
But Mr. Gargano said he had pressed for the project with the intention of benefiting the city.
"We will be keenly aware that this is a New York property, and make sure that the resources are allocated appropriately," he said.
But other questions remain. It was unclear, for example, whether a developer would have to pay property taxes on the new high rise over the terminal, since the Port Authority itself is tax exempt. Instead of property taxes, the Port Authority pays fees to the city on a schedule negotiated in the 1970's.
At City Hall, Bernadette O'Leary, a spokeswoman for the Mayor, declined comment yesterday. A spokeswoman for Mr. Gargano, Caroline Quardararo, said the question of how much tax, if any, would be paid on the new building was "something to be resolved down the road."
Proponents of the Port Authority plan said it would benefit the city by heightening the momentum of development around Times Square and by giving the bus terminal a new, safer and more attractive identity.
Other projects at the bus terminal have been announced by the Port Authority in recent months. They include a plan to put up large neon signs along the exterior of the terminal's stark, industrial-looking bus ramps, and to install a golf driving range on the roof of the terminal's southern section, bounded by 40th and 41st Streets between Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
"The proposal we are now exploring can insure that the bus terminal continues to be a catalyst for the rebirth of 42d Street," said Robert E. Boyle, the executive director of the Port Authority.
In addition to the new 35-story tower, the plan calls for turning over to the developer about one-third of the existing interior space of the north passenger terminal. The space would be used for an entrance to the new building and for retail space.
Although construction would cause disruption for many of the thousands of people who use the bus terminal each day, Port Authority officials said it could be held to a manageable level, because the bus ramps would not be moved. Alan Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority, said the developer would be required to plan construction in phases to reduce disruptions.
The agency said the bus terminal, built in stages beginning in 1960, was designed to support a high-rise development. The potential pitfall of bus fumes rising into the new high rise was eliminated, they said, in the terminal's original design: exhaust fans blow the fumes out over the surrounding streets, instead of straight up.
Development companies that have expressed interest in the project include Silverstein Properties, Forest City Ratner Companies, the Related Companies and Tishman Realty and Construction Company.
Those who responded to inquiries yesterday said their interest in the bus terminal was tentative. "We submitted something sketchy, just saying let us have a look," said Joyce Baumgarten, a spokeswoman for Forest City.
The plan provoked sharply divided reactions in the real estate industry. At Cushman & Wakefield, a large commercial brokerage, Bill Shanahan, the firm's senior director, said the plan would benefit from the terminal's link to commuter bus lines and its location directly above several subway lines. He estimated that developers would bid up to $100 million for the building's air rights.
But at another company, Insignia/ Edward S. Gordon, Mary Ann Tighe, the executive managing director, said the bus terminal retained a sufficiently seedy image that would discourage developers from offering top dollar.
"The fact that someone would have to say his building is the one above the bus terminal does not conform to my definition of something that will command high rents," she said, adding that her estimate of what developers would pay was $35 million to $40 million.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Six New York City developers are interested in the space above the Port Authority Bus Terminal on 42d Street and Eighth Avenue. (Marilynn K. Yee/The New York Times)(pg. B6)
 
Map of Manhattan showing locations of The Port Authority bus terminal and the site of the new 35-story building: The Port Authority wants to cash in on its 42d Street location. (pg. B6)

HEADLINE: Cheered by Wall Street, Some Asia Stock Markets Revive

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Share prices jumped 7.1 percent in Hong Kong yesterday, with the benchmark index recording its biggest one-day gain ever in terms of points, as investors drew strength from Wall Street's surge on Tuesday and snapped up shares that had plunged in the last few days, the steepest part of the Hong Kong market's worst slump since 1989.
Tuesday's sharp rally in the United States, which sent the Dow Jones industrial average up 3.38 percent, or 257.36 points, helped lift stocks in some other Asian markets, as well, although local factors played the chief role. 
 In Indonesia, for instance, shares surged 7 percent after the Government announced its intention to increase exports and abolish the 49 percent limit on foreign ownership of shares sold in initial public offerings. The day before, the central bank in Jakarta moved to stabilize the value of the currency, limiting large foreign futures and options transactions against the rupiah.
Stocks rose in the Philippines for the first time in nine sessions after the central bank moved to allow banks to increase lending.
In Malaysia, however, the benchmark index fell for the ninth consecutive session, dropping 5.7 percent, as the currency continued to weaken and Government efforts to prop up the market continued to fail.
Southeast Asian stock markets have been on a wild ride in recent weeks as regional currencies have tumbled and interest rates have risen. Hong Kong's market -- Asia's second largest, after Tokyo -- has been hurt further by sharp swings in speculative China-related shares.
Earlier this week, the benchmark Hang Seng index fell below its level at the start of the year. Yesterday, though, it regained a big piece of lost ground, jumping 978.66 points, or 7.1 percent, to 14,713.99.
Despite the battering the region's markets have been taking, Andrew Look, an investment manager at Prudential Portfolio Managers Asia Ltd., said: "There is nothing, absolutely nothing, structurally wrong with Asia. It's selective buying during the downfall."
In Indonesia, the Jakarta Stock Market Composite Index rose 33.57 points, or 7 percent, to 512.59.
Shares were lifted by a statement from the Government that it would take "credible proactive measures" to restore stability to the currency and economy. In addition to increasing exports, it promised to cut spending and reduce interest rates.
Yet it announced little in the way of a specific program, and the 49 percent limit on foreign ownership of initial stock offerings will remain with companies that are already publicly traded. "We've heard all this before," said Agnes Safford, president-director of ABN Amro Hoare Govett Asia Indonesia. "It's like there's nothing really there."
But Felix Otto D'Souza, head of research at Peregrine Securities, said that the change in the foreign-ownership limit "can only be seen as a precursor to total deregulation." He said local investors believed that the Government measures would be good for the economy, while foreign investors were "desperately waiting" for a drop in interest rates.
Philippine stocks rose after the central bank said it would cut to 6 percent from 8 percent the portion of their total funds that commercial banks must keep on deposit with it. The central bank had tightened the requirement a week earlier, acting to push up interest rates in an effort to support the Philippine peso. But commercial banks and Government officials had called for relief from the resulting cash shortage.
Share prices rose for the first time in nine sessions, with the Philippines Composite Index increasing 43.72 points, or 2.2 percent, to 1,994.13.
In Malaysia, though, the benchmark Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 44.97 points, or 5.7 percent, to 750.76. "It's all about confidence," said David Yong, a trader at Arab-Malaysian Securities. "The foreign investors are the main sellers. I don't see any rebound in the near term."
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad called last week for local investment funds to buy shares, and regulators have imposed trading restrictions, but stocks have declined for nine sessions nonetheless. One reason has been the weak Malaysian currency, the ringgit, which traded yesterday at its lowest level against the dollar in 26 years.
The Prime Minister said yesterday that the Government planned to raise a total of 60 billion ringgit, or $20.4 billion, some of it through a bond sale, and to use the money to buy stocks.
Elsewhere in Asia yesterday, shares rose 1.3 percent in Singapore and fell three-tenths of 1 percent in Thailand. The baht continued to fall, sliding as much as 7 percent to another record low against the dollar.

HEADLINE: From the Top of the Barrel;
Gallo Powers Its Way Into the Premium Wine Market

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

DATELINE: HEALDSBURG, Calif.

 BODY:
Over lunch recently at Bistro Ralph, a wine makers' hangout here in the heart of the California wine country, somebody mentioned that E.& J. Gallo Winery Inc., the mass producer of inexpensive jug brands like Carlo Rossi and Gallo Hearty Burgundy and street fortifiers like Thunderbird, had placed in the top 10 in a rating competition with one of its new Sonoma wines. But the remark only exasperated Gina Gallo, a third-generation marketing executive with the company.
"First would have been better," Ms. Gallo said, pausing between bites of her lamb burger. "Second is O.K., too. But just being in the top 10 is unacceptable." 
 Gallo has always wanted to be No. 1 at everything it does. And it mostly has. Since it was founded in 1933 by the brothers Ernest and Julio Gallo, it has grown into the biggest winery in the world, with production of nearly 900 million bottles last year and revenue approaching an estimated $1 billion. (The privately held company does not release its financial results.) Sales representatives like to quote a line by Ernest Gallo, the 88-year-old family patriarch: "We don't want most of the business; we want it all."
One market segment always eluded Gallo, though. That was premium fine wines, those cabernet sauvignons, chardonnays and pinot noirs aged in wooden barrels and corked in 750-milliliter bottles. So, after several false starts in the marketplace, the company is trying once again to conquer that territory. And finally, despite its reputation as a mass rather than a class wine maker, Gallo has managed to make a name for itself in the midpriced and premium categories, too.
The name, though, is not just Gallo. They are Turning Leaf, Gossamer Bay, Indigo Hills, Zabaco and Marcelina, all new wine labels owned by Gallo that sell anywhere from about $7 a bottle to as much as $20. Not only is the Gallo name never mentioned on those labels, they usually say "Made in Healdsburg," rather than Modesto, where the Gallos got their start and which has become almost synonymous their name.
Other new lines rely on the Gallo name, though the labels vary from the traditional one, often displaying simply the signatures of the founders. These include the Single Vineyard varietals -- chardonnays, cabernets and the like with price tags of $14 to $18 -- and the top-of-the-line Sonoma Estate wines, including a chardonnay that retails for $30 and a cabernet sauvignon that goes for more than $40.
A $40 bottle of Gallo wine? Yes, and to the consternation of Gallo's competitors, some of the wines are winning raves among customers and critics. Chez Panisse, the Berkeley restaurant owned by Alice Waters that is in the vanguard of the best in California cuisine, recently bought its first cases of Gallo Sonoma wines.
"They said it couldn't be done," said Ed Everett, an importer and wine consultant based in San Francisco. "Everyone in the industry said Gallo could never shake off its jug-wine image. Which is just the kind of challenge the Gallos love. And they've done it."
There is a good reason, of course, why Gallo is so determined to remake its image. Consumption of the blended table wines on which Gallo feasted for years has stagnated while varietals, named for the predominant grape used to make them, have taken off. Last year, for example, the volume of varietals shipped by California wineries was up nearly 10 percent, to 76.7 million cases, according to Impact, an industry trade journal, while table wine was up only 1.7 percent, to 52.9 million cases. In 1985, generic table wine accounted for 81 percent of all California wine shipments; last year, it was down to about 40 percent.
Responding to this shift in taste, Gallo has moved production of its premium wines to Sonoma County, where it has been buying up land for years. And to give the Gallo designation more panache, the family began removing its name from some of the cheaper wines and shrinking it on others, selling them with alternative labels, including Sheffield and Livingston Cellars. They abandoned the three- and four-liter bottles for Hearty Burgundy, once the country's best-known jug wine, confining it to standard 750-millimeter and 1.5-liter bottles with corks, low-key labels and a price of $4 for the smaller bottles.
"It's not inconceivable that one day the Gallo name will be associated only with top-of-the-line varietals," said Mr. Everett, the wine consultant.
But that day is a long way off. To capture more consumers with highbrow tastes, the Gallos swallowed their pride and excised the Gallo name from most of the new Sonoma brands, as well as from the two big Modesto sellers, Turning Leaf, begun in 1995 with a price of about $7, and Gossamer Bay, introduced last year for around $8.
Marking many of its labels "Made in Healdsburg" is worth "many millions of dollars to the Gallos," according to the wine consultant Jon Fredriksen, because it avoids the Modesto identification that is a Gallo give-away. In fact, a recently introduced Turning Leaf Reserve line is made at Sonoma instead of Modesto, benefiting from the cachet of the Healdsburg address.
Gallo had little choice. It had largely missed out on the seismic shift of America's wine drinkers from jug wines to varietals.
Gallo, slow to tap into the varietal boom, had come out with some uninspiring brands in the 1980's. It let other big names grab a big slice of that market -- particularly the Benziger family with its Glen Ellen line, which it sold to Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s Heublein unit in 1993.
But now Gallo is in a hurry to make up for lost time. To help meet demand for its new brands, the recently completed winery in Sonoma just west of Healdsburg is operating 24 hours a day, producing an estimated two million bottles a month. Gallo expects to increase its capacity by 30 percent within the next couple of years in addition to opening three more wineries on the California coast.
The Sonoma winery property, known as the Frei Ranch, is unmarked and surrounded by high fences and guarded gates, as are the immense Gallo wineries in the Central Valley. No tours or tastings, those staples of the California wine business, are offered. The scene is bucolic but a turn in the road reveals a multimillion-dollar plant, probably the most technically advanced in the world, that presses and processes the grapes from Gallo land in Sonoma.
At Frei Ranch, the company has embraced an ancient tool of the trade that it shunned at Modesto -- great wooden barrels for aging the wines -- building an underground cellar the size of a football field with room for 60,000 of the casks, A second cellar of the same size is on the drawing board. Gallo buys about 20,000 of the barrels a year for Sonoma, importing most of them from master builders in France at a cost of around $600 each.
"We buy two-dozen barrels from a cooper and test them before we buy in quantity," said a senior wine maker, Marcello Monticelli. At any time, he said, hundreds of tests involving different wine and barrel combinations are under way.
At least one competitor believes Gallo stepped over the ethical line in pursuit of its marketing ambitions. Last year, Kendall-Jackson Winery Ltd. sued the company for trademark infringement, contending that Gallo's new Turning Leaf label replicated the autumn-leaf logo on its huge-selling Vintner's Reserve line. A jury decided against Kendall Jackson in March, but the winery is appealing the decision.
In its marketing effort, the company has deployed a small army of third-generation Gallos -- 15 in all, out of 20 grandchildren of the founders. Gina, 30, started out in sales, studied wine making at the University of California at Davis and now oversees all wine production at Sonoma. Her brother Matt, 34, is operations manager at the Sonoma properties, and their cousin, Caroline Coleman Bailey, handles marketing. Both Gina and Matt play dual roles. They have become the attractive and highly visible new faces of a company long known for its secretiveness and suspicion of the outside world. Both spend time on the road meeting with sales representatives, wine writers and customers.
Meanwhile, the center of power has shifted to the second generation, who were long overshadowed by Ernest and Julio. Julio was killed in a car accident four years ago at the age of 83, and Ernest, still stricken by the loss, has removed himself from daily operations. He continues to deal with long-range planning, though, and remains an intimidating presence. "He's into every aspect of the business," a Gallo manager said, "and God help you if you can't answer one of his questions."
Now running the show are three second-generation co-presidents: Julio's son Robert, in charge of viniculture and wine making; his son-in-law James Coleman, in charge of production, and Ernest's son Joseph, in charge of sales. A fourth co-president, Ernest's older son, David, died in March of a heart attack at the age of 57.
There was a time when wine makers in Sonoma County and over the mountain in the Napa Valley shrugged off the threat from the Gallos. Now it gives them sleepless nights.
"The Gallos are laying down a challenge with these wines and anyone around who's not up to that challenge would be wise to consider another line of work," said Rodney Strong, the founder of Rodney Strong Vineyards in the Sonoma County town of Windsor, who sold out and retired two years ago.
Gallo has moved into the premium segment while maintaining its dominant position in the twist-off-cap category. The Sonoma winery's annual output of 26.5 million bottles a year is dwarfed by the 388 million bottles of its bread-and-butter Carlo Rossi, Livingston Cellars and the Wine Cellars of Ernest & Julio Gallo labels.
Still, it is the lure of luxury that pumps up the family these days. And they are jumping in in typical Gallo fashion -- all out.
Gallo's buying spree in Sonoma has given it eight different properties covering 6,000 acres in one of the most fertile wine growing regions of the country. Among others, it has acquired the old Italian Swiss Colony Asti vineyards for $11 million and a 1,700-acre cattle ranch once owned by the late actor Fred MacMurray for $7 million. There, it plans to cultivate about 500 acres of once hilly terrain that it has reshaped to wine-making specifications with immense land-moving machines previously used to build the Alaska pipeline.
"Gallo was slow to get into premium wines, but that's their style," said Mr. Fredriksen of Gomberg Fredriksen, the wine consulting firm in San Francisco. "They watch, they wait, then they jump in and take over. They have no stockholders and they put everything back in the business. They take advantage of their massive economies of scale, and they are very, very aggressive."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Ernest, top, and Julio Gallo founded the company in 1933. Julio died in 1993. Gina and Matt Gallo run the premium Sonoma wine division. (pg. D1)

Ernest and Julio Gallo became the biggest winery in the world by mass producing inexpensive table wines, like Carlo Rossi and Hearty Burgundy. Today, Gallo is also producing premium, fine wines in its latest attempt to capture the higher end of the market. The Gallo name is not on the labels or is reduced only to the signatures of its founders. Here's how Gallo describes their traditional wines and its newest labels.

HEADLINE: New Type of Bond Sold by City Gets Higher Credit Rating

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
A new type of bond being sold by the New York City government received a favorable reception from Wall Street credit-rating agencies yesterday, which should allow the city to save hundreds of millions of dollars in interest payments over the next few decades.
The Wall Street agencies gave higher ratings to the new bonds than those for the city's regular bonds, which have remained relatively low since the municipal finances were battered by the recession in the early 1990's. 
 The new bonds are being issued by the New York City Transitional Finance Authority, which Gov. George E. Pataki and the State Legislature established earlier this year to help the city get around a cap on its outstanding debt that is set by the State Constitution.
The limit prevents the city from selling more bonds, which in the past have financed billions of dollars in spending on schools, bridges and other projects.
Under the new arrangement, $7.5 billion in bonds will be sold not by the city but by the authority, which is quasi-independent from the city government and not subject to the debt ceiling. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's budget director, Joseph J. Lhota, is overseeing the sale.
Moody's Investors Service, one of the rating firms, rated the authority's debt at A2, which is two notches above its rating for the city's regular debt, Baa1. Standard & Poor's Corporation and Fitch Investors Service have also told the city that they are planning to give the finance authority's bonds higher ratings than the bonds of the general municipal debt.
"This is really very good news for the city," Mr. Giuliani said.
While the city's economy and finances have improved in the last year, largely because of the boom on Wall Street, the credit agencies said they were giving good ratings to the finance authority's bonds largely because of the way they are structured.
The higher ratings should allow the city to pay less in interest to bondholders than it does for its regular debt.
The agencies said the finance authority's bonds are more secure than the regular debt because they are more insulated from the municipal finances.
The city has also pledged the receipts from its personal income tax as backing for the finance authority's debt.
"This rating is not an indication of the city's basic fiscal health," said Renee Boicourt, a managing director at Moody's Investors Service. "The rating is an indication of the security of these bonds, which have a lot of technical features that make them better than the city's general obligation debt."

The index of leading economic indicators rose at the fastest rate in five months during July, and construction spending advanced.

HEADLINE: Arizona Governor Convicted Of Fraud and Will Step Down

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Sept. 3

 BODY:
A Federal jury today convicted Gov. Fife Symington of Arizona of seven felony counts of defrauding his lenders as a commercial real estate developer, forcing his resignation and leaving him facing the prospect of prison and hundreds of thousands of dollars in fines.
"I have never been one to linger, and I don't intend to start now," a solemn but composed Mr. Symington told supporters in a farewell announcement at the Capitol about 90 minutes after the verdict. "My lot is to offer best wishes and full support, to say thank you and move on." 
 The jury was deadlocked on 11 of the 21 counts over all, and acquitted Mr. Symington on 3 charges. But under state law, Mr. Symington, a Republican, had to leave office if convicted of even a single felony count.
Mr. Symington's lawyer said the 52-year-old Governor's resignation would take effect at 5 P.M. on Friday. Since the state has no lieutenant governor, Secretary of State Jane Dee Hull, a fellow Republican, will serve as governor until the regular statewide election next year.
After a 17-week trial that involved more than 1,400 pieces of evidence assembled in a five-year investigation, the jury convicted Mr. Symington, who took office in 1991 and was once a rising star in national Republican circles, of filing false financial statements in an effort to shore up his crumbling real estate business in the late 1980's and early 90's.
Of the three counts on which Mr. Symington was acquitted, one of the most serious was that he used his power as Governor to threaten to steer state tenants away from a troubled downtown development if the union pension fund that financed it listed him in default. Judge Roger G. Strand of Federal District Court here declared a mistrial on the 11 deadlocked counts, and prosecutors said they would consider whether to seek a new trial on those counts.
In all, Mr. Symington faced 21 counts accusing him of lying to lenders about his true financial condition, of extorting the pension fund and of perjuring himself in a bankruptcy hearing.
It was the second time in a decade that an Arizona Governor faced felony charges. Gov. Evan Mecham, also a Republican, was eventually acquitted of accepting illegal campaign contributions, but not before being impeached in 1988.
Mr. Symington is the third Governor in the 1990's to be forced from office because of a conviction. Last year Gov. Jim Guy Tucker of Arkansas, a Democrat, resigned after his conviction on fraud and conspiracy charges in Whitewater-related business dealings. In 1993 Gov. Guy Hunt of Alabama, a Republican, was convicted and forced from office for looting his 1987 inaugural fund.
Today's verdict was a stunning blow for Mr. Symington, a great-grandson of Henry Clay Frick, the turn-of-the-century coal and steel magnate, and a cousin of Stuart Symington, a Democratic Senator from Missouri.
Fife Symington, an Air Force veteran of the Vietnam War era, parlayed his real estate career into state politics, before being forced to declare bankruptcy after taking office.
In office, he quickly established a reputation as a fiscal conservative and an aggressive free-marketeer, cutting taxes, reigning in spending, helping Republicans gain control of both houses of the Legislature and leading a move to require a two-thirds legislative majority to raise taxes. But for the last five years he has been dogged by the criminal investigation.
Today, prosecutors pronounced themselves pleased with the outcome of the trial.
"We're always pleased when justice is done," the lead prosecutor, David Schindler, said in an impromptu news conference after the verdict.
Mr. Symington's lawyers, who had argued that the errors in his financial statements were the inadvertent mistakes of a beleaguered entrepreneur, said they would try to have the verdict set aside, and then to appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit.
"If this was a football game, we'd be home and one," the chief defense lawyer, John Dowd, said.
"We've won 16 of them and we're not done. We'll move to have the verdict set aside and then appeal," Mr. Dowd said, referring to the 11 deadlocked charges, 3 acquittals and 2 counts that were dropped from the case before the jury got the case.
Had he been convicted on all counts, Mr. Symington would have faced maximum penalties of 300 years in prison and $14 million in fines, but prosecutors have said it would be difficult to estimate any realistic sentence because sentencing guidelines were different during the various periods covered by the charges.
Mr. Dowd said today that the guidelines were "enough to make your eyes cross."
But prosecutors said Mr. Symington appeared likely to serve some prison time, and Nora M. Manella, the United States Attorney in Los Angeles who supervised the case, said the guidelines prohibited a sentence of probation for some of the charges on which the Governor was convicted.
In a news conference after the verdict, Ms. Manella said the verdict showed that "no amount of pedigree" can excuse anyone "from playing by the rules."
The heart of the Government's case was that Mr. Symington falsely inflated his true net worth in efforts to get more loans by making himself appear wealthy, and then painting himself as poorer than he was to have loans forgiven.
In his closing argument to the jury, Mr. Schindler said that what Mr. Symington did was "no different from any other con artist."
But, in a week on the stand in his own defense, the Governor repeatedly contended that the mistakes in his statements were innocent errors.
In his instructions to the jury, Judge Strand told the panel that in determining whether Mr. Symington made "material" false statements to his lenders, it was not important whether the information he gave actually had an impact on the banks' decisions, only that the information was "capable of influencing" the lenders' decisions.
The convictions centered on two of Mr. Symington's biggest projects, the Camelback Esplanade hotel and shopping complex that is home to the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Phoenix, and the Mercado, a turreted Mexican-style shopping complex in downtown Phoenix.
In the Esplanade case, the jury found that Mr. Symington inflated his net worth in false statements in the early 1990's to the Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank of Japan, which made nearly $130 million in loans for the project, to avoid being declared in default.
At one point, prosecutors said, Mr. Symington sent the bank a letter falsely claiming a net worth of $5.3 million when another statement showed him to be $4.1 million in the red. In interviews on the courthouse steps afterward, jurors said the multiple statements had helped convince them that Mr. Symington intended to lie, but several described the process of reaching their verdicts as very difficult.
On the Mercado project, the jury found that in the late 1980's Mr. Symington repeatedly filed false financial statements to win loans from a group of Arizona pension funds.
The verdicts capped a tumultuous trial and long deliberations. At 10:30 this morning, the jurors told Judge Strand that they had reached unanimous conclusions on some counts but were deadlocked on others. Despite a plea from Mr. Schindler to send them back for further deliberations on the unresolved counts, the judge agreed to declare a mistrial on the deadlocked counts.
It was the 18th day of deliberations over all, and the 10th since deliberations were forced to begin again after an alternate joined the panel. On Aug. 19, Judge Strand dismissed Mary Jane Cotey, a 74-year-old juror, after her fellow jurors complained that she was unable to focus on the issues, and needed help filling out her lunch requests.
Mr. Symington was released on his own recognizance, with the only requirement that he check in with Mr. Dowd once a week. Judge Strand set sentencing for Nov. 10.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Daily Briefing;
Homeowners Call for Help

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: ASBURY PARK

 BODY:
In a plea to state officials to bail out their beach community, an Asbury Park homeowners association has prepared a thick report on the city's financial crisis, rising crime and decaying neighborhoods.
The report, which accuses the city government and the Board of Education of corruption, was based on a six-week investigation, the treasurer of the Asbury Park Homeowners Association, Kate Mellina, said yesterday. "We are begging everybody, from the Governor to the Attorney General to the State Board of Education, to help us down here," she said. "This is way too big for us to handle." 
 The tax base in Asbury Park, which has a population of 15,600, declined $14.4 million last year, according to Ms. Mellina. But Kenneth Saunders, who has been the Mayor since June, said his administration did not cause the city's problems and complained that the report was politically motivated.

HEADLINE: For Welfare Recipients, Employment Is Elusive

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The implicit point in your Aug. 28 front-page article on welfare-to-work incentives is that earnings in the low-wage labor market will typically be insufficient to support a family. We can argue all day about the extent to which "earnings disregards" -- which allow working welfare recipients to keep a portion of their benefits -- encourage work, but we're still stuck with the fact that many former recipients are likely to be economically worse off once they leave the rolls. 
 So what is the most effective way to raise the incomes of families that depend on the low-wage labor market? Minimum wage increases, training programs, expanded wage subsidies and child care subsidies may all play a role. Most important, however, is for the Federal Reserve to continue accommodating low unemployment until real wages of low-wage workers start to rise.
 
JARED BERNSTEIN
Washington, Aug. 29, 1997
 
The writer is a labor economist with the Economic Policy Institute.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 5; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: For Welfare Recipients, Employment Is Elusive;
How Employers See It

 BODY:

To the Editor:
While economic incentives may impel welfare recipients in the direction of what is deemed desirable behavior (front page, Aug. 28), if the transition from welfare to work is to succeed, then the welfare recipient must become someone else: a worker. This is not simply a matter of being on a payroll; it is a cultural matter, entailing the transformation of people's perceptions, values and posture. 
 Surveys show that employers' reluctance to hire inner-city applicants is based less on the applicants' lack of skills than on the perception that they did not have the necessary professional posture. In a society where a chronically unemployed underclass has been institutionalized, the culture of unemployment must give way if the transition from welfare to work is going be successful.
The Industrial Revolution was as much a cultural as an economic phenomenon. Millions of people in England and Western Europe who had never seen a machine or earned a wage -- and lacked role models who had -- underwent a profound cultural transformation in becoming the first industrial working class in history. We must create conditions in which the millions of Americans who have yet to undergo a comparable transformation are supported to perform their parts in the culture of work.
 
GABRIELLE KURLANDER
New York, Aug. 29, 1997
 
The writer is president of the Community Literacy Research Project.

HEADLINE: European Part-Timers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Only Employment for Many in Europe Is Part-Time Work" (front page, Sept. 1): While you mention that most Western European employers extend benefits to part-time workers, you do not stress the different philosophy in Europe from that of the United States: Part-time work in Europe is not seen as a way for employers to escape from paying benefits but as the most effective weapon to fight unemployment in an age of automatization.
 
HANS KONING
Fairfield, Conn., Sept. 1, 1997

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Natural Gas Prices Plummet On Strong Inventory Report

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Natural gas prices plunged 4.6 percent yesterday, their biggest loss in three months, after an unexpectedly large gain in inventories eased concerns about supplies for this winter.
American natural gas inventories rose 84 billion cubic feet last week, to 2.212 trillion cubic feet, the American Gas Association said after trading on Wednesday. The nation's inventories are 4.3 percent above levels a year ago as mild, cool weather holds down demand from utilities. 
 "The market will be in good shape if there are a few more weeks of milder weather like this," said Todd Speiser, a trader at the Enserch Corporation in Houston.
Natural gas for October delivery fell 13 cents, to $2.677 for 1,000 cubic feet on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the largest one-day drop for gas since June 2. Prices are down 2.9 percent so far this year.
In other markets, gasoline fell to a seven-week low, while coffee rose for the eighth consecutive day.
Gasoline fell amid expectations that the end of the summer travel season would erode demand for motor fuels when refinery output is close to record levels.
The American Petroleum Institute said after the markets closed on Wednesday that American gasoline inventories fell 1.97 million barrels last week, to 187.53 million barrels. While that drop was close to expectations, traders said a more substantial decline, as retailers stocked up for the Labor Day holiday travel weekend, was needed to justify current high prices.
"We needed more to sustain the rally," said John Kilduff, vice president of energy risk management at the ABN Amro Chicago Corporation.
Gasoline for October delivery fell 2.63 cents, or 4.2 percent, to 59.92 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the first time the active gasoline contract has been below 60 cents a gallon since July 15. October crude oil dropped 21 cents, or 1 percent, to $19.40 a barrel.
Coffee rose for an eighth day, reaching a three-month high amid concern that dry summer weather had hurt crops in Latin America.
Coffee for December delivery rose 5.5 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $1.95 a pound on the Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York, the highest closing price for the contract since June 3.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Eases Against Mark On German Rate Comments

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The dollar fell against the mark yesterday on mixed signals from the Bundesbank over the direction of German interest rates. In late trading in New York, the dollar settled at 1.8153 marks, down from 1.8203 marks on Wednesday.
It eased a bit against the British pound, which rose to $1.5843 yesterday from $1.5841. 
 Traders were hesitant to buy dollars before today's August employment report for signs on whether the United States economy is growing fast enough to prompt the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates. While higher rates would make the dollar more attractive, they could also spur selling of stocks and bonds, dragging the dollar down with them.
In European trading yesterday, the dollar got brief help against the mark after the Bundesbank left interest rates steady. But it gave up the gains amid concern that the bank might not stand pat for long.
Its president, Hans Tietmeyer, said earlier this week that a recent rise in Germany's inflation rate was "thoroughly occupying" central bankers. Though the bank left two important interest rates unchanged yesterday, signs that the economy was accelerating prompted speculation that it might raise other rates as soon as next week.
Mr. Tietmeyer, interviewed in the magazine Die Woche, also said that a well-timed move on interest rates would help stabilize or even bring down bond yields, which he said was crucial for economic growth.
Dieter Bluhm of Wells Fargo Bank observed, "Bundesbank officials are raising a cautious finger, suggesting that because of recent economic figures, they might manipulate interest rates."
Higher German rates would presumably spur the value of the mark, which is down about 15 percent against the dollar this year, by making mark assets more attractive. They might also help fight inflation by making imports less costly. Still, higher rates could choke Germany's fragile economic recovery.
Against the Japanese yen, the dollar was slightly higher, settling in New York at 120.87 yen, up from 120.85 Wednesday. Early gains were bolstered when C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics, said that the yen could fall as low as 127 to the dollar.

HEADLINE: August Auto Sales Kept Up Strong Pace

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 4

 BODY:
For the second consecutive month, buyers flocked to car dealerships in August, giving the auto industry stronger-than-expected summer sales.
The Ford Motor Company said today that its sales in August rose 3.6 percent, helping the industry as a whole register a sales increase of 5 percent from a year earlier. On Wednesday, the General Motors Corporation reported strong sales, while other auto makers posted mixed results. 
 Wall Street analysts said that over all, August's results were among the strongest this year. Last month's auto sales "have put the second half of 1997 on a stronger pace than we saw during the first half of 1997," said David M. Garrity, an auto analyst at Smith Barney.
But the stronger sales are unlikely to lead to worries that the economy is overheating, causing higher inflation, because auto prices have been falling, analysts said. Many auto makers are offering buyers substantial rebates, and most have held prices steady or even dropped prices for their new, 1998 models.
"Mostly, there are people out there looking for deals," said Wendy Beale Needham, an auto analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin, & Jenrette.
For the industry as a whole, August sales reached a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 15.6 million. In July, the rate was even stronger, at 15.9 million, according to Commerce Department statistics. That is far higher than during the second quarter, when the annual rate averaged just 14.9 million. Perhaps heartened by the strength of the industry's sales in the last two months, Ford announced today that it would build 25,000 more cars and trucks in the third quarter than it had previously planned.
"We continue to be optimistic about the sales outlook for the remainder of this year and into next year," said Robert L. Rewey, Ford's group vice president for marketing, sales and service. "After consumers paused to catch their breath in the second quarter, they are back in the market."
Still, the strength for a number of Ford's models last month was driven by rebates and discounted lease deals. Sales increased for the Mercury Grand Marquis and Ford Crown Victoria, which carry $1,500 rebates, and for the Lincoln Town Car, which carries a rebate of up to $5,000 in some markets. But sales of Ford's mainstay family sedan, the Taurus, dropped 1.4 percent, despite the company's offers of $1,500 rebates and interest rates as low as 4.8 percent on car loans. Ford's overall car sales dropped 3.5 percent from a year earlier, but the company made up the difference and then some with strong truck sales. Ford's sales of pickup trucks, sport utility vehicles and vans rose 9.6 percent.
Many auto makers have watched their truck sales grow as their car sales have slipped. In the latest sign of car market weakness, G.M.'s Saturn division said today that for the rest of this year, it planned to stop making cars during the day shifts on Monday and Friday. The workers on those shifts will undergo additional training and perform extra maintenance tasks instead of being laid off.
Still, on Wednesday, G.M. reported a 7.5 percent gain in its sales for August. Other auto makers had mixed results. Honda's sales jumped 38.2 percent and Subaru sales rose 29 percent. All percentage calculations are based on a daily selling rate because there were 26 selling days last month, but 27 in August of 1996. The Chrysler Corporation's sales rose 0.5 percent, but Toyota dropped 4.4 percent, Nissan sales fell 12.5 percent and Mazda fell 3.3 percent.

SECTION: Section D; Page 15; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
The Economist wants readers to see it as bold, not bland.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE ECONOMIST magazine is embarking on an ambitious effort to help change a perception -- surprisingly widespread among potential readers -- that a typical issue features articles like "Monetary Policy Made Murkier," "A Yen for Yen: Favorite Foreign Currencies" and "Alan Greenspan: Legend or Icon?"
A campaign that will begin on Monday by Weiss, Whitten, Stagliano in New York, the magazine's agency since April, seeks to redefine The Economist in North America, which accounts for almost 45 percent of the magazine's circulation. The intent is to establish The Economist as an international weekly focusing on topics far broader than matters that matter only to economists, including general business, politics, science, technology and the arts. 
 That idea is underscored by the theme of the campaign, "Subscribe to a global point of view," which is infused with low-key humor. For instance, one print advertisement proclaims: "Many people find international business and politics frustrating, arbitrary and unnecessarily complicated. What an opportunity."
The budget for the campaign, which also includes TV ads and airport and transit posters, is estimated at more than $2 million. The campaign represents a departure for The Economist beyond being the magazine's initial foray onto TV to bolster North American subscriptions.
Usually, the North American ads for Economist Newspaper Ltd. -- the British company half owned by Pearson Group P.L.C. that publishes The Economist and calls itself Economist Group -- have been based on or been evocative of a popular, successful campaign in its home market. That campaign, centered on the signature red color of The Economist, was created by Abbott Mead Vickers BBDO in London, which is minority owned by Omnicom Group.
Research by Economist Group and Weiss, Whitten discovered that "there's a lack of perception in North America among people who should know and understand what The Economist is but don't," said Beth O'Rorke, chief operating officer of the Economist Newspaper North America unit of Economist Group in New York.
"People who wear blinders to avoid global business are simply not people who would enjoy reading The Economist and are not the people we're after," she added. "What we're looking for are people who ought to be subscribers, who realize The Economist is a read that is not for the faint of heart."
But the research, conducted in what ought to be fertile ground for The Economist -- professional-managerial households with annual incomes of more than $100,000 -- showed significant difficulties.
"In each of the last four years, we've done a representative benchmark study primarily on awareness and comprehension," said John Lizars, corporate marketing director at the Economist Newspaper North America. "The bottom line was that we realized we had to do a much more intensive job."
"Our comprehension scores moved only slightly," he added, and many respondents "had no awareness of us at all or thought we were a journal of economics. That left us in not an enviable position."
The Economist, founded in 1843, is of course not the only venerable magazine bearing a name that may puzzle contemporary readers. The New Yorker's purview extends well beyond New York, Harper's Bazaar covers fashion rather than fairs and Redbook is neither red nor a book.
Enter Weiss, Whitten, an agency known for stylish campaigns for premium-priced, imported products like Guerlain fragrances and Bass ale -- an appropriate shop for a British magazine with a basic subscription rate of $125 annually.
"We had no intent of compromising the magazine's editorial integrity," said Nat Whitten, partner and co-creative director at Weiss, Whitten, "or turning off its existing constituency, which is sizable." His reference was to North American circulation of 278,176 for the first six months of 1997 -- up 26.7 percent from the corresponding period five years ago -- out of estimated worldwide circulation of 630,000.
"The challenge was to maintain The Economist's reputation but be more aggressive in courting readers," Mr. Whitten said. To do that, he added, the agency chose to present The Economist as "the only news and business magazine with the kind of international coverage it has."
So "we wanted every ad for The Economist to be The Economist," Mr. Whitten said, "using visuals from the magazine and taking its tone of voice."
For example, one television commercial, titled "Wake-Up," features the magazine's logo snoring like a sleeping person until an alarm sounds. As articles from The Economist appear on screen, an announcer says: "If you've never subscribed to The Economist, perhaps you've taken the name literally. One might guess it's about money supply theory, that sort of thing. In fact, it's the only weekly international business and news magazine with global insights and opinion."
And a print ad with a photograph from The Economist of soldiers in gas masks declares: "You think international politics are ugly? You should read our science section."
The commercials will run on broadcast stations in Atlanta and Washington and on the Arts and Entertainment, Bravo, CNBC and CNN Headline News national cable networks. There will also be spots promoting underwriting of "The Lehrer News Hour" on PBS. The posters will appear in large markets like Chicago and New York.
In addition to the Weiss, Whitten campaign, Economist Group will continue a trade campaign meant to increase sales of advertising pages. That campaign is created by Mad Dogs and Englishmen in New York.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Investors Get Easier Access To Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
The Treasury announced several measures today to make it easier and less expensive for small investors to buy and sell Government securities.
Most significantly, the Treasury said that its bills, bonds and notes could now be bought simply by debiting a bank account and could be sold without going through a bank or broker. 
 In upgrading its 11-year-old system called Treasury Direct, which holds the accounts of 825,000 investors, the department said it was adding to the appeal of the Government's securities while paring costs of administration.
"It is a breakthrough," John D. Hawke Jr., Under Secretary of the Treasury for Domestic Finance, said in an interview. The new measures, which take effect immediately, "relieve some of the inconvenience and hassle in the present program" and, he said, avoid the need for those selling securities before they mature to maintain a brokerage account.
Treasury Direct customers, 85 percent of whom are individuals 55 or older, now may pay for new securities by authorizing the department to debit their bank account for the exact amount on the day the security is issued. Until now investors had to pay for their securities when ordering them several days before issue. The new system means they will not lose interest and can eliminate a trip to the bank for a certified or cashier's check.
It also means the Government will not have to provide refund checks for the many investors who must now, in advance of a sale of the securities, send in more money than proves necessary when the bidding for that issue ends.
Also, investors will now be able to sell securities in their Treasury accounts without first transferring them out -- typically by wire -- to a bank or broker. The Treasury will charge a flat $34 for each security, regardless of the amount of money involved, less than would be charged by nearly any bank or Wall Street firm.
In disposing of securities for customers, the Treasury will operate through the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, which is to obtain three market quotations, accept the highest and transfer the proceeds directly into the customer's bank account. The $34 charge covers only the Government's costs, officials said.
Although today's action may mean less commission business for banks and brokers, there was no outcry from Wall Street or banks since bond commissions are typically modest, infrequent and involve relatively high costs. Indeed, one specialist described such transactions as mostly a "nuisance" for the industry.
Still, some brokers fretted about being cut out as middlemen as sales proceeds flow directly from the Treasury to the investor's bank account. This deprives the broker of the chance to guide reinvestment of the money.
Rather than lost commissions, "I'm more concerned about the retention of assets," said Tony Burns, manager of the downtown Washington branch of Quick & Reilly, a large discount brokerage house.
He predicted that the Treasury, "by making it much more convenient, is going to bolster their business" in marketing securities. Some $83 billion is now held in Treasury Direct accounts, somewhat less than the level a year ago.
A third element in today's package allows Treasury Direct customers to reinvest maturing securities by telephone at any hour of the day or night.
After receiving a notice in the mail, investors need only dial 1-800-943-6864 and follow the step-by-step instructions.
The Treasury hopes to make Treasury Direct nearly all electronic during 1998. Mr. Hawke said the plan was to provide forms on the Internet to conduct transactions. By the end of this year, he added, the savings bond program is also to be largely electronic.
The Government is also replacing the six different forms used to buy various securities with a single tender form.
Investors can get more information about the Treasury Direct program from the Bureau of the Public Debt site on the World Wide Web: www.publicdebt.treas.gov.

Bonds Mark Time
 (By Dow Jones) -- Treasury prices traded in a narrow range yesterday as investors were content to play a waiting game ahead of the report today on unemployment in August.
The price of the 30-year bond fell slightly, ending the day at 97 1/32 , down 3/32 , leaving the yield at 6.60, unchanged from Wednesday.
Though there was an array of economic reports yesterday, from August chain-store sales and July factory orders to weekly jobless claims, they did not prompt much of a response from the market.

HEADLINE: H & R Block Shares Up on Report of Compuserve Sale Talks

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
Shares of H & R Block and Compuserve rose yesterday following a report that the New York-based investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe was in talks to buy a majority stake in Compuserve, Block's faltering on-line service.
Block shares rose 68.75 cents, to $40.75, while Compuserve gained 25 cents, to $12.875. The Wall Street Journal reported yesterday that Block and Welsh Carson were close to a deal in which Welsh Carson would purchase a controlling stake from Block and seek to acquire the 20 percent of Compuserve that is publicly traded. Block would retain a minority stake. Since selling 20 percent of its shares to the public in April 1996, Compuserve's stock price has fallen nearly 60 percent. 
 Officials at both Block and Welsh Carson declined to comment on the report. But two of Welsh Carson's general partners, Anthony DeNicola and Thomas McInerney, were in meetings with Block executives yesterday, Block employees said.
Welsh Carson, a leveraged buyout firm that has acquired several electronic information companies in recent years, could use Compuserve to augment its presence in that arena, or it could divide the company up and sell off its parts.
" I see Compuserve as a real distressed property, so if you're bottom-feeding it might make sense to pick it up," said Adam Schoenfeld, a senior analyst for Jupiter Communications Inc. in New York. "It was a cash cow for H & R Block for a long time, but they didn't look forward and now it's fallen by the wayside. It's kind of sad."
Block, the tax-preparation company, has been trying to rid itself of Compuserve, the nation's oldest on-line service, since last September, when it was forced to cancel plans to spin off its remaining 80 percent of the service because of financial losses and fading interest on Wall Street in proprietary on-line services as the Internet gained popularity.
America Online, a relative newcomer to the on-line service market that has far outstripped the venerable Compuserve in recent years emerged as an early prospective buyer, but Block reportedly turned down the bid because it involved too much stock.
The company declined to comment on reports that Bertelsmann A.G., the German media giant, had joined America Online in making a more cash-rich offer earlier this summer. Another suitor is said to be Worldcom Inc., a telecommunications company.
When Block bought Compuserve in 1980 and started an early incarnation of the current service it quickly became the only choice for businesses, professionals and early high-tech aficionados experimenting in the new world of on-line information.
But by the early 1990's, when America Online came along with its easy, friendly design and the graphical World Wide Web suddenly drew on-line users' interest, the explosion in the consumer market passed Compuserve by. The service has lost nearly half a million United States subscribers since last summer, bringing its total subscriber base to about three million, compared with America Online's nine million subscribers worldwide.
Indeed, one of the company's most valuable assets now is its subscriber lists -- which could be sold or folded into a buyer's own subscriber base. Its network services division, which provides Internet access and private networks to businesses, is also very healthy, and could be spun off at a premium, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Factory Orders Rose in July; Analysts Had Expected Drop

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Orders placed with factories unexpectedly increased in July to a record level, a sign that manufacturing could be poised for faster growth.
The Commerce Department said today that factory orders rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July, to a record seasonally adjusted $330.28 billion, after a revised gain of 1.7 percent in June. Analysts had expected the July report to show a decline of one-tenth of 1 percent. 
 In a separate report, the Labor Department said the number of workers filing for unemployment benefits rose by 2,000 in the week ended last Saturday, to a seasonally adjusted 326,000. The increase was close to analysts' expectations.
Stronger demand for vehicles and parts, metals, food, textiles and plastics led July's gain in orders. Orders for aircraft, electronics and communications gear declined.
Factory inventories increased half a percent in July after having risen three-tenths of 1 percent in June. Analysts have warned that a buildup in inventories could lead to slower factory orders as companies attempt to empty their warehouses and stores of merchandise.
In the months ahead, strength in manufacturing will come from auto makers, said Kevin Flanagan, an economist at Dean Witter Securities in New York. They will be stepping up output because strikes hampered production of cars and trucks earlier this year, he said. The Ford Motor Company and the General Motors Corporation this week reported vehicle sales for August that were stronger than expected.
Aerospace, too, will be a source of strength. This week, the Boeing Company announced it had won a $4.5 billion order to build 61 jetliners for the aviation-leasing arm of the American International Group. Additionally, consumer spending remains healthy, with major retail chains reporting today that August sales met or topped expectations.
Many economists caution that it is difficult to discern trends from month-to-month shifts in factory orders, which are heavily influenced by large changes in orders for commercial jetliners and military weapons.
Excluding aircraft and other transportation equipment, factory orders rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in July. Excluding the military industry, orders increased three-tenths of 1 percent.
Orders for durable goods, which are made to last three or more years, fell three-tenths of 1 percent in July. In an advance report on Aug. 26, the Commerce Department said durable goods orders unexpectedly declined six-tenths of 1 percent in July.
Orders for nondurable goods, including food and clothing, increased nine-tenths of 1 percent.
Factory shipments, a gauge of current demand, rose 1.4 percent during July. Unfilled factory orders, a measure of pent-up demand, decreased half a percent.
The jobless claims data for last week were distorted by the effects of retooling of auto assembly lines and by the strike against United Parcel Service, David Shabelman, an economist at MMS International in Belmont, Calif., said.
The four-week average for new jobless claims, a less volatile measure of employment conditions, rose to 326,500 in the latest week from 321,000 in the previous week.
