HEADLINE: Once Again in Arizona, Secretary of State Is Suddenly Thrust Into the Job of Governor

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM 

DATELINE: PHOENIX, Sept. 4

 BODY:
She is a fiscally conservative former schoolteacher with a broad streak of social moderation. She is a veteran legislator and the first woman to be Speaker of the Arizona House of Representatives. And for most of the last year, she has been quietly waiting for the day she might suddenly become Arizona's 20th governor.
For Jane Dee Hull, the Arizona Secretary of State, that day is Friday, when she will take the reins from Gov. Fife Symington, who was forced to resign on Wednesday after being convicted on Federal charges of defrauding his lenders as a commercial real estate developer. It is the second time in less than a decade that a woman in Ms. Hull's shoes has assumed the top job in a state that has no lieutenant governor. In 1988, Secretary of State Rose Mofford became the state's first female governor when she took over after the impeachment and ouster of Gov. Evan Mecham on charges of campaign finance irregularities. 
 Unlike Ms. Mofford, a 50-year state employee who took a caretaker approach and decided not to run for election in her own right, Ms. Hull, a 62-year-old Republican who moved to Arizona in 1962 after hearing a Barry Goldwater speech, is expected to plunge into what promises to be a rollicking campaign next year. It will decide who wins the right to run this prosperous, fast-growing state and redeem an image darkened by a legislative corruption scandal in the early 1990's and the five-year investigation into Mr. Symington's finances.
"It's a tough moment, no matter what, when your Governor's convicted on felony counts," said Lisa Graham Keegan, the state Superintendent of Public Instruction and a longtime Hull ally. "What Jane brings to that for the moment is a whole lot of class."
Since Mr. Symington was indicted last year, friends say, Ms. Hull has been determined to do all she can to be ready to take over if needed, without seeming to hover or gloat. Even today, she chose not to hold a news conference or make a public appearance, instead meeting privately with Mr. Symington about transition matters and giving individual interviews to local reporters. Her spokesman, Chris Herstam, declined an interview request from The New York Times.
In an interview today with KTVK-TV here, Ms. Hull said of her situation: "It's difficult, but you know you find yourself having been in that saddle for 15 years as a legislator, you find yourself thinking, 'Well, the issues haven't changed that much, they've gotten a little more complicated.' And it all comes back."
Ms. Hull will automatically assume the powers of office when Mr. Symington's resignation takes effect at 5 P.M. Friday, but she will not be officially sworn in until a public ceremony on Monday. She becomes the third female governor in the nation, joining Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey and Jeanne Shaheen of New Hampshire.
As Secretary of State for the past two years, Ms. Hull has overseen a largely ministerial office, responsible for running the state election system, keeping campaign finance and business records. But first as a state legislator and then as House Speaker, she established a take-charge reputation, heading committees on government operations, economic development and ethics.
"She had a reputation of being someone who was firm, and as someone who did a reasonable job of keeping factions generally moving in the same direction," said Sam Coppersmith, a former Congressman who until January headed the Arizona Democratic Party.
Nor did Ms. Hull hesitate to differ with Mr. Symington, a fellow Republican, when she saw fit.
"She's not afraid to differ with anybody," Ms. Keegan said. "And she does her own business. She doesn't send messengers to tell you she's upset with you. She comes and does it herself."
At the same time, Ms. Hull is widely expected to be more consensus-oriented than Mr. Symington, who brought a brusque businessman's style to the governorship. She was first elected to the Legislature in 1979 with a reputation as one of its most conservative members, and once suggested the state could save money and reduce its inmate population by letting air conditioners at a desert prison break down. But in recent years, she has taken increasingly moderate stands on social issues like education, juvenile justice and abortion rights.
"She's fiscally conservative and she will follow along in the direction Fife went: cutting taxes, trying to cut back the size of government," said Bruce Merrill, director of the Media Research Center at Arizona State University in Tempe and an informal Hull adviser since Ms. Hull took one of his graduate courses two decades ago. "Where there is a very clear difference, and where she is much more moderate, is on the social issues."
Ms. Hull is already facing sniping from her right flank.
State Senator Thomas Patterson of Phoenix and Tom Rawls, a former Maricopa County Supervisor, are expected to challenge Ms. Hull in the Republican primary next year.
Two of Mr. Symington's Democratic adversaries, Eddie Basha, a supermarket chain owner, and Paul Johnson, a former Phoenix Mayor, are expected to compete for the Democratic nomination.
Mr. Basha, who campaigned as a "chubby grocer," won the Democratic nomination for governor in 1994 and was leading Mr. Symington in the polls until just before the election, when he said he would be willing to sign legislation legalizing same-sex marriages.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Malaysia, in Crisis, Will Delay Projects

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, Sept. 4

 BODY:
Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said today that Malaysia would have to delay several big projects, including the 13.6 billion ringgit ($4.55 billion) Bakun hydro-electric project, because of its currency problems, the official news agency Bernama reported here.
Dr. Mahathir indicated that other projects might also be delayed: a northern regional airport in Kedah, the Linear City in Kuala Lumpur, and a road linking three highlands in the central range of the peninsula. 
 The Prime Minister also said that efforts would continue to cut costs by scaling down imports of goods that are already available in the country.
Dr. Mahathir said the Bakun project might cost at least 20 percent more if the Malaysian currency, the ringgit, stayed at its current low levels -- settling in New York today at 2.9830 to the dollar, a further loss from 2.9353 late Wednesday.
The Prime Minister conceded that "obviously, we can't build this dam without using some foreign imports." He said, however, that the Bakun project could not be scrapped, as more than 100 million ringgit had been spent to build diversion tunnels.
Shares of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, the Swiss-Swedish engineering company, fell today amid reports that its contract to build the Bakun dam was in jeopardy. The company's American depository receipts fell $6.125 to close at $143.50 in Nasdaq trading.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Financing Is Ready for 3 Mixed-Income Buildings

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
With the New York State Housing Finance Agency given the green light last month by the State Legislature to sell $350 million more in tax-exempt bonds, financing is in place for three mixed-income rental projects in Manhattan to move forward under New York City's 80-20 program.
Under this program, developers use the proceeds from the sale of the bonds to construct buildings in which 80 percent of the units are rented at market rates and 20 percent at reduced rates to tenants whose income is less than half the median income for New York City. 
 The buildings are also eligible for a 20-year city tax abatement.
The state finance agency approved two of the projects last month. One, a 42-story building with 340 units, is to be developed by the Rockrose Development Corporation of Manhattan using $70 million in bond financing on a site fronting the Hudson River in Battery Park City. The other, with up to 466 apartments in a 30-story structure, will be built by the Glenwood Management Corporation of New Hyde Park, N.Y. using $119 million in bond financing on a vacant site at 240 East 39th Street between Second and Third Avenues.
The third development, which the agency approved yesterday, will have 396 apartments in a 27-story building. It will be developed using $85 million in bond financing by the Related Companies of Manhattan on another riverfront parcel in Battery Park City.
While rents for the market-rate units at each of the projects have not been determined, those for the apartments reserved for low-income tenants will be capped at 30 percent of their income.
The developers say the program's incentives -- a lower interest rate than the rate on a conventional loan and a 20-year property tax reduction -- make rental projects feasible in Manhattan, where land and construction costs are high.
Stephen J. Hunt, president and chief executive officer of the state finance agency, said increased demand from developers in the 80-20 program prompted the agency to ask the Legislature for the additional bonding authority.
He said that the agency was currently reviewing applications from developers for loans totaling $900 million for projects throughout the state, most of which are 80-20 developments in Manhattan. That loan figure is up from $150 million in 1995.
Mr. Hunt said his agency expected to help finance eight affordable-rent projects in the state this year using about $450 million in loans. Five are 80-20 buildings in Manhattan, with a total of 2,000 units, which include the two Battery Park City projects and the one at 240 East 39th Street.
The other two Manhattan projects, which received state financing earlier, are a 240-unit building being developed by the Related Companies on the block bounded by 13th and 14th Streets, Fourth Avenue and Broadway, and a 550-unit building at 250 West 50th Street being developed by Jack Resnick & Sons of Manhattan.
Once a project is approved for inclusion in the 80-20 program the state, or city, sells the bonds to provide permanent financing to the builders, typically at rates that, because the bonds are tax exempt, are lower than would be obtained through other financing sources.
While the production of apartments in the city is creeping up, the 3,000 to 4,000 units, most of them rentals, being developed annually are much lower than the 10,000 a year level achieved in the late 1980's, said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental brokerage in Manhattan. Rents continue to rise, indicating demand still outpaces supply, Ms. Packes said.
"Given the current economy and the strength of the sales market, the amount of new rentals planned will not significantly lower rental prices," she said.
Average monthly rents on the Upper East and West Sides, for example, range from $1,300 for a studio to $3,000 for a two-bedroom apartment, she said.
Work on the Rockrose project at 401 Chambers Street in Battery Park City started this week. Called Tribeca Landing, it will be built over the next 14 months and have studio to three-bedroom units, with 550 to 1,323 square feet of space, said Kevin P. Singleton, vice president and general manager at Rockrose.
"Notwithstanding the number of rentals planned, there is a dearth of product and a constant demand," Mr. Singleton said.
David J. Wine, president of the Related Companies' management arm, Related Management Company, added, "The market is still strong enough to absorb the new supply."
He said his company expected to start construction on its Battery Park City project, Tribeca Park, by next month, with completion 18 months later. It will have studio to two-bedroom apartments, with 550 to 1,250 square feet of space. Hypo Bank and Marine Midland Bank are providing the letter of credit for the project.
At the Saxony, Glenwood Management's East 39th Street project, plans, which are still being made final, call for 466 one- and two-bedroom units in a 30-story building, said Gary Jacob, Glenwood's executive vice president. The apartments are expected to range in size from 600 to 1,400 square feet.
Mr. Jacob said construction would start when his company closed on the financing, which was expected by early next year. The project, which has secured a letter of credit from a bank Mr. Jacob would not identify, will take 18 months to complete.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Strong Results for Stores, Auto Makers And Factories
Growth continued at a robust rate this summer, a number of reports hinted. Strength was seen at several levels in the economy -- at retailers, among auto makers and in orders placed with factories.
Consumers stocking up on lunch boxes, jeans and other back-to-school goods helped bolster stores' results in August, lifting the Goldman, Sachs retail index 5.7 percent. [Page D2.] 

Ford Motor said that its sales in August rose 3.6 percent, helping the industry as a whole register an increase of 5 percent. [D2.]
 
Factory orders unexpectedly increased by two-tenths of 1 percent in July, to a record level, a sign that manufacturing could be poised for faster growth. [D2.]
 
Calenergy to Buy Back Stake
Calenergy, the big power generation company, said that it would pay $1.15 billion to buy out a big shareholder, Peter Kiewit Sons, which has a 30 percent stake in Calenergy and minority interests in its power plant projects. [D4.]
 
Blue Chips Off as Small Stocks Gain
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 27.40 points, to 7,867.24, but most other stock indexes rose. The Nasdaq composite index ended within a few points of its record, while the Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies edged up to a new high. [D4.]
 
The shares of two chip makers headed in opposite directions. After warning that it expected to report a quarterly loss, Advanced Micro Devices saw its stock fall more than 9 percent. But the shares of another chip maker, National Semiconductor, jumped by that percentage after it reported earnings that exceeded estimates. Market Place. [D4.]
 
NBC Appoints a Cable Executive
NBC named a former Turner cable television executive, Scott Sassa, president of its station division, giving him control of the stations that the network owns. [D2.]
 
Hamill Out at Daily News
Mortimer B. Zuckerman, the owner of The Daily News of New York, said that Pete Hamill's tenure as the paper's editor in chief was over, making Mr. Hamill the third editor in less than five years to leave or be removed from that post. [B1.]
 
Saks President to Join Burberrys
The president of Saks Fifth Avenue, Rose Marie Bravo, resigned to become chief executive of Burberrys Worldwide, the British maker of apparel and luxury items. [D2.]

Making It Easier to Buy Treasuries
The Treasury announced measures to make it easier and less costly for small investors to buy and sell Government securities. [D15.]
 
Report Lifts Compuserve and Block
Shares of H & R Block and Compuserve rose after a report that the New York-based investment firm Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe was in talks to buy a majority stake in Compuserve, the faltering on-line service that is controlled by Block. [D4.]
 
Malaysia to Delay Projects
Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahathir Mohamad, said that his nation would have to delay several big public works projects because of the plunge in the currency. [D3.]
 
Deal Reached on Dodgers' Sale
As expected, Rupert Murdoch's Fox Group has reached an agreement to buy the Los Angeles Dodgers from Peter O'Malley. A price was not disclosed, but the O'Malley family business, which includes the team, has been expected to sell for about $350 million. [B7.]

HEADLINE: Panel Upholds Giuliani Offer On Police Pay

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY 

 BODY:
An arbitration panel announced yesterday that it was upholding Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's wage offer to the New York City police union, all but ending an unusually vitriolic dispute that had been fought from precinct station houses to the State Capitol.
The panel said the Mayor had presented a reasonable proposal to the powerful union, the 29,000-member Patrolmen's Benevolent Association, when he offered a salary increase of 13.3 percent over five years, roughly the same raise that unions representing other municipal workers have received. 
 The panel chastised the police union for seeking more money than other municipal workers had got, which the union said it deserved because its members were responsible for the sharp drop in crime in the city recently. It said that granting such a request would throw labor relations into turmoil because other unions would then contend that they should garner similar increases.
"It would create chaos," the panel wrote in its ruling. "Whipsawing efforts by every municipal union undoubtedly would follow. This would severely damage the city's financial stability."
The police union said it might appeal the ruling, which was handed down by a three-person panel appointed by the city's Office of Collective Bargaining, though labor experts said such appeals were difficult to win. If the union does not file an appeal, which it has up to a month to do, the new contract will go into effect immediately, retroactive to 1995, when the last contract expired.
The union president, Lou Matarazzo, said he would consult with senior union officials about whether to set up picket lines in front of police station houses, raising the possibility that officers might be demonstrating against the Mayor at the height of his re-election campaign.
The union mounted similar protests last January after it formally rejected the Mayor's last offer and the impasse went to arbitration.
During those protests, officers carried signs that said, "No zeroes for heroes," a reference to a wage freeze in the first two years of the contract.
Mr. Matarazzo also vowed to retaliate with one of the union's most effective weapons, the State Legislature.
The union wields strong influence in Albany, and in recent years the Legislature has repeatedly come to its aid by approving bills that change contract and workplace regulations in the union's favor -- usually over the objections of Mr. Giuliani and his predecessors.
The current conflict has lasted more than two years, in part because the union sought state legislation that would have moved arbitration proceedings from the city agency to a state one that the union believes would treat it more favorably. The Legislature approved the bill over Gov. George E. Pataki's veto, but the Mayor successfully challenged it in court.
Union officials said yesterday that any state legislation they obtained would probably not affect the basic terms of the new contract, but they said they would ask the Legislature for help in negotiating the next contract. They said they would submit new legislation to move arbitration proceedings to the state panel.
"I am extremely disappointed that we couldn't get a fair shake from the arbitrators," Mr. Matarazzo said. "We are now going to take it up to Albany."
Mr. Giuliani hailed the ruling by the arbitration panel, saying he hoped that it would convince rank-and-file officers that he was being fair. "This decision makes clear that the offer that the city made to them is a very generous one," he said.
But many officers said they were still upset with the Mayor, in what is perhaps one of the more unexpected hallmarks of his tenure: a chief executive who has prided himself on his success as a crime fighter is unpopular with many members of his police force.
Some officers also expressed anger toward the union, which has weathered a number of blows in the last year, including the indictment of its chief lawyer.
"I'm totally disgusted," said Officer Vincent Martinelli, a union delegate in the 108th Precinct in Queens. "I felt that the P.B.A. should have taken a hard line, an aggressive stance against Mayor Giuliani and the arbitration panel. We're working harder than we ever have and we've lowered the crime rate drastically. We deserve more. I feel we should have played hardball."
Officer Martinelli, who worked phone banks for the Mayor's 1993 campaign, added, "We were stabbed in the back by the Mayor."
Mr. Giuliani said police officers should blame the union leadership for employing a failed strategy for wresting more money from the city.
"I really feel very bad for them," he said, "because I think that they were not well served in the way in which this whole thing was handled by their leadership."
In the new contract, the Mayor had offered the union a five-year package that follows the pattern of the deals he negotiated with the other municipal unions: the two-year wage freeze, followed by annual increases of 3 percent, 3 percent and 6 percent. When the increases are compounded, the total raise under the package approved by the arbitration panel is 13.3 percent in salary alone, or 15.3 percent when all other benefits are included, officials said.
By the end of the old contract, an officer with 10 years' experience was receiving $50,400 in salary and other cash benefits, said James F. Hanley, the city's Labor Commissioner. By the end of the new contract, that officer will be earning $57,584, an increase of $7,184, or 14.25 percent, slightly more than the 13.3 percent because other cash benefits are included.
The P.B.A. had originally refused to accept the two-year wage freeze. Its leadership later relented, but said that in addition to the 13.3 percent, it wanted what it referred to as productivity bonuses of at least a few thousand dollars for each officer.
"They fail to recognize the type of work that our people do," Mr. Matarazzo, the union president, said yesterday after the panel rejected the productivity demand.
The Office of Collective Bargaining is independent and is governed by a board on which both unions and the city have representation.
Mr. Hanley and Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine advised Mr. Giuliani in his dealings with the police union. The three men said the ruling showed the wisdom of the labor strategy that the Mayor put in place in 1995, when he sought the two-year wage freeze, which was intended to help the city cope with a large budget gap.
Mr. Giuliani said that the panel agreed with his view that the unions could not seek big increases from the city by comparing their wages with those in nearby suburbs, where the salaries are typically higher.
He said the panel had demonstrated that police officers historically received raises that outpaced inflation.
"From the point of view of the fiscal integrity of the city and the ability of the city to deal with all of the unions," Mr. Giuliani said, "it is a vindication of the city's position."

HEADLINE: Raw Recruits Survive Lunchroom Wars as Aides Replace Teachers

BYLINE: By JACQUES STEINBERG 

 BODY:
Like rookie police officers setting off on their new beats, Irene Cuebas and Margarita Delgado rushed into the lunchroom at Public School 306 in Brooklyn at 10:40 yesterday morning.
Ms. Delgado headed for an accident scene: a kindergartner had dropped her plastic tray and dumped pizza and green beans onto her chair. Ms. Cuebas ran for the lunch line, where some of the school's 1,100 children were opening and spilling their milk cartons long before getting to their seats. 
 It was the first of four lunch periods on opening day at the city's 660 elementary schools, and Ms. Cuebas and Ms. Delgado are among the hundreds of new school aides assigned to supervise cafeterias and playgrounds this year. The task had been performed by teachers, but effective this fall City Hall relieved them of that duty under the new teachers' contract.
Though Ms. Cuebas and Ms. Delgado had received only a few hours of training for their new jobs and were replacing four teachers, the school in East New York, Brooklyn, fared better in some ways than many others yesterday: some principals reported that their aides did not show up at all, and if they did, they had no idea what to do.
If there was one change that principals were dreading over the summer, it was the replacement of the teachers with more than 1,000 inexperienced aides, most of them parents and few of them high school graduates. The change was intended to free teachers to spend more time tutoring children in small groups, but the school system spent little time planning how to replace them.
At Intermediate School 145 in Jackson Heights, Queens, only one of six newly-hired aides showed up for work yesterday for the second day in a row, said the principal, Perry Sandler. Mr. Sandler said he hired a second aide 15 minutes before lunch by calling the district office and recruiting someone off a waiting list. He then shifted two security guards from lobby duty to the lunchroom, along with an office aide, a physical education teacher, a home economics teacher and a volunteer.
A spokeswoman for the Council of Supervisors and Administrators, the union representing principals, said that the Board of Education had agreed yesterday to conduct a survey of the schools to determine whether the $70 million spent on new aides had been sufficient.
But the spokeswoman, Bonnie Impagliazzo, said that the overall picture yesterday had been much cheerier than on Wednesday, when the city's middle and high schools had opened for the year.
At P.S. 306, the school principal, Arthella Addei, had four aides returning from last year, as well as the two new aides for the cafeteria and two playgrounds. She said she still needed at least two more aides than she had received from the district office. That left her no choice but to assign both an assistant from her office and the coordinator of special education to pick up the slack.
Yesterday morning, the special education official called to say he had been hospitalized, so Mrs. Addei took over the cafeteria herself.
"With the little ones, teach them to open the milk themselves," Mrs. Addei yelled to Ms. Cuebas, a 57-year-old grandmother, as the chaos of the lunchroom swirled around them. "Don't just do it for them. I want them to learn."
To Mrs. Addei, the lunchroom is as much a teaching environment as the classroom. And Ms. Delgado, a 33-year-old mother of two who also works as a cashier at a Waldbaum's supermarket, seemed to take the instruction to heart yesterday, when she spied a 7-year-old boy curled up underneath a long white table.
As she brought the boy to his feet, he startled her by asking, "What would you do if you didn't have a father?"
After a short pause, Ms. Delgado responded: "I'd try to concentrate on my mother or my sisters. Do you have any sisters?"
"No," said the boy, adding that his father had left his mother three weeks ago.
"Then you've got to concentrate on who you are," she said, "and what you want out of life."
For the two new aides, the action was continuous. At one point, Ms. Delgado took a green windbreaker from a little boy as he tried to hold it and his tray in both hands while walking with his shoes untied.
The only problem was, when she tried to return it, she couldn't remember what he looked like.
But there was also the proud moment when she singlehandedly led 12 small students down the hallway, holding the hands of four in each of her own as if they were a bouquet of balloons.
"So far, so good," she said as the day wound down.

HEADLINE: The Aging of Japan May Aid Economy

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A Sept. 2 Business Day article ably describes the challenge Japan faces in supporting its rapidly aging population, but it is less convincing when predicting possible solutions. Among the likeliest scenarios, you suggest much higher taxes and the dwindling of family savings. 
 Far more likely, the Government will chip away at social security. Japanese families not only will bear more of the burden of caring for aged relatives, but they also will choose to lower their living standards rather than deplete their savings.
Japan is not unique in facing the problem of an aging society. But it is distinctive in having dampened expectations of social programs for the elderly even before many received such benefits and before they developed a sense of entitlement. In a brilliant public relations campaign over the past two decades, officials and the cooperative media have trotted out the specter of Japan's "aging society crisis," cautioning families not to rely on the Government.
As a result, some 55 percent of Japanese aged 65 and older still live with their children -- a percentage that may rise as Government cuts back. And the household saving rate has hovered around an impressive 13 percent since 1989. Japan's future is hardly a bright one for families, but its economy may benefit as costs of entitlements are contained to a degree politically impossible in Western nations.
 
SHELDON GARON
Princeton, N.J., Sept. 2, 1997
 
The writer is a professor of history at Princeton University.

HEADLINE: TELEVISION REVIEW;
A Big Case With Racial Overtones. Familiar?

BYLINE: By CARYN JAMES 

 BODY:
The political types in the Showtime film "Color of Justice" include a show-no-mercy Manhattan district attorney, a bleeding-heart civil rights lawyer and a black minister savvy in the ways of media manipulation. This story of a white woman from suburban New Jersey who dies after an encounter with four young black men in a stolen car hits every hot-button issue from police brutality and racial bigotry to Constitutional rights.
All of this would be too broad-stroked to be taken seriously, if it weren't also eerily and freshly familiar. The Abner Louima case, in which New York City police officers are charged with torturing a Haitian man in their custody, inadvertently adds a news element to the film, which was finished long before the Louima incident occurred. That accident of timing only makes "Color of Justice" seem more prescient. Its shrewd central theme depicts how quickly a crime, especially one with racial overtones, becomes political fodder. 
 "Color of Justice" is weak as drama. It is too bluntly provocative and full of bad dialogue in which characters announce their motives. Yet the film is so timely and probing that it becomes fascinating despite those major flaws.
When Betty Gainer (Lisa Pelikan) is forced to stop behind the stalled stolen car, she sees four black men approach her car, and she pulls out her mace. In the struggle that follows, she is thrown to the ground and killed, and the stage is set for a political media event.
F. Murray Abraham is the Manhattan District Attorney, ever mindful of his law-and-order image, who insists on trying the youths as adults. Because the crime took place on the George Washington Bridge, a liberal New Jersey district attorney tries to claim the case for his own political reasons, and eventually the female United States Attorney General gets into the act, too.
But this is essentially a New York story. Judd Hirsch plays the court-appointed lawyer for the young men; he believes the arresting officers denied his clients their rights. Gregory Hines plays the minister who believes their racial background and social disadvantages are to blame; his self-proclaimed motto is, "I'm on television, therefore I am." (The characters may not correspond in every detail to real people, but viewers are given everything but a secret decoder ring to prod them to think of names like Giuliani and Sharpton when watching the D.A. and the minister.) As the victim's angry husband, Bruce Davison carries the weakest part of the film.
In its hit-or-miss way, "Color of Justice" eventually makes a strong comment on how racial politics thrives, and how little room that allows for subtle moral distinctions.
 
COLOR OF JUSTICE
Showtime, tomorrow night at 8
 Written and produced by Lionel Chetwynd; directed by Jeremy Kagan; Iris Dugow, executive producer; Preston Fischer, co-executive producer; edited by Michael Economou.
 WITH: Bruce Davison (Frank Gainer), F. Murray Abraham (Jim Sullivan), Gregory Hines (Reverend Walton), Judd Hirsch (Sam Lind), Saul Rubinek (Norm), Dule Hill (Kameel), Eugene Byrd (Kenny), Mark Taylor (Rodney), Malcolm Goodwin (Shawn), Gloria Carlin (Jill), Lisa Pelikan (Betty Gainer), Mia Korf (Linda Chang), Jackie Richardson (Judge Winslow), Paul Butler (Stan) and Sandra Caldwell (Kameel's mother).

'First-Time Felon'
HBO, tonight at 9
 The fact-based "First-Time Felon" offers a more restrained take on race and crime, and offers a richly realistic texture. It is the story of Greg Yance, a young black drug dealer from Chicago, who instead of prison opts for an experimental boot camp meant to reform first-time convicts. He helps flood victims in rural Illinois, and after his release decides to go straight, but nearly despairs when no one will give him a job.
Omar Epps, who plays Yance, is a strong screen presence (familiar as the medical student who committed suicide last season on "E.R."). And the actor Charles S. Dutton, directing his first film, creates some powerfully grim scenes. When Yance walks into a sleazy hotel, and when he first goes to jail, the hazy, disorienting feeling reflects his chaotic life. But "First-Time Felon" has more trouble with its uplifting scenes. Because the film never convincingly takes viewers inside Yance's mind, his character's positive turns seem murky, and this true story of heroic struggle carries the pat feel of a made-for-television melodrama.

INTERNATIONAL 3-10
 
Israelis Mourn in Jerusalem But 11 More Die in Lebanon
Thousands of Israelis converged in Jerusalem to mourn their four compatriots killed by a triple suicide bombing, and to show their resolve against terrorism. Their anguish was deepened by news that at least 11 commandos on a raid in southern Lebanon had been killed. 1 

The naval commandos who died in Lebanon were part of a small but legendary Israeli unit trained for covert missions behind enemy lines. Flotilla 13 accepts only soldiers who seek danger and hardship. 8
 
Emotional Queen Praises Diana
Speaking "from the heart," Queen Elizabeth praised Diana, Princess of Wales, in a personal address of a kind rarely seen in her 45 years as monarch. 1
 
Diana's mother and sisters have filed a civil suit in Paris that would allow them to seek damages based on the results of a trial to determine the cause of the car crash that killed the Princess and her companion, Emad Mohamed al-Fayed. A trial could potentially rule against photographers who pursued Diana's car, or against the Ritz Hotel, owned by the al-Fayed family, for providing a driver alleged to be drunk. 7
 
Defection in Japan's Parliament
A legislator from Japan's New Frontier party defected to the Liberal Democratic Party, giving the Liberal Democrats a controlling majority in Japan's 500-seat lower house of Parliament for the first time since 1993, when the long-dominant party was humiliated at the polls. 10
 
Bombs on Cuban Anniversary
Four bombs went off in Havana, one in a tourist restaurant and three at seafront hotels. The Cuban Foreign Ministry said the attacks were part of a campaign of terrorism organized by "ex-Batistas in the city of Miami." The bombings took place on the anniversary of a 1933 coup d'etat led by the dictator Fulgencio Batista, whom Fidel Castro overthrew in 1959. A State Department spokesman said the United States had no idea who was behind the bombings but would punish Americans responsible if evidence emerged. 4
 
Mir Space Walk Begins
Two astronauts, one Russian and one American, donned spacesuits and ambled out of the beleaguered Mir space station on a complex and potentially hazardous space walk. They hope to find the hole created in the Mir by a collision with a cargo craft in June. The walk was scheduled to last six hours, during which time Mir will circle the Earth four times. 3
 
Candidates Die in Algeria
Four candidates from the conservative Party for Algerian Renewal were assassinated by Islamic militants in eastern Algeria, the party said, without giving much more detail. Thousands have died in five years of civil war in the North African nation, but this was the first attack against candidates running for municipal elections scheduled for Oct. 23. (Agence France-Presse)
 
NATIONAL 11-13
 
Reno Said to Consider Prosecutor for Inquiry
Attorney General Janet Reno and her inner circle have sharply changed their attitude and are seriously weighing whether to refer the inquiry into campaign fund-raising abuses to an independent prosecutor, law-enforcement officials said. The change follows news reports that some money raised by Vice President Al Gore in telephone calls from the White House were improperly funneled directly into President Clinton's campaign instead of to legal party-building activities. 1
 
Ford Faces Safety Lawsuit
Ford Motor withheld information from Federal regulators about an engineering defect that can cause its cars and light trucks to stall at high speeds, documents filed in a lawsuit suggest. The suit seeks the recall of at least two million vehicles produced between 1983 and 1995 and the replacement of a circuit. It also asks for damages that could run to more than $2 billion under California law, even if no punitive penalties are assessed. 11
 
Iraq Panel Criticizes Pentagon
A special White House panel said the Pentagon had lost so much credibility in its investigation of the release of Iraqi chemical weapons in the 1991 Persian Gulf war that oversight of the investigation must be taken away from the Defense Department. In its final public hearing after a two-year inquiry, the panel called on the White House or the National Security Council to draw up plans to transfer oversight to an agency other than the Defense Department -- possibly one with subpoena power, some panel members suggested. 11
 
Ramsey Evidence Reported
A broken piece of paintbrush found in Patsy Ramsey's art supplies matches the wooden section used to strangle her daughter, JonBenet Ramsey, two Denver newspapers reported. JonBenet, 6, was strangled with a garrote -- a stick with a cord attached, at her home in Boulder, Colo., according to the coroner's report. 13
 
Questions on Bail Deaths
The five men who broke into a Phoenix home and shot a couple to death, allegedly in search of a bail jumper, are all in custody, charged with second-degree murder. But the police said the case is becoming more complicated than first reported. One man is not only a convicted felon, but also a longtime police informer, and the authorities say the suspects may have simply been using bail documents to commit a home invasion. 11
 
Small Role Seen for Thalidomide
Thalidomide, the drug that was banned worldwide in the 1960's after it produced thousands of babies with missing and stunted limbs, took a step toward Government approval when a committee of scientific advisors recommended that the Food and Drug Administration make it available to leprosy patients, but with tight restrictions. 13
 
NEW YORK/REGION 25-29
 
Private Group to Manage Central Park for City
The Giuliani Administration has decided to turn the management of Central Park over to a private group, though they are in effect formalizing a relationship that has been growing steadily for 17 years. The Central Park Conservancy, a nonprofit organization with a prestigious board of corporate and civic leaders, will receive a 10-year contract to continue the work they have been doing: maintaining and restoring the park. 25
 
Partnership to Build Tower
The Rudin Organization, one of the oldest real estate families in New York, and Reuters are forming a joint venture to build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square for the British media company. 26
 
SPORTS 32-37
 
Athens Regains Olympics
The Olympics returned to the country of their ancient beginnings and the city of their modern revival when Athens was selected by a surprisingly wide margin over co-favorite Rome to host the 2004 Summer Games. By a vote of 66 to 41, the members of the International Olympic Committee removed the sting of rejection that Athens felt seven years ago when Atlanta was chosen to host the 1996 centennial Olympics. It was in Olympia, Greece, that the ancient Games began in 776 B.C. and Athens revived the modern Olympics in 1896. South Africa, Sweden and Argentina had also sought the games. 33
 
OBITUARIES 30-31
 
Mother Teresa
The Roman Catholic nun of Albanian descent who won the 1979 Nobel Peace Prize for her work among the poorest of the world's poor in India, where she worked for 68 years and became a citizen, was 87. 1
 
Sir Georg Solti
The vigorous and exacting Hungarian-born conductor who shaped the Chicago Symphony Orchestra into a gleaming virtuoso instrument during his 22 years as its music director, and who won more Grammy Awards than any other performer, classical or pop, was 84. 1
 
BUSINESS DAY 38-51
 
Job Growth Slows Down
The economy created jobs at a slower pace in August, as the unemployment rate inched up one-tenth of a point, to 4.9 percent, from a 23-year low, the Government reported. While the strike at the United Parcel Service held payroll growth to its slimmest rise in nearly a year, other gauges of the labor market provided further evidence that economic growth continues to be robust. 39
 
France Privatizes by Degrees
The Socialist-led Government reached diametrically opposite decisions on privatizing the country's two most visible state-owned companies: Air France and France Telecom. In Paris, the chairman of Air France, Christian Blanc, announced plans to quit after Prime Minister Lionel Jospin firmly rejected his pleas to turn the country's flagship airline into a private company. But just a few hours later, Government officials sent out their formal recommendations to proceed with a much-delayed plan to sell off one-third of France Telecom, the national telephone monopoly, most likely in a public stock offering later this year.

HEADLINE: Reuters to Build 32-Story Headquarters in Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Rudin Organization, one of the oldest real estate families in New York, and Reuters are forming a joint venture to build a 32-story headquarters in Times Square for the British media company.
The partnership plans to build an 844,000-square-foot building at the northwest corner of 42d Street and Seventh Avenue, according to two people involved in the negotiations. The retail stores currently on the site, opposite Disney's New Amsterdam Theater, would be demolished. 
 Under the proposed venture, the Prudential Insurance Company, which controls the property, would sell the parcel to Reuters and the Rudin Organization. Prudential's Capital Group may also provide the partners with a $250 million construction loan.
Reuters executives in New York, who have been negotiating with Prudential for more than six months, are expecting officials at its London headquarters to approve a proposed letter of intent between the company and the Rudins, according to people involved in the negotiations. Reuters is also completing negotiations with both Prudential and city and state officials, who must approve the project.
"It's wonderful news that the Rudins are continuing to develop in Times Square," said Douglas Durst, a developer who is building a 1.6-million-square-foot tower on the opposite corner. "I can think of no one we'd rather have as a neighbor."
For the Rudin family, which has not put up a new building since 1989, the project represents a plunge into a neighborhood that until a short time ago was known mainly for its peep shows and prostitutes. Reuters had talked to other developers, but it was William Rudin, heir to an empire of 39 buildings worth an estimated $1.5 billion, who jumped at the chance to build in Times Square, said several people in the real estate business. Under the terms of the deal, Reuters would initially take about three-quarters of the office space and the Rudins would be responsible for leasing what remained.
Neither William Rudin nor his father, Lewis, returned calls requesting comment. Prudential declined comment, although one official said a deal was in the works.
Prudential has invested $467 million in Times Square since the company was selected by state officials in 1987 to redevelop the area around Times Square and 42d Street. But in recent years, the insurance giant has had no desire to build the four office towers called for in the redevelopment plan.
Prudential sold control of one parcel to Mr. Durst last year, and company officials say they plan to begin marketing two other properties later this month to a select group of developers, including Mr. Durst, the Tishman family and Vornado Realty Trust.
"We have nothing new to report on our search for a real estate site," said a spokesman for Reuters, Robert Crooke. "We continue to look at various sites within New York City and in Connecticut and New Jersey."
Reuters employs about 1,850 people in New York City, most of them at 1700 Broadway, 40 East 52d Street, 199 Water Street and 875 Third Avenue. Although the company has considered locations outside New York, Reuters began focusing on Times Square months ago.
Reuters has asked the city for special tax breaks for the project even though the site is within the borders of the 42d Street redevelopment project and therefore already has an unprecedented level of municipal subsidies. Civic activists have opposed granting companies additional tax breaks to move to Times Square because it is now one of the most desirable locations in the city.
But last year, the Giuliani administration granted the Conde Nast publishing company a $10.75 million tax break to move to Mr. Durst's building at what is known as 4 Times Square. City officials say Reuters wants a similar deal.
"The Mayor has long made it clear he would like to see development as soon as possible in Times Square, and, of course, we would like Reuters to stay in New York," said Charles Millard, president of the Economic Development Corporation. "But I cannot comment on whether we're in those kinds of discussions."
The design of the proposed tower could become a sticking point. State officials had previously approved a relatively staid, corporate design by the architect Philip Johnson that they now find out of harmony with the colorful, neon-infused atmosphere of Times Square. They have encouraged Reuters to design a building with flashing electronic signs and ground-floor retail space, but the company has yet to hire an architect.

HEADLINE: '97 Tax Bills Up About 3% In New Jersey

BYLINE: By MELODY PETERSEN 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
Property tax bills in New Jersey, already among the highest in the nation, went up an average of 3 percent this year, according to preliminary estimates released today by the Whitman administration.
The administration noted that the increase was the smallest since 1991. That year, property taxes rose only 1.4 percent, but it was also the year that an increase in the state income tax was adopted under Jim Florio, the former Governor. 
 "Because of Governor Whitman's leadership, we are seeing a greater commitment to accountability in municipal and county governments as well as school districts," said Jane M. Kenny, Commissioner of the State Department of Community Affairs. "More local leaders are paying attention to the bottom line and that's exactly what the taxpayers are demanding from all of us."
But the 3 percent statewide average increase masks the estimated double-digit increases in two dozen of New Jersey's 566 municipalities. Many of those towns are growing and struggling to keep up with rising school populations.
And the property tax numbers are only estimates. While officials of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's administration say they believe that the actual numbers will not be much different, they say that those numbers may not be available until after the gubernatorial election on Nov. 4.
Four years ago, when Governor Whitman began phasing in her 30 percent cut in state income tax rates, Democrats warned that local government officials would be forced to raise property taxes as the state sent less money to schools and towns.
But the Whitman administration said today's report was proof that that did not happen. The average annual rise in property taxes during Mrs. Whitman's four-year term -- 3.9 percent with today's new estimates for 1997 -- is indeed far less than the property tax increases of 12 and 13 percent in the latter half of the 1980's.
But Governor Whitman's Democratic opponent, James E. McGreevey, was quick to criticize the report.
"The official calculations now document what homeowners already know all too well -- that property taxes have grown to be a terrible financial burden for the residents of New Jersey," Mr. McGreevey said. "The Governor said earlier in her term that property taxes were not her problem, and she has proven it by pushing them upwards by $1.9 billion in only four years."
According to a recent study by the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy, in Washington, the average young married couple owning a home in New Jersey paid $3,562 in property taxes in 1995, far more than in any other state. The next highest property tax bills were in Connecticut, where an average couple paid $2,573.
Some of the largest property tax increases this year were in rural counties, Hunterdon and Somerset, where farmland is turning into housing developments. In both counties, the average property tax bill rose about 6 percent -- double the average increase for the state as a whole.
In Bernards Township in Somerset County, for example, property tax bills rose an estimated 17 percent this year. Barbara Pence, the township's administrator, said that much of the increase was needed to pay for the rising number of public school students. She said that many young families had recently moved to town.

HEADLINE: Cubans Blame Exiles in U.S. for 4 Bombings in a Single Day

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
A bomb exploded in one of Havana's best-known tourist restaurants late Thursday night, following three bombs earlier in the day at three of the city's seafront hotels, in which an Italian businessman was killed.
Employees at the restaurant, the Bodeguita del Medio, made famous by Ernest Hemingway, said there were no injuries from the small bomb, which damaged furniture. 
 The Cuban Foreign Ministry said that bomb attacks were part of a campaign of terrorism organized by Cuban exiles living in the United States, with the intention of damaging the Cuban economy. There were two bombings in July in Cuban tourist offices.
A State Department spokesman here, James Foley, said the United States had no idea of who was behind the bombings, and that the Cuban Government "has not responded to our repeated requests for substantive information or evidence to support that contention" of American involvement.
"We reiterate our commitment to investigate if the Cuban Government provides substantive information or evidence, which they have not done to this date," Mr. Foley said.
Another American official said that Washington had told Havana that the United States was opposed to terrorism everywhere, and would act to punish Americans responsible if evidence was provided that proved Havana's assertions.
But the bombings "are hard to fathom in such a tightly controlled society," the official said, remarking that "it's odd that the Cubans haven't trotted anyone out" as responsible. Given the level of police and Interior Ministry control, violent crime is low in Cuba.
There were numerous theories about who was behind the bombings, the official said, including internal dissidents opposed to the Government, nationalist Cubans offended by the prostitution and glitz of the tourist trade and even the Cuban Government itself in an act of provocation to keep anti-American feeling and national solidarity at a high level.
The Cuban Foreign Ministry blamed Miami-based devotees of the ex-dictator of Cuba, Fulgencio Batista, who was supported by the United States but was overthrown by Fidel Castro in 1959.
The bombings took place on the anniversary of a 1933 coup that first brought Mr. Batista to power, the Foreign Ministry noted, but American officials said the dates could be purely coincidental.
Cuba's tourism industry has become its fastest-growing economic sector and has attracted foreign investment, overtaking sugar exports as the main source of hard-currency income. The bombs seemed aimed at damaging Cuba's efforts to promote tourism and show the island to be a safe place for foreigners.
In Havana, the Interior Ministry said it was "taking the necessary measures against these cowardly and repugnant acts," but provided no details. Pope John Paul II is due to visit Cuba in January.

HEADLINE: Small Stocks Up Again, While Dow Drops

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
Investors continued their infatuation with the stocks of smaller companies yesterday, pushing a leading index of those companies to new highs. But concerns about Asian market turmoil and a strengthening dollar weighed on the stocks of larger multinational companies, which could see their earnings reduced by exposure in those countries.
Reflecting the Asian situation, the dollar inched up against the yen but declined against the German mark. The dollar was quoted in late New York trading at 121.06 yen, up from 120.87. The dollar finished at 1.8024 marks, down from 1.8153 late Thursday. 
 Large consumer product companies were major contributors to the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average as multinational members of that group -- like Procter & Gamble -- faltered. Some stocks in the consumer product sector, including P.& G., were downgraded by a Smith Barney analyst.
"One of the reasons the currencies really came to the fore now is the domestic economy really seems to be in cruise control," said Douglas R. Cliggott, United States equity strategist at J. P. Morgan.
With the economy moving along at a moderate growth pace, investors are beginning to question the wisdom of paying hefty premiums for the blue-chip companies that have led the market rally this year, Mr. Cliggott said.
"The lack of concern about a big breakdown in earnings, coupled with the strength of the dollar is shifting investors' focus" toward smaller companies because now "it's desirable to be domestically oriented rather than global," he said.
Larger-company stocks also declined because Treasury bonds slumped despite a smaller-than-expected gain in August employment growth. Although shorter-term Treasury issues finished higher, longer issues declined amid continued investor concern that the economy would begin showing signs of inflation pressures, prompting the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates before the end of the year, said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker.
The 30-year bond dropped 13/32, to a price of 96 20/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 6.64 percent, from 6.60 percent on Thursday.
The Dow Jones industrial average finished 44.83 points lower at 7,822.41, although the index posted a gain of 2.6 percent for the week.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks slipped 1.82, to 929.05, but was still up 3.3 percent this week.
The Nasdaq composite index gained 11.14 points, to 1,635.77, a new closing high. And the Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies moved up 3.33, to 433.04, a new high, marking the ninth consecutive session the index has posted a gain.
"The underperformance of the group has been ridiculous and that is simply unsustainable," said Audrey Snell, a senior vice president and portfolio manager at SunAmerica Asset Management, referring to the earlier neglect of small stocks by investors.
She said that the Russell 2000 index was up 20.6 percent this year, compared with a 26 percent gain in the S.& P. index. The Dow, up 21.4 percent this year, is doing slightly better than the small-company measure.
"The Dow has performed magnificently," she said. "It's gone as far as it can go in the near-term given the growth rate," explaining why investors have begun to focus on smaller companies.
"I think it's really the hunt for those sectors that have underperformed in a magnificent market," she said. "The sense is that the Dow is fully valued and the relative value is in the small-cap side."
But the shift in investor affections does not signal that the market rally is winding down, analysts said.
"It just means the market is broadening out and you're not going to get the pickup in the same places,"Mr. Cripps said.
"I find this extremely bullish," Ms. Snell of SunAmerica said. "Healthy markets broaden; they don't narrow."
In the bond market, even the smaller-than-expected gains in the August employment growth of 49,000 and the increase of four-tenths of 1 percent in workers' average hourly earnings were not weak enough to provide much comfort. Some traders took advantage of the bounce in the market when the data were released to sell at higher prices ahead of next week's report on retail sales and producer prices.
While the yen weakened against the dollar, most Asian markets finished higher yesterday, as investors reacted positively to moves of several governments in the region to shore up foreign investor confidence in those markets.
The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong closed up 2.6 percent. The Kuala Lumpur Composite Index in Malaysia leaped 12.4 percent. The Jakarta Composite Index in Indonesia rose 11 percent.
Among United States equities, Procter & Gamble, which led the Dow lower, fell 3 7/16, to 133.
Shares of several other companies faltered yesterday as they reported that third-quarter earnings would not meet expectations.
One was Boston Scientific, a medical device maker, which cited slipping sales growth and higher selling costs in Europe. Earnings for the company, however, will still be positive, analysts said. Boston Scientific closed at 62 5/8, down 13 1/4.
Tupperware shares fell 6 11/16, or about 19 percent, after the company warned that earnings would be significantly lower on declining Latin American sales. Tupperware closed at 28 7/16.

HEADLINE: Job Creation Slowed in August As U.P.S. Strike Curbed Hiring

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
The economy created jobs at a slower pace in August, as the unemployment rate inched up one-tenth of a point, to 4.9 percent, from a 23-year low, the Government reported today.
While the strike at the United Parcel Service held payroll growth to its slimmest rise in nearly a year, other gauges of the labor market provided further evidence that economic growth continues to be robust. 
 "The U.S. economic expansion continues to barrel along at an unsustainable pace," analysts at Salomon Brothers told clients today.
The expansion added 49,000 jobs to the nation's payrolls last month, less than expectations of a gain of 70,000. When the effects of the U.P.S. strike are discounted, the payroll increase would be between 190,000 and 200,000 jobs, Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, estimated at a hearing of the Joint Economic Committee of Congress.
With unemployment at 5 percent or less for the fifth consecutive month, the White House again seized on the Labor Department's report -- the first comprehensive indicator of the economy's August performance -- to point, among other things, to the remarkable lack of wage and price pressures that traditionally have accompanied such a tight job market.
"Our economy continues to roll at a healthy pace," Janet Yellen, President Clinton's chief economic adviser, said in a statement. "Unemployment remains historically low and inflation is in check."
But while private analysts generally stuck to the widely held belief that the Federal Reserve would decide against raising interest rates at its Sept. 30 policy meeting, those ruling out increases at the following session in mid-November have become an ever-shrinking minority.
Paul L. Kasriel, an economist with the Northern Trust Company in Chicago, described today's report as "warm and fuzzy on the outside, threatening on the inside." In other words, figures that showed slower job growth and benign inflation were pointing to continued benign inflation, but were masking less obvious signs of danger.
One such sign, Mr. Kasriel and other economists said, was an accelerated surge in the proportion of the unemployed who quit their most recent job instead of being discharged, laid off or just entering the work force. The August jump -- reflecting increasing confidence of finding another, possibly better, job -- was to 13.7 percent of the unemployed from 12.6 percent in July and 12.2 percent in May and June.
Another surprisingly strong figure was the rise of 47,000 in factory jobs last month, a vigorous rebound from the decline of 17,000 in July, even when allowing for August's return of 10,000 strikers in the steel and automotive industries. Analysts also noted that this came despite a huge buildup in inventories during the first half of the year that many had assumed would force production cutbacks in the second half.
In addition, the length of the private-sector workweek expanded by 12 minutes in August, average hourly earnings climbed a solid 5 cents an hour and the key retail trade sector added 31,000 jobs.
"It still looks like a fairly strong economy," said Subhasis Das, senior economist at Barnett Banks in Jacksonville, Fla.
The payroll number was sharply affected, as expected, by the strike against U.P.S. Although the strike directly involved 185,000 teamsters, some crossed picket lines and there was substantial hiring elsewhere in the transportation business and at the Postal Service. Government jobs climbed by 72,000 last month, reflecting temporary postal workers and jobs in local school systems where the trend toward an earlier end to summer vacation has confounded the seasonal adjustment process and exaggerated recent job gains.
But analysts also noted that the bureau revised sharply higher, to 365,000, the payroll increase for July, which had initially been put at 316,000.
As for the department's survey of households, in which strikers are counted as employed, the job gain last month was a modest 96,000, not quite enough when combined with a 190,000 expansion of the labor force to prevent a slight rise in the unemployment rate, which, before rounding, moved to 4.89 percent from 4.83 percent. The Government regards as statistically insignificant any move of less than two-tenths of a point.
But analysts did consider noteworthy the improved job situation of blacks, whose overall unemployment rate edged down to 9.3 percent as the rate for black men 20 and older dropped to 7.5 percent, the lowest since the mid-1970's, from 8.2 percent in July.
"Declines of this magnitude can be taken as clear evidence of a significant improvement in the employment prospects of black males," said Dean Baker, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
Alexis Herman, the Secretary of Labor, cited a 4.3 percent jobless rate for blacks with a college degree as proof of the value of training. "You can see the gap narrowing" with whites, she said of black unemployment. The jobless rate for white college graduates is 2.4 percent.
Geographically, the Northeast fared best in August as its unemployment rate eased to 5.3 percent from 5.5. The South's rate was unchanged at 5 percent while the rate rose three-tenths of a point in the Midwest and West, to 3 percent and 5.6 percent, respectively.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Voices Doubt On Statistics

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 5

 BODY:
With investors worldwide awaiting his every word, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, cast doubt again tonight on the reliability of key economic statistics but drew no firm conclusions on why the economy has remained inflation-free despite strong growth and low unemployment.
Mr. Greenspan also touched on what he called "the implications for financial and economic stability of the extraordinary rise in equity prices" and noted that asset prices had to be an integral factor in setting monetary policy. 
 But he suggested that the Fed would not seek to rein in stock prices, saying that "unless they are moving together, prices of assets and of goods and services cannot both be an objective of a particular monetary policy."
In his only direct reference to the possibility that the Fed might decide to raise rates later this year to insure against an outbreak of inflation, Mr. Greenspan said that "with labor resources currently stretched tight, we need to remain on alert."
Because Mr. Greenspan's speech was scheduled to be delivered to the Center for Economic Policy Research at Stanford University in Palo Alto, Calif., late on a Friday night -- a time when nearly all financial markets around the world would be closed -- many analysts and investors had expected him to speak more freely than he normally might about stock prices and the changing nature of the economy.
Indeed, the speculation surrounding the speech became so intense that rumors circulated widely on Wall Street during the day that Mr. Greenspan would use the speech to announce his resignation. Mr. Greenspan issued a statement calling the rumors "nonsense."
In the end, his speech broke little new ground. But it continued a process in which Mr. Greenspan, long attacked by critics in Congress for being too secretive about the Fed's deliberations, has essentially thought out loud about some of the most vexing and sensitive issues facing the central bank.
The speech sought to put into historical context the Fed's current efforts to cope with economic conditions that seem to break many of the rules and assumptions that have long guided monetary policy.
Mr. Greenspan discussed how policy makers had abandoned as formal guideposts predictors of inflation like gold prices and money supply figures when it became clear that the changing nature of the economy had made them less meaningful. And he noted how specific conditions, like the stock market crash of 1987 or the credit squeeze among banks in the early 1990's, could force a reshaping of policy.
"Most recently, the economy has demonstrated a remarkable confluence of robust growth, high resource utilization and damped inflation," Mr. Greenspan said in a text of the speech that was released by the Fed. "Once again we have been faced with analyzing and reacting to a situation in which incoming data have not readily conformed to historical experience."
Mr. Greenspan did not explore in any detail the debate over the long-held belief among economists that strong growth at a time of low unemployment invariably pushes up wages and prices, causing inflation. By that rule, the economy now would be deep into a zone of inflationary danger, but there are almost no signs that price increases are actually accelerating.
Mr. Greenspan, however, repeated his long-held belief that the most likely explanation for the current puzzle is that the most widely used measures of productivity are not capturing the improved efficiency of American businesses.
"Nonetheless, the still open question is whether productivity growth is in the process of picking up," Mr. Greenspan said. "For it is the answer to this question that is material to the current debate between those who argue that the economy is entering a 'new era' of greatly enhanced sustainable growth and unusually high levels of resource utilization, and those who do not."
Mr. Greenspan said monetary policy currently focused on achieving stable product prices.
"But what about prices of claims on future goods and services, like equities, real estate or other earning assets?" Mr. Greenspan asked, and then pointed to the economic pain felt in Japan after the bursting of a real estate bubble in recent years as a partial answer.
"The prices of final goods and services were stable in Japan in the mid- to late 1980's, but soaring asset prices distorted resource allocation and ultimately undermined the performance of the macroeconomy," he said.
History, Mr. Greenspan said, "is somewhat ambiguous on the issue of whether central banks can safely ignore asset markets, except as they affect product prices."

HEADLINE: Excellent Albert

BYLINE: By Naomi Bliven; Naomi Bliven is the author of a novel, "On Her Own."

 BODY:

UNCROWNED KING
 The Life of Prince Albert.
 By Stanley Weintraub.
 Illustrated. 478 pp. New York:
 The Free Press. $27.50. 
 Stanley Weintraub's sympathetic biography persuades us that Prince Albert "was one of his era's unsung great men." Some aspect of greatness is always elusive, and what is mysterious about Queen Victoria's husband is the source of his social imagination. He was born in a German backwater, Saxe-Coburg-Gotha, attended the University of Bonn and toured Italy's art treasures. None of this seems adequate preparation for his role in Britain, the world's leading commercial and industrial power, with its expanding overseas empire. How did Albert know what needed doing and who needed encouraging in a foreign country that was in the midst of headlong transformation? That remains Albert's secret.
Weintraub's book is as fascinating as his subject, partly because of what Albert did and partly because of what Weintraub doesn't do. He never claims too much. His Albert is human: he overworks, grumbles and makes mistakes. And Weintraub does not sentimentalize the royal romance. The 20-year-olds who married in 1840 continued to need and love each other until Albert's untimely death in December 1861, but Weintraub candidly records their tiffs and misunderstandings.
Parliament designed the terms of the marriage to exclude the Queen's husband from government, but starting with Victoria's first pregnancy -- she bore nine children -- he became, in the words of his private secretary, "in fact, though not in name, Her Majesty's Private Secretary." Ministers who had dreaded an alien interloper appreciated his intelligence and efficiency. While Albert never gained popularity with the wider public, those who worked with him liked and respected him. The exception was Lord Palmerston, who, as Foreign Secretary, made policy without consulting the Queen. Yet even he, in time, came around. He was Prime Minister when the American Civil War broke out, and, like other members of his cabinet, hoped for the breakup of the Union. They took advantage of a naval incident in 1861 -- an American warship stopped a British packet on the high seas and took off two Confederate emissaries bound for Europe -- to compose an arrogant note that practically demanded a declaration of war. Palmerston showed the draft to Victoria, who showed it to Albert. He was on his deathbed but summoned the strength to modify the ultimatum to make it acceptable in Washington.
Without formal power, Albert nevertheless wielded immense authority. His innumerable projects outside politics ranged from encouraging "ancient" music to slum clearance.
Elected chancellor of Cambridge in 1847, he discovered that the university did not teach history, economics, law, psychology, chemistry, geography, art, astronomy, natural history or modern languages. Albert went to work, and in 1848 the university senate voted to teach them all. The "Industry of All Nations" exhibition, the famous Crystal Palace of 1851, was another of Albert's triumphs. It turned a profit, which Albert used to finance several institutions in South Kensington, including a museum of the decorative arts that was innovative because it was dedicated to teaching as well as display. Everywhere you find Albert grasping what a modern civilized society should offer its citizens and trying to supply it.
Weintraub is at home in the period (his previous books include biographies of Victoria and Disraeli) and conveys nuances as easily as facts. He allows readers to observe that England's free press could be as cruel to royalty in the 19th as it is in the 20th century: on the eve of the Crimean War, newspapers accused Albert of supporting Russia, and rumors circulated that he and Victoria had been imprisoned in the Tower for treason.
Candid about Albert's flaws, Weintraub can usually find a reason, if not an excuse. Albert's prudishness seems excessive, but unchastity had wrecked his parents' marriage and his brother's health. Victoria's habit of dramatizing her feelings has turned her admiration of her husband into a stale joke. Yet Weintraub, recording Albert's achievements without Victoria's italics, shows that, however irritating her style, her judgment was accurate: Albert was a marvel.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: UNCROWNED KING (BOOK)

HEADLINE: The Birth of a Notion

BYLINE: By Nicholas Wade; Nicholas Wade is a science reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

The Inflationary Universe
 The Quest for a New Theory of Cosmic Origins.
 By Alan H. Guth.
 Illustrated. 358 pp. Reading, Mass.: Helix Books/
 Addison-Wesley Publishing Company. $25. 
 Modern physicists have settled on a theory of the world's origin that would flunk almost any nonscientist's reality check. The entire universe, they insist, was once the size of a grapefruit. Rationalists may furtively wonder if supernatural versions of the world's creation are not rather easier to swallow.
For those willing to let the high priests of physics make their pitch, Alan H. Guth's new book, "The Inflationary Universe," is a user-friendly guide to getting one's mind round the big bang and, weirder yet, the events that preceded it. His explanations are probably as clear as can be, given that they are translated from their original language of mathematical physics. His book is also a significant document in the history of science, since it portrays an intellectual revolution of which Guth was the principal mover.
For readers who enjoy David-and-Goliath tales, Guth offers the real thing. As a young physicist with almost nothing on his resume, he conceived a radically new idea about the first critical instants in the birth of the universe. Establishments do not generally fold their hands easily, especially to obscure upstarts in a field. But so compelling was Guth's notion -- the astronomer Joseph Silk has called it "the only new idea in cosmology since Einstein" -- that it quickly succeeded.
One night in December 1979, while still an unknown 32-year-old physicist at the Stanford Linear Accelerator Center, Guth had a remarkable insight that showed how to sweep away a bunch of embarrassing discordances between the big-bang theory and observed facts about the universe. "Spectacular realization," he wrote in his diary above a statement of his as yet unscrutinized idea.
Guth's great idea was that the universe, during its first instants of existence, expanded at an exponential rate (doubling at every unit of time) before assuming the steady expansion rate of the big-bang theory. This early phase of hyper-expansion, known as inflation, explained three highly puzzling features of the universe that the big-bang theorists could not account for. These are known as the flatness problem (having to do with the universe's mass), the horizon problem (its homogeneity) and the absence of magnetic monopoles. Magnetic monopoles, particles carrying a single north or south magnetic polarity, could and should exist in profusion, according to current theory, yet none have been found. It was in trying to figure out the strange absence of monopoles that Guth came up with the inflation scenario.
With amazing brashness Guth publicly tossed this firecracker into cosmology, a field he had to school himself in as he was overturning it. He describes hastily reading a semipopular account, the physicist Steven Weinberg's book "The First Three Minutes," to prepare for a critical presentation of his work at Stanford. The cram job sufficed. "HELL OF A GOOD DAY," Guth afterward confided to his diary. The usual fate of radical new ideas is to be ignored, suppressed or stolen, particularly when they come from someone without allies or standing in a field. Guth had been rejected for all the assistant professorship jobs he had applied for and was in essence an itinerant scholar. It says much for the brilliance of his idea, and the openness of the physics community, that within a few days of his Stanford lecture he had received job offers from Harvard, Princeton and six other universities.
Guth rejected all of them for a job at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. One brilliant idea had propelled him from nowhere to the pinnacle of success. But then triple catastrophe struck. He had to undergo major surgery, the removal of his colon. His proposed mechanism for getting the early universe to work turned out not to shut off in the right way (creating what was known as "the graceful exit problem"). And as his idea became known it emerged that a Russian scientist, Aleksei A. Starobinsky, had conceived a form of the inflation theory several years before Guth. Another Russian, Andrei Linde, who is now at Stanford, subsequently found a solution to the graceful exit problem and developed what is now the current form of the theory, known as chaotic inflation. But it was Guth who sold the world on the idea and so deserves a large share of the credit.
Inflation, despite its drab name, is an idea of vast importance because it affords a glimpse of what may have happened before the big bang. Inflation suggests that there are many universes, continually being created and destroyed like bubbles on the ocean. The idea is not yet proved but most astronomers and physicists, it is probably fair to say, regard it as highly attractive. The language and concepts of inflation have not yet sunk into the public consciousness as deeply as has the big-bang theory, which inflation modifies, but will doubtless do so in time.
Evident from Guth's account are both his luck and his cleverness. He had the good fortune to be working on the monopole problem with an obliging fellow postdoctoral student, Henry Tye of Cornell. Tye made essential contributions to their monopole work but allowed Guth to write up the inflation hypothesis separately. Both were trained in the physics of subatomic particles, and were ignorant of some of the other fields into which their monopole pursuit led, such as plasma physics and cosmology. "There is a whole branch of physics associated with the complicated behavior of plasmas, and Henry and I knew none of it," Guth notes in his account of the monopole work. Like a couple of amateur adventurers, Guth and Tye kept discovering papers in the physics literature that had anticipated their conclusions, sometimes by decades. They cadged scraps of information from experts. Lunchtime conversations with colleagues would send them racing off in a different direction. Eventually they developed an idea worth publishing, and it was near their deadline, with Tye about to go on a long visit to China, that Guth conceived the idea of inflation. His cleverness lay in perceiving instantly how helpful inflation would be in cosmology, and in being quick enough on his feet to persuade other physicists he had a winner.
Alan Guth's book is written in a brisk, engaging style uncharacteristic of scientific autobiographies. His story tells much about how science sometimes works, how the universe may work and how on occasion one bright individual can cause an intellectual revolution.
