BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:

September
 
"BANDWAGON" A North Carolina garage band tries to balance ambition and inspiration. With Kevin Corrigan, Matthew Hennessey, Steve Parlavecchio, Lee Holmes and Doug MacMillan. Friday. 

"DIFFERENT FOR GIRLS" Who's that girl? Rupert Graves and Steven Mackintosh star in a British serio-comedy about school buddies who meet years later after one has had a sex change. Friday.
 
"THE DISAPPEARANCE OF GARCIA LORCA" Andy Garcia plays the murdered Spanish poet and playwright in a whodunit with a lush, spooky, political atmosphere. Friday.
 
* "THE END OF VIOLENCE" What if an overhead surveillance system were invented to monitor whole neighborhoods? Wim Wenders sets this hallucinatory gadget-clogged drama of paranoia and government skulduggery in contemporary Los Angeles. Bill Pullman plays an action-adventure movie producer who disappears and Andie MacDowell his neglected wife. Antonioni's "Blowup" meets Altman's "Short Cuts." Friday.
 
"THE GAME" Michael Douglas is a modern-day Scrooge whose brother (Sean Penn) sends him a deadly mind-maze as a present. "Wall Street" goes psycho? Opens Friday.
 
"RIDING THE RAILS" A documentary, acclaimed at Sundance, remembers the thousands of freight-hopping teen-agers who took to the road during the Depression. Friday.
 
"THE MYTH OF FINGERPRINTS" "Home for the Holidays" redux, with different geography and class setting: New England and upper-middle. With Blythe Danner, Roy Scheider, Noah Wyle and Julianne Moore. Sept. 17.
 
"GOING ALL THE WAY" Sex in the repressed 1950's had to be lurid, torrid or seamy. This movie of Dan Wakefield's novel about two Korean War veterans' sexual hang ups stars Ben Affleck and Jeremy Davies as a period stud and his wimp sidekick looking for action. With surreal touches. Sept. 19.
 
"IN AND OUT" Is the Streisand-loving high school teacher (Kevin Kline) who is outed by a former student on the Oscars telecast really gay? And how does he feel when Tom Selleck (as a gay TV journalist) plants a juicy kiss on his mouth? The comedy, written by Paul Rudnick and directed by Frank Oz, is aimed at the same Middle American audience that embraced "The Birdcage." Sept. 19.
 
* "L.A. CONFIDENTIAL" More pulp fiction. Los Angeles in the 50's is a rat's nest of vice, blackmail and police corruption in Curtis Hanson's snazzy adaptation of James Ellroy's 1990 novel. Think "Chinatown" by way of Confidential magazine, with the Lana Turner-Johnny Stompanato scandal thrown in. With Guy Pearce, Russell Crowe, Kim Basinger, Kevin Spacey and Danny DeVito. Sept. 19.
 
* "A THOUSAND ACRES" "King Lear" goes to Iowa in this adaptation of the acclaimed Jane Smiley novel. Jessica Lange, Michelle Pfeiffer and Jennifer Jason Leigh portray the warring sisters who are tyrannized by a proudly dotty father (Jason Robards). Jocelyn Moorhouse ("How to Make an American Quilt") directed the drama, which softens the novel but not enough to compromise its doomy fatalism. Sept. 19.
 
NEW YORK FILM FESTIVAL The festival, in its 35th year, will present 28 films from 18 countries. It opens Sept. 26 with "The Ice Storm," by Ang Lee, and closes Oct. 12 with Pedro Almodovar's "Live Flesh"; the "centerpiece" film is "The Sweet Hereafter," by Atom Egoyan, to be shown Oct. 4. The schedule also includes highlights like "Taste of Cherry," by Abbas Kiarostami of Iran; "Mother and Son," by Aleksandr Sokurov of Russia; "Happy Together," by Wong Kar-Wei of Hong Kong; "The Apostle," by Robert Duvall, and Richard Kwietnowski's "Love and Death on Long Island."
 
"THE ASSIGNMENT" The world's deadliest terrorist is flushed out in an impersonation scheme. With Donald Sutherland, Ben Kingsley and Aidan Quinn. Sept. 26.
 
"THE EDGE" Machismo and paranoia rule in a survival drama written by David Mamet, directed by Lee Tamahori and starring Anthony Hopkins and Alec Baldwin. They're stranded in Alaskan forest, with one knife, seven matches and thoughts about a woman (Elle Macpherson) between them. Sept. 26.
 
"KICKED IN THE HEAD" Kevin Corrigan is a New York slacker whose life becomes a comic nightmare when he camps out in the apartment of a pal (Michael Rapaport) and gets caught up in his uncle's criminal shenanigans. With James Woods, Lili Taylor and Linda Fiorentino. Sept. 26.
 
"THE LOCUSTS" Dark family secrets haunt a Kansas family in the early 60's. With Kate Capshaw, Vince Vaughn, Jeremy Davies and Ashley Judd. Sept. 26.
 
* "THE PEACEMAKER" The first feature film from the Dreamworks studio stars George Clooney and Nicole Kidman as American intelligence operatives, one who plays by the rules (she), the other who doesn't (he). Mimi Leder directed the suspense thriller, which begins in Eastern Europe with the theft of several nuclear devices and ends up near the United Nations during gridlock. Sept. 26.
 
"SOUL FOOD" Cozy Sunday dinners help a black family whose daughters, played by Vanessa L. Williams, Vivica A. Fox and Nia Long, are locked in strife. Sept. 26.
 
* "THE ICE STORM" Ang Lee's adaptation of Rick Moody's novel explores the impact of the 60's sexual revolution on a WASPy Connecticut suburb in 1973 during the Watergate hearings. Without any supernatural tricks, the film, which stars Kevin Kline, Sigourney Weaver, Joan Allen and Christina Ricci, manages to have a horror movie's feel. Sept. 27.
 
October
 
"THE BUTCHER BOY" The director Neil Jordan and Stephen Rea, who teamed so successfully on "The Crying Game," are back together in this adaptation of the prize-winning novel by Patrick McCabe about a very troubled Irish family. Oct. 3.
 
"FAST, CHEAP AND OUT OF CONTROL"
Errol Morris's documentary about work and obsessiveness is an offbeat collage that examines the work of a lion tamer, a topiary gardener, a robot maker and a student of naked mole rats. Oct. 3.
 
"THE GINGERBREAD MAN" Robert Altman directed the first original screenplay by John Grisham, but Polygram is re-editing the film and Mr. Altman is angry and may demand that his name be removed from it. Was the iconoclastic director too iconoclastic? With Kenneth Branagh, Embeth Davidtz, Robert Downey Jr. and Daryl Hannah. Oct. 3.
 
"KISS THE GIRLS" A "collector" of beautiful women kidnaps the niece of a Washington police detective (Morgan Freeman), and the hunt is on. Ashley Judd joins Mr. Morgan; director is Gary Fleder ("Things to Do in Denver When You're Dead"). Oct. 3.
 
* "U-TURN" Oliver Stone forgoes paranoid politics with this nasty film noir, based on John Ridley's novel "Stray Dogs," about a tough con man (Sean Penn) who turns up in an Arizona desert town full of oddballs with seething passions. Can the grandiose director of "J.F.K." and "Nixon" think lean and mean? With Jennifer Lopez, Billy Bob Thornton, Claire Danes and Joaquin Phoenix. Oct. 3.
 
* "WASHINGTON SQUARE" Agnieszka Holland directed the high-toned adaptation of the Henry James novel that inspired "The Heiress." This version, starring Jennifer Jason Leigh as a homely spinster torn between her domineering father (Albert Finney) and a handsome fortune hunter (Ben Chaplin), dispenses with the melodrama while maintaining a feminist perspective that is generous toward its central character. Oct. 5.
 
* "SEVEN YEARS IN TIBET" The central character in this epic story of adventure and spiritual enlightenment is Heinrich Harrer (Brad Pitt), a real-life Austrian mountain climber (and, it was revealed early this year, Nazi) who is captured by the British as World War II begins, then escapes from a prison camp in India. He treks to the Tibetan city of Lhasa, where he meets the young Dalai Lama and becomes his tutor. Can Mr. Pitt make the stretch from pinup to spiritual pilgrim? With David Thewlis as his fellow adventurer and B. D. Wong as a Tibetan courtier. Oct. 8.
 
"YEAR OF THE HORSE" Jim Jarmusch rocking with Neil Young. Oct. 8.
 
"THE HOUSE OF YES" A satirical comedy about yet another dysfunctional family meeting for Thanksgiving. With Parker Posey (as a wacko sister who calls herself Jackie O), Josh Hamilton, Genevieve Bujold and Tori Spelling. Oct. 10.
 
* "BOOGIE NIGHTS" Mark Wahlberg, a k a Marky Mark, is a 70's porn star with a tiny I.Q. and a huge sexual endowment. The movie remembers those pre-AIDS days of disco nights and cocaine cowboys in the San Fernando Valley. Burt Reynolds is the egotistical daddy (and would-be serious filmmaker) who has put together a dysfunctional family of X-rated performers. Paul Thomas Anderson directed the movie, which bashes the 70's even as it pines for the decade's excesses. Oct. 12.
 
"HAPPY TOGETHER" In this visually aggressive seriocomedy that won Wong Kar-Wai the best-director prize at the Cannes Film Festival, a gay couple from Hong Kong moves to Buenos Aires to start a new life only to break up and have more troubles. Oct. 13.
 
"TELLING LIES IN AMERICA" The superstar screenwriter Joe Eszterhas wrote the screenplay for this autobiographical film around the time he wrote "Flashdance." The locale is Cleveland, the time is the early 60's, and the central player is an immigrant teen-ager (Brad Renfro) who learns the ways of a new world from a crooked, charismatic rock-and-roll deejay (Kevin Bacon). Oct. 15.
 
"THE DEVIL'S ADVOCATE" A supernatural drama about an idealistic young New York lawyer (Keanu Reeves) who discovers his boss (Al Pacino, in attorney drag) is the Devil himself. Directed by Taylor Hackford. Oct. 17.
 
"EYE OF GOD" Martha Plimpton is an Oklahoma waitress who marries her prison pen pal (Kevin Anderson), now a fundamentalist Christian. The film won Ms. Plimpton a best-actress citation at Sundance. Oct. 17.
 
"GUMMO" Harmony Korine, who wrote "Kids," directed these harsh vignettes of alienated teen-agers in Xenia, Ohio, a town still shellshocked from a tornado that struck 20 years earlier. With Chloe Sevigny, Max Perlilch and Linda Manz. Oct. 17.
 
"PLAYING GOD" David Duchovny plays a doctor mixed up with gangsters, one of whom is played by Timothy Hutton. Oct. 17.
 
"BEAUMARCHAIS" The French star Fabrice Luchini appears as the womanizing 18th-century playwright and spy. Oct. 24.
 
"EVE'S BAYOU" Samuel L. Jackson stars in this account of a well-to-do family on the Louisiana bayou with skeletons in its closet and the 10-year-old girl (Jurnee Smollett) who reveals them. Oct. 24.
 
"FAIRYTALE: A TRUE STORY" It's the summer of 1917, and Sir Arthur Conan Doyle (Peter O'Toole) and Harry Houdini (Harvey Keitel) disagree on whether photographs taken by two children offer the first scientific evidence of the existence of fairies. Oct. 24.
 
"GATTACA" Genetic engineering inspired this paranoid science-fiction fable about a young man (Ethan Hawke) seeking to transcend his assigned place in a society based on DNA readings. With Uma Thurman. Oct. 24.
 
"HURRICANE STREETS" Brendan Sexton (from "Welcome to the Dollhouse") portrays a teen-age petty criminal on the streets of New York with a mother in prison and an abused Latino girlfriend. Oct. 24.
 
* "A LIFE LESS ORDINARY" From the makers of "Trainspotting" comes a surreal romantic comedy about a janitor (Ewan McGregor) who kidnaps his boss's daughter (Cameron Diaz) and the benevolent guardian angels (Holly Hunter and Delroy Lindo) who have trouble making them fall in love. Glasgow meets Hollywood by way of film classics past. Oct. 24.
 
"PHANTOMS" When a mysterious underground force kills 700 people in a Colorado town, Peter O'Toole and Joanna Going find themselves among the few survivors. The supernatural thriller is based on a novel by Dean Koontz. Oct. 24.
 
"SWEPT FROM THE SEA" Beeban Kidron's adaptation of Joseph Conrad's short story "Amy Foster" is the downbeat story of the love between an English servant girl (Rachel Weisz) and an immigrant adventurer (Vincent Perez) who is washed ashore in a violent storm. Oct. 24.
 
"WONDERLAND" John O'Hagan's affectionate documentary about Levittown coincides with the 50th anniversary of the cookie-cutter dream town. Oct. 24.
 
"SWITCHBACK" A serial killer kidnaps the son of an F.B.I. agent (Dennis Quaid). Directed by Jeb Stuart, who wrote "The Fugitive." With Danny Glover. Oct. 31.
 
November
 
"BEAN" The British comic Rowan Atkinson as a hapless museum employee. Nov. 7.
 
"CRITICAL CARE" "Network" goes to the hospital. Sidney Lumet directed this satire about modern medicine, euthanasia, artificial life support and greed. With James Spader as a young doctor tempted to do the wrong thing. With Kyra Sedgwick, Helen Mirren, Anne Bancroft and Albert Brooks. Nov. 7.
 
"HUGO POOL" Robert Downey ("Putney Swope") directed this zany tale about a female swimming-pool cleaner who falls in love with a man with Lou Gehrig's disease who has magical powers. With Sean Penn, Malcolm McDowell, Robert Downey Jr. Nov. 7
 
"MAD CITY" John Travolta is a disgruntled museum security guard who accidentally shoots a fellow employee, then takes hostages. Dustin Hoffman is the sleazy, ambitious television reporter who exploits the crisis for all it's worth. Directed by Costa-Gavras. Nov. 7.
 
* "SICK" Not for the faint of heart, Kirby Dick's documentary portrait of the late Bob Flanagan, a Los Angeles performance artist and professional masochist, asks disturbing questions about the lines separating art and life, pleasure and pain, love and compulsion. Flanagan, who suffered from cystic fibrosis, is nailed, impaled, pierced and penetrated by his female companion in rituals that are often harrowing to watch. Nov. 7.
 
"STARSHIP TROOPERS" The director Paul Verhoeven ("Showgirls") returns to sci-fi with an adaptation of a Robert Heinlein novel in which humans battle giant bugs. Nov. 7.
 
* "THE WINGS OF THE DOVE" Can the moral complexities of Henry James ever be made cinematically compelling? This lavish adaptation, starring Helena Bonham Carter, pours on the finery and picturesque scenery. Linus Roache is her lover, and Alison Elliott is the dying American who can make them rich if they behave unscrupulously. Nov. 7.
 
"ANASTASIA" Can a lavish animated adaptation of the 1956 Ingrid Bergman film about a woman claiming to be an exiled Russian princess stir children's imaginations? With a musical score by Lynn Ahrens and Stephen Flaherty ("Once on This Island"). Nov. 14.
 
"A FURTHER GESTURE" Stephen Rea is an Irishman who gets out of prison, then moves to New York to start a new life and finds himself involved in an assassination plot cooked up by Guatemalan exiles. Nov. 14.
 
"THE JACKAL" An Irish terrorist (Richard Gere) is recruited by an F.B.I. director (Sidney Poitier) to track down an elusive assassin (Bruce Willis). Will these heavy hitters click together? Nov. 14.
 
"ONE NIGHT STAND" A Los Angeles adman (Wesley Snipes) has a passionate one-night fling with a New York beauty (Nastassja Kinski), but can't get her out of his mind after returning to his wife. Mike Figgis ("Leaving Las Vegas") directed. Nov. 14.
 
* "OSCAR AND LUCINDA" Gillian Armstrong directed Ralph Fiennes and Cate Blanchett in the story of a rebellious heiress and a risk-taking minister who determine to erect a glass church in the Australian wilderness. Adapted from Peter Carey's Booker Prize-winning novel. Nov. 14.
 
"THE TANGO LESSON" Sally Potter wrote and directed the story of a restless film maker who agrees to cast an Argentine tango dancer in her next movie if he will teach her to be a professional dancer. Nov. 14.
 
* "WELCOME TO SARAJEVO" Mixing fiction and documentary clips in a way that you can't always tell the difference, Michael Winterbottom's film follows a group of war correspondents in Bosnia. Stephen Dillane is an English reporter who bends the rules to take a Bosnian child to London. With Woody Harrelson and Marisa Tomei. Nov. 14.
 
"LIAR" Renee Zellweger is a prostitute who's murdered in Charleston, S.C., and Tim Roth (Hollywood's fave new psychopath) the prime suspect who manipulates the investigating detectives. Nov. 21.
 
* "MIDNIGHT IN THE GARDEN OF GOOD AND EVIL" Can Clint Eastwood capture the magnolia-scented decadence of John Berendt's best-selling portrait of Savannah, Ga.? Kevin Spacey seems tailor-made for the role of Jim Williams, a gay antique dealer who is murdered, and the drag queen Lady Chablis plays herself. That's a promising start. John Cusack is the author and narrator. Nov. 21.
 
"THE RAINMAKER" Where do nice guys finish in the nasty 90's? An idealistic lawyer (Matt Damon) battles a big insurance company and its legal eagles in this adaptation of John Grisham's best seller. Francis Ford Coppola directed. With Claire Danes, Danny DeVito and Danny Glover. Nov. 21.
 
"SLIDING DOORS" Another British role for Gwyneth Paltrow, this time as a yuppie at a crossroad (a London subway platform) who lives out two possible futures. Nov. 21.
 
"ALIEN RESURRECTION" Jean-Pierre Jeunet, the visually innovative director of "City of Lost Children," takes over, and in this fourth chapter, Sigourney Weaver's character has literally been resurrected. Winona Ryder is also on board. Nov. 26.
 
"FLUBBER" Robin Williams (in the Fred MacMurray role) stars in another remake of a 60's Disney hit. How much baby-boom nostalgia can the market bear? Nov. 26.
 
"ILLTOWN" In Nick Gomez's urban drama, a drug deal goes wrong. With Lili Taylor, Kevin Corrigan and Michael Rapaport. Nov. 26.
 
"RED CORNER" Richard Gere is a lawyer framed for murder while on a business trip to China. Jon Avnet directed. Nov. 26.
 
"THE NUTCRACKER PRINCE" From Imax, a 3-D version of the E. T. A. Hoffmann story that is most familiar in its ballet version, directed by Christine Edzard and starring Miriam Margolyes. Nov. 27.
 
December
 
"OFFICE KILLER" The artist Cindy Sherman directed this story of an about-to-be-unemployed copy editor who resorts to murder to keep her job. Dec. 3.
 
"BENT" Martin Sherman's searing drama about the Nazi persecution of homosexuals stars Clive Owens and Brian Webber as lovers on the run and features Mick Jagger as an androgynous club owner. Dec. 5.
 
* "AMISTAD" In his most serious film since "Schindler's List," Steven Spielberg takes on the true story of a mutiny on a Cuban slave ship in 1839 in which 53 Africans gained their freedom only to be captured off the New England coast and tried for murder. With Djimon Hounsou as Cinque, the leader of the rebellion, Morgan Freeman (an abolitionist), Anthony Hopkins (former President John Quincy Adams), Nigel Hawthorne (President Martin Van Buren) and Matthew McConaughey (the Africans' defense lawyer). Dec. 12.
 
* "DECONSTRUCTING HARRY" Woody Allen's new comedy has the usual stellar cast (Mr. Allen, Kirstie Alley, Bob Balaban, Eric Bogosian, Billy Crystal, Mariel Hemingway, Julia Louis-Dreyfus, Demi Moore, Elisabeth Shue, Stanley Tucci and Robin Williams). Set (where else?) in Manhattan, among the literati. Dec. 12.
 
"SCREAM 2" The inevitable sequel to Wes Craven's teen-age horror blockbuster is a pre-Christmas goody for screamers. Dec. 12.
 
* "SPHERE" Barry Levinson directed this science-fiction thriller based on Michael Crichton's best seller about a psychologist (Dustin Hoffman) summoned as part of a team to investigate an alien craft submerged on the ocean floor. Terror grips the crew as their worst fears are physically manifested in a claustrophobic environment. With Sharon Stone as a marine biologist and Samuel L. Jackson as a mathematician. Dec. 12.
 
* "THE HORSE WHISPERER" Robert Redford directed and stars in the film adaptation of Nicholas Evans's novel about a 14-year-old girl (Scarlett Johansson), who is traumatized by a terrible riding accident. Her concerned mother (Kristin Scott Thomas) sends the girl and her horse to Montana to work with Tom Booker (Mr. Redford), a legendary "horse whisperer" (someone with a gift for curing troubled horses). Dec. 19.
 
"THE MIGHTY" Adapted from a novel by Rodman Philbrick, the inspirational comedy explores the friendship between adolescent outcasts: giant, shy, slow-witted Maxwell, and tiny, fearless Kevin (Kieran Culkin), a genius in leg braces. Sharon Stone is a plain, Middle Western mom. Dec. 19.
 
* "TITANIC" The maritime disaster (and favorite pop-culture metaphor for the folly of grandiose aspiration) that won't die is re-imagined, at a cost of nearly $200 million. Prominent in its web of stories is the love affair between an aristocrat (Kate Winslet) and a passenger in steerage (Leonardo DiCaprio). Written and directed by James Cameron, it will do its rumbling, groaning best to plunge you under the ice with the ill-fated ship. Dec. 19.
 
"TOMORROW NEVER DIES" Pierce Brosnan returns as Agent 007, and Jonathan Pryce is the bad guy in the 18th installment of James Bond on film. Dec. 19.
 
"THE WINTER GUEST" It's the coldest day of the year in a seaside Scottish town, and a widowed photographer (Emma Thompson) receives a surprise visit from her strong-willed mother (Phyllida Law, Ms. Thompson's real-life mother, who resembles her uncannily). Their confrontations are interwoven with the doings of other residents. Talky but deep evocation of life's passages. Alan Rickman's directorial debut. Dec. 19.
 
* "THE SWEET HEREAFTER" The Canadian filmmaker Atom Egoyan makes a huge artistic leap ahead in his adaptation of a novel by Russell Banks. Ian Holm is a greedy lawyer who visits a small town in British Columbia that is racked with grief after a schoolbus accident has killed many of its children. The dramas of individual townspeople are hauntingly folded into the story of the Pied Piper of Hamelin, which is read in flashback by a teen-age survivor of the accident (Sarah Polley). The story touches on the deepest questions of faith and accountability in those places where disaster strikes seemingly at random. Dec. 24.
 
"AFTERGLOW" Alan Rudolph's first film since "Mrs. Parker and the Vicious Circle" is a moody marital drama set in Montreal. With Nick Nolte, Julie Christie (as a fading B-movie star), Lara Flynn Boyle and Jonny Lee Miller. Dec. 25.
 
* "THE BIG LEBOWSKI" Fresh from the success of "Fargo," the Coen brothers come back with a comedy of mistaken identity, as a bowling fanatic is taken for a millionaire. Expect bold genre-bending. With Jeff Bridges, John Goodman, Julianne Moore, Steve Buscemi and John Turturro. Dec. 25.
 
"FOR RICHER OR POORER" A shady real estate salesman (Tim Allen) and his wife (Kirstie Alley) pose as an Amish couple to escape the I.R.S. A comedy. Dec. 25.
 
"GOOD WILL HUNTING" Matt Damon is a young mathematics genius from South Boston, Robin Williams the therapist who helps him when he runs afoul of the law. Directed by Gus Van Sant. Dec. 25.
 
* "JACKIE BROWN" Quentin Tarantino's first full-length film since "Pulp Fiction" has a lot to live up to. This adaptation of Elmore Leonard's novel "Rum Punch" stars the 70's blaxploitation star Pam Grier as a flight attendant who smuggles money into the country for an illegal arms dealer. With Samuel L. Jackson, Robert Forster, Bridget Fonda, Robert De Niro and Michael Keaton. Dec. 25.
 
* "KUNDUN" "The Last Temptation of Buddha"? Not to be confused with Brad Pitt's Tibetan adventure, Martin Scorsese's Himalayan odyssey recounts more fully the life of the person who was recognized in 1937, at age 2, to be the 14th incarnation of the Dalai Lama, the Buddha of Compassion. The film chronicles his early life, through the Chinese invasion of Tibet and his exile in India, featuring a cast of unknowns including Tibetan monks. Dec. 25.
 
* "MA VIE EN ROSE" What should parents do when their 7-year-old son (Georges du Frense, in a remarkable star turn) insists that he's a girl who plans one day to marry a classmate who happens to be the son of Daddy's boss? Done lightly (including fantasy sequences) but with an edge. Dec. 25.
 
"MR. MAGOO" Leslie Nielsen appears as the famous cartoon character. Dec. 25.
 
"MOUSE HUNT" Two hapless brothers (Nathan Lane and the British comic Lee Evans) inherit a dilapidated mansion that turns out to be an architectural masterpiece. But they have to get rid of its longtime tenant, an extremely wily rodent. Dec. 25.
 
"OLD FRIENDS" Can three New York eccentrics find harmony on a road trip to Baltimore? Jack Nicholson is a bitter novelist, Helen Hunt a waitress and single mother and Greg Kinnear a gay artist recovering from a vicious bashing. James L. Brooks directed the romantic comedy. Dec. 25.
 
"THE POSTMAN" Kevin Costner, who directed and stars, returns to the Gary Cooper mode in a drama set in a crumbling post apocalypse America ruled by a tyrannical general and his army. Mr. Costner, a man called the Postman, wanders into an isolated town in the Northwest and inspires the people to fight back. With Will Patton. Dec. 25.
 
* "THE BOXER" The credentials of this Irish drama speak for themselves. Jim Sheridan ("In the Name of the Father") directed. Daniel Day-Lewis stars as an Irish fighter released from prison after 14 years. Emily Watson, in her first major role since "Breaking the Waves," is his former love. He finds trouble around every corner. Dec. 31.
 
"GREAT EXPECTATIONS" It worked with "Clueless," which updated Jane Austen, so why not try it again? The Dickens novel is now set in contemporary New York and stars Ethan Hawke as an aspiring artist. With Gwyneth Paltrow as Estella and Anne Bancroft as the Miss Havisham character (renamed Nora Dinsmoore). With Robert De Niro. Dec. 31.
 
Early 1998
"AMERICAN HISTORY X" Edward Norton stars in a heavy drama about a bigot struggling to reform himself and his violence-scarred family.
 
"BLUES BROTHERS 2000" Those funky would-be soul men are back, with John Goodman standing in for John Belushi.
 
"DARK CITY" William Hurt is a man who discovers that his memories and reality are artificial creations in this thriller.
 
"FEAR AND LOATHING IN LAS VEGAS"
Only a director as fearless as Terry Gilliam would grab hold of Hunter S. Thompson's comic-paranoid chronicle of outrageous excess in the world capital of glitz. With Johnny Depp, Harry Dean Stanton, Ellen Barkin, Cameron Diaz and James Woods.
 
"LOST IN SPACE" Space adventure inspired by the old TV series. With Gary Oldman, William Hurt, Matt LeBlanc and Mimi Rogers.
 
"MERCURY FALLING" Bruce Willis is an F.B.I. agent on the run to protect an autistic boy from the Government after he inadvertently gains access to top-secret files.
 
"MRS. DALLOWAY" The Virginia Woolf novel, full of very British themes, has been adapted by the Dutch filmmaker Marleen Gorris ("Antonia's Line"). Starring Vanessa Redgrave, Natascha McElhone, Rupert Graves and Michael Kitchen.
 
"NIL BY MOUTH" Gary Oldman's directorial debut won Kathy Burke the best actress award at the Cannes Film Festival and has an original score by Eric Clapton. Inspired by Mr. Oldman's childhood in South London, it shows the bleaker side of working-class life.
 
"PRIMARY COLORS" The nasty Bill Clinton-inspired novel by Anonymous is now a comedy-drama directed by Mike Nichols with a screenplay by Elaine May. It's easy to imagine Emma Thompson as First Lady, but John Travolta as President? With Kathy Bates and Billy Bob Thornton.
 
"SAVING PRIVATE RYAN" A World War II drama directed by Steven Spielberg and starring Tom Hanks. Start anticipating.
 
"THE TRUMAN SHOW" Jim Carrey, in his first dramatic role, is an insurance salesman who doesn't realize that his life is being filmed and broadcast to a worldwide audience 24 hours a day. Even his family are actors. Peter Weir directed.
 
"TWO GIRLS AND A GUY" James Toback wrote and directed this story about two women (Heather Graham and Natasha Gregson Wagner), each of whom believes she has been carrying on a monogamous relationship with the same man (Robert Downey Jr.).
 
"WAG THE DOG" A White House spin doctor (Robert De Niro) and a Hollywood producer (Dustin Hoffman) team to manufacture a war. The credits are juicy. Barry Levinson directed, and David Mamet and Hilary Henkin wrote. With Anne Heche, Woody Harrelson, Denis Leary and Willie Nelson.

HEADLINE: Down by the Riverside

BYLINE: By William Grimes; William Grimes is an arts reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:

The New York Waterfront
 Evolution and Building Culture
 of the Port and Harbor.
 Edited by Kevin Bone.
 Illustrated. 280 pp. New York:
 The Monacelli Press. Paper, $35. 
 In 1870, a naval engineer, Ralph Aston, submitted a design to New York City's newly created Department of Docks. Executed in delicate pastel colors, it envisioned a Manhattan waterfront devoted equally to commerce and leisure. A dense, sawtooth arrangement of piers, drydocks and boatyards would wrap around the lower third of Manhattan, but spaced at regular intervals would be a chain of seven small parks, each with its own boathouse, baths and steamboat landing. The Aston plan was never adopted. Throughout the city's history, the demands of commerce and transport have been paramount, and as a result, the residents of New York, a city defined by rivers, wetlands and ocean, have a surprisingly distant relationship with their own waterfront.
The authors of the essays in "The New York Waterfront: Evolution and Building Culture of the Port and Harbor" want New Yorkers to take a close look at the city's "forgotten edge," a sorry fringe of derelict structures that, the authors say, represents one of the country's great opportunities in urban planning. "Today we are at a decisive point," Donald Squires and Kevin Bone write in the book's first essay. "Should the port facilities be restored in the hopes of reinvigorating commercial and industrial use of the harbor, or should we pursue a course that seeks to make the harbor into a useful natural resource suitable for a wide variety of civic purposes, like recreation?" The book does not answer the question. Instead, in six essays by architects, historians, teachers and students associated with Cooper Union, it offers a historical framework for debating the future of the waterfront and, in documenting the great engineering projects of the past, lays down a challenge to the city.
Before the Department of Docks, under Gen. George B. McClellan, adopted a plan in 1871 to encircle Manhattan with a masonry river wall and wooden piers, waterfront development moved in spasms. Peter Stuyvesant established the first pier at the foot of present-day Pearl and Broad Streets in the 1640's, and citizens were given land grants for carrying out waterfront improvements. By 1800, most of the tip of Manhattan was ringed with bulkhead and landfill. The arrival of steamships in 1807 and the opening of the Erie Canal in 1825 turned New York into the country's leading port. By 1853, the waterfront bristled with 112 piers, but a welter of often conflicting agencies ruled it. By 1870, it consisted of "mean, rotten and dilapidated wooden wharves," The New York Times complained, "the abode of rats and the hiding places of river-thieves."
The creation of the Department of Docks ushered in the era of municipal planning, and the harbor became a laboratory for experimenting with new maritime techniques and materials: "At the peak of port activity, thousands of harbor structures were built. . . . Virtually every foot of shoreline was occupied by some kind of maritime building: basins, docks, piers, wharves and sea walls, as well as the headquarters of traders, haulers, shipbuilders, blacksmiths, rope makers, riggers, oyster merchants, brewers, carpenters and all other conceivable maritime support trades."
Decline set in in the 1930's, as the automobile eliminated ferry traffic and container ships bypassed New York for New Jersey. Today the waterfront has reverted to its condition before 1870. "One of the greatest urban planning opportunities in the world lies sterile, fallow and crumbling," the authors write.
Change is stirring. The book's final two essays review several waterfront projects, some of them already under way, notably Route 9A, the offspring of Westway, which will result in a five-mile boulevard along the Hudson, divided by a median and flanked by a walkway and bicycle paths. A companion project, the Hudson River Waterfront Park, will complement Route 9A with a 270-acre strip running for four miles between the river and the new road. Across the East River from the United Nations, ground has been broken for Queens West, a 74-acre mixed-use development. Future plans range from Donald Trump's proposed Riverside South development on the West Side to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's recent proposal to create a container-cargo superport in Brooklyn with a rail-freight tunnel to New Jersey.
But the only municipal blueprint for the waterfront is the Comprehensive Waterfront Plan, adopted in 1992. Tentatively and tellingly described as a "discussion document," it calls for a bit of everything: port revitalization, parks, open spaces, public access to the water, housing and commercial activity. A series of follow-up studies by the Parks Department envisions an "emerald necklace" of parks and bicycle paths ringing Manhattan.
Will any of this happen? The city's civic culture, riven by small, entrenched interest groups with a genius for spiking any project, affords small hope that the city could ever plan on a scale to equal the Department of Docks. In his introduction, Bone states that one purpose of "The New York Waterfront" is to "inspire a quest for the kind of greatness in public works that has distinguished New York City in the past." But in the late 20th century, the authors conclude, greatness may be too much to ask. We are well into the age of small steps rather than great leaps.

SECTION: Section 6; Page 40; Column 3; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 988 words

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Show Me the Money

BYLINE: By John Tierney 

 BODY:
"The Millionaire Next Door" has created an unsettling mystery for New Yorkers. The book, which has been on the New York Times best-seller list for more than seven months, describes the results of the most comprehensive research ever done on America's wealthy. It reports that the typical millionaire is a self-made man who owns a small business, lives in a $320,000 home and has never spent more than $140 for a pair of shoes, $235 for a watch or $399 for a suit.
The mystery, of course, is, next door to whom? Manhattan is lousy with millionaires, but who has ever spotted one of these guys from the book? Last year it was reported that Si Newhouse, the chairman of Conde Nast Publications, had economized by buying a Ford Taurus, but the news seemed so aberrant that it triggered widespread panic about the future of the magazine industry (especially among the editors who submit expense accounts to Newhouse). 
 Are there hordes of rich tightwads hiding in Manhattan? Not according to the experts I consulted at a shrine of capitalism, the plaza of the World Financial Center, on a balmy evening when thousands of traders and investment bankers were drinking, counting their winnings and gazing lustfully at the large yachts moored along the Hudson River. They reacted incredulously when I described the typical attributes of the "Millionaire Next Door."
"Where is this guy from, Kansas?"
"He's not on my floor. Where in New York could you find a suit for $400?"
"Everyone in my office is a millionaire, and the worst they'll drive is a low-end BMW."
"Well, a lot of the millionaires on the trading floor do dress like slobs. But their watches start at $2,000."
"Maybe there are some millionaires like that. But remember, these days a million is, like, nothing."
Finally, though, I found a broker, Jeff White, who reported multiple sightings. "You won't see this type working on Wall Street," he explained, "and he may not live in Manhattan, but we do see him among our clients. I've been amazed to discover that multimillionaires will come to investment seminars just to get the free pens and legal pads."
This was the same surprising discovery that the book's authors, Thomas Stanley and William Danko, originally made in 1973 when they first interviewed a group of people worth more than $10 million apiece. Stanley and Danko, marketing researchers at the State University of New York in Albany, rented a penthouse on the Upper East Side and hired gourmet-food designers to supply four kinds of pate and a case of fine Bordeaux. When the first decamillionaire arrived, he turned down the Bordeaux by explaining that he drank two kinds of beer: "free and Budweiser." The other decamillionaires shared his gourmet instincts. Not one of them touched the pates.
Why is it surprising to discover that typical millionaires are so . . . typical? One reason is they keep a low profile -- with their budgets, they don't get out a lot. But it's also because the popular image of the millionaire comes from Manhattan, which is the last place most self-made millionaires want to live. They may make their fortunes in New York -- Stanley and Danko found an exceptional number of Russian and Hungarian immigrants who have become rich here in unglamorous businesses like janitorial services -- but they're still bridge and tunnel people at heart. They live in the other boroughs and the suburbs because they can't stand frittering away their hard-earned money here.
Scrimping may be the key to wealth elsewhere, but here the traditional secrets to the good life have been skimming and scamming: skimming a percentage of the riches flowing through Wall Street and corporate headquarters, scamming to put other people's money to your personal use. The city's great high rollers are the members of the expense-account class, who provide themselves with meals, box seats, corporate cars and apartments by spending the money of their shareholders -- many of whom are those tightwad millionaires living elsewhere in America.
It may seem unfair that these frugal souls end up subsidizing profligate Manhattanites, but they themselves often choose to do it directly, because many of them voluntarily send checks to their own children here. "These millionaires have money but no status," Stanley says, "so they'll pay for their children to get it by subsidizing them to live in Manhattan. A scrap-metal dealer in Cleveland will provide financial aid to a child who's working at a low-paying, prestigious job in Manhattan -- a writer, a medical researcher, an art historian, a lawyer at a nonprofit group. And that child is not going to be as frugal as his or her parent, because it's much easier to spend other people's money. We've found that people who inherit money spend much more on a car and a home than people who make it themselves."
This is a good deal for New York in some ways, because the infusions of cash support the creators of the city's culture and style. But sometimes these high-minded children are inspired to dabble in public policy, and their perspective on finance creates problems. Some of New York's greatest spending binges came at the hands of wealthy scions like Robert Moses and Nelson Rockefeller.
In practical matters, New York would be better off relying on the parents who created the wealth. I have long advocated requiring Manhattanites with trust funds to turn their voting privileges over to their parents, but until this is done (a few quibblers have raised constitutional objections) the quickest way to benefit from the parents' wisdom would be to invite them to move here.
We need a public-relations campaign -- "NY loves $$$$$$$" -- to lure these frugal millionaires here. It will be difficult to get them to splurge, but we can probably open a few wallets with the right message: "Millionaires, move next door to us. If you don't spend your money here, someone else will."

HEADLINE: Where Children Rule

 BODY:
I wanted to congratulate Nicholas D. Kristof for his article "Where Children Rule" (Aug. 17). I started primary school in Japan, came to the United States in the second grade and returned to Japan in the seventh grade. I personally never felt much difference in the level of academic content between the two systems. The emphasis definitely differed, and I learned more in the United States in some subjects and more in Japan in others. What I remember most vividly is the shock I felt when I saw a janitor, a grown man, cleaning up after us second graders for the first time. 
 When I started junior high school in the United States, I remember the pressure of suddenly growing up. Teachers stopped telling some students to work and try harder. In Japan, teachers continue to be paternalistic until the end of junior high, maybe even senior high. What a relief it was when I returned to Japan and was allowed to be a kid again.
 
Reiko Aoki
Assistant Professor of Economics State University of New York Stony Brook, N.Y.

HEADLINE: The Fall and Rise of Kilmer McCully

 BODY:
Michelle Stacey's article about Dr. McCully offered a profound and poignant commentary on a number of critical issues in scientific research ("The Fall and Rise of Kilmer McCully," Aug. 10). 
 When scientific issues are controlled by insiders with reputations and money issues at stake, there are severe consequences for both science and health. Publicly financed research support should not be a popularity contest or the result of economic forces or political dexterity at empire building. Peer review has significant limitations, and given the forces at work in science today, the press can play a vital role in assuring that important issues receive the attention they deserve. Hopefully, the issues raised in the McCully article will serve as a stimulus for sustained and extensive news coverage of controversial issues that affect the public welfare.
 
Martin Blank, Ph.D.
Reba Goodman, Ph.D.
Columbia University
College of Physicians
and Surgeons
New York

LENGTH: 1907 words

HEADLINE: Turning to 'Violence' to Kill Time

BYLINE: By JAMES BARRON 

 BODY:
FOR THE GERMAN director Wim Wenders, "The End of Violence" -- a meditation about paranoia, computer-controlled gadgetry and government nefariousness in Los Angeles that opens on Friday -- began with an unexpected delay in the long-planned production schedule for "Billion-Dollar Hotel," a high-tech thriller Mr. Wenders had developed with his friend Bono, the lead singer in the rock band U2.
"Instead of sitting around waiting," said the director, "we figured we'd rather do something." 
 Bono departed for a tour with U2. Mr. Wenders and the screenwriter Nicholas Klein, who had also been working on "Billion-Dollar Hotel," began brainstorming what Mr. Wenders came to call "our little movie that didn't need to be anything." It was, first and foremost, a vehicle for killing some time. Until "The End of Violence" picked up two real stars, Bill Pullman and Andie MacDowell. And until Mr. Wenders was invited to have its premiere come as the centerpiece of the Cannes International Film Festival last May.
But that invitation did not arrive until later. Mr. Wenders's initial conversation with Mr. Klein turned to the notion that violence has become a fact of everyday life, cutting across social and economic lines, from inner-city neighborhoods that are dominated by drug gangs to expensive communities where the cocktail-party chatter is about security guards and carjackings carried out with military precision.
So they decided to write a screenplay about violence, with one ground rule: this would be a nonviolent film -- no blood and guts just for the sake of blood and guts. "We had nightlong discussions about how to represent it," Mr. Wenders said. "When we finally said, 'What do we do now?' it almost imposed itself: where else to put it if not Los Angeles?"
Three months is how long some directors take to shoot individual scenes, not whole movies. But Mr. Klein knows how to write fast; in the 1980's, he turned out scripts on tight deadlines for weekly television shows like "MacGyver." For "The End of Violence," he spent a month at his word processor. Then he spent another month polishing the script while Mr. Wenders handled preproduction details. That left 27 days for shooting on a budget of $5 million raised by Deepak Nayar, who produced the David Lynch film "Lost Highway."
"THE TIMING SEEMED fairly preposterous," Mr. Klein said, "but that was its allure. From conception to opening in Cannes was about nine months. From, 'Hey, let's make a movie' to 'Here we are,' it was pretty fast." Mr. Wenders, who is best known for haunting films that blend traditional Hollywood forms with an ambivalence about Western culture since World War II, added, "Very fast by Hollywood standards, and I guess by any other standards."
Still, all they had originally was a theme. "Normally, you come up with a story, and inside that story, certain characters get developed according to the needs of your plot," said Mr. Wenders, who won awards at Cannes for "Paris, Texas" in 1984 and for "Wings of Desire" in 1987. "We did the opposite. We had a theme -- violence -- and we agreed that we wanted it to remain the subject, not to become the device or texture."
He and Mr. Klein made what Mr. Wenders calls "Christmas lists" of potential characters. "When we compared our lists, we kept the ones we had in common and threw out the others," Mr. Wenders said. "He had a wonderful character that he had to give up that was a voyeur, and I had a character that was a fireman."
That left several characters to flesh out, plus a story that would tie them together. One character was a NASA-trained surveillance expert who had been hired to set up a network of remote-control video surveillance cameras that would record street crime as it occurred. The cameras -- hundreds of them, on rooftops, utility poles and apartment-house marquees, with unobstructed views of dingy flophouses and shady freeway underpasses and the ability to zoom in for tight close-ups -- were supposed to eliminate violence.
The idea was that muggers and murderers would stop committing mayhem once they realized that it would be captured in living color -- meaning they might be, too. Never mind the Orwellian overtones or the fact that large-scale surveillance cameras had already been installed in downtown Baltimore, where they were credited with bringing about a drop in crime, and in Miami Beach, where they were abandoned after one year as ineffective. New York City tried similar cameras in the early 70's and dropped them after almost no arrests resulted. "The most boring viewing material on earth" was how one police official described the tapes.
Clearly, Mr. Wenders and Mr. Klein could dream up something more interesting. But they were not that far along when they worked out the other main character, a Hollywood producer named Mike Max whose specialty is state-of-the-art thrillers. When he is carjacked in an incident that may or may not have been orchestrated by the shadowy agency installing the cameras, he makes an only-in-Hollywood plea to his captors: "I want to give you a million bucks," he says. "In points."
"We were, more than anything, playing with different genres -- to some degree Hitchcock, to some degree Tarantino," Mr. Klein said. "You always face the question of to what degree do you engage in the genre and to what degree do you spoof it. As we refined the script, we started getting more and more linear and more and more plot-driven."
But first they gave Mike Max a wife, Paige -- an unhappy, unfulfilled woman whom Mike had literally put on hold once too often -- and realized that the actress they saw in the role was Ms. MacDowell. Mr. Wenders remembered her from Steven Soderbergh's "Sex, Lies and Videotape"; he was the president of the jury that honored the film at Cannes in 1989. "She took us by surprise," he recalled. "We were all totally in love with her."
Mr. Wenders said that when he called to offer Ms. MacDowell the part, there was just one problem: "I never had a script to send to her." It was still in Mr. Klein's computer.
That did not matter. "It was an opportunity for me to get to do a character I had not been seen doing," said Ms. MacDowell, whose credits include "Green Card," "Groundhog Day" and "Four Weddings and a Funeral." "It's so funny how people sometimes can have a lack of imagination. They can't imagine that you can do something until you show them that you can. They see me as this romantic comedy person, I guess."
She even liked the costumes. In one underwater shot in "The End of Violence," she wears a swimsuit that is perhaps best described as minimalist. "That bathing suit was so cheap," Ms. MacDowell said. "The woman who did the wardrobe told me she went shopping where Heidi Fleiss shops."
To play Mike Max, the filmmakers eventually settled on Mr. Pullman, who had appeared in Mr. Lynch's "Lost Highway" and as the President in "Independence Day." By coincidence, Mr. Wenders saw both films the same week. "It hit me," said the director, "that a guy who could do these two characters convincingly could be this producer character in 'The End of Violence' who really has to stretch to go from this cocky, arrogant power player to a humble human being. Bill imposed himself by that double play."
Gabriel Byrne got the part of the surveillance expert after a strange encounter at the Hollywood nightclub the Viper Room. "In the darkness of the back room," Mr. Wenders said, "I was introduced to an actor whose face I couldn't see." And Mr. Wenders hired Loren Dean, a veteran of a number of Off Off Broadway productions who claimed to have seen Mr. Wenders's "Wings of Desire" 35 times, on the strength of an audition tape.
Almost before they knew it, it was time to start shooting, but off-camera action got in the way. "I'm superstitious," Mr. Wenders said. "Any movie where we have a bad start, in my own experience, will come to a good ending." In "Kings of the Road," in 1975, he said, "we shot for three days, three full days, then we got our first report, something with the shutter of the camera was wrong; we had to go back to square one."
But "The End of Violence" was, he said, "the worst start ever." The technicians had barely set up in what was to be Mike Max's house when sirens went off -- brush fires were heading toward the neighborhood. "We had to jump in our cars and leave the place," Mr. Wenders said, "and literally five minutes later, the fire was on the other side of the street." The production was shut down for three days. "We had no other set to go to," he said."
On such a low budget, Mr. Wenders had no leeway, and the actors had commitments at the end of the 27-day shoot.
THEY WERE SHOOTING so fast that Mr. Klein found himself writing one scene without realizing that Mr. Wenders was already shooting it. "I had written a few lines, and he says, 'Would you print those out?' He looks at them and says, 'This is good.' I said, 'Where are you going with this?' He just says, 'Keep going.' I think, 'Surely he's shooting another scene now and we'll talk about it.' Then I realize that he's just shot those three sentences."
As if the rushed schedule were not vexing enough, "The End of Violence" was Mr. Wenders's first film in Cinemascope -- and the first full-length film for his director of photography, Pascal Rabaud, whose credits included music videos and commercials. "Before I knew we were shooting it, we had made that decision," Mr. Wenders said, "and soon I was seeing rushes." The wide-angle format affected the way he worked. "Scope is not just a different format," he said. "It's an altogether different way of organizing what's happening inside the frame, how you resolve a scene. I really had to learn it. The first week, I made all the mistakes you can possibly make."
The film that moviegoers will see starting this month is not the same film that was shown at Cannes; Mr. Wenders spent $500,000 -- about 10 percent of his budget -- to re-edit and remix "The End of Violence" after the Cannes screening. "We pretty much rushed it to get ready for Cannes," he said. "You have to lock your picture cut in order to have a print that can be shown in Cannes. I had this slight uneasy feeling that we had locked it a little too early. That feeling persisted, and after the screening, I went back and incorporated some changes. The film became a little shorter and a little more linear. It had been a little complicated before, unnecessarily so. So I thinned it out."
The post-premiere re-editing was something he had done before, with "Paris, Texas." "It was exactly the same," the director recalled. "We had to go to Cannes, we made it with the print the day before, we subtitled it overnight, just like 'End of Violence.' I saw it sitting in the audience."
And for Ms. MacDowell, seeing it in the audience -- that particular, hypercritical audience, filled with past Palme d'Or winners -- was "pretty intimidating."
"It was just this little film we had made," she said, "and there in the audience were all these directors I was in awe of. Not that I don't feel good about the work -- it's a good film. But I wanted to applaud them."
Mr. Wenders maintains that "The End of Violence" is not a "message" film. "It doesn't have a message that you can sum up in the end and leave the theater with," he said. "Violence is too complex an issue to put into a handy formula, pro or con."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 8; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: Ever Earnest and Funny, Ever Relevant to Youth

 BODY:
AT 81, WITH A CAREER OF more than six decades in the theater, the eminent playwright Arthur Miller is in the midst of a renaissance, especially, it seems, among directors who are almost a half century younger.
At the Signature Theater Company in New York, Mr. Miller is the subject of a yearlong retrospective involving four of his plays. The season opens in October with a revival of "The American Clock," directed by James Houghton, 38, the founder and artistic head of the Signature. 
 The following month, the Roundabout Theater Company will present a revival of "A View From the Bridge," directed by Michael Mayer, 37, and starring Anthony LaPaglia.
A production of Mr. Miller's "All My Sons," directed by Barry Edelstein, 32, ran in June at the Roundabout to critical acclaim, where it had arrived from a stint at the Williamstown Theater Festival last summer.
Another Miller play staged that season at Williamstown, the American premiere of "The Ride Down Mount Morgan," directed by Scott Elliott, 34, the artistic director of the New Group, a young New York theater company, is expected to be presented at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in the 1998-99 season.
Mr. Edelstein, Mr. Elliott and Mr. Houghton talked recently at The New York Times about the reasons for the new interest in Mr. Miller's work, especially among younger theater people. Here are excerpts from their conversation.
 
Scott Elliott. There's a great deal about Arthur that is misunderstood in this country. I think that happens any time you have your biggest success in your 30's. Americans have come to expect "Death of a Salesman" after "Death of a Salesman." Arthur continues to evolve as an artist, to experiment with form, no matter what anybody thinks. That's really what art is about.
 
Barry Edelstein. When we did "All My Sons" at Willamstown, before it moved to the Roundabout, there were dozens of apprentices working all around the theater. They're in their late teens and early 20's and very few of them had seen or read the play. I would watch these kids walk out of that theater a mess, burbling with tears. That generation has no sense of how powerful theater can be. I don't think people at that age associate going to the theater with that kind of cathartic experience.
 
Elliott. It tells you something about our educational system here, as opposed to what happens in London. We don't encourage our youngsters to understand theater or go or anything. And it's scary.
 
James Houghton. That's rooted in the hit-or-miss ethic that exists in this country. Students probably have read "Death of a Salesman" and maybe "The Crucible." They've read "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?" They're reading the hits. And they don't dig any deeper, which is really disturbing, especially if we're talking about theater students.
The consistent theme with all of our great writers is that they're constantly searching for a deeper understanding of themselves through their work and through the environment they live in. We'll go and see a whole exhibit of Picasso or Monet and appreciate each work for what it is in its part of the process, but we won't do that with the theater or writers in general.
 
Elliott. Last summer I worked at Williamstown with Jon Robin Baitz and Arthur Miller back to back on two plays that had been done elsewhere, which they were rewriting because of things they had learned from other productions. Working with Robbie and with Arthur, 50 years apart, it felt like they were both the same age.
 
Houghton. Their common bond is their passion. There's no other reason to be in the theater than for passion and a need to communicate in that form. You're not going to make money. Arthur and Robbie seem the same age because it's the same passion that feeds them both.
 
Elliott. You sit down to your lunch of pizza and beer with Arthur and you feel like you're talking to a contemporary because he has such a need to reach out to younger audiences. He wants people to come to the theater.
 
Edelstein. The thoughts he has about the world -- the way it is, the way it could be, the way it ought to be -- still agitate him as powerfully now as they did when he sat down at age 32 to write "All My Sons."
What's happening with this sudden resurgence of interest in his plays in New York is, I think, a response to the fundamental seriousness of Arthur's writing. His plays are characterized by an almost complete lack of glibness. They're very funny at times, but they're earnest. You sit in their presence and you feel there's a thoughtfulness and a gravity about them. That has, on the one hand I think, created this impression of, "Oh boy, we don't want to go there because we're going to be lectured to." But on the other hand it involves a genuineness that can be cathartic and refreshing to witness.
 
Houghton. It's why we can go back to the Greeks, why we can go back to classic drama and feel rooted to it, to something real.
 
Elliott. Arthur feels there is a relevance in his plays that can appeal to a younger audience. That is one of the reasons he's reached out to younger artists to direct his work -- he thinks that maybe they'll be able to tap into it. We're from the therapy generation. It's a very different one than the older generation of directors. But the themes he explores through all of his work are still pertinent and important today.
The beauty of what Arthur did is he said, "I'm going to do what I believe in, because it's all I know how to do, and if you like it, you don't like it, tough luck." It's what happens with every artist.
Who would have thought that Edward Albee would have a new resurgence after he went through a period where everybody was sort of turning their nose up at his writing? All of a sudden, people are saying it's brilliant again.
 
Edelstein. We're living now, I hope, at the end of a moment that's been so saturated with irony that you can't mean anything, you can't say anything without it being undercut or spun around into something glib and dripping with cynicism. I think people are hungry once again for something that actually means something.
 
Houghton. The odd turn of events in recent years is such that now it's almost hip to go back to our writers.
 
Elliott. You know why? Because the people who could be the playwrights of our next century are writing movies. You can't make a living in the theater. You have to do it in between. And you can be sure that in 50 years they're going to be doing "An American Daughter" by Wendy Wasserstein and "Sex and Longing" by Christopher Durang to great accolades. Because those plays are going to be representative of an era of theater that happened now, that our critical environment loathes to accept. That same thing seems to be happening today with people like Albee and Miller.
 
Houghton. If you're going to say, "O.K., I'll see Barry's production of 'All My Sons,' and it better be good," it puts an incredible amount of pressure, and the wrong kind, on all the artists involved. I think the overall theater audience tends to be defined by a very small percentage of the theater -- the Broadway theater-going audience. And this notion of having to see a hit comes about because Broadway is a theater of economics. All theater is, but hopefully, as you move along the scale, it becomes less about economics and more about balancing. It's true throughout our regional theater as well. We can't define our audience using just one aspect of the theater.
 
Edelstein. That's a very good point. It isn't productive to look at what's happening between 42d Street and 50th Street as in some way representative of the entire country's theater-going needs.
 
Houghton. It's an insult, not only to the audience but to all the artists who are working beyond 42d Street, across the country. Without those people there will be no new plays, there will be no rush of new talent bubbling to the surface. The theater that is not Broadway must absolutely be supported, or else we're going to lose our artists completely. They'll all move, because they economically must, to television and film.
 
Elliott. Unfortunately, I think the economics once again speak to it. It's very expensive to go to the theater. In the smaller theaters like our own, we try to keep ticket prices low for that reason, although we hurt ourselves in the meantime because we don't charge as much as we could. We set them low because one of the philosophies we have is to try to keep younger people in the theater. I don't think that they don't want to go or that they're not curious or don't want to explore it. But when it comes to laying down bucks like that, it's hard.
 
Edelstein. It's odd to be at the age we are and feel like dinosaurs. Which is why Arthur's passion is such an inspiration. When he started out, it was hugely different. To hear him tell stories about Boston tryouts and endless periods of development -- it's shocking how the landscape has changed.
 
Houghton. It's interesting though. When I worked with Horton Foote -- they're contemporaries -- Horton and I talked about that and this thriving time when Broadway was everything and plays were all over the place. And he sort of nipped that in the bud right away. He said, "Yeah, there were lots of plays, but there were lots of really bad plays." Still, there were more opportunities, that's for sure.
 
Elliott. But that's a good thing. What's bad and what's good? A lot of people tell me something's bad and I'll go see it and think it was great. It's all relative. There should be that choice.
 
Houghton. Absolutely. But my point is that it's all perspective. Our perspective on what was then is very different. They were living it and struggling with it and, frankly, people have complained about it for years. "Theater's about to die. Theater's dead." People have been saying that since it was created, since the guys in the cave were banging stones.
Yet everyone in the business knows there's nothing more special about a moment that works in the theater. It's never about the set or the auditorium. It's about the human element, people affecting one another. When it gets down to those bare bones, which is as bare as it gets, that is the theater. That's why it takes us to a place that's different from what happens with movies.
 
Elliott. Well, we're very vulnerable.
Houghton. We're extremely vulnerable, and it's a living, breathing moment, never to be repeated in the same way.
 
Edelstein. There is a sense of fragility in Arthur's plays that connects to what you both are saying about the vulnerability of the theater itself. In Arthur's plays, wonder is a very big idea. Willy Loman talks about how extraordinary certain things are. He keeps saying, "Isn't that remarkable? Isn't that remarkable?" There's a simple sense that human existence is a miraculous thing.
I think that Arthur, for all of his ferocious intellect, has a very childlike and awesome sense that a human being is a marvel. It's at the core of all of his plays and at the core of all great art -- a simple perception that life is a miraculous thing.
There was a big tribute to him not long ago at the Roundabout and one of those who spoke was the British director Nicholas Hytner, who said about Arthur, "In England we revere him as one step above God and one step below Shakespeare." The wonderful thing is that when you meet the man, he does not wear the mantle of Mosaic wisdom. He's a theater guy.
 
Houghton. If he did, his plays would not speak to us.

HEADLINE: Apartment Seller Picks a Different Approach

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WANT to own your own home? Here's how! Send $100 and a statement convincing me that you are the owner of this dream home. The winner gets: a spacious, sunny 1 bedroom garden apartment in Hartsdale, w/private entrance, designer ELK, DR, terrace, pool, free parking, pets welcome, walk to shopping and train, quiet neighborhood, cozy retreat nestled amidst ample cultural and social events, 35 minutes from mid-town NYC.
"To be considered, please include certified check for $100 made payable to Big Dreamz, your name, address, tel. no. and a SASE, with your entry and mail to Big Dreamz -- Contest Web Site. 
 "You must demonstrate income to cover maintenance fees and pass board interview. Deadline to receive your entry is Sept. 20. Winner will be chosen on Sept. 27, 1997."
This is the text of a flier displayed at the 42d Street Deli at the Avenue of the Americas and 42d Street in Manhattan.
It was time to sell, but instead of listing her co-op apartment with an agent, Susan E. Cifelli, a marketing executive, came up with an unusual plan.
"Selling it in the conventional way was out," she said.
"I bought the co-op on Oct. 23, 1987, the height of the market, so I paid a top price, $98,500. Then came a big remodeling job, putting in a modern kitchen, redoing the floors, putting down new wall-to-wall carpeting and installing a brand new water heater to the tune of an additional $30,000. Now it's time for me to move on, but I know I can't get my money out today."
Observing that in 1988 prices for co-ops began to decline, Miss Cifelli said:
"And they continued the slide until this year. Although the market is now rebounding, it is still below 1987 levels, so I started exploring other ways to sell the place."
When she bought the apartment, she was 29, a newly transferred executive.
"I came from New England Telephone Company, a subsidiary of Nynex, in Boston," she said. "In college I majored in economics and Italian and from there I went into a very good management training program at New England Telephone. To my surprise, I found I had an affinity for computers and I was able to develop key technical skills on the job.
"Eventually, I was made responsible for planning, implementing a fully automated department. I grew up in Yorktown. And when Nynex offered me a promotion in the corporate internal auditing department in White Plains, as associate director of systems and technology, it was both a good career move and a good move personally."
She continued: "Nynex gave me all sorts of incentives in a generous relocation package, including moving expenses, closing costs and a special working-in-Westchester enhancement, because Westchester is more expensive than Boston."
She started her new job in June 1987 and lived in a hotel for several months before she found an apartment that suited her.
"The rooms are large and sunny," she said. "The building is only three stories high, set in nicely landscaped grounds. There's a pool, and I have a terrace. I've been very happy in it.
"The neighborhood is quiet, and the neighbors are nice, but now I can afford to buy a house. And that's my dream, to have a house with a huge garden. I love to garden."
By chance, while watching the movie "Spitfire Grill," she said she found the way to sell her apartment .
"It was one of those rare moments when I realized I had the right solution. The movie gave me the idea for a contest, which would not only raise the money for my house, but it would make someone else's dreams come true, someone who otherwise could never afford to own a home."
The first item on the agenda was obtaining legal advice. "I ran the concept by my attorney, and he agreed to research the legalities of the project," she said. "After contacting various state and municipal agencies regarding possible laws or regulations preventing such a contest, he gave me the go-ahead."
Initially, Miss Cifelli planned to use only print advertising. "I knew it would be very expensive to have a Web site developed, but my dad encouraged me to develop one myself."
She started researching the most logical place for her site and chose America Online.
"I wanted to build a commercial site, and when I called America Online, I got a very knowledgeable support engineer who told me about America Online Press, how it worked and how to find it on the Web. I was amazed at how straightforward and intuitive it was. Creating my first page was no more complicated than creating a text document. At first, I didn't think beyond having a Web page, but soon the idea grew into a site. I wanted to have other things besides the details of the contest, like music, art, poetry to attract people to my site."
Finally, after many failures to go on line and a period of frustration, Miss Cifelli had a successful launch of her Web site, named Big Dreamz. "I then filed a listing request with each of the major search engines, companies like Yahoo that supply technical information about Web sites, to make sure that someone looking for Big Dreamz could find me. I also had my contest fliers distributed in delis and places where lottery tickets are sold in Westchester and Manhattan. My goal is for 5,000 entries."
The launch took place on June 27. The winner is to be selected by lottery on Sept. 27. By Aug. 26, Miss Cifelli had received checks for $100 from 300 contestants.
Yet she remains optimistic, even buoyant. "I think there has been a very positive reaction," she said. "One of the things about lotteries is that the closer they get to the date, the more people line up to take a chance. The dynamics of my Big Dreamz contest are the same. I'm expecting activity to really heat up now."
For the drawing to take place, Miss Cifelli said she needs a minimum of 1,500 entries. "If I don't reach that number, I will be obligated to return all the money -- $100 to every contestant."
Now a product manager at Nynex, now Bell Atlantic, on the Avenue of the Americas in Manhattan, Miss Cifelli is in charge of developing and carrying out marketing initiatives to meet annual revenue commitments of $25 million.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
A Mixed-Housing Program to Stabilize Urban Areas

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
OVER the last year neat clusters of mixed-income one- and two-family homes have sprouted in cities across New Jersey, thanks to the state's $240 million Urban Homeownership Program.
The program pairs state subsidies with public and private construction financing to produce low- and moderate-income and market-rate housing on sites in city neighborhoods. By encouraging home ownership and a mix of housing to draw buyers, including the middle class, back into cities the program seeks to stabilize urban areas and spur more development, state housing officials said. 
 In the first year of the program a total of $130 million in public and private financing has been awarded to 45 developments. While most of the projects mix market-rate housing with lower-cost units, some contain only the latter.
The projects now in various stages of development will produce 1,342 mixed-income residences in 18 municipalities, including Lakewood, Newark and Long Branch. Of that total 486 homes will be sold at market rates and 856 will be sold to low- and moderate-income families -- those earning 50 to 80 percent of their area's median incomes. The total will also include 240 rental units in two-family houses.
Ultimately, the program -- the largest initiative under the Whitman administration's 1995 housing policy -- is expected to produce 2,250 homes over the next three years, according to data from the New Jersey Housing Mortgage Finance Agency, the semi-public arm of the Department of Community Affairs, which oversees the state's housing. The mortgage agency administers the program -- the state's first attempt at promoting home ownership in cities, where ownership rates are low.
"Home ownership is the critical piece in taking back these neighborhoods," said Timothy J. Touhey, executive director of the state mortgage agency. In providing construction incentives to builders to mix market-rate and lower-cost units the hope is that "a market can be created that can sustain private investment," Mr. Touhey added, noting that partnering with private lenders "evenly spreads the risk."
For banks, sharing in the financing of such projects helps them fulfill their obligation under the Federal Community Reinvestment Act, which requires lenders to meet the credit needs of the communities they serve.
Under the program the state mortgage agency provides half of the construction financing for each project from its administrative funds or, if necessary, through the sale of bonds. The other half comes from one of 14 private lenders participating in the program.
Moreover, the state provides $25,000 to $45,000, respectively, in subsidies for each low- and moderate-income home, keeping prices down. The state also provides up to $25,000 in subsidies for market-rate units in nine cities that are part of the administration's Urban Initiative, which channels resources to marginal neighborhoods in those municipalities.
Thirty-year, fixed-rate mortgages, at a 5 percent interest rate with zero points and 3 to 5 percent down, are also being offered to qualified buyers by the state's mortgage finance agency through more than 75 lenders.
The lower-cost units must be reserved for low- and moderate-income buyers for 10 years. In some cases, in municipalities where the state has determined that there is a need to increase the amount of low- and moderate-income housing, the term has been extended to 30 years.
When the house is first sold profits from appreciation are shared equally with the state as a way for it to recoup its investment. The same is true for the subsidized market-rate units.
Most developers view the program favorably, saying it offers a kind of "one-stop shopping" since construction financing, subsidies to underwrite the lower-cost units and mortgages to buyers can be obtained in a single process. Some, however, would like to see the program modified so that, among other things, the profit-sharing provision on the sale of units is removed, making the units more marketable.
Affordable housing advocates also have some concerns. "Generally, there is an agreement that promoting a mix of affordable and market-rate housing will help revitalize urban areas," said Rick Sauer, associate director of the Affordable Housing Network, a Trenton-based organization that represents private and nonprofit developers of low- and moderate-income housing. "But we question the use of the state's limited pool of public funds to subsidize market-rate units that do not become a permanent part of the affordable housing stock."
MR. SAUER said that although members of his group were using the program because it is a key financing source, "there needs to be a multiprong strategy" to reviving the state's cities.
Among the larger projects financed under the program is Forest Park at Lakewood. Its developer received $13.6 million in construction financing and $2 million in state subsidies to build 120 mixed-income town houses, with three to five bedrooms each on Pine Street in an area of this Monmouth County community dotted with vacant land and older houses.
Once a chicken farm, the Pine Street site was approved three years ago for all market-rate town houses, which never got built "because the market was not there," said Christiana Foglio, president of Community Investment Strategies, a New Brunswick-based consulting and development company. Her concern is working with the developer, Pine Street Developers of Lakewood, on the Forest Park project.
Receiving the state subsidies "changed this from a nonworkable to a workable project," said Ms. Foglio. The idea was that once "we created a neighborhood we could attract buyers for the market-rate units," she added.
Forest Park ultimately will contain, 45 market-rate town houses, each with 2,000 square feet of space, and 75 low- and moderate-income units, each with 1,800 square feet of space. Prices range from $69,500 for the lower-income residences to $123,750 for the market-rate models.
So far 22 houses have been sold and contracts have been signed on 20 more, said Ms. Foglio. The project already has had an economic ripple effect, she added, pointing to it as proof renewed developer interest on nearby vacant parcels.
Ms. Foglio's firm together with Procida Realty and Construction Corporation of the Bronx was awarded $1.8 million in construction financing and $375,000 in state subsidies to develop 18 mixed-income homes on scattered sites in Long Branch. Construction on the three-bedroom homes, with space ranging from 1,400 to 1,500 square feet, is to start in the spring of 1998. Sale prices are to start at $55,000 for the lower-income units and range up to $100,000 for the market-rate units.
In Newark, $4.2 million in construction financing and $1.35 million in state subsidies are being used to build Hilltop Gardens, comprising 25 two-family homes and 9 single-family houses. The project also received a five-year abatement on property taxes from the city.
The homes are now rising on four long-dormant acres on 18th Avenue in the city's Central Ward, the site of the 1960's racial riots. Twenty percent are being sold at market rates, with the rest being made available to families with low and moderate incomes. United Metropolitan Ministries, a group of four local churches, is developing the project. It is being constructed by America's Dream Homes of West Paterson.
"Without this program," said Paul R. DeBellis, the company's president, "the nonprofit developer would not have been able to secure construction financing from a bank alone."
The two-family homes contain an 800-square-foot two-bedroom unit topped by a three-bedroom apartment with 1,000 square feet. The one-family houses have three bedrooms and 1,200 square feet of space. Sale prices range from $79,900 to $124,900. Average monthly rents for the apartments are $600.
So far, 23 of the houses at the project have been sold. Mr. DeBellis said the tax abatement together with the state subsidies and mortgage financing make the project attractive to buyers of all incomes.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Forest Park at Lakewood, left, will have 125 mixed income town houses. Hilltop Gardens in Newark will have 25 two-family and 9 detached homes. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);
