HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/ Valley Stream, L.I.;
Family-Centered and Hugging Queens

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
WITH nearly 34,000 residents living along its tightly packed streets of one-family houses on small lots, Valley Stream is the third most populous village in New York State. It is also among the more affordable communities in Nassau County, one of the most expensive housing markets in the country.
For considerably under $200,000, a compact, detached, well-maintained Cape Cod, colonial or ranch-style house, typically built in the 50's or 60's, may be purchased in this middle-income, low-to-the-horizon area where public schools send about 90 percent of graduates on to higher education. 
 Local real estate brokers say good schools -- there are three high schools to choose from -- and a short commute to the city from the village's two Long Island Rail Road stations are key attractions. Young families, often from Queens and Brooklyn, are frequent buyers.
"The key selling point is proximity to Manhattan while still being on Long Island," said Robert R. Miller, broker-owner of Century 21 Miller and Miller in Valley Stream.
Villagers speak of amiable, family-centered neighborhoods where children are once more much in evidence, as they were during the village's suburban boom time 40 years ago.
But residents pay a price for living east of Queens, which abuts the village. Property taxes are more than twice those west of the border. "They feel suburban living is better for their families, so they are willing to pay higher taxes," said Dorothy L. Potter, broker-owner of Valley Stream Realty and a village resident for 33 years.
MAYOR JIM DARCY, a villager since the age of 2, said higher taxes must be weighed against the benefits of living in an intact hometown with a vivid history, where people care enough to contribute, as they did this summer, toward medical expenses for a native son with leukemia.
A large number of civic and service groups, village sports programs including midget football, two local papers -- The Valley Stream MAILeader and The Valley Stream Herald -- and a local chamber of commerce intent on revitalizing downtown areas add energy and texture to village life.
While single-family detached homes predominate, there are some other housing choices.
At the 89-unit Gibson Gardens Cooperative, a brick complex near the Valley Stream railroad station, the asking price for a two-bedroom co-op is $65,000, with monthly maintenance of $900.
One-bedroom units are $50,000, with maintenance of $780. Sponsor-owned units rent for $1,200 and $1,000, respectively.
The average cost of a three-bedroom unit in the smattering of condominium units in the village is about $155,000.
The main village-owned recreation area, the 36-acre Hendrickson Park, has three outdoor swimming pools, a fitness trail, tennis and handball courts and lakeside promenades. Seasonal pool passes are $125 for a family and $55 for single adults.
THE nine-acre Barrett Park is in the 1920's vintage Gibson neighborhood south of Sunrise Highway. (East of it is the North Woodmere section, which juts out into Woodmere in the shape of a musical note.)
The park has two baseball fields, a playground, a roller hockey ring and handball and basketball courts. The 13-acre Firemen's Memorial Park has baseball and football fields and is a center for local sports teams. These parks are free for village residents.
The 97-acre Valley Stream State Park, which is partially in the village, has basketball courts, softball fields, picnic tables, bike paths and walking trails. Admission is $4 a car or $39 for an annual pass.
The predominantly Republican village is in the Town of Hempstead, the home base of the powerful Nassau Republican Party. It has its own justice court but relies on the county's Fifth Precinct for police services. The police say it is a low crime area.
From May to June, street fairs are held downtown on the last Thursday of the month. A summer concert series, this year featuring the West Point band one week and the Great South Dixieland Jazz Band the next, is offered at the Village Green by Central Avenue and Sunrise Highway, where the Valley Stream Fire Department Carnival and Casino was held last month.
Small businesses and franchise outlets crowd Merrick Road, Central Avenue and Sunrise Highway.
But for serious shopping there is the 200-store Green Acres Shopping Center, at the village's southern boundary. Anchor stores include Macy's, Sears, Caldor and J. C. Penney.
Valley Stream's beginnings date to 1640, when the Dutch West India Company bought land the village now occupies from the Rockaway Indians.
In the 1840's, Robert Pagan, a local shopkeeper, led a successful effort to gain a local post office to spare residents the trip to Hempstead. Inspired by the village's valleys and streams, he coined the name Valley Stream, which was quickly adopted.
Carol C. McKenna, the president of the Valley Stream Historical Society, said the name was unique in the United States. "We are very proud of that fact," she said.
In the early 20th century, the village gained renown as a place for fast living. People called the downtown area Rum Junction. There was also Cookie Hill, a coy reference to another area's saucy reputation. And Merrick Road, which runs through the heart of the village, was dubbed the Great White Way of Nassau County.
The legendary nightclub entertainer Texas Guinan greeted customers at one of two well-known roadhouses with her trademark "Hello Sucker." Rudy Vallee and Guy Lombardo performed at the other.
The village incorporated in 1925, midway through a decade of early growth. By then, William R. Gibson, a builder of houses and apartments in the Ridgewood, Richmond Hill and Elmhurst sections of Queens, was already erecting homes for white-collar workers from the city in the neighborhood that still bears his name.
An architecturally matching Long Island Rail Road Station, paid for by Mr. Gibson in exchange for a guarantee of rail service, opened in 1929. It is also named for him.
By the mid-50's, village population was 36,000 and space was at a premium. Mayor Arthur J. Hendrickson, a titan in village history, negotiated purchase of 36 acres next to Valley Stream State Park for creation of the village park named in his honor.
Schools have always been a top priority for the village. But the organization of local public schools is a bit confusing. The Valley Stream Central High School District, one of only three high school districts on Long Island, is comprised of three high schools.
There are also three separate elementary school districts, Districts 13, 24 and 30, with a total of 10 schools.
MOST students in the village attend Valley Stream Central High School, not to be confused with the central school district. But students may now attend either of the other two high schools -- Valley Stream North and Valley Stream South -- with the permission of the district superintendent.
Combined enrollment for the elementary and secondary schools is about 8,400. The schools also serve North Valley Stream and parts of Elmont, Franklin Square, Malverne and Lynbrook.
Nearly 70 percent of the high schools' Class of 1997 graduates earned Regents diplomas.
A district program encourages students to take the most rigorous academic program appropriate for their abilities. School officials say this accounts for the high percentage of Regents diplomas. The high schools offer advanced placement programs in 16 subjects. Valley Stream Central High School teaches grades 10-12. A separate junior high school, Valley Stream Memorial, teaches grades 7-9. Valley Stream North and Valley Stream South are combined junior-senior high schools for grades 7 through 12. The district has no middle schools.
The central high school district and the three elementary districts are currently studying consolidation into a single school district or two districts for grades K-12.
"We are trying to decide the best path to take," said Martin G. Brooks, the interim superintendent of the Central High School District. He said tricky school tax questions were involved.
Overcrowding has become a problem in some elementary schools in the past four years, he said.
There are two Roman Catholic schools in the village. About 300 students attend Holy Name of Mary School.
Tuition ranges from $830 to $1,870 for nursery through pre-kindergarten, $1,870 to $3,720 for the higher grades, depending on grade and the number of students from one family attending. Outsiders in kindergarten through grade 8 pay $2,800 to $,4300.
Blessed Sacrament School has about 425 students in nursery classes through grade 8. The school has a new computer laboratory, and an extended-day program for students of working parents work is planned. Tuition for grades 1 through 8 is $2,190. Varied fees apply for nursery through kindergarten. Outsiders are charged $2,580 in kindergarten through grade 8.
Villagers always know which way the wind is blowing. When it is from the east, flight paths for John F. Kennedy International Airport shift, bringing jet noise. But east, some point out, is not the prevailing wind direction.

RESTORATION: The Pagan-Fletcher Restoration, a National Historic Site where Valley Stream history is preserved, is opened from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. on Sundays and by arrangement. That the rambling white house, with its Greek Revival facade, has survived at all is a tribute to years of effort by local preservationists led by Theodore O. Libath who stepped in to save the rundown house. "I opened my mouth," said Mr. Libath, the chairman of building restoration for the Valley Stream Historical Society, which administers the site. "I got tired of seeing nothing done." In 1977, the village purchased the house from its developer owners. By 1992, after years of fund raising, the restoration was complete. Though altered and added to over the years, the house is on the site where Robert Pagan and his wife, Ellen, settled after arriving from Scotland in about 1837. It served, variously, as a farmhouse, general store and Methodist religious center, and was enlarged by subsequent owners. A Victorian era parlor and kitchen and historical documents are on display. Admission is free. Donations are accepted.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Linked to Weehawken, N.J., Ferry;
Plans for Waterfront

 BODY:
As development grows along New Jersey's Hudson River waterfront, plans are being made to turn part of Weehawken's shoreline into a commercial and residential enclave built around an expanded ferry terminal.
Plans for the 100-acre site are being advanced by a partnership between Arcorp Properties of Weehawken and Roseland Property of Roseland, N.J. Arcorp is owned by Arthur E. Imperatore, who owns New York Waterway, which runs the terminal. Roseland bought 150 adjacent acres in West New York from Mr. Imperatore in 1995 and is building a 4,080-unit residential community. 
 Mr. Imperatore's original plan was to build a Venetian-style city on the entire tract, but the recession and other problems intervened. On the Weehawken site he opened a marina and a restaurant and began the ferry service to Manhattan.
Up to 2,200 residences and 2 million square feet of commercial space could be built on the site, but "the likelihood is the density will be lower," said Arthur E. Imperatore Jr., president of Arcorp and New York Waterway. The partners intend to emphasize commercial development. "There is a greater opportunity for it," given the transportation improvements, said Carl J. Goldberg of Roseland. The expanded terminal is to be ready in 1999.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
Beyond Retailing: Westbury Mall Aims to Entertain

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: WESTBURY

 BODY:
WITH the grand opening two days ago of the Source on a 38-acre site on Old Country Road, shoppers can experience what mall developers say is the newest approach to retailing: The 736,000-square-foot mall, which includes an existing 213,000-square-foot Fortunoff, has been designed to entertain.
Visitors can shop at one of 65 stores or kiosks (with more to come), while eating in a food court shaped like an airplane hangar or in one of four restaurants. The mall, whose architect is RTKL Associates of Baltimore, will also have a spa. 
 About two-thirds of the retailers are open for business; others are still finishing up their space. All but 40,000 of the 523,000 square feet of new retail space is leased.
"The idea is that you come to one place," said Alan Fortunoff, the president of Fortunoff. "That becomes a day's experience in an environment that's entertaining, without having to get in and out of a car." Parking for 4,000 cars is available.
The Fortunoff chain, started 75 years ago in Brooklyn, has had its flagship store in its Westbury location since 1964. The $145 million expansion was developed in a joint venture with the Simon DeBartolo Group of Indianapolis, which built the Mall of America in Bloomington, Minn.
In 1989, Fortunoff signed a deal to sell its property to Westfield, an Australian shopping mall developer, which intended to develop it as a mall incorporating Fortunoff and drawing tenants like Neiman-Marcus. But Westfield pulled out of the deal in December 1990 after the downturn in the economy.
"After a thoughtful pause, we decided that demand was increasing for quality merchandise at a lower price than the conventional department store offered," Mr. Fortunoff said, explaining the shift in concept to a mall at which so-called off-price retailers are the anchor tenants.
Off-price means brand-name merchandise sold at a discount. At the Source, that category of retailers includes Off 5th -- Saks Fifth Avenue Outlet and Nordstrom Rack, which are newcomers to Long Island, along with a Loehmann's, an Old Navy store and Fortunoff itself.
Simon DeBartolo, a leading shopping center developer, has ownership interests in 187 properties around the country, of which 115 are regional malls, including the 1.4 million-square-foot Smith Haven Mall in Smithtown.
At the Source, the Indianapolis developer is continuing an approach that has been successful elsewhere : blending off-price retailers with restaurants and entertainment.
The mall will include a two-story Virgin megastore and a Rainforest Cafe, both newcomers to Long Island. The 375-seat restaurant, on the mall's second floor, surrounds patrons with steamy waterfalls, simulated thunder and lightning and jungle noises, along with animated figures of jungle animals such as elephants, monkeys and snakes, and live parrots and tropical fish in large aquariums. Giant fake butterflies flap around among artificial and real greenery.
Two other restaurants, a 172-seat Bertolini's and a 300-seat Cheesecake Factory, are also open. The 270-seat Brooklyn Diner is scheduled to open by the end of the year.
Stores also offer entertainment.
At the Fortunoff Watch Store, rear walls set up like garage doors roll up to display stock. Innovation Luggage has an imitation airport carousel, a giant compass and a big spinning globe.
At SegaGameworks, to open in the spring, patrons are to be able to play a broad spectrum of virtual-reality games and others in what is described as a fantasy atmosphere.
The Great Train Store allows customers to play with trains, and also has electric trains circling the store on trestles suspended from the ceiling.
ABC Home on the Road, a branch of ABC Carpet and Home in Manhattan, will sell its furniture, linens and antiques in what ABC's president, Evan Cole, called a "stage setting without the curtains and the sets," with a "show that changes all the time." The store, 50,000 square feet, opens in October.
Shoppers can indulge in some pampering, too. Cosmetics Plus, a cosmetics superstore, has a facial salon. The Pure Maximus Spa/ Salon, to open in November, will have a spa for both men and women, with massages and thermal baths. A Continental breakfast and snacks with Champagne will be served, and there will be a cappuccino bar. Special events will include fashion shows and lectures on health and beauty.
Long Island has become a magnet for developers and national retailers, because they view its demographics as among the best in the country.
A market study for Simon DeBartolo found that 1.5 million people with an average annual household income of $78,078 live within a 10-mile radius of the Source, and that the average annual income on Long Island as a whole is $58,118. Annual retail sales in Nassau and Suffolk have increased over 30 percent in the last five years and now total $33 billion. Fortunoff sales exceed $166 million annually.
Retail developers say there is room for more stores, even in the crowded environment of the Nassau Hub, which includes the Source, the 2.4 million-square-foot Roosevelt Field Shopping Center, where a 225,000-square-foot Nordstrom department store recently opened, and 600,000 square feet of retail space at Roosevelt Center, a 2.6 million-square-foot mixed-use development that adjoins the Fortunoff property.
"Every business has a point at which there are not enough dollars left to go around, but we haven't reached that point," said Louis L. Ceruzzi Jr., president of Ceruzzi Properties of Westport, Conn., which is developing Roosevelt Center, where hotels, offices and housing are still to be built, in partnership with Edward J. Minskoff and Allen Silverman of Manhattan. "Shoppers will now have more reason to come to this area because of the variety of choice and because of the competition," Mr. Ceruzzi said.
Wilbur F. Breslin, a Garden City developer, who recently broke ground for a 1.6-million-square-foot mall in Yaphank, has long maintained that Long Island is "undermalled."
"If you took a ring of 2.6 million people anywhere else in the United States, you'd find 20 to 25 regional malls servicing that amount of population," he said. "Long Island has seven regional malls, and ours will be the eighth."
Additional malls and so-called power centers, which are shopping centers with large national tenants, are on the way.
THE Taubman Company of Bloomfield Hills, Mich., in partnership with the Tribune Company of Chicago, is proposing a one-million-square-foot shopping center in Syosset near Exit 43 of the Long Island Expressway. Neiman-Marcus, Bloomingdale's and Nordstrom have expressed interest in locating there, said Tony Ness, Taubman's senior vice president of development.
The 40-acre site, owned by the Tribune Company -- which had planned to build a printing plant for The Daily News, but then sold that newspaper -- was once occupied by Cerro Wire and Cable. The developers need a special use permit from the Town of Oyster Bay before the project can proceed. "Right now there is no critical mass of better retailing anywhere else on Long Island," Mr. Ness said. "We would have a whole shopping center full of the kind of stores you find on Madison Avenue, with anchors like Neiman-Marcus, in an enclosed environment."
Closer to construction, with a spring start scheduled, is the 736,000-square-foot Airport Plaza Shopping Center in Farmingdale. There, 300,000 square feet will be occupied by a three-story sports complex called Sports Expo, featuring hockey rinks, basketball and tennis and a soccer field.
"To me, the formula for success is a top location and a good tenant mix of big advertising and power stores that offer value to the consumer," said Peter L. Levine, president of Levcom, a West Paterson, N.J., shopping center developer that is building Airport Plaza for the property owner, the Fairchild Corporation of Chantilly, Va.
"That success is more assured if you combine retailing with entertainment and the latest category, which is sports," Mr. Levine said. "I predict that in 10 years there won't be retailing power centers or malls, but destination points that offer themes and multiple attractions to families."

HEADLINE: Chasing a Goal on a String in the Satellite Tour

BYLINE: By CHUCK SLATER 

 BODY:
THE splendor and riches that are big-time professional tennis have been on display in Queens for the last two weeks. In today's finals of the United States Open, the winning man and woman will each receive a check for $650,000. Their opponents will have to be consoled with $350,000 apiece.
Even the losers in earlier rounds, some separated from the finalists by just a few strokes or a shot a half-inch wide, went home with large checks. The total purse for the competitors in this year's United States Open is $11.8 million, half of it going to women. 
 For the young professionals at the top of the Women's Tennis Association tour, the travel is first class, the hotels are first rate, the cities are the most glamorous, and appearance and endorsement fees often exceed the generous paychecks.
Perhaps 200 young women fit that description. About the same number make a living on the fringes of the main tour.
But a few more strokes and light years removed from that world, thousands more chase the dream in more modest circumstances.
The purse money may be $10,000 for the entire field. Travel is economy class. Hotel rooms are of the $50-a-night variety and usually shared. Tournament sites are dots on the map.
This is a world of long practice sessions, longer waiting periods and short paybacks. It is made palatable only by a love of tennis and because, for a very few, the main tour and a place among the elite 200 is the reward.
It is called the satellite tour. It is Barrie Bernstein's world.
Last Wednesday, as the field was sorting itself out for the big-money final rounds at the Open, Ms. Bernstein, who grew up in Scarsdale and divides her time between Briarcliff Manor and Manhattan, was on a plane to Romania. Ahead of her were three satellite tournaments in three weeks. In the fall, there will be others in Israel and Egypt.
She will keep her eye on the ball. And on expenses.
"Usually the hotel minimum is $50," she said, "so we share a room. In Europe, we save on breakfast since a Continental breakfast is provided. Bread and juice. I have lots of bread and juice.
"In most of these towns, the town is just a hotel and maybe three tennis courts. You practice and then you wait. If, say you're fourth up on court 3, you might get on at 10:30 at night, so you wait around, watch and read a lot. You spend a lot of time in the hotel, too.
"In Elvas, Portugal, on the Spanish border, there's nothing there but a tennis club."
Then there are the paychecks. If a player loses in a satellite qualifier, there is no check. Achieve the main draw and each victory brings a return of sorts.
Ms. Bernstein, whose knowledge of the game makes her a strong doubles player, has had virtually all of her limited success in doubles. That includes her first professional paycheck.
"My partner and I won a round in the main draw in Bossoneens, Switzerland, last September," she said. "We split $50. So my first check was for $25 -- no, $20 after taxes. It's the most exciting $20 I ever made in my life."
A satellite player has to love tennis. Barrie Bernstein, 24, does.
"She picked up a racquet when she was 2; my husband and I played," said Randee Bernstein of Briarcliff Manor, the mother and chief booster of the young professional. "She always had fantastic hand-eye coordination."
At Scarsdale High School and the University of Pennsylvania, Ms. Bernstein played first singles for four successful years. "I thought I'd had enough tennis," she said. "I didn't know if I could take it further. Little did I know how much I would miss it."
Less than a year after graduating and going to work, she asked her parents to support her efforts to make it in professional tennis.
"It wasn't an easy conversation," Ms. Bernstein recalled. "Dad was skeptical. But I told them that if I didn't do it now, I might well regret not giving myself a chance for the rest of my life."
Mrs. Bernstein said: "We said we would give her two years. And it costs us more now than a year of college. She needs a personal coach, but we can't afford it."
And Ms. Bernstein said: "I feel I'm just getting back to where I was when I stopped tennis for a year." She picked up two doubles medals at the Maccabiah Games in July during "the most exciting tennis experience I've had" and headed for Romania with racquets and hope.
"But if this tennis thing doesn't work out," she said, "I'm planning to go to graduate school."
For now, she is reaching for her star and loving it.
"I could not be happier," she said. "I'm in shape. I'm traveling the world. I'm doing something I love. I couldn't ask for much more."
Just that big breakthrough to the big time.

HEADLINE: Long Island Q&A: John J. Shalam;
With a Fine Eye for Trends in Electronics

BYLINE: By SUSAN KONIG 

 BODY:
IT began almost by accident 30 years ago. Problems with a buyer left John J. Shalam, a partner in a tiny Japanese import concern, with 2,000 car radios that he thought he would never sell.
But not only did he sell them. In a few months he had formed his own company, the Audiovox Corporation, to keep up with the growing demand. 
 Today, Audiovox, in Hauppauge, is a leading designer and supplier of sound and security systems for automobiles and cellular telephones. Last year the company, which is listed on the American Stock Exchange, recorded sales of just under $600 million. Cellular telephones account for most of its business, selling two million last year.
The company is a formidable factor in automobile electronics, domestically and worldwide. Its car-security systems hold the largest share of their market in the United States.
Audiovox also has a small home electronics division. And, of course, there are the car stereos, which changed Mr. Shalam's life.
Mr. Shalam, 63, came to the United States from Egypt in the 1950's to attend the Wharton School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania, from which he earned a bachelor's degree in economics. The Continental Grain Company in New York offered him a job that he turned down because he was not a citizen. He worked without pay until his visa was issued. Later he worked briefly for Custom Imports Inc., the Japanese business, before starting Audiovox in 1965.
An avid horseman, Mr. Shalam is president of the Old Westbury Horsemen's Foundation, which creates and maintains trails.
He and his wife, Jane, live in Old Westbury. They have three sons.
Q. How did you start in the import business?
A. As a bachelor in the 60's, I went to my sister's house several times a week for dinner. There I met a man named Caesar, who was also originally from Egypt. He operated a small trading company out of Japan and he asked if I'd go out and promote some business for him.
We struck an agreement. I'd solicit people in New York who wanted to buy any kind of product made in Japan, while Caesar, who was in Tokyo, would go to the factories, order them and ship them here. We built up a pretty nice business with pocket transistor radios, baseball gloves, binoculars -- many different sundry items.
Q. What was the turning point for you?
A. Caesar sent me a box with a sample car radio in it. My job was to find buyers. I found a guy in Brooklyn who wanted 3,000 of them. But when they arrived, he would only open a letter of credit for 1,000. Basically, I was left with 2,000 radios, which I had to sell pretty fast or we'd lose a lot of money.
I searched for distributors in the Yellow Pages. Not only did I find people to buy them, they liked the product so much that they asked me to ship more. I was reluctant to do it since the last deal had gone sour. But they kept calling me. So finally I agreed. The items became so popular that by 1965 I phased out all other products to focus exclusively on car radios. That was the start of Audiovox.
Q. Was growth rapid?
A. Yes. Auto electronics is a tremendous industry. It began with AM radios. Then FM became popular. There was FM stereo, four and eight-track tape players. Now it's cassette and CD players. Every few years there's a whole new product that comes along and restimulates this industry.
Q. What will be the next revolution?
A. Everyone is talking about automobile navigation systems, which are already in some rental cars. They let you find the best route, the least trafficked areas, etc. If you're in an unfamiliar area, they direct you to hotels and restaurants. They're somewhat expensive right now, around $2,500, but I think that, with time, as their production increases and it becomes more competitive, you're going to see a lot of this type of equipment in people's cars. It's something we are working on.
Q. Do you design and sell car security systems?
A. Yes, the little transmitters people walk around with on their key chains, where you push a button and the doors unlock, and the lights flash. We have probably the largest market share on this product in the U.S. today.
Q. Why do those items have to be "sexy" to sell well?
A. People in this country don't buy products strictly for security. Seat belts wouldn't sell if they weren't mandated. And if you had a car alarm which simply sounded when someone broke in, but there was no other evidence to suggest that you had it, people wouldn't buy it.
But if you combine the alarm with features that can make the door locks pop up and and the trunk pop open remotely, from the outside, then you've got something. The ability to start your engine remotely is also becoming very popular. You can stand up to 50 feet away from your car, push a button, and the engine starts itself. In the winter, when your car's outside, you can warm the engine for 10 or 15 minutes before you leave. The heater is left on, and the car is warm and comfortable when you get in. It's the same in the summer with air-conditioning. These features are all incorporated in alarm systems today.
Q. How did you enter the cellular telephone business?
A. Back in late 1983 people started talking about these new cellular telephones that were manufactured by Motorola. We were heavily involved in the auto-sound business, but we could see it was going to have a limited future because, increasingly, manufacturers were shipping cars with complete accessory packages.
We thought the cell-phone business was a natural for us, because in those days all of these phones were for the car. There were no portables until six or seven years ago. And who was best suited to install phones in cars? The guys who were installing the radios. They had facilities -- the garages, the installers.
I'd always thought cars and communications were the two things Americans were most in love with, and here was a perfect setup. So we went to Japan and established a relationship with Toshiba. In 1985 they started supplying phones under the Audiovox brand. Now we work with Toshiba and other overseas manufacturers.
Q. How many Americans own cell phones?
A. Right now there are 45 million subscribers, and that number is expected to reach or exceed 50 million by the end of this year. Ninety percent of cell phones sold today are portable, not car phones, though we still carry both products.
Q. How much do they cost?
A. In the very beginning cell phones sold for around $3,000. They came down quickly, to $1,500, then $1,200. Today we sell some mobile units for as low as $115. Cell phones are the only product in the world whose retail price is less than the manufacturing cost, because phone companies are willing to subsidize the price to get you to sign on for a one-year contract. So they will buy a phone for, let's say, $150 and they'll offer it to you for $49.99, provided you sign a contract.
Q. Don't owners pay for air time on outgoing and incoming calls?
A. Yes, although the average cell-phone bill is under $50 a month. We are trying to get the industry to change, however. In some countries in South America the caller now pays for the air time, and they've found that as a result the use of air time has become much greater. In this country, people are afraid to give out their cell phone numbers, because they don't want too many calls.
Right now I think it would be even more advantageous to eliminate roaming fees, the fees they charge when you use your phone outside your home area. Instead of paying just 50 cents a minute, you pay 50 cents a minute plus an additional $1-a-minute roaming fee. This becomes very expensive, and it discourages a lot of people from using their phones. But many companies are working to eliminate it. I think roaming fees will be gone within the next few years.
Q. Are you involved with the telephones on airplanes?
A. No, we're not.
Q. How small will cell phones become?
A. Technically, you could have the old Dick Tracy wristwatch as a two-way radio right now. We have the technology. But realistically the size of cell phones are limited by two factors. The keys must be large enough so that you don't press two numbers at once, and the battery, which is the heaviest component of these phones, has to support a reasonable amount of talk time.
Our smallest model, the MVX-800, weighs 5.4 ounces and is 5 inches high, 1.7 inches wide and 0.90 inches deep. It used to be the smallest phone in the world. But Motorola has come out with a slightly smaller one. Basically, I think the cell phones we have now are about the smallest you'll see. They're light and they fit right in your pocket or purse. And they have sufficient talk time, which surveys have shown is very important to people. I don't really think they need to be any smaller.
Q. How do you feel about links between car phones and increased automobile accidents?
A. If you're going to grab the phone and take your eyes off the road, then, yes, they can be dangerous. But if you have a phone with a car kit that allows for hands-free usage, that's a different story. I use one all the time and I consider it very safe. It should be mounted high up, as close to the dashboard as possible, so you don't have to deflect your eyes from the road. If they are mounted and installed correctly, they're safe. But you have to use them properly.
Q. Where is the communications industry going?
A. There are some interesting new products being developed in car security. Car tracking is very exciting. When a car is stolen the owner can simply contact a monitoring center which will pick up a signal via satellite, indicating where the car is. This is just being introduced now. And it has other functions. If you lock your keys in the car, you can call the monitoring station and ask them to pop up the door locks. It's all done through satellite.

GRAPHIC: Photo: John J. Shalam at the headquarters of his company on Marcus Boulevard in Hauppauge. (Steve Berman for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 338 words

HEADLINE: Complex Calcutta

 BODY:

To the Editor: Kate Wheeler aptly points out that hiring a rickshaw in Calcutta enables the man pulling it to eat. But paying him five times what he asks -- rather than bargaining and paying the going rate -- inflates costs beyond the means, potentially, of many local people, devalues the efforts it normally takes to earn prevailing rates, and sets up Ms. Wheeler and her fellow Westerners to be seen as cash cows. It would be more constructive to give money to reputable local charities and to use services like rickshaws more frequently while paying the going rates. 
 In four months of traveling from Vietnam to Nepal, I found that the differences between communities that had been exposed to Western tourism and those that had not were profound. The loss of integrity, dignity and appreciation of cultural heritage seemed far more the results of Western tourists' poorly informed good intentions in handing out money than of crude or boorish behavior.
 
ANDREW KAUFMAN
New York, N.Y.
 
Ms. Wheeler responds: I appreciate the outline of the tricky issues that enter informal transactions; it's not always easy to know what to do. My policy is to learn what price local people pay, talk to other travelers and then allow for variations. I do give to charities, too, but visiting places of strong economic suffering, I try to give away 10 percent of what I spend on myself each day. Each transaction is an attempt at a genuine relationship. It is a drag to be seen as a cash cow, but there is often room for visitors to pay more than local people do. Some Indian vendors have multitiered prices: Japanese tourists pay most, Americans and other "Western" tourists less, and Indians least of all. But if a rickshaw driver asks five times the going rate, I'll refuse to pay it, if possible. We all make mistakes. Yet our terror of inflicting damage bears examining, too. Perhaps it disguises a wish to see exotic people preserved in a "purity" that's really just cheaper and more exciting for visitors.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Traveling by rickshaw in Calcutta, India. (Rakesh Sahai/Black Star, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Asians Are Making an Impact on L.I. Life

BYLINE: By RAMIN P. JALESHGARI 

 BODY:
WHEN Indu Jaiswal moved to Nassau County 20 years ago, her traditional Indian clothing often got second looks. During the 1960's Shi Ming Hu, who came to teach at Stony Brook University in the 1960's, had to travel to New York's Chinatown for basic Asian foodstuffs. Ten years ago, in Great Neck, Henry Pak, a Korean physician, could not get brokers to show him houses in the more "exclusive" parts of town.
Backlash against Asians had deep roots. In the early part of this century the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service placed stringent entry quotas on the amount of Asian immigrants allowed into the country. Those that did get in were denied naturalization and the right to own property. Americans who married Asian nationals lost their own citizenship. 
 Today, women in saris on the Island rarely raise an eyebrow, and Asian foods have become regular fare, gaining their own aisle in supermarkets. And, Asian home buyers have little problem finding houses in the neighborhoods of their choice.
Once unwelcome, those from the Far East are the fastest growing immigrant group in America. Long Island is high on the list of preferred residences, ccounting more than 50,000 people in the 1990 Census. A Census Department study also noted an almost 5 percent rise between 1990 and 1994. The projected rise through the year 2000 is 15 percent, with a steady increase of 15 to 18 percent through 2025.
Next to the Hispanic population, Asians are the quickest growing minority group in the country. The bulk of Asian immigrants to the Eastern seaboard arrived in the late 1960's, often settling in enclaves in Flushing, Queens, which changed from predominantly Eastern European to Korean and Indian.
The 1980's became a time for relocation, and many Asians began to look forward to "the better life" on Long Island.
"Asians have been, in many ways, very different kinds of immigrants," said S. N. Sridhar, a linguistics professor at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, whose efforts to start an India Studies Center at the school came to fruition this year. "Asians tend to come to America with specific job skills, or, once they arrive, voraciously seek out higher educational training. This affords them entry to well-paying, professional employment and they tend to move into areas of economic influence fairly quickly."
Census statistics prove this. A 1994 study indicates that educational attainment for Asians tends to be twice as high as that of Americans of other racial heritage. Consequently, the median income for Asian American families tends to be around 10 percent higher than that of white families, averaging near $45,000 annually in 1993.
The number of businesses owned by Asian-Americans increased 56 percent nationwide from 1987-1992 with revenues of hundreds of millions of dollars. Doing business with Asian entrepreneurs is high on the agenda for Marine Midland bank, whose Asian Business Unit, with permanently placed agents dedicated to cultivating the Long Island area, specializes in business loans to Asian-run establishments.
"A growing number of our Asian clientele is coming from Long Island," said Peter Boland, senior vice president in charge of trade finance at Marine Midland Bank. "We see Asian-American businesses as a dynamic ever-increasing group." The bank has paid careful attention to those business owners doing international trade with "home" countries in the East -- most notably India.
"India is the world's fifth largest economy -- it is increasingly an economic force to be recognized," said Ram Khanna, who heads Marine's Asian Business Unit. "American and Long Island business people need to tap into this fertile market by learning more about it -- one way to do that is to examine the Asian community all around them."
Marine's efforts to recognize the Asian society as a plentiful business resource have included providing personal finance seminars in Great Neck to Asian-American professionals like doctors and lawyers, and being host to cultural events as well.
In 1996 the bank was host of a festival in Manhattan in honor of the Hindu holiday Diwali, with an eye on a Long Island location for this year's celebration, in October. It was private donations from Long Islanders of Indian heritage, amounting to more than $100,000 that enabled the establishment of the state university's India Studies Center. And, over the last 20 years the Korean community has donated more than $700,000 for the school's Korean Studies program.
Also intended for Stony Brook University: an Asian-American Cultural Center, to be built through a $25 million donation by Charles Wang, whose Islandia-based company, Computer Associates International Inc., a global software giant, is one of the largest local employers.
Remembering his first days in the states when his family was denied home ownership in Queens because of their Chinese ancestry, Mr. Wang asserted his hope that "the Asian-American Cultural Center will serve as a catalyst for a host of cultural, academic, business and technology initiatives."
The mark made by Long Islanders of Asian heritage is apparent in ways outside the business forum as well. In Hicksville, the small hardware stores, butcher shop and dress makers lining Main Street (Route 107) are now East Indian grocers, sari palaces and Hindi language video emporiums. In Huntington, Oriental grocers cater to a wide variety of Asian and non-Asian clientele. "There was a time when we were practically the only Asian market on Long Island -- it was either us, or, travel into Queens," said Rajesh and Gita, owners of Modern Bazaar, an Indian food market in Hicksville. "Now, there are so many, we're really feeling the competition -- but the population is there to support it."
Restaurants are another indicator. While Chinese restaurants have long been popular on the Island, Japanese sushi bars, Thai and Indian eateries are becoming ubiquitous along the main roads of Nassau and Suffolk Counties.
"As little as five years ago," said Chani Singh, co-owner of the Curry Club, an Indian restaurant in Setauket, "I would never have dreamed that an Indian restaurant would do well in Suffolk County, especially the farther away you got from the city."
Opening last December to crowds of 250 people per night, the Curry Club expanded and also opened a Southold location. "Most of our clients are actually not Asian," Mr. Singh said. "They're American. Americans have become very familiar and comfortable with Indian culture and cuisine."
In other mainstream venues, Asian-Americans are making a mark as well. Jennifer Choi, a physician certified in physical medicine and rehabilitation, has built a practice based on acupuncture techniques. With offices in Huntington and Smithtown, the Korean-born physician noted that s the ancient Chinese art had become an acceptable method of treatment in traditional medical arenas.
"Ninety-eight percent of my patients are non-Asian and we see up to 60 patients a day -- some from as far away as the Hamptons," said Dr. Choi.
Officials in Suffolk and Nassau County have also been instrumental in addressing the concerns of Asians in their districts, and promoting Asian cultural programs. A concert series sponsored by Nassau County in Eisenhower Park included an Indian-American night in July and Korean and Chinese American nights in August.
Dr. William Keh, director of the Chinese Cultural Association in Great Neck, said, "Our local politicians, County Executive Tom Gulotta and Congressman Gary Ackerman have been very receptive to our community voice -- they really participate in organizing activities that include us."
Indu Jaiswal, president of the Indian Association of Long Island, agrees, noting that support in county government has made annual events like an India Day parade and yearly Diwali festivals in Long Beach possible. Despite the niche Asian-Americans have made for themselves on Long Island, and their increasing influence in various aspects of the area's daily life, being an Asian-American Long Islander is not always easy.
"Asians-Americans have always tried to hold on to their cultural heritage-in terms of rituals, religion, and language," said Kamal Sridhar, director of the English as a Second Language program at Stony Brook and co-founder of the India Center there. "This can be particularly hard on second-generation Asian-Americans who want to remain loyal to their families and culture but don't want to be different from their friends and classmates."
Shalin Bhatt, an 18-year-old college student from Hicksville, primarily speaks the Indian language Gujrati at home. He has observed the difficulty this sometimes presents to school-age youngsters in his family.
"My cousin entered school with a low attention span -- because English wasn't his primary language," he said, "The school didn't realize he came from a bilingual home and what the implications of that were, so they wanted to put him in a special education class.It took some time, but he eventually adapted and his teachers realized he was very bright -- that his whole problem had been the language."
Eriko Sato Zhu, a Japanese-born adjunct professor at Stony Brook, noted that "many Japanese who live here are very lonely and feel they don't fit in" with the mainstream culture.
"Friends from other Asian countries tell me they feel the same way. When they're outside their ethnic enclave they are disoriented and unhappy and many long to return to native lands." Ms. Zhu also said that while there may be more Asians on Long Island, they tend to live in tight-knit communities -- near colleges for example.
Valley Stream, for example, is home to a large number of Korean and Pakistani families. And, while many Asian-American students live directly at/or around Stony Brook University, the number of Asian families making their permanent home in the Three Village area surrounding the school are few.
Asian culture groups attempt to alleviate some of the problems that Asian-American Long Islanders face. Dr. Keh's organization sponsors five Chinese language schools in Nassau County -- mainly for the benefit of second-generation Chinese Americans. The group has also started a series of cultural awareness programs at New York Institute of Technology in Old Westbury, including this year's Long Island Chinese Festival. The India Association of Long Island, helps raise funds for the American Heart Association, North Shore University Hospital, and other local charities.
"In this way," said Mrs. Jaiswal, "we can become part of the community -- by showing the non-Indian, non-Asian population that we too are serious and dedicated to the area we live in."
For Drs. S. N. and Kamal Sridhar, efforts like these make the future of Asians on Long Island seem very hopeful. Standing proudly in the backyard of his Stony Brook home, by the 4-foot Japanese maple planted to commemorate the first talks of the India Studies Center that has now become a reality, Dr. Sridhar said, "That tree was a tiny thing when it was put here -- like the trickle of Asians to Long Island just 15 years ago.That tree has grown by leaps and bounds, and today, like the Asian community, it is firmly rooted in the Long Island landscape."

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:

WOMEN ARTISTS
 
 An opening reception for "Between the Wars: Women Artists of the Whitney Studio Club and Museum" is scheduled on Thursday from 6 to 7:30 P.M. at the Whitney Museum of American Art in Stamford. The public is invited free of charge.
More than 100 prints and drawings by 35 artists, produced in the 1920's and 30's and drawn from the permanent collection of the Whitney in Manhattan, will be on view. Among them are Isabel Bishop's "Noon Hour," Marguerite Zorach's "Woman and Cat," Mabel Dwight's "Harlem Rent Party," and Peggy Bacon's "The Social Graces."
The collection was begun by Gertrude Vanderbilt Whitney in 1918, when she established the Whitney Studio Club to support women artists. Because there were so few opportunities for them to show their work in museums and galleries, she mounted exhibitions for them and bought many of their works. Many of the paintings and drawings became part of the permanent collection when she established the Whitney Museum in New York in 1930.
The exhibition will remain through Nov. 12. The museum's Connecticut branch is at the corner of Atlantic Street and Tresser Boulevard and is open Tuesday through Saturday from 11 to 5. Free illustrated brochures are available and free gallery talks are given on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Saturdays at 12:30. The number for more information is (203) 358-7652.

WORDS AND MUSIC
Calliope's Chamber is the name of the duo of Lois Swann, novelist, and Joyce Balint, string instrumentalist. They will combine their talents in a performance called "Masks," to be presented next Saturday at 5 P.M. in the Ridgefield Library, 472 Main Street.
Ms. Swann, will read from "Sippicon," the third book in a trilogy that she has written, set in 18th century Venice. After each reading Ms. Balint will illuminate the text with arias by Vivaldi, Corelli and Veracini, performed on the mandolin and violin.
Ms. Swann's books are published by Scribner's and include "Torn Covenants," 1981. Boston University has a collection of her work in its archives.
Ms. Balint is the mandolin soloist with the Metropolitan Opera Company Orchestra, and half of the Balint Duo with her husband Sandor Balint, a violinist with the Metropolitan orchestra. Admission is free.

FILMS BY SAYLES
The work of an independent filmmaker, John Sayles. will be screened from Monday through Friday at the Stratford Library, 2203 Main St., daily at 1 P.M. Recommended for mature audiences, the films will be shown free of charge and viewers may bring bag lunches.
Monday's offering will be "The Return of the Secaucus Seven" (1980), about a reunion of radical 60's college friends. "City of Hope" (1991) is on Wednesday's bill, (there is no film on Tuesday) with Angela Basset, Vincent Spano, Tony Lo Bianco and Joe Morton as urban denizens, and Sayles in a small role.
"Passion Fish" (1992), a comedy about a paralyzed soap opera queen and her domineering nurse, is Thursday's film, and "Lone Star" (1996), a drama of prejudice and corruption in a Texas town will be shown on Friday. The number for more information is (203) 385-4162.

PHOTOS BY SPENDER
The Yale Center for British Art in New Haven is the first museum in the United States to mount an exhibition of Humphrey Spender's photography. It opens tomorrow through Nov. 9 and is titled "Humphrey Spender's Humanist Landscapes: Photo-documents, 1932-1942."
Like his brother, the poet and author Stephen Spender, Humphrey recorded the sociology of depression-era and wartime Britain in the context of his art. More than 70 of his images of poverty and unemployment in England's industrial cities, and shots of people in pubs, parks, markets, factories, offices and locker rooms, testify to what he calls his "obsession that the truth would be revealed only when people were not aware of being photographed."
The exhibit is supplemented with copies of the magazines in which his narrative photos appeared, and drawings, prints and paintings by artists who were his contemporaries.
A conversation with Mr. Spender will take place on Wednesday, and a symposium on changes in the role of documentary photography is planned on Saturday. Other events related to the exhibition are a film series, exploring the British documentary movement of the 30's and 40's; dramatic readings by Yale School of Drama students; gallery talks and a children's photography program.
The center is at 1080 Chapel Street and viewing hours are Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5, Sunday from noon to 5. Admission is free. For more information and a schedule of events the number is (203) 432-2800. The center's web site is http://www.yale/edu/ycba.

SCHWEITZER FESTIVAL
"Words of Albert Schweitzer and the Music of Bach" by Thurston Moore, produced by Tennessee Players, Inc., will be presented free of charge this evening at 7:30 at the First Church of Christ, 250 Main Street in Wethersfield.
The program inaugurates what is scheduled to be an annual Albert Schweitzer Organ Festival that next year will begin once-a-year competitions for young organ students. Winners will receive awards to help pay for their musical education.
Today's program consists of a 90-minute slide presentation with organ music and three narrators of Schweitzer's writings: Dr. Gilbert Bond of the Yale School of Theology; Joanne Nesti, Channel 30 news anchor, and Donald Morgan, First Church minister emeritus.
Bach's music will be performed by several noted organists, including Ronald Ebrecht, Christa Rakich, and John Rose. David Spicer, minister of music at the church, will direct the choir in "He Comes to Us" by Jane Marshall, with text from Schweitzer's book, "The Quest of the Historical Jesus." On display from the Schweitzer archives is the small reed organ that he used in Africa. The number for more information (860) 563-7759.

HINDU FESTIVAL
Navarati, the Hindu festival in honor of the goddess Durga, will be celebrated for the 21st year at Wesleyan University in Middletown. It will begin on Thursday at 5:30 with a procession from the Connecticut Valley Hindu Temple Society at 11 Training Hill Road and will end at Crowell Concert Hall on the campus.
At 7 P.M. the first event in the festival, which continues until Sept. 20, will be a concert by the Krishnamurthi Nagaswaram Ensemble at the Center for the Arts on High Street. The nagaswaram is a double-reed oboe used in temple ceremonies and weddings, thought to be an instrument of good luck. Admission will be free.
Five concerts of Indian music and dance will begin on Friday at 8 P.M. in Crowell Concert Hall, when Birju Maharaj will present a program of North Indian classical dance. On Saturday at 8 P.M. T. Viswanathan, adjunct professor music at Wesleyan, will play South Indian flute music, accompanied by violin, percussion and a vocalist.
Additional concerts will be performed in the following week. Series tickets are $48, single concert tickets are $12, and discounts are available. The number is (860) 685-3355 for reservations or more information. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
When One Good Turn Deserves Another

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY; Brett Pulley reports from Trenton for The New York Times.

DATELINE: EAST ORANGE

 BODY:
It's not exactly 40 acres and a mule, but black Democrats in the state have just received their recompense for the extraordinary work they did last year in gathering votes for President Clinton and Senator Robert G. Torricelli.
The big pay back came last week when Mr. Clinton took a moment from his vacation on Martha's Vineyard to issue a statement saying he would nominate Cardell Cooper, the second-term Mayor of East Orange, to become an assistant administrator at the Environmental Protection Agency -- a high-ranking post that will require confirmation by the Senate. 
Now, to be sure, it is unfair to Mr. Cooper, a man of esteemed background and qualifications -- as well as political agility -- to suggest that he has been selected for such a lofty post simply as a matter of political indebtedness. Nevertheless, although he heads a city of 80,000 people, Mr. Cooper has not had a lot of direct experience with environmental issues, and the two people who most recently held the same E.P.A. post had extensive prior experience within the agency.
However, Mr. Clinton's environmental appointments and initiatives have typically been thoughtful and well-received by environmentalists, and apparently the President must feel confident that Mr. Cooper is aptly suited to head the agency's solid-waste and emergency-response offices, which oversee the cleanup of Superfund hazardous waste sites and the reclaiming and redevelopment of urban industrial tracts known as brownfields.
In its release to the news media, the White House cited Mr. Cooper's residential waste-recycling program and improvements to the city's drinking water as examples of his qualifications. The Environmental Protection Agency's top administrator, Carol M. Browner, said that Mr. Cooper's "years of leadership in protecting public health in real communities will serve this agency and the nation well."
But despite all those well-prepared statements, what clearly made the biggest impression on Mr. Clinton is the job the Mayor did last fall as chairman of the Clinton-Gore coordinated campaign in New Jersey. Leading the effort that combined the Presidential campaign with local races, Mr. Cooper received much of the credit for the overwhelming plurality received by the Clinton-Gore team in New Jersey, and the strong urban turnout that helped elect Mr. Torricelli to his first term in the Senate.
As a result, Mr. Torricelli, and the state's senior Senator, Frank R. Lautenberg, have been pushing for the past eight months to get the President to nominate Mr. Cooper to a top administration post, and for many weeks there was much speculation about which agency it would be. Mr. Clinton may not want environmentalists to think that he would play politics with such an important job, but in reality, that is often the way of the world.
Mr. Torricelli, after all, earlier this year cited his own efforts to get a White House nomination for Mr. Cooper as an example of what he has done in acknowledgment of the strong support he received from black voters. Under fire from activists who charged that he had not hired enough blacks to work in his Senate office, Mr. Torricelli pointed to the impending Cooper nomination as proof that he had not forgotten who buttered his bread last November.
Even though politics did indeed play a big part in the selection, there is no reason for Mr. Cooper to do anything but hold his head high over this appointment, one of the most important ones that the Clinton administration has bestowed upon a New Jersey resident.
During an interview in his office after the announcement, Mr. Cooper said he was certain he would "meet the challenges and opportunities that lie ahead." And for the 45-year-old mayor, the ticket to Washington comes just in time. After seeing his support wane in the city, Mr. Cooper decided not to seek re-election this year, and his $73,000-a-year mayoral job was thus ending on Dec. 31.
His nomination to the E.P.A. job, which pays $115,700, is not expected to receive much resistance in the Senate. Mr. Lautenberg, the ranking Democratic on the Environment and Public Works Committee, has said that he will personally shepherd the nomination through the committee.
Mr. Cooper, whose previous jobs have included Essex County Administrator, business administrator for the city of Irvington, and director of the East Orange Department of Human Services, was wistful when asked how he felt about leaving City Hall. "It's a reflective moment," he said, as he recalled how his two young daughters "came into the office to visit for special events and ran up and down the hallways."
It is not easy to keep everyone happy in a struggling patronage-hungry city, and Mr. Cooper acknowledged that there had been difficult times. "I have no regrets about the ups and downs of public life," he said. "That's the reality of the job." But, he added, "I will always be the city's son." Ever mindful not to forget whence he has come, Mr. Cooper said he wants his new job to "bode well for the citizens of New Jersey." He didn't offer any specifics, but for all others, perhaps there is hope that more rewards are on the way.

LENGTH: 2229 words

HEADLINE: Guess Who?

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

DATELINE: PARAMUS

 BODY:
CRYSTAL SCHIFFER was clad entirely in black except for the words on her T-shirt: Constantly Miserable. Jonathan Miller had shaggy hair, a tie-dyed shirt and shoelaces shockingly pink. Sitting on a curb outside Garden State Plaza last week, the couple enthusiastically explained why their high school classmates referred to them as freaks.
"Everyone else can walk through the hallways and nobody notices them," said Jonathan, a skinny 17-year-old who started his senior year at Lakeland Regional High School in Wanaque last week. "We come in wearing combat boots or black lipstick, whatever, and everyone is staring, nobody can believe it. We stand out. That's our point." 
 Whether they want to bare their souls or exude mystery, draw a crowd or blend into one, teen-agers define themselves by the clothes they wear. While there is some risk involved -- like the time Jonathan wore flowered pants to school and some jocks threatened to kill him -- it is safer, in the four-year drama that is high school, to make a statement through clothes than through words or deeds.
It is also easier, in an era when retailers are bombarding the teen-age population with mail-order catalogs, television advertisements and layouts in fashion magazines. Fashion trends set by movie stars and musicians spread faster than ever these days, in music videos and movies, on tabloid television shows and computer screens. And teen-agers, the most eager and impressionable consumers, take it all quite seriously.
"They are trying to identify themselves and tell people who they are," said Ruth Rubenstein, a professor of sociology at the Fashion Institute of Technology in New York City. "So, yes, it makes sense that they are the ones most likely to buy. The marketers know that and they've gotten very clever in their merchandis ing. Marketing toward teens is stronger than ever before."
That means the choices are more dizzying than ever, which is why several teen-agers interviewed said that picking out clothes was more stressful than fun. Dozens of stores sell black T-shirts, for example, but only a few brands are considered universally cool. Baggy jeans are the rage, but the boy who wears them four times bigger than his size instead of three can expect to be heckled. It is enough to make Ricky Jones, who is switching from parochial to public school in Jersey City this fall, dread life without a uniform.
"Kids these days get judged on what they wear, no doubt," said Ricky, 15, who was shopping at Newport Centre Mall last Tuesday. "I would rather stick to a uniform because it's less pressure."
But even though some public schools have adopted dress codes in the hope of turning students' attention away from clothes, most still allow anything that is not too short or tight or full of holes. With so many options, most teen-agers gravitate toward styles that make them feel distinctive, but still part of a group, said Maurice Elias, a professor of psychology at Rutgers University.
"Their way of being different is not unique in the true meaning of the word," said Professor Elias, who specializes in adolescent psychology. "They might want to be significantly different from the mainstream, but it's the unusual kid who wants to be totally out there on their own."
Instead, as students return to the high schools of New Jersey this month, they are also returning to niches defined by boot-cut jeans (preferably faded) and flannel shirts (plaid only), track pants (Adidas, please) and clunky black shoes (Doc Martens, even though they make your feet look huge). There are preppys and jocks, hippies and homeys, ravers, skaters, and freaks.
While a teen-ager's look is partly a product of where he lives and how wealthy he is, some things -- beepers, boots and extra-large T-shirts, for example -- are coveted by everyone, everywhere. And increasingly, fashion statements are cutting across geographic and economic borders.
As difficult as they are to explain, clothing styles are a pet topic among high school students, who can discuss the subtleties of teen fashion with the authority of connoisseurs. Questioned about their wardrobes, teen-agers shopping at malls around the state last week expounded at length. Some even waxed philosophical.
"It's all about being yourself," said Seta Papazian, 16, a senior at Paramus Catholic High School who wears rings in her nose and lip, a tongue stud and a leather jacket with faux-fur insets. "Clothes are your creativity being manifested onto a physical plane."
 
The Hip-Hop Look: Big, Bold, Booted
 To understand why Randy Tiller dresses the way he does -- baggy black jeans with the waistline creeping toward his knees and a black baseball cap snug on his head -- look no further than the music videos of Wu-Tang Clan. The Wu, as Randy calls them, are the most popular rap group in the country, and probably the most commercial. Their CD's come with advertisements for their clothing line, known as Wu-Wear. And the hip-hop boys of Jersey City do not miss a detail.
"Whatever the Wu wear, I wear," said Randy, 17, a senior at Snyder High School. "See how big these jeans are? Even though nobody else is going to wear them, we will because the Wu started us off."
Sitting near the glass elevator at Newport Centre, Randy and three of his friends ticked off the staples of hip-hop fashion, which they said was dictated by rap stars and spread through videos, magazines and song lyrics. Sturdy hiking boots by Timberland, Mountain Gear or Lugz, embraced by rap stars and young inner-city dwellers since the early 1990's, topped their list.
"They last long, we like the quality and they're rugged," said Charles Townsend, 17, who was drowning in a navy T-shirt and baggy Nautica jeans, with tan suede boots by Lugz. "In cities you need rugged."
Both Charles and Randy said they spent more than $1,000 of their parents' money on clothes each year, and when Ricky said he spent $300, they howled. "He's lying, he's lying!" Randy said. "Got to spend almost that much on a pair of boots!"
Oversized rugby shirts like the one Amin Norris was wearing -- by Rigo Sport, with navy, gold and white stripes -- are essential to urban hip-hoppers. The most popular rugby shirts are made by Tommy Hilfiger, an upscale company whose logo was spotted on at least a dozen chests at Newport Centre last week.
"Tommy Hilfiger takes out of the African-American tradition with bold colors, but the cut of the clothes is preppy, which also appeals," said Professor Rubenstein of the Fashion Institute of Technology. "The whole look is bold, and it's very clever merchandising. What boy doesn't want to look bold?"
Randy Jones does, but he said that on the streets of Jersey City, bright shades are being replaced with black, the only color worn by members of Wu-Tang Clan.
Another trick is wearing sweatpants with one leg rolled up to the knee, a look Randy said was invented by drug dealers who stowed cash or marijuana in the rolled pant leg. "That's the hustling thing," he said. "But now people do it who don't even know what it means. They do it so people think they're hard."
Unlike preppys, freaks and hippies, who want their clothes to appear well-worn, hip-hoppers appreciate the fresh-off-the-shelf look. Charles frowned at his new-looking jeans, pronouncing them too faded.
"You've got to look presentable," he said, adding that he planned to wear khaki pants and a button-down shirt on his first day as a senior at Ferris High School. Randy agreed, saying that the handful of skaters, freaks and ravers were the subject of contempt.
"Some kid comes in with a disco shirt with crazy designs, all polyester, it's like he enjoys being cracked on," Randy said. "Those ones that dye their hair, chains hanging off their clothes, they cut holes in their pants like a fool, they know that's not presentable."
He added, "Those kids always transfer out."
 
Making a Statement By Understatement
 Dainty wool sweaters in navy and gray. White tennis shoes, moderately scuffed. Khakis, faded Levi's and Adidas track pants with neat stripes down the sides. If these staples of Lisa Puorro's wardrobe sound simple, that is precisely the point.
She is a preppy, after all, and preppy garb is the very definition of understated.
"I haven't worn bright colors probably since grammar school," Lisa, who lives in New Providence, said last Tuesday, sitting on a bench outside the Mall at Short Hills with seven shopping bags from Bloomingdale's, Armani, J.Crew and Banana Republic at her feet. "I think they're ugly."
Instead, Lisa, 16, and other preppy teen-agers stick to basics: beige, dusty pink, darkest green and lots of black. Anything patterned is too busy, too trendy. Preppies blend effortlessly into crowds with their muted colors and classic designs, and while some would accuse them of being too conventional, they say their style is the most natural one around.
"We don't map out every single thing we wear to school and obsess about how it's going to look," said a 16-year-old girl who would identify herself only as Rachel, saying she did not want to be retaliated against by more flamboyant dressers. "We don't give into lame trends and we don't dress outrageous just to freak people out."
Their detractors say that preppies are the least creative dressers, buying clothes for the designer labels and wearing subtle styles because they are afraid to stand out.
"They buy all this expensive, boring crap and you hear them at the food court," said Seta Papazian, the leather-jacketed Paramus Catholic student, who raised her voice half an octave to do an imitation. "They're like, 'Oh my God, can I use your cell phone for minute because I have to call Steve and tell him I got that Gucci dress'."
The teen-agers picking through merchandise at three of the preppiest stores at Short Hills -- J. Crew, the Gap and Banana Republic -- appeared to be taking some fashion risks. Tank tops were the most popular attire among girls, but bra straps -- all the rage in nightclubs and on catwalks this summer -- were prominently displayed. One wore combat boots beneath a flowing, flowered skirt.
But Lisa Puorro, who held up a demure, newly purchased gray cardigan from Armani before riding off in her mother's black Jeep, said the chicest clothes were the simplest ones. She does not even mind wearing a uniform -- wool skirt, white oxford shirt, navy sweater -- at Mount St. Mary Academy in Watchung, where she will be a junior. "It's a lot easier," she said, "when everyone looks the same."
 
Looking Freaky, And Proud of It
 Once a year, on the day school photographs are taken, Kerri Tamburro abandons her lace-trimmed slip skirts, steel-toed boots and studded leather bracelets for plain old pants and a sweater. There is a perfectly good explanation.
"My grandfather pays me $20 to $40 to look normal for the picture," said Kerri, a sophomore at Ridgefield Memorial High School who bears a slight resemblance to the grunge rock star Courtney Love and likes to point it out. "He hates what I wear with a passion, but what's he going to do, lock me out?"
It has not come to that, not yet, but Kerri and her friends, all self-described freaks, said family members, classmates and strangers criticized their clothes, hair and makeup at least once a day. They claimed not to mind the attention, which they said only confirmed that they were the most creative, nonconformist teen-agers in town. Jonathan Miller, the shaggy-haired Lakeland Regional student, said he dressed outrageously just to provoke his peers.
"Sometimes I wear black lipstick," said Jonathan, who lives in Ringwood and describes himself as "a freak by nature but a hippie at heart." "First I did it because it was fun, and then I realized how much it bothered people, how much they wanted to beat me up just for that. "
Jonathan's girlfriend, Crystal Schiffer of Wanaque, said she got a similar reaction after she painted "666" on her forehead for a Marilyn Manson concert at Giant Stadium. She got sunburned and the numbers were branded on her forehead for days.
"People stayed away," she said. "I didn't care. You become an impenetrable fortress of your own oddness."
But the attention is at least occasionally ego-bruising. Although dozens of teen-agers were loitering outside Garden State Plaza one recent afternoon, Crystal and Jonathan were the first to be reprimanded by security guards. And Seta Papazian, who wears punk attire wherever she goes, said she could not enjoy a recent visit to the Jersey Shore.
"I got called a Nazi and a satanist," said Seta, who was wearing black stockings she had shredded with a razor blade and an impossibly short plaid skirt held together with safety pins. "It's like, you small-minded idiots. My real friends are the ones who are going to get to know me before labeling me. You don't judge a person by their clothes."
But if that is true, why was Jonathan planning to wear a shredded Marilyn Manson T-shirt, black cutoffs, black combat boots and black lipstick on the first day of class? Did he really want his classmates to ignore his appearance?
"No way," he said, closing his eyes as if to imagine his arrival at school, a sea of conventionally dressed students parting to let him through. "I've got a whole new generation of freshmen I have to scare."
