HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: In Uphill Battles, 3 Democrats Offer Visions to Challenge the Mayor's;
Messinger Sounds the Alarm

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN 

 BODY:
On the hot Sunday afternoon before Labor Day, Ruth W. Messinger stood on the deck around a swimming pool at the Skyview Apartments, a co-op complex in the Riverdale section of the Bronx, squinting as the sun glittered off the water, and came face to face with what may be the biggest obstacle in her quest to become mayor of New York.
Before her stood not the Rev. Al Sharpton or Councilman Sal F. Albanese of Brooklyn -- her two main opponents in Tuesday's Democratic primary -- nor Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, the pugnacious Republican incumbent, but Cyndee Blauner, a schoolteacher and mother of two, a registered Democrat who will certainly cast a ballot in November. 
 "I think things in the city right now are better than they've been in a long time," Ms. Blauner said, making a point often repeated to Ms. Messinger at campaign stops around the city. It is not that Ms. Blauner is certain she will vote for Mr. Giuliani, as she did in 1993, but that she wonders whether there is reason not to.
On the long summer's march toward Primary Day, Ms. Messinger has sought to provide many reasons, particularly what she describes as Mr. Giuliani's dismal record on education. She has visited almost a public school a day, sometimes two, to talk about overcrowding, poor reading scores and what she calls inadequate spending on education.
"I am attacking Rudy Giuliani's record in education," Ms. Messinger said recently during a visit to Public School 19 in Corona, Queens. "I am telling you that on his watch, in Giuliani time, the budget of the schools has been cut, reading scores have gone down, schools have become increasingly overcrowded and education for a million children has deteriorated."
Ms. Messinger has also sought to blame the Mayor for incidents of police brutality. In her public comments, she frequently makes references to "Giuliani time," the words that Abner Louima, a Haitian immigrant, says were uttered by police officers who have been charged with brutalizing him in the bathroom of a police precinct house in Brooklyn.
And she often makes the city's unemployment rate another mark against Mr. Giuliani. "Unemployment is hovering just under or just at 10 percent, more than twice the national average," she told Brooklyn business owners. "We rank highest among the 20 largest cities in this country in our unemployment numbers. We rank 19th out of 20 in job creation. That's bad for the future of the city."
But even after more than 20 years in public service that took her from a school board to City Council and on to Manhattan Borough President, and even as she has sought to present herself as the leading Democratic contender -- usually ignoring her primary opponents to focus on Mr. Giuliani -- Ms. Messinger is relatively unrecognized beyond her core constituents in Manhattan. At campaign stops, passers-by like Jose Olea, 24, who saw her in Washington Heights, often ask, "Who's Ruth?"
During a visit by Ms. Messinger to P.S. 69 in Jackson Heights, Queens, Migdalia Guzman, 42, a bookkeeper and mother of two, spoke to her last week about the struggles of working parents. After a few minutes, perhaps tipped by the television crews and campaign posters, she asked, "Are you Ruth Messinger?"
Ms. Messinger's focused attacks on the Mayor have come at a price. She has been attacked, in turn, by many of the Mayor's allies, including Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew and Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato.
It also led to early, direct comparisons to Mr. Giuliani, who remains popular. Alfreda Wilson, 41, a civilian police employee, saw Ms. Messinger outside P.S. 249 in Flatbush, Brooklyn. "I like what she's saying about education," Ms. Wilson said. "But what does she say about crime?"
Mr. Giuliani is not invincible, many voters on the street say. Ms. Blauner, at the Skyview Apartments, said that her concerns about police brutality had made her think twice about voting for the Mayor.
But the Messinger campaign so far has been unable to capitalize on any such weakness to energize large numbers of voters. Her campaign events do not generate large crowds. And at times, logistical missteps by her campaign, such as her late arrivals to Bushwick High School on the first day of school last week, have cost her opportunities to win more attention.
Some say they need to know more before voting for change. "I am not a big fan of Rudy Giuliani, but I am not quite sure how strong a candidate Ruth Messinger is," said Michelle Foster, who runs an employment agency and was at the Skyview pool. "I would like to see an alternative. I would like to see a strong alternative. I just don't know how good a leader she is."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ruth W. Messinger campaigned at yesterday's labor parade. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

Chart: "ISSUES: The Candidates' Plans"
Where the Democratic mayoral candidates stand on issues.
 
CRIME
 
Sal F. Albanese -- Would not support any reduction in size of police force. Supports creation of an independent board to monitor instances of police brutality. Would hire 500 sergeants to increase supervision of younger officers. Would institute tighter screening in hiring.
 
Ruth W. Messinger -- Would put more officers on police patrol through increased use of civilians on desk jobs, but might also seek to reduce overall size of force to trim the budget. Supports creation of an independent oversight agency to monitor police brutality.
 
The Rev. Al Sharpton -- Opposes reduction in size of police force. Would push for more focus on community policing and having officers work closely with community groups. Supports independent review board of police department.
 
EDUCATION
 
Sal F. Albanese -- Would hire more teachers to reduce class sizes to under 25 in first three grades. Supports perfor 2/3mance-based standards for principals, using salary increases or, converse 2/3ly, specter of dismissal to im 2/3prove their performance. Undecided on retaining Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew.
 
Ruth W. Messinger -- Would hire more teachers to decrease class size. Would set tougher standards for student promotion, eliminating automatic grade promotion based on age. Would institute performance standards for teachers and principals. Would likely dismiss Chancellor Crew.
 
The Rev. Al Sharpton -- Would hire 3,000 more teachers and review each teacher's performance and negotiate for penalties for teachers who don't perform well. Undecided on Chancellor Crew.
 
ECONOMY
 
Sal F. Albanese -- Would hire an economic development czar from the business world to encourage small-business develop 2/3ment. Would advocate residency for prospective city employees to increase local employment. Would focus most economic development efforts on small businesses.
 
Ruth W. Messinger -- Supports targeted tax credits to foster development. Believes companies that do business with New York should be required to hire a certain number of city employees. Believes that companies that get tax abatements should be required to create jobs in New York.
 
The Rev. Al Sharpton -- Would set goal of 120,000 new jobs and pledges to cut unemployment in half. Would accomplish that with a public works program and a requirement that contractors and companies that get tax incentives or city business pledge that 80 percent of new employees be city residents.
 
WELFARE
 
Sal F. Albanese -- Believes welfare recipients should be required to work. Would bring in someone from a city that has been innovative in welfare reforms. Would increase day care programs for welfare recipients. Supports giving welfare recipients working in government jobs the right to organize.
 
Ruth W. Messinger -- Believes welfare recipients should be required to work. Believes participants in Work Experience Program should be allowed to organize and are entitled to workplace protection. Supports increased spending on day care and education training.
 
The Rev. Al Sharpton -- Says welfare recipients should be required to work in real jobs or be placed in training programs. Would give people in welfare work programs the right to organize. Would emphasize training and day care programs.
 
TAXES
 
Sal F. Albanese -- Supports increasing taxes if we needed to, and specifically mentions the commuter tax and the tax rate on higher income New Yorkers. Supports cutting taxes on unincorporated business, com 2/3mercial rent and clothing sales.
 
Ruth W. Messinger -- Does not believe taxes would have to be raised in her term. Supports cutting taxes on unincorporated business and commercial rent, and also supports cutting sales tax on clothing.
 
The Rev. Al Sharpton -- Would ask state Legislature to increase the commuter tax and, if the city went into a downturn, would reinstitute a stock transfer tax. Would not support any other for city residents. Supports cutting taxes on unincorporated business, commercial rent and clothing sales.

INTERNATIONAL 3-20
 
Millions in Britain Bid Farewell to Princess Diana
Britain bid farewell to Diana, Princess of Wales, with a grand tribute as rich in popular pageantry as it was in regal pomp. At a high church ceremony in Westminster Abbey, her coffin was wrapped in the maroon and gold royal standard and carried by Welsh guards. Outside, millions of people listened to the service in rapt silence and then showered the departing hearse with flowers. 1
 
Faithful Flock to Mother Teresa
Weeping masses of people gathered in the rain in Calcutta, India, to pay homage to Mother Teresa, the Roman Catholic nun who served as a tireless minister to the world's poor. She died Friday of a heart attack at 87. Her order, the Missionaries of Charity, announced that the funeral had been pushed back until Saturday to give more people a chance to pay their respects. 6 

Spacewalk Fails to Fix Mir
A six-hour spacewalk by Russian and American astronaunts failed to locate the hole in the Mir, dealing a major setback to efforts to restore the stricken space station. The complex spacewalk had been billed as reconnaissance mission to find the damage caused to the Mir during a June 25 collision with a cargo vessel. Russian officials did not conceal their disappointment. 6
 
Mali Becomes Test for Africa
Mali set an example in the wave of democratic reform that swept Africa in the early 1990's. But with the country now deep in political crisis, eyes are again on it, and its success or failure will quickly be used in the debate over whether the world's least-developed continent is ready for Western-style democracy. 3

Pollution Suit That Charges Racial Bias Bogs Down
A Federal lawsuit based on claims that racial minorities are disproportionately subjected to pollution hazards is in limbo, with racial tensions overshadowing questions of medicine and science. 32
 
Town's Savior a Gamble
When the casino industry moved into Black Hawk, Colo., to keep the town alive, it was the camel getting its nose into the tent. Now the casinos' needs may override concerns over the town's heritage. 24
 
Doing Battle With Kudzu
A caterpillar may be just the weapon to fight kudzu, an exotic vine that has become the scourge of the South. 24
 
Rules Would Limit Codes
The Clinton Administration wants to regulate the technology that protects electronic information by encoding it. All codes would have to permit access by any law-enforcement officers who had a court order allowing a wiretap. 31
 
No Proof on Chinese Role
The Senate committee on campaign financing has not produced any evidence to back up the claim that money from China affected the 1996 Presidential election. 28
 
Recharging the Ethics Panel
The House ethics committee has been quiescent since the Newt Gingrich case. It may start taking new complaints soon, but filling the seats on the panel won't be easy. 28
 
Tracking a Cosmic Collision
Chunks of the space rock that crashed into the asteroid called Vesta billions of years ago are still falling to Earth as meteorites. 42

Jobs on Horizon in East Harlem
A new manufacturing plant will soon open in East Harlem, and if all goes as planned, there will be many more. This projected burst of economic activity seems likely to follow the city's sale of about three acres of derelict property to dozens of small companies that would provide solid jobs. 45

HEADLINE: Ernst C. Stiefel Dies at 89; Lawyer Fled Hitler

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Ernst C. Stiefel, a German-born Jewish lawyer whose answer to Adolf Hitler was to become one of Germany's pre-eminent lawyers -- while practicing in New York -- died on Wednesday at a hospital in Baden-Baden. He was 89.
In a half-century of advising American corporate investors on the intricacies of German commercial laws and providing corresponding advice for German companies investing in the United States, Dr. Stiefel (pronounced STEE-ful) never forgot that he was one of the lucky ones. 
 As a lawyer, he felt the sting of Nazi anti-Semitism early enough to get out before things turned seriously ugly. He was a prime example of the unfathomable folly of Hitler's campaign against the Jews, which hounded thousands of Jewish lawyers and judges into exile and enriched dozens of other countries with exported talent. One bitter irony of the Holocaust is that the value of the millions of lives cut short and careers foreshortened is best measured by the accomplishments of those who survived.
A native of Mannheim, he demonstrated such an early and brilliant affinity for the law that a monograph on insurance law he wrote at the age of 17 is still being cited. Yet after receiving a law degree from the University of Heidelberg, he was able to practice in Mannheim for all of two weeks in 1933 before he and other Jewish lawyers were disbarred.
Lest anyone forget the magnitude of that wound, Dr. Steifel made it one of his life's missions to document and chronicle the contributions made to dozens of foreign legal systems by refugee Jewish lawyers. And as an adviser to the Allied military government in Germany after World War II, he helped lay the legal groundwork for a system of restitution and reparation that by the German Government's own account has sent more than $50 billion to Holocaust survivors living abroad.
Obtaining law degrees from the University of Paris and the Middle Temple in London, as well as an advanced degree from the University of Strasbourg, Dr. Stiefel practiced briefly in France and England before moving to New York in 1939, when he found that his multiple degrees qualified him for a position as a restaurant dishwasher: a job, he later recalled, whose meager salary and limited kitchen privileges left him hungry only some of the time.
He later became a chauffeur for a prominent lawyer and eventually found work as a clerk in a law office, where his duties included going out for sandwiches.
Along the way he impressed two Sullivan & Cromwell partners, John Foster Dulles and his brother Allen, who secured him a job with the wartime Office of Economic Warfare studying international insurance company records to identify strategic German industrial targets.
Dr. Stiefel, who became an American citizen, passed the New York State bar examination in 1944, making him what colleagues insist was the first and only lawyer licensed to practice in four countries.
An independent practitioner, he was first affiliated with Cleary, Gottlieb. Since 1971 he had been with Coudert Brothers.
As a New York lawyer with a practice focused largely on Germany, Dr. Stiefel, who maintained an office in Dusseldorf, made numerous trips to Germany, typically traveling with so much luggage that airline personnel must have taken him for something of a clotheshorse; they didn't know that 9 of his 10 suitcases were crammed with legal papers.
A short, energetic man whose idea of a relaxing vacation was to hike barefoot through the Swiss Alps, Dr. Stiefel had an enormous capacity for work. He wrote scores of books and papers on complex legal issues, taught at New York Law School, and never retired. On his final trip to Germany he was pressing a claim for a family he had represented for almost 50 years.
For all his regret over the Nazi era, Dr. Steifel, who was credited with rewriting the German traffic code after the war, made so many contributions to German commerce and German law that in 1995 he was decorated by the German Government.
Still, when it came to academic philanthropy, Dr. Steifel, whose legal work and shrewd investments made him a multimillionaire, focused his attention on New York Law School. Among other contributions, he endowed a $1.5 million chair in comparative law.
Dr. Stiefel, who was married briefly, is survived by a nephew, Eli Maor of Cleveland, and a niece, Shulamith Nathanson of Israel.

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATES;
Mayoral Candidates Court Voters In Last Days of Muted Campaign

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
From a labor parade up Fifth Avenue to a campaign caravan across the five boroughs, the Democratic candidates for New York City mayor vigorously tried to court voters yesterday in the final weekend of a primary campaign that has turned into one of the least contentious and most muted Democratic mayoral contests in a generation.
But even as the campaign played out its quiet final days, the Democrats -- attending a parade that has historically been closely identified with Democratic dominance in New York politics -- were reminded of the political stature of the man they were seeking to defeat. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani marched with union leaders near the front of the delayed Labor Day parade -- a privilege always given the incumbent and a reminder that the Republican Mayor had lined up the support of nearly 30 unions. 
 Two of the Democrats seeking to unseat him -- Sal F. Albanese, who has considerable organized union support, and Ruth W. Messinger, who does not -- walked farther back in the line of the parade, which drew relatively few spectators along most of the route. The Rev. Al Sharpton skipped the parade altogether, protesting that "the labor movement has turned to Giuliani." Mr. Sharpton instead appeared at a news conference with the family of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors say was assaulted by the police last month.
The events yesterday provided some of the last opportunities the candidates will have for on-the-street campaigning before the primary on Tuesday. Their activities, under an intermittently slate-gray September sky, signaled the closing of a contest so subdued that several Democrats said the only real intrigue was how low the turnout would be, and whether there really might be a chance that Ms. Messinger, who has been viewed as the overwhelming front-runner, might receive fewer than than 40 percent of the votes and thus be forced into a runoff.
Between news conferences, parades, breakfasts and Mr. Sharpton's campaign caravan, the Democrats described themselves as satisfied with the campaigns they had run, asserting they had presented voters with a full portrait of their candidacies.
Mr. Albanese described his campaign as "picture perfect" as he stood outside a pre-parade breakfast of union leaders. "We have been subject to a media blackout," he said. "The media has anointed Ruth Messinger as the front-runner. We have overcome those odds. People are saying there will be a runoff."
As she waited a block from Fifth Avenue for the parade to begin, Ms. Messinger shrugged off her poor showing of union support, and instead beamed confidently about her prospects in Tuesday's primary. She said her campaign, with its repeated visits to overcrowded public schools, had set the tone for the general election against Mr. Giuliani.
"We have defined education as the single most important issue for voters this year," Ms. Messinger said.
Mr. Sharpton, who is hoping that few voters will turn out for Ms. Messinger, forcing a runoff between them, said that the campaign had ratified his standing as a political force in the city.
"When I entered this race, the reaction was a sort of tongue-in-cheek snicker: 'What can he do?' " Mr. Sharpton said. "Now, people are speculating about whether there will be a runoff. We have turned the critics and the cynics around."
Ms. Messinger walked the parade route and then went to Queens, where she campaigned among the bustle of back-to-school shoppers on Jamaica Avenue, drawing cheers and chants of encouragement at every step. "I'm not voting for Giuliani," said Tony Medy, 23, a United Parcel Service driver. Mr. Medy said he did not know whether he would vote for Ms. Messinger, either.
Mr. Albanese was greeted warmly during the parade. He walked the route twice, and then lingered to shake the hand of everybody who stopped by to say hello.
"I was going to vote for Messinger but she hasn't caught fire," said Katherine Avakian, 58, one of those who stopped. A secretary from the Upper East Side, she said that Mr. Albanese "comes across as a human being who doesn't change his ideas every minute."
Mr. Albanese and Ms. Messinger ended their public appearances to prepare for two debates today: an official Campaign Finance Board debate at 11:30 A.M., which will be broadcast on Channel 7, and a debate that is scheduled to begin at 5 P.M. on Channel 4. A debate that was taped on Friday will be televised on Channel 2 at 11 A.M.
Mr. Sharpton spent his afternoon and evening in an eight-car motorcade, on what he promised would be a 20-stop swing through the city.
"They're saying the city has gone to sleep," he told a small crowd in front of Fluffy Unisex hair salon in Queens. "Unemployment is higher than it's ever been. The case of Abner Louima has brought police brutality into the open. We can win this primary."
Besides Mr. Albanese, Mr. Sharpton and Ms. Messinger, the field includes two lesser-known candidates, Roland Rogers, a businessman, and Eric Ruano-Melendez, a civil engineer in the city's Environmental Protection Department. A potentially formidable candidate, Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, dropped out earlier in the year.
Several potentially strong challengers to Mr. Giuliani, like city Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, skipped this contest, in deference to what they saw as his strength this year and in recognition of the fact that he would, if re-elected, be barred from running again in four years by the city's term-limit law.
Indeed, as a political event, the Labor Day parade -- which was switched to Saturday from Labor Day in hopes of drawing more people -- was probably as much a portrait of the state of the political field today as it was a preview of the political candidacies to come. Among those probable future candidates in the parade were Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn and Public Advocate Mark Green, who are planning to challenge Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato next year, and Mr. Hevesi, who is almost certain to run for mayor in 2001.
If there was a politician at the center of things yesterday, it was Mr. Giuliani. By virtue of his office, he was allowed the prominence of marching at the front of the paradeand giving a speech at the union breakfast, at the Hotel Intercontinental on East 48th Street.
But notwithstanding the union support of Mr. Giuliani, there were signs yesterday that the support for the Mayor -- who cut 23,000 jobs from the city's work force through severance and attrition during his first three years -- is not particularly deep. Only half the room applauded when he rose to speak at the breakfast, and Sandra Feldman, the president of the United Federation of Teachers, which has not yet endorsed a mayoral candidate but will before the general election, pointedly credited "this being an election year" for the fact that Mr. Giuliani had supported more spending on schools.
In the parade, Mr. Giuliani marched beside Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council. There was occasional applause for the Mayor, and on every block or two, in a very organized fashion, three or four supporters of the Giuliani campaign carried signs that read, "Rudy." There were far fewer anti-Giuliani catcalls than during last year's parade, when members of several unions and leftist groups repeatedly heckled him.
Still, at the breakfast, Mr. Giuliani was better off than Mr. Albanese, who has won the support of 34 unions but, as a Councilman from Brooklyn, was not permitted to speak. Mr. Albanese stood at the side of the room with a single aide. Ms. Messinger, as Manhattan Borough President, was allowed only to present a brief proclamation at the breakfast.
Both Ms. Messinger and Mr. Albanese said later that they were neither surprised by nor concerned about the organized-labor support for Mr. Giuliani, and asserted that it would not figure in the campaign.
"I am the only candidate with real labor support," said Mr. Albanese, who marched first with a contingent of communications workers and then with auto workers. "I would argue that Giuliani's labor support is based on the fact that he's in charge and he's ruthless."
Ms. Messinger, who marched with members of the department store workers union, said she now had the support of about five unions. Ms. Messinger said that she would win Tuesday's primary, and after that would begin displaying the breadth of union support that customarily comes with being a Democratic nominee.
"We'll pick them up and we'll let you know," she said.
As the campaign closed down, the candidates continued to refrain from attacking each other. Mr. Albanese seemed perplexed when asked why he had refrained from criticizing Ms. Messinger, until his campaign manager, Don Crouch, intervened.
"You don't kick a candidate when they're going down," Mr. Crouch said.
"Yeah," Mr. Albanese said, lighting up. "You don't kick a candidate when they're going down."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani greeted onlookers yesterday from his position near the head of the belated Labor Day parade up Fifth Avenue. Two of his Democratic challengers marched farther back; one skipped the event. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)(pg. 46)

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:

PAYDAY
Unions Gather Strength, But So Do Executives
Organized labor had reason to celebrate last Monday: unions are at their strongest position in nearly a generation and are poised to gain membership after a two-decade decline, union leaders and many experts say. What's more, the 15-day United Parcel Service strike created a surge of sympathy for unions, and the A.F.L.-C.I.O., with 13 million members, is spending $20 million a year on organizing, an eightfold increase from the early 1990's. Still, union members' gains pale in comparison with those of executives. Data from the I.R.S. show that tax-deductible executive pay, before inflation, climbed 182 percent, to $307.6 billion in 1995 from $109 billion in 1980. In the same 15-year period, corporate revenues rose 129.5 percent, and corporate profits gained 127 percent. "Chief executives can pay themselves," said Robert Monks, a principal of Lens Inc., an investment fund, explaining the variance. But one group remains unhappy: 37 percent of working women say that making ends meet has become more difficult in the last five years, an A.F.L.-C.I.O. survey found, and 32 percent complain that their jobs do not provide equal pay for equal work. "Equal pay was women's No. 1 concern," said John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 

THE MARKETS
A Day to Remember
Stocks have given investors a bumpy ride this year, but if the general direction is up, who can complain? On Tuesday, the Dow industrials roared back from the holiday weekend with the biggest one-day point gain on record -- 257.36 points -- only to settle down for a a peaceful couple of days before closing on Friday at 7,822.41, down 44.83 for the day but up 199.99 for the week. Big stocks like Procter & Gamble and Gillette slid, while selected technology issues like Compaq chalked up gains. The Nasdaq composite index rose 48.45 for the week, closing at 1,635.77, a record.
 
THE ECONOMY
Orders Fall but Sales Boom
The economy continued to throw out mixed signals. The National Association of Purchasing Management's factory index unexpectedly fell to 56.8 last month from 58.6 in July, reflecting a drop in orders and production. Traders took the decline as a signal that the Federal Reserve was less likely to raise interest rates to cool down the economy. Further, the economy added 49,000 jobs in August, fewer than the 72,000 that were expected, and the unemployment rate rose to 4.9 percent, from 4.8 percent in July. But August vehicle sales were up 5 percent, as Americans continued on a buying spree. The latest expensive truck models -- notably the new Mercedes-Benz sport utility vehicle and the Lincoln Navigator -- were among the most popular. G.M. said its sales rose a stronger-than-expected 7.6 percent in August; Chrysler reported a 0.5 percent gain and Ford, 3.6 percent. Retailers enjoyed similar gains, thanks to back-to-school shoppers. The Goldman, Sachs retail composite index rose 5.7 percent. The Gap, Kmart and Wal-Mart Stores were among those reporting gains.
 
CIGARETTES
7 Cents Higher
The nation's largest cigarette makers, taking Wall Street by surprise, raised wholesale prices an average of 7.6 percent, which will mean a climb of 7 cents a pack at retail. The increase, believed to be the industry's largest single such move, is expected to bring in nearly $1.6 billion over the next 12 months. The money could be used for payments on settlements of lawsuits with Florida and Mississippi and one expected with Texas. The suits seek to recover medical costs of smoke-related illnesses. Congressional leaders said that they had no plans to act on the proposed $368 billion tobacco settlement this year, but advocates of the proposal feared that such a delay could kill the deal.
 
GAS PRICES
An Expensive Thirst
With a summer surge in demand, the price of gasoline at the pump took one of its biggest monthly jumps ever in August -- as much as 15 cents a gallon for regular unleaded fuel at some New York stations, where the average price was $1.29 a gallon. Even running their refineries at a record 99.4 percent of capacity, oil companies have barely kept up with the nation's drivers, who increasingly favor hefty, less-efficient sport utility vehicles. Also, Americans have driven more this summer, some to escape rising air fares and others because a strong economy has given them the money to travel.
 
FRENCH PRIVATIZATION
Socialist or Capitalist?
France's Socialist-led Government reached diametrically opposite decisions on privatizing the country's two most visible state-owned companies. The chairman of Air France, Christian Blanc, announced plans to quit, after Prime Minister Lionel Jospin rejected his pleas to turn the country's flagship airline into a private company. But just a few hours later, Government officials formally recommended proceeding with a much-delayed plan to sell off one-third of the national telephone monopoly, France Telecom. That privatization would give the Government a $4 billion windfall, which would help lower its deficit enough to qualify for Europe's forthcoming single currency.
 
ACQUISITIONS
Hotels, Ships and Meat
Promus Hotel and the Doubletree Corporation agreed to a merger that would create one of the world's biggest hotel companies, with combined revenue of $5 billion from 1,136 hotels whose brands include Red Lion and Embassy Suites. The deal values Promus at about $2.1 billion and Doubletree at $1.8 billion. Hudson Foods agreed to be bought by Tyson Foods in a cash-and-stock deal valued at $681 million; a tainted-beef crisis at Hudson last month led to the largest recall of meat in the nation's history. In Frankfurt, Preussag A.G. agreed to buy Hapag-Lloyd A.G. for $1.5 billion, shifting its focus from coal and metals to shipping and the fast-growing tourism business. Beckman Instruments, which makes medical testing equipment, said it would pay $875 million for the Coulter Corporation, a privately held maker of machines that analyze blood cell counts, and assume $175 million of Coulter's debt.
 
SUPERCOMPUTERS
9,072 Pentium Pros at Work
Janus, the world's fastest supercomputer, at Sandia National Laboratories in Albuquerque, N.M., can perform a once-inconceivable trillion mathematical operations a second. Housed in 84 tall gray cabinets, it uses 9,072 Pentium Pro processors built by Intel to simulate complex events -- like explosions, nuclear fusion reactions, missile impacts or the crash of a comet into Earth -- with a fineness of detail that was hitherto impossible.
 
APPLE'S DEAL
$100 Million for a Clone Maker
Apple Computer agreed to buy the Macintosh business of its largest licensee, Power Computing of Austin, Tex., for $100 million. The move effectively ended the embattled personal computer maker's strategy of trying to grow through the cloning of its Macintosh computers. Apple will buy the technology, direct marketing and build-to-order capabilities of Power Computing, the largest and most aggressive of the handful of companies that have been selling computers that run the Macintosh operating system. It will also take on some employees.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2876 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Hiltons They Aren't: 2 Guys In a Hurry

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
J. WILLARD MARRIOTT built his food and lodging empire from a root beer stand opened with $500 in Washington, D.C. Conrad Hilton turned a $5,000 investment in a fleabag hotel in Cisco, Tex., into one of the world's best-known hotel companies. And two Harvard classmates, Ernest Henderson and Robert Moore, started the Sheraton chain by pooling their World War I veterans' bonuses to invest in real estate.
So much for humble beginnings. Today, after more than two decades in which the main action in the hotel industry revolved around conglomerates, investment banks and big property developers, the hotel moguls are back. But this time, they need more than just a dollar and a dream; they need financial acumen, deep-pocketed backers and, if they can swing it, control of a real estate investment trust -- better yet, a paired-share real estate investment trust. 
 Most people don't have a clue what that is, of course, and that is where two improbable magnates -- Barry S. Sternlicht, 36, a financial whiz from Connecticut who is the son of a Holocaust survivor from Poland, and Paul A. Nussbaum, 50, a lawyer from Brooklyn, himself no slouch at finance -- have a great advantage: They do.
Their understanding of how to capitalize on the REIT (rhymes with "heat") has helped them put together two of the fastest-growing hotel empires in the United States. It has also won them the admiration of real estate analysts and professionals. "They're both very competitive, very smart, good deal makers," said Barry Greenfield, the manager of Fidelity Investments' real estate fund, "and both have a vision for their company and know how to appeal to Barry Greenfield to buy their stock."
Others are buying their stock, too.
Mr. Sternlicht is chairman and chief executive of Starwood Lodging Trust, the nation's biggest hotel REIT, with a market capitalization of about $2.2 billion. Based in Phoenix, Starwood owns or controls about 100 hotels and is said to have the inside track to buy the 100 properties of Westin Hotels and Resorts for about $1.4 billion.
Starwood trades on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol HOT -- and it has lived up to the label. The stock almost doubled last year and so far this year has gained 31 percent, closing at $48.06 on Friday. Those gains outpaced the broader bull market and other hotel stocks, though the company certainly basks in the glow of the industry's remarkable recovery. Last year, hotels racked up $12.5 billion in pretax profits, their best year ever and 40 percent more than their cumulative $8.7 billion profits over the last 14 years, according to Smith Travel Research, the lodging industry's unofficial scorekeeper.
Riding close on Mr. Sternlicht's heels is Mr. Nussbaum, the chairman and chief executive of Patriot American Hospitality in Dallas, the second-biggest hotel REIT, with a market capitalization of about $1.6 billion. With 65 hotels and resorts, many of them acquired in the last year, its portfolio of owned or leased properties will rise to 105 late this year upon completion of several agreements, including the billion-dollar acquisition of the Wyndham Hotel Corporation. One of Patriot American's properties, the Aristocrat Hotel in downtown Dallas, was the first hotel built by Conrad Hilton, in 1925.
Patriot American's stock is also sizzling. Its price more than doubled last year and has done even better so far this year, closing on Friday at $24.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
NOT everyone is enthusiastic about REIT's, especially those analysts who have seen them rise and fall.
"Lost in the euphoria of mergers and acquisitions is the inevitability of the business cycle," said Stanley Turkel, a hotel consultant. "While REIT's are brilliant vehicles of acquisition, they are public corporations with stringent and constant earnings requirements. How will they survive a downturn in the marketplace? Not too well, I believe."
But for now, REIT's are riding high. Asked whether Patriot American or Starwood would be the better investment, Barry Vinocur, editor of the Realty Stock Review, said both were "terrific." Having to choose between them, he added, "is like having to choose between your children." But he said he would probably give a slight edge to Starwood if it acquired Westin and proceeded to put its other hotels under the Westin banner.
In contrast to their more colorful early 20th-century counterparts -- Mr. Hilton, for example, was briefly married to Zsa Zsa Gabor -- both Mr. Nussbaum and Mr. Sternlicht are content to pull the strings in relative obscurity. While they are workaholics -- perhaps because they are workaholics -- both are content to avoid the limelight.
"I don't need my name on my hotels," Mr. Sternlicht said. "I get my satisfaction from the share price performance."
Moreover, the new moguls have been content to buy, rather than to build, their hotel empires. Most of the early hotel pioneers put their chains together from scratch, at least until the Depression's devastating aftermath resulted in a glut of solid if rundown hotels that could be picked up for next to nothing. Mr. Hilton's goal in the early 1920's was to put up a new hotel each year; outpacing his objective, he had built eight before the crash of 1929.
"He was able to make the kind of deals that, because of the incredible competition, are just virtually impossible to make today," said his son Barron Hilton, the chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, who succeeded his father at the company's helm in 1966. As the elder Hilton built hotels around the world, "in exchange for putting up the working capital, he would get one-third of the profits, and the owners would get two-thirds," Barron Hilton said of his father's practices. "Those kind of deals just don't get done anymore." (The elder Hilton died in 1979.)
But if neither Mr. Sternlicht nor Mr. Nussbaum is exactly another Conrad Hilton, that is not to say the two men have led humdrum lives.
Mr. Sternlicht, a graduate of Brown University and Harvard Business School, led JMB Realty's unsuccessful effort to buy the Hilton hotel chain in the late 1980's. He also headed a team at JMB that analyzed the finances of Randsworth Trust P.L.C, a British real estate company, before JMB, together with a partnership of American pension funds, bought it in 1989. Randsworth's collapse two years later left shareholders holding the bag for more than $425 million. Interviewed at his office in Greenwich, Conn., Mr. Sternlicht said of that fiasco, "You learn a lot more from your failures than your successes."
Mr. Nussbaum is perhaps an even more improbable hotel mogul. After covering high school sports as a stringer for The New York Journal-American, he had visions of becoming a writer -- until, as a student at the State University of New York at Buffalo, he took a course in creative writing from John Barth, whose novels abound in word play, allegory and metaphor. "That humbled me," Mr. Nussbaum remembered.
So he abandoned fiction for Georgetown Law School, where his entrepreneurial bent emerged. He held a one-seventh interest with other law students in a nearby bar and grill and, with two other classmates, provided legal research for law firms in the Washington area.
"If it was over our heads," he said with a laugh, "we hired our professors."
SOON after graduation he began a 20-year career practicing real estate law. But by 1991, certain that real estate would soon rebound along with the American economy, Mr. Nussbaum decided it was time once more to test his entrepreneurial talent, this time on a larger scale. He formed the Patriot American Group with New York and Canadian investors, including William Mack, senior managing partner of the Mack Company and president of Apollo Real Estate Management Inc., and John H. Daniels, a co-founder of the Cadillac Fairview Corporation in Toronto.
Patriot American initially went shopping for the cut-rate jewels that had fallen into the hands of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the Government agency, now defunct, that handled the savings and loan bailout of the late 1980's and early 1990's. Patriot American bought 26 office buildings and the Bourbon Orleans Hotel in New Orleans from the R.T.C. in 1992.
Over the next few years, the company acquired more hotels at bargain prices as banks, savings institutions, insurance companies and other lenders delightedly left a business they had entered -- literally by default -- during the recession that began in the late 1980's.
In 1995, Patriot American Group put the hotels into Patriot American Hospitality, whose initial public offering that year sold at $24 a share (the stock has since split) and raised more than $300 million. Today, the company's holdings include luxurious properties like the Tutwiler in Birmingham, Ala., the Tremont House in Boston and the Union Station Hotel in Nashville.
Mr. Sternlicht had financial backing from his own set of big financial players, starting Starwood six years ago with a $10 million investment from the Ziff publishing family and an identical infusion from the Burden family of New York, descendants of Cornelius Vanderbilt. Both families have since increased their initial investments substantially, and the Pritzker family of Chicago, which owns the Hyatt hotel chain, has also put up money.
At first, Mr. Sternlicht's properties consisted largely of thousands of multifamily garden apartments, most of them in the Southwest, bought at deep discount from the R.T.C. But as competitors jumped in and his small staff could not manage the apartments, he sold them to Sam Zell, the Chicago real estate giant, and turned his attention to hotels.
WHY hotels? Mr. Sternlicht said that while hotels were then out of favor with investors, "they had the best demand profile of any asset class, and construction financing for upscale hotels was hard to obtain."
As for Mr. Nussbaum, he said simply that what sparked his interest was that "a lot of good hotels were selling for 25 cents on the dollar."
Mr. Sternlicht's company, Starwood, is named for a community near Aspen, Colo., where the company was put together. In 1993, it bought 15 hotels from the Westinghouse Electric Corporation for about $85 million and the assumption of $180 million in debt. Today, Starwood's portfolio includes Ritz-Carltons, Sheratons, Hiltons and Hyatts as well as Days Inns and Holiday Inns.
What they lack in the earlier generation's flamboyance, Mr. Sternlicht and Mr. Nussbaum more than make up for in their understanding of modern finance -- in particular, REIT's.
A REIT, basically, is an investment pool, a way to raise money for real estate investments and, likewise, for people to diversify their real estate investments across a number of properties. In their early days, in the 1960's, REIT's existed mostly as mortgage holders, but in the 1980's they began to own property outright, often focusing on specific sectors like office buildings, apartments, malls or nursing homes, as well as hotels.
Today, about 300 REIT's with a combined market value of $70 billion, are publicly traded. Investors like them because they do not pay corporate income tax, and instead are required to distribute at least 95 percent of net income to shareholders. In addition, because they trade as stocks, they are much easier to get into or out of than limited partnerships or the direct ownership of properties.
In the hotel industry, REIT's are clearly where the action is. In the first six months of 1997, hotel REIT's raised about $1 billion in public stock offerings, up from $732 million in the corresponding period of 1996, according to Coopers & Lybrand, the accounting firm. By contrast, the capital raised by non-REIT hotel companies slumped in the first half of this year, to $1.2 billion, from $2 billion in the first half of 1996.
The rise of the REIT's "marked the first time that investing in the real estate side of the lodging industry did not mean having to tie up lots of money in an illiquid asset," said Bjorn Hanson, the chairman of the hospitality unit at Coopers & Lybrand.
Moreover, while still accounting for just 5 percent of all hotels, REIT's have vastly increased their holdings in the last four years, from 39 properties to 562. And analysts expect that number to continue to grow indefinitely.
Mr. Sternlicht and Mr. Nussbaum are a big reason for that increase.
Each had the prescience to link up with REIT's that, through a grandfather clause in a 1984 Federal law, are allowed to do what no other REIT can: manage as well as own property.
These entities are known as "paired share" REIT's, because they are allowed to own separate real estate and management companies (the "pair") that are traded as a single unit (the "share"). And there are only four of them in the nation.
Last October, Patriot American obtained the special status by buying the California Jockey Club and Bay Meadows Operating Company for $195 million. (Bay Meadows operates the Bay Meadows horse racing track in the San Francisco suburbs and leases the land from California Jockey.) Starwood did the same two years ago by taking control of Hotel Investors Trust, which had piled up nearly $200 million in debt and whose stock had sunk from about $25 a share in 1986 to less than $1 in 1994.
Patriot American and Starwood thus became the only two paired-share hotel REIT's -- and if that is a mouthful, it is also a huge competitive advantage.
Other REIT's, prohibited from actively managing the properties they own, must lease the properties to third parties or to management companies established by the REIT's officers and directors. But Patriot American and Starwood do not have to pay those management fees, and they get to keep the after-tax profits of their management companies. In acquiring Wyndham and Westin, respectively, the two hotel REIT's could use those established brand names as the management companies for many of their hotels, without having to pay anyone for the privilege, and they would have direct control of pricing and capital spending on maintenance and renovations.
In the view of Thomas P. McConnell, a director of Arthur Andersen's hospitality consulting practice, the rest of the industry has not fully grasped the impact of the two companies' new structures.
"A lot of people have been paying lip service to paired-shares," he said, "but I don't think they've really understood their full power until recently." He tempered his enthusiasm, though, by noting the market risks of the REIT structure, which is so tied to the day-to-day profit of a company's portfolio "that there's inherent volatility."
Both Patriot American and Starwood Lodging still have a long way to go before ranking with the Marriott Corporation, the industry standard, whose Host Marriott owns 84 hotels and whose Marriott International manages or franchises 1,400. And the budding magnates surely lack the Horatio Alger heritage of the industry's pioneers.
J. Willard Marriott, for example, rode the Utah range as a teen-ager, pistol at his side, tending his father's flocks of sheep and cattle. He married his college sweetheart, did mission work for the Mormon church and then opened his root beer stand on the same day that Charles Lindbergh began his flight across the Atlantic.
Conrad Hilton did not ride the Utah range, but as a young man he drove mule trains through the Southwest, sleeping under the stars and stopping at haciendas during the day to buy, sell and trade cattle, mohair and hides. He also played the piano for hire, managed a trio of female musicians and served in the Army in France in World War I. Once he looked on horrified as a partner was shot dead in a Texas hotel lobby by a drunken former partner of theirs, who for years afterward threatened to do the same to Mr. Hilton.
NEITHER Mr. Nussbaum nor Mr. Sternlicht has to look over his shoulder for quite the same reason, but both are clearly aiming to join the ranks of the giants.
"Our goal is to build a world-class hotel company," Mr. Nussbaum declared, expressing special pride in his recent $47 million acquisition of the two hotels and management company of Grand Heritage Hotels of Annapolis, Md., which specializes in independent, often older hotels that have aged gracefully.
Mr. Sternlicht says Starwood has slowed the pace of its acquisitions, trying to be more strategic. "If I have four hotels in Chicago, do I need a fifth?" he said rhetorically.
But in the next breath, he said, "I'd buy anything I can get in New York and Boston at a reasonable price, and we're also missing Miami."
After all, he added, "We're the fifth-largest hotel company, and we're aiming for No. 1."

PUB-DATE: September 7, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1455 words

HEADLINE: Never Angry, Often Disappointed

BYLINE: By James Traub; James Traub, a staff writer for The New Yorker, is the author of "City on a Hill: Testing the American Dream at City College."

 BODY:

Long Way To Go
 Black and White in America.
 By Jonathan Coleman.
 451 pp. New York:
 Atlantic Monthly Press. $26.50. 
 It has become possible, in the last few years, to glimpse the emerging outlines of a kind of guilt-free zone of racial conversation. Black scholars like Randall Kennedy and Glenn Loury, and black journalists like William Raspberry and Stanley Crouch -- none of them, save perhaps Loury, conservative -- have very consciously laid down the bludgeon of racial accusation. This act of unilateral disarmament offers an invitation to liberal white scholars and journalists, accustomed to treading ever so gingerly, to think and write about vexing issues like poverty and crime and academic standards without looking over their shoulders at the racial proprieties. This ought to be an exhilarating invitation. But the impulse to see practically everything as an expression of racism is very deeply ingrained, in whites as well as blacks. It's an impulse, or a need, that provides an unintended second meaning to the title of Jonathan Coleman's book, "Long Way to Go."
Coleman is a white journalist, formerly with CBS News, who spent time in the early 1990's in Milwaukee, one of the most segregated and impoverished cities in the country. The mission that he set himself was simply to talk to everyone -- leaders and led, white and black -- and thus come to understand how, despite the heroic gains of the civil rights struggle, the economic and psychic gulf between the races could remain so vast. It's a serious and important task, and Coleman is a very conscientious guide, a Christian Pilgrim of the inner city. He has no ideology to vindicate; he does, however, come equipped with a set of conventional liberal attitudes.
At the very outset of his journey, Coleman arranges to meet with Michael McGee, an alderman and self-described revolutionary, and Jerrel Jones, an entrepreneur who is McGee's pal. Coleman gives McGee a respectful hearing as he talks of taking up arms, and he's disturbed when Jones declares that, no matter what his achievements, whites will always view him simply as "a nigger." But then he reflects that he was viewing the problem "through my lens, not Jones's. It was a mistake I would have to keep in mind as time went on, a mistake that in large part had to do with the unconsciousness of being white."
Our pilgrim turns out to be afflicted with a rather severe case of liberal guilt. Coleman insists on seeing McGee as an authentic, if deeply troubling, tribune of black opinion, and at one point he taxes Milwaukee's Mayor, John Norquist, with failing to conduct a dialogue with the alderman. Yet McGee strikes the reader as the kind of dangerous huckster who makes a career out of exploiting racial anger, and it comes as not much of a shock to learn at the end of the book that he has formed a friendship with the head of the White Aryan Resistance. Coleman seems to lack the language of condemnation; he writes that it was "disappointing to hear him talk of sabotage."
Coleman is so persuaded of the salience of race and the ubiquity of racism that sometimes he fails to notice his own evidence to the contrary. One of McGee's constituents, Maron Alexander, a proud but hard-pressed member of the black working class, tells the author "that when he died, he wanted his headstone to reflect that he was an American, not a black American, that as far as he was concerned way too much was made of race." Coleman passes over this profession of faith in a non-racial identity without comment. But when, sadly, the Alexanders' daughter, Tennille, is arrested for bringing a gun to school to impress gang members, Coleman observes: "The same stuff went on in the suburbs, but . . . you simply didn't hear about it or read about it. . . . It was another form of inequity, another way in which white privilege quietly exerted itself." This is, of course, untrue, and the reader has to wonder if the Alexanders themselves would agree; perhaps they would say that Tennille had fallen in with a bad crowd. Coleman is so desperate not to blame Tennille that he practically denies her the power of individual agency -- a form of condescension that borders on what Jim Sleeper describes as "liberal racism" in his recent book of the same name.
At times, Coleman moves well beyond the platitudes. The most intriguing character in "Long Way to Go" is Howard Fuller, who became superintendent of Milwaukee's schools while Coleman was doing his research. A former black nationalist, Fuller opposes busing to achieve integration, and advocates an all-black school with an Afrocentric curriculum. He is a figure of stoical dignity and unshakable commitment -- a race man, as Coleman writes. And yet by accepting the superintendent's job, and by trying to enlist white businessmen in his campaign to reform a dismal school system, Fuller becomes a target for black leaders who hold the views that he himself once did. He's accused of selling out when he fires a black principal.
And there's an additional wrinkle: Fuller champions a referendum to increase funding for the schools, and he presents the issue as a test of moral resolve and transracial commitment. The referendum loses by a 3-to-1 margin, and Coleman finds both blacks and dedicated white educators who have voted against it, reasoning that the money will be wasted unless the system is reformed first. The loss of consensus on social spending, in other words, is not simply a matter of "racial fatigue," to use one of Coleman's favorite phrases.
Coleman seeks out both black and white dissenters from racial orthodoxy and gives them a fair hearing. And yet he is always pulled back to the view, or perhaps the preconception, that the solution to black poverty and isolation lies in the conversion of white hearts. This leads to several passages so painful that one almost yearns for the likes of Derrick Bell, who has proposed a "racism tax" as an alternative to futile hortatory efforts.
Coleman spends a good deal of time visiting a therapy group, Beyond Racism, in which whites sit in a circle and unpack "an invisible weightless knapsack" of the 44 "unearned assets" that come with their skin color. He identifies strongly with a social worker named John Fitzgerald, who becomes almost obsessed with the task of confronting his own unacknowledged racism. Finally the strain becomes too much, and Fitzgerald provides an unexpected lesson in one of the dangers of racial guilt. In his journal, he writes exhaustedly, "Do I want to be perceived as the person who challenges norms -- who reminds people always of their prejudices -- who challenges each and every system?" Our pilgrim, however, draws an entirely different moral. If even Fitzgerald finds that "his enjoyment of the status quo" outweighs the risk of changing hearts, Coleman writes, "then there was ample reason to despair that change would ever come."
Fitzgerald is almost a parody of the author himself: the awareness of purported racism ties him in such knots that he can neither trust his own reactions nor formulate new ones. But we understand the sense of taboo that governs both writer and character. Any reasonably sensitive white person who has written about, or even talked about, the situation of blacks is aware of this taboo; perhaps the same is true of any member of a dominant class writing about a group that that class has oppressed. One's hand is stayed by the knowledge of innumerable past hurts and misdeeds. The recognition of those wrongs, along with the acceptance of the sense of collective responsibility -- guilt -- that comes with recognition, is a precondition to entering the discussion.
But it is only a precondition; and over time racial guilt has produced intellectual paralysis, placing blacks, as Shelby Steele has argued, in the role of helpless victims and making liberal whites perform the intricate pirouettes of euphemism and tact to which Coleman is prone. We need to say that racism remains a powerful force in American life but that it may no longer be the principal cause of black immiseration.
Coleman admits to genuine bewilderment about the solution to persistent black poverty. Most of the admirable characters in his book feel the same way; only the charlatans have easy answers. What apparently has not occurred to Coleman, though, is that the obsessive focus on racism and injury, the vigilant patrolling of the borders of racial identity, is part of the problem rather than part of the solution. He is absolutely right in thinking that ordinary people need to break out of the shell of racial isolation and talk to one another. But perhaps they need to talk about something other than race.

PUB-DATE: September 7, 1997

SECTION: Section 7; Page 15; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1978 words

HEADLINE: Affirmative Action and Reaction

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is the national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and the author of "The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America."

 BODY:

America in Black
 and White
 One Nation, Indivisible.
 By Stephan Thernstrom and
 Abigail Thernstrom.
 704 pp. New York:
 Simon & Schuster. $32.50. 
 The baseline for this book is "An American Dilemma," by Gunnar Myrdal. Stephan Thernstrom and Abigail Thernstrom's very first and very last paragraphs are reverential recapitulations of Myrdal. Plainly their ambition is to produce a survey of race relations that is so large and authoritative that it changes the way the issue is understood, as Myrdal's did.
In one sense, the two books can't fairly be compared. "An American Dilemma," which was published in 1944, was based upon extensive firsthand field work, mostly in the Deep South, while "America in Black and White" is done from work in the library, from reading secondary sources. Politically, however, there is a parallel. "An American Dilemma" was underwritten by a liberal foundation (the Carnegie Corporation) and written by a scholar with a mission in mind: eliminating the Jim Crow system in the South. "America in Black and White" was financed by a congeries of conservative foundations (Bradley, Olin, Smith Richardson, Earhart, Carthage), and aims to bring down affirmative action and most other policies whose stated goal is to give special help to African-Americans.
Like Myrdal, the Thernstroms are whites with a history of engagement in issues of social justice. Abigail Thernstrom has long been one of the country's leading opponents of affirmative action, especially in the drawing of electoral districts. Stephan Thernstrom, a history professor at Harvard, became the object of black student protests in 1988 as a result of a remark he made about the black family in an ethnic history course he was teaching. He later complained that he was hung out to dry by the Harvard administration and stopped teaching the course. Since then the incident has been used, in Dinesh D'Souza's "Illiberal Education" and elsewhere, as a prime example of the depredations visited upon universities by the forces of political correctness.
To assume the Myrdal mantle means speaking in a calm, clear, generous voice, but "America in Black and White" does this only intermittently. It is irresistibly tempting to discern a split personality in a volume with two authors; whether or not that is the reason, this book veers back and forth between two sensibilities, one reasonable and large-spirited, the other pugnacious and angry to the point of occasional bitterness and sarcasm. The Thernstroms' treatment of Myrdal himself provides a small example: while they invoke him as a patron saint in some places, elsewhere they convincingly take him down a peg or two. Martin Luther King Jr. gets the same treatment: portrayed sometimes as a hero with a simple, magnificent dream of a color-blind society, other times as a savvy, borderline-cynical media politician.
"America in Black and White" does have a clear, consistent line of argument, although the variability of tone vitiates it somewhat. The Thernstroms begin with a long historical section, taking up a third of the book, about the South during the age of legal segregation. It is meant to remind us how almost unimaginably bad things were for most black Americans until not all that long ago.
The Thernstroms' main point, though, is that the civil rights movement and the Federal Government intervention it brought about deserve far less credit for African-American progress than they are ordinarily given. In the authors' view, World War II, not civil rights legislation, was what firmly set black America on a better course. The economy boomed, and millions of blacks left the realm of Jim Crow for a much better life in the North. The Thernstroms also use polling data (which they rely upon heavily throughout this book) to make a case that a wholesale improvement in white attitudes toward blacks was under way before the 1960's.
The main civil rights milestones -- the Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Education decision in 1954, the 1964 Civil Rights Act and the 1965 Voting Rights Act -- get the Thernstroms' wholehearted approval. But they present all the Government's efforts aimed specifically at improving conditions in black America -- as opposed to guaranteeing the basic rights of citizenship -- as a terrible mistake, producing no gains for blacks and great resentment (wholly justified, in their opinion) by whites. In area after area -- especially affirmative action -- the Thernstroms sketch a bombed-out landscape of liberal failure. If we would abandon these race- and results-conscious efforts, they say, we could resume our former progress toward a healthier black America and better race relations.
It seems to me that most books on race relations, by authors black and white, liberal and conservative, implicitly claim to be written from the black point of view -- that is, they present themselves as being concerned solely with what's good for blacks. "America in Black and White" has less than the usual complement of this quality. It insists throughout on a more benign view of white sentiments and behavior than is customary. In their conclusion the Thernstroms say that "too much remains" of white racism. But this is inconsistent with the tone of the rest of the book; not many pages earlier, they were declaring that white "haters have become a tiny remnant with no influence in any important sphere of American life" and that "few whites are now racists." To the extent that whites are race-conscious, they say, "that has been one of the regrettable results of public policies that stress racial identity."
The Thernstroms treat black racism, on the other hand, as a much more serious problem. Since the late 1960's, they maintain, "the balance of power in racial confrontations has shifted," and what now dominates is a dynamic of "black anger" and "white surrender." The voices in black America that they hear most loudly and quote from most often are those of the race-man camp, expressing the kind of sentiments that strike them as "tribalistic effusions." There is much Derrick Bell in the text, and little William Julius Wilson.
Whites who are liberal on race issues appear here in cartoon form as radical-chic types who find black rage appealing, or as cringing, guilty softies. White supporters of affirmative action embrace "policies built on deference to black victimization through which they can display their racial virtue." When the Thernstroms take the trouble to present calmly a specific counterargument to their position and then dismantle it, as they do with the 1968 report of the Kerner Commission on urban riots, the result is fresh and interesting. But usually they are content to give a version of the other side that makes it sound merely idiotic. For example, they summarize a statement about violence in schools from an official of the A.C.L.U. thus: "So when a student won't turn off his blaring boom box in class . . . and throws a chair at another student, it's the school's fault for not having provided him with 'meaningful education.' "
Some readers undoubtedly will find the Thernstroms' version of American race relations to ring true, and will feel that their frequent citations of poll results cinch the case. But limning racial attitudes is not hard science. I found myself consistently thinking that the Thernstroms were a few degrees away from a sure, comfortable sense of the state of racial sentiments. "The white supremacist South of old was rapidly dying by the 1960's," they write, but that doesn't call forth the place where I grew up. When President John F. Kennedy was shot, spontaneous cheering broke out among my fellow fourth graders in a New Orleans private school, which was a reflection of months of parental complaining about the proposed Civil Rights Act. With regard to contemporary America, I think they overplay the importance of the utter-bleakness strain in the public conversation about race. Is it really "one of the best-kept secrets of American life today" that "more than 4 out of 10 African-American citizens" along with two-thirds of whites, "consider themselves members of the middle class"?
Interviewing people in the opposition camp might have made the Thernstroms more empathetic, or at least better attuned to nuance. As it is, they are richly understanding about one side of the racial and political divide, and often dismissive or dense about the other. They describe the verdict of the black-majority jury in the O. J. Simpson case, angrily, as "in short, another instance in which a court was overwhelmed by the politics of racial grievance." Earlier in the book, though, in a discussion of the possible biases of white juries in Georgia, they treat the phenomenon of racial jury nullification in a strikingly more forgiving way: "It is certainly not implausible that white prosecutors, judges and jurors in Georgia found it easier to identify with white victims than with African-Americans, and viewed crimes with African-American victims differently from crimes whose victims were their fellow whites. The capacity to feel empathy across racial lines is in short supply today." Another example of their reductive treatment of positions they disagree with is their handling of black nationalism, a venerable, complicated, important aspect of African-American life that comes across in these pages as completely pernicious, and also marginal.
The Thernstroms' dislike of the other side in the race-relations debate is so strong that it regularly trumps the intellectual consistency of their argument. When they are criticizing aggressive, results-oriented enforcement of the Voting Rights Act, they present it as a betrayal of the simple ideals of the mid-1960's: "In 1965, access to the local restaurant, the local hospital and the polling booth was the aim that informed the whole civil rights movement." But elsewhere, when they are trying to reduce the credit the civil rights movement gets for America's racial progress, they paint quite a different (and more accurate) picture, observing that as early as 1964 the movement "was splintering." They heatedly deny that affirmative action has helped blacks economically ("manifestly absurd"), but also say that the number of blacks in affirmative action programs is much too high. Can none of these blacks be benefiting from their undeserved good fortune?
The same phenomenon is at work in a larger and more important way in the Thernstroms' attitude toward the state of black America. The sincerity of their desire for better race relations and better conditions for African-Americans can't be doubted. Although their overall stance is that things are much better in black America than the guilty liberals and self-appointed civil rights leaders want you to know, they also, when trying to show that Government programs haven't worked, haul out many, many alarming statistics about the racial gap. Black crime is much too high, black poverty is stuck where it was in the early 1970's, black educational performance continues to lag far behind white, most black children don't grow up with two parents at home. The Thernstroms remind us of all this when it serves their purposes.
A book that truly succeeded in putting forth a sweeping, inspiring new vision of how to solve the problem of race in America would, after making us aware of these terrible conditions, propose to do something about them. The Thernstroms, after insisting, lengthily, that past liberal remedies have been ineffective and, briefly, that "black poverty impoverishes us all," do not. They propose instead, with real eloquence, toughness and conviction, that "it is on the ground of individuality that blacks and whites can come together." That looks more like an argument against affirmative action than the second coming of Gunnar Myrdal.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 5; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1249 words

HEADLINE: In Newport, the Many-Faceted Legacy of Doris Duke

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH ABBOTT 

DATELINE: NEWPORT, R.I.

 BODY:
IN her $1.2 billion will, Doris Duke left her 40-room oceanfront mansion here, Rough Point, to a nonprofit foundation with instructions that it become a museum.
That bequest alone has been hailed in Newport, a city whose economy depends on tourist attractions like the mansions that line its famous 10-mile Ocean Drive. 
 But Miss Duke's real estate legacy to Newport is far greater than Rough Point.
She also left two other museums -- the Samuel Whitehorne House in Newport, a restored circa 1811 Federal-style building that houses a collection of furniture by Newport craftsmen, and Prescott Farm, an assemblage of Colonial-era buildings, including a working windmill, on eight acres in neighboring Middletown, R.I.
There is more.
In 1968, when Newport was a somewhat grimy Navy town despite its famed Newport cottages, Miss Duke formed the nonprofit Newport Restoration Foundation. Its purpose was to recover the city's rich architectural heritage. Over the next 15 years or so, the foundation restored 83 properties, most of them houses dating back to Colonial times. Rents and contributions from the Duke estate support the foundation's work.
Among local residents the restorations are known simply as Duke houses and they are highly desirable rentals. Not only are they beautifully restored, but they are also impeccably maintained by workmen, who reproduce historic moldings and other woodwork in a Newport mill Miss Duke opened for that purpose.
Not insignificantly, rents in the Duke houses have traditionally been lower than Newport's rents, which are high for Rhode Island. They range from $750 for a one-bedroom house to $1,900 or so for houses with four and five bedrooms and several full baths.
By comparison, most decent one-bedroom houses in Newport start at $1,000 a month.
"We don't advertise," said Arthur Murphy, the foundation's lawyer. "We haven't had to." Only a few Duke houses become available every year and there is a waiting list, Mr. Murphy added.
The reclusive Miss Duke took her Newport restoration work seriously. Until her death in 1993, she personally supervised the smallest details. Her philosophy was to respect the historical integrity of a house, but make it livable, too. Thus, all the homes have modern plumbing and baths even though most of them were built in the 1800's. All of them have working fireplaces.
"Miss Duke called all the shots until she died," said Mr. Murphy. "She decided what houses would be redone over the years, what colors they would be."
On a recent drive through the city's Point section -- an area that Mr. Murphy said used to be a "slum," but thanks largely to Duke's effort is now mostly revived -- painters were touching up a Duke house using a vibrant blue. Mr. Murphy slowed the car, rolled down the window, and asked if the color was correct.
"Miss Duke's favorite," the painter called back. "She called it California blue."
Was such a blue used in Colonial times? Research shows it was, said Daniel Snydacker, executive director of the Newport Historical Society.
Miss Duke made some historical mistakes in her restoration, Mr. Snydacker said. For instance, some historians have questioned the fact that she moved many of the houses around the city and, in a few cases, even brought houses to Newport from as far away as New Jersey. "But overall she was very good," Mr. Snydacker said.
He credited Miss Duke with restoring much of Newport's streetscape to its original character without destroying anything of historic value in the process. "She took the preservation of Colonial houses in Newport to a heroic level," he said.
In the late 1960's, there were others working to preserve Newport's architectural heritage, notably Operation Clapboard, a grassroots organization, and the Preservation Society of Newport County, the group that now manages many of the city's opulent Gilded Age mansions. "But Miss Duke had the drive and the vision to take it the next level," Mr. Syndacker said.
NOT to mention the resources. As heiress to a tobacco and utilities fortune amassed by her father, James Buchanon Duke, Duke was considered one of the world's wealthiest women throughout her life.
"She made Newport what it is," said Kay Norton, who used to live in one Duke house and now rents another, where she and her husband, Aylward, run an Oriental art gallery.
It makes Mrs. Norton angry to hear tour guides note the more lurid aspects of Miss Duke's life, yet fail to mention her extraordinary architectural achievement in Newport. "If Doris Duke hadn't come in, we wouldn't have the tourism we have today," Mrs. Norton declared.
The tenants in the Duke houses are an eclectic group that has been handpicked over the years by Benjamin Reed, a close associate of Miss Duke's who ran the foundation until last April, when a stroke put him into a nursing home. Mr. Reed carefully screened tenants to insure they respected Miss Duke's restoration effort.
"They know more about us than our childen do," Mrs. Norton said with a laugh.
Tenants must abide by several esthetic restrictions. Among them are rules forbidding air-conditioning units in the front of a house or placing a barbecue grill too close to it. Pets are allowed on a case-by-case basis, partly because Miss Duke loved animals.
Indeed, Miss Duke was famous in Newport for keeping a llama and Alsatian hounds on the grounds at Rough Point.
"We very definitely want people who will care for the house," said Mr. Murphy, who is filling in for Mr. Reed until his successor is appointed.
"They want people who will treat them like antiques," said Timothy O'Shea, who rented a Duke house on Thames Street, with his wife, Beth, until a new job recently forced the couple to move to Boston.
"It's the best," Mr. O'Shea, said of renting a Duke house. "My wife is sick about the fact that we had to move."
"I still get calls from people asking if I can help them move up the waiting list," said Mr. Snydacker. The restored houses have attracted interesting and sophisticated people to Newport, who have helped to make the city more cosmopolitan, he said.
Miss Duke's legacy doesn't stop in Newport, of course. In addition to Rough Point, she left one of her other five estates, Shangri-La in Hawaii, to become a museum. And she left the bulk of her fortune to foundations charged with furthering her passionate interests in art, wildlife, historic restoration and other causes.
A battle over her will didn't negate Miss Duke's wishes, but it did keep the Duke property in limbo until May 1996, when her estate was finally settled. In Newport, things are still somewhat up in the air because of Mr. Reed's stroke, but Mr. Murphy outlined some plans for the future. These include raising the rents on many of the Duke houses.
"Some are fine, but some haven't been touched in years," Mr. Murphy said.
Some day in the future, although it is not clear when, tourists will be able to visit Rough Point, the estate Duke called home most summers.
Built in 1889, the mansion houses an extensive collection of Chinese porcelains, rugs, paintings and other art, which Miss Duke amassed over the years.
And the Newport Restoration Foundation hopes to continue Miss Duke's work in Newport by buying and restoring more houses, Mr. Murphy said. It also plans to enlarge Prescott Farm and make it more of a working enterprise. Why do that?, he was asked.
"I think it is one of the visions Miss Duke had for it," Mr. Murphy said.
