INTERNATIONAL A3-11
 
Thousands Gather To Honor Mother Teresa
Thousands of Indians of all faiths and classes filed past the body of Mother Teresa in Calcutta. The glass-enclosed bier of the nun, who died on Friday, had been placed on public view in the quiet convent chapel where she entered religious service in India nearly 70 years ago. The demonstration of respect and homage to her memory was expected to last a week. A1
 
Grieving Continues for Diana
The day after Diana's funeral, it seemed as if Britain could not stop grieving. If anything, the lines of people waiting to pay their respects, write their thoughts in condolence books or light candles at the sites associated with the late Princess of Wales were longer than they were last week. A10 

Lawyers close to the case said investigators were searching for the driver of a car that might have been trying to slow down the Mercedes carrying Diana on the night she died so that the photographers pursuing her on motorcycles could take her picture. A10
 
Albright Prepares for Mideast
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright is to make her first official trip to the Middle East on Tuesday. Senior American officials said she would read the riot act to Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, about cracking down on terrorism. They said she would also press Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to take steps to restore mutual confidence with the Palestinians. A1
 
Debate Over Israelis in Lebanon
A simmering debate over whether Israel should keep troops in southern Lebanon gained new strength after 12 Israeli commandos were killed deep in Lebanese territory on Friday. Another Israeli soldier was killed yesterday in southern Lebanon, where Israel maintains what it describes as a buffer zone against attacks by guerilla groups. A7
 
China Dims Panama's Spotlight
China succeeded in drastically reducing the scope of a conference in Panama on the 20th anniversary of the Panama Canal treaties. Many business leaders and heads of state stayed away after Panama stumbled into the bitter dispute between China and Taiwan. The outcome was an embarrassing and politically costly setback for President Ernesto Perez Balladares. A3
 
Moscow Celebrates Itself
The City of Moscow began a three-day extravaganza to celebrate its 850th anniversary, hauling out circus animals, dancers, musicians, and pop stars. Millions of Russians attended the festival, which honored the city, but also served as a platform for the political ambitions of Mayor Yuri Luzhkov, who climbed on stage and rang a giant golden bell. A4
 
NATIONAL A12-17
 
The Tiniest Are Left Behind In AIDS Drug Revolution
Eighteen months ago, when a new class of drugs called protease inhibitors brought unprecedented improvements in treatment for people with H.I.V., a fresh sense of optimism swept over patients and doctors; for many, the new drugs, when used in combination with older antiviral medications, seemed to transform AIDS from a terminal illness into a chronic, treatable disease. Yet experts now agree that children are not receiving nearly the same benefit as adults. A1
 
Warning About Plutonium
A former emergency-preparedness operations officer at the Kennedy Space Center, who was involved in the launching of two spacecraft that carried plutonium, criticized NASA for its plan to launch the Cassini mission's spacecraft, which uses plutonium batteries. He said that an accident involving the craft, which is to study Saturn, could expose thousands or perhaps millions of people to plutonium, a potentially deadly radioactive element, and the risk of cancer. A12
 
Helms to Fight Back on Weld
A spokesman for Senator Jesse Helms said the Senator would publicly defend his refusal to grant a hearing on the nomination of a fellow Republican, William F. Weld, left, to be Ambassador to Mexico. The spokesman's comments came after Mr. Weld asserted on a television program that it was "not the American way" for a single senator to bar a hearing for an ambassadorial nominee. A17
 
A Deadly Link to the Past
Richard Keech, who is to go to trial today in Long Beach, Calif., on a charge of first-degree murder, plans to offer this defense: the aftereffects of his World War II experiences as a prisoner of the Japanese had a hand in his killing of his son-in-law. "I snapped," Mr. Keech said in an interview. "I was afraid for my life. I thought I was back in the prison camp, and I was about to be beaten to death." A12
 
Bay Area Railroad Strike
The San Francisco Bay Area's commuter railroad was shut down by a strike. With a breakdown in negotiations, both sides said a speedy resolution appeared unlikely. The strike could paralyze traffic on the already overburdened bridges and highways that link San Francisco, Oakland and the suburbs. A12

An Underground War
The never-ending struggle to eradicate the scourge of chewing gum from New York City subway platforms is led by one Joseph N. Burzo, aptly known to his cleaners and scrapers as Bazooka Joe. Mr. Burzo says that he detests gum so much that he will not chew it, though he admits that some members of his family do "just to get at me." The cleanup effort has made progress in 75 remodeled stations, Mr. Burzo says, though some riders beg to differ. B1

More renters in New York state are unable to afford their apartments than in any other state in the country, according to a national study, because they are caught between rising rents and subsistence wages. B4

HEADLINE: ALBRIGHT PLANNING SOME TOUGH TALK TO ARAFAT ON TRIP

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Under pressure from Congress and domestic American politics, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright will head to the Middle East on Tuesday ready to read the riot act to Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, about cracking down on terrorism, senior American officials said today.
She must insure that Mr. Arafat commits himself wholly and publicly to the pursuit of peace with Israel "and stops trying to have it both ways," a senior official said. But she must also insure that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel "does not use security as a pretext" to avoid talking about Israel's own responsibility for the breakdown in mutual confidence with the Palestinians and the larger Arab world. 
 But Ms. Albright's first official trip to the Middle East also has raised regional concerns that a heavy-handed public defense of Mr. Netanyahu can only harm, the officials said.
With the negotiations between the Palestinians and Israel in tatters and the chance of a comprehensive Middle East peace fading, the United States is facing the prospect that the coalition it built after the Persian Gulf war to contain both Iraq and Iran is also fraying.
The Saudi Crown Prince, Abdullah, concerned about a rise in Islamic fundamentalist anger at home, has told the United States that Saudi Arabia, "under the current conditions," cannot possibly attend the American-sponsored Middle East economic summit meeting, to be held in mid-November in Doha, Qatar, the officials said.
The Syrians have already said they will not attend, and if the Saudis also boycott the meeting, so may many of the small, wealthy and moderate Persian Gulf states. The meeting, only in its fourth year, includes an Israeli delegation. The meetings symbolize the American vision of a peaceful, cooperative Middle East concentrating on trade and mutual interests rather than on recrimination and suicide bombers .
These concerns help explain why Ms. Albright will also travel to Egypt, Jordan, Syria, Saudi Arabia and possibly Lebanon and has left her itinerary open-ended. "She has no intention of shuttling in the Middle East," a senior official said. "But she's got a lot to do out there."
For Ms. Albright, this trip presents her greatest public challenge so far as Secretary of State.
Success on this trip has not been precooked, and it will be hard even to define. Her aides are already saying she "is not a magician." But after months of hesitation about the right moment to make her first official trip to the Middle East, she finds herself condemned to plunge in now, when the temperature is hottest and the leaders on both sides seem least able to bend.
A senior Administration official acknowledges that it will bring an easy success in American political terms if she yells loudly at Mr. Arafat to arrest Palestinian extremists and to crack down on Hamas instead of kissing its leaders. Everyone from Mr. Netanyahu and House Speaker Newt Gingrich to the liberal Democratic Senator from Connecticut, Joseph Lieberman, have pressed her to do that. But that will not be sufficient, the senior official said.
Not only must she press Mr. Arafat, and Mr. Netanyahu as well, to meet their responsibilities toward peace but she must also bear in mind the concerns and interests of America's moderate Arab allies, as Jordan's King Hussein and Egypt's President, Hosni Mubarak, tried to enunciate them today in their meeting with Mr. Arafat in Cairo. In a statement, they urged Israel to refrain from actions alien to "the spirit of the peace" -- as Ms. Albright did in a policy address a month ago.
They urged Mr. Netanyahu to put into effect all the clauses of the interim Oslo accords, which he suspended on Friday, demanding Palestinian compliance with obligations for security cooperation first. Those accords include a troop withdrawal from the West Bank originally due today and another due within a year.
How Ms. Albright deals with Mr. Netanyahu's suspension of Israel's obligations under the accords, even if the suspension is presumably temporary, will be closely watched throughout the Middle East.
She must also try, as another senior official said, to get agreement from both Israelis and Palestinians on American ideas that could "clear a pathway to accelerated final-status talks" on a comprehensive peace settlement between them.
Despite the new carnage and the emphasis on Mr. Arafat's security obligations, "it is also a reality that she has to go out there and engage on both issues" -- security and peace, the official said.
Ms. Albright will reinforce Mr. Clinton's declaration in telephone conversations with Mr. Arafat last week that he must take "unilateral and direct action against Hamas," the official said, adding that "our message to Arafat is that there can be no more attempts at co-opting Hamas, and no more kisses" of its leaders.
While the Palestinians have been working with the Israelis, with an American C.I.A. officer as mediator and witness, to identify the key Hamas and Islamic Holy War members engaged in planning or carrying out terrorism, the official said, "Now we want the Palestinian Authority to arrest them."
But movement toward peace is vital to larger American interests, the official stressed, saying, "Progess on the peace process is important for us to do many things, and there's no question that it's more difficult to do other things without progress on peace."
Those "other things," he said, "are containing Iran and Iraq."
Another senior American official said, "There is a serious concern that our ability to confront the enemies of peace -- Iran and Iraq -- is underminded by weakness and stalemate in the peace process."
That concern is sharpened by the election of a more moderate Iranian President, Ayatollah Mohammed Khatami, though he does not control Iranian foreign policy. Mr. Khatami will be the host of this year's Islamic summit meeting, in Teheran in early December, just after the Doha meeting, and American officials do not want their moderate Arab allies to show up in Teheran after boycotting the meeting in Doha.
Administration officials have told the Saudis that their presence in Doha matters, and that "there's lots of time to change the atmosphere between now and November," a senior official said, adding, "But we have to start to change it now."
Edward P. Djerejian, former American Ambassador to Syria and Israel, says he thinks that some of the regional shifts are tactical and do not negate fundamental conflicts between Syria and Iraq or Iran and Iraq.
"But if this stagnation in the peace process worsens, we may see more of an anti-Israel realignment, with more of the pan-Arab and nationalistic rhetoric we thought we put behind us, as Arab countries move to stave off internal pressures from Islamic groups," Mr. Djerejian said.
American strategies must respond to those internal changes in Arab societies as well as to the deterioration in the peace negotiations that worsens them. "We can't just rely on military policies and deterrence," he said. "What good is the fleet if the threat comes from within?"

HEADLINE: Growth of Machine Tool Orders Slows on Pullback in Midwest

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Machine tool orders by American manufacturers rose 4.5 percent in July compared with a year earlier, a slowdown from the blistering growth rates of earlier months, according to an industry survey. Moreover, July's orders were down 13.4 percent from the preceding month.
The data showed a particularly strong pullback in the Midwest, home to the nation's big auto makers and other important industries. 
 Machine tools are used to make products ranging from home appliances to airplanes. A rise in orders suggests manufacturers are confident enough about the economy to expand or upgrade their factories.
Total orders in July were estimated at $666 million, compared with $637 million in July 1996 and down sharply from June's estimate of $769 million, the survey said.
The report is to be released today by the American Machine Tool Distributors' Association and the Association for Manufacturing Technology, two industry trade groups.
In the first half of 1997, orders were up 19.7 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier. After adding July's data, year-to-date spending rose 15.9 percent.
"Steady capital investment from the U.S. manufacturing sector has driven machine tool orders to exceed last year's impressive growth," Ralph Nappi, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said in a statement yesterday. "One concern facing manufacturing, however, is the shortage of a technically skilled work force."
Orders in the Midwest fell 22 percent in July compared with a year earlier and were down 25 percent from June. For the seven months through July, orders rose just 2.2 percent, making it by far the weakest region.
The biggest growth in July was in the West, usually a quiet area for manufacturing, where spending rose 53 percent from a year earlier. The Northeast was next with 25 percent growth, followed by the South and Central regions at 23 percent.
Export data showed that foreign demand for American machine tools slipped 62 percent from July 1996, to $48.3 million. However, orders were still up 16 percent through the first seven months of 1997.

HEADLINE: An Idea Not Yet Born, But a Custody Fight

BYLINE: By GEANNE ROSENBERG 

 BODY:
Everywhere Evan Brown goes, he brings with him, nestled in the gray matter of his brain, an asset his former employer demands: the record of what may be a multimillion-dollar software system that could update old, outdated computer software, making it usable on modern computer systems.
Two questions about this piece of intellectual property are keeping lawyers busy. To whom do Mr. Brown's thoughts belong? And, if they do not belong to him, can the owner of Mr. Brown's thinking force him to hand it over? 
"In some ways it's quite intrusive," Mr. Brown observed dryly of his closely watched legal case.
The ranks of those staking claims in Mr. Brown's potential invention -- which he said could save companies billions of dollars -- are swelling. Among the parties: Mr. Brown; the DSC Communications Corporation, his former employer, which dismissed and sued him in April after he refused to divulge his ideas, and Lance Flores, a computer programmer who says he may be the original thinker of the thoughts at issue and is now seeking to intervene in the lawsuit.
Even Mr. Brown's lawyer, Richard A. Sayles, of Sayles & Lidji in Dallas, has a stake. He said he agreed to take the case -- which is scheduled for a jury trial in a Collin County, Tex., district court in November -- on a contingency basis with his fee tied to Mr. Brown's profits from the software solution. "Believe me, I've asked him if it works," Mr. Sayles said.
Mr. Brown's case would be a fairly typical trade-secret dispute -- except that his purported solution has apparently never been articulated. There are no notebooks, computer files or audio tapes to help establish whether it works or to whom it belongs.
Moreover, there is no way anyone can seize custody of the ideas without Mr. Brown's cooperation. Mr. Brown has already refused to comply with orders from two county court judges to disclose his ideas.
"There is no case like this," said Roger Milgrim, a partner at Paul, Hastings, Janofsky & Walker, and a leading authority on trade-secret law. Mr. Brown's case, in Mr. Milgrim's view, "addresses the possible limits of judicial power."
If Mr. Brown is ordered to disclose and declines, "What can a court do?" Mr. Milgrim asked.
DSC has sought to have Mr. Brown held in contempt, but so far a Texas appeals court has declined to do so.
Mr. Brown, 45, a self-proclaimed "computer geek" who now lives in Plano, Tex., has been a software tinkerer for some time. In the late 1960's, while in high school, he wrote a program to calculate square roots at a time when calculators were not available, he said.
He majored in computer science at Texas A & M University and began working as a computer programmer during college. After years as an independent consultant, he joined DSC in April 1987.
About one week later, he said, he was told to sign a written agreement requiring that he communicate to DSC and grant the company rights to any "inventions" relating to the telecommunications computer company's business -- or suggested by his work for the company.
According to George Brunt, the general counsel of DSC: "Our technology is very valuable to us. We're under an obligation to our shareholders to protect our technology and not let it walk out the door."
Indeed, DSC takes a broad view of its ownership of employee inventions. "All of our employees sign that agreement," Mr. Brunt said. "It's a condition of employment."
Mr. Brown argues that his software-translation idea was 80 percent complete before he ever joined DSC. He also thought that his agreement with the company covered only telecommunications inventions, not the slowly coalescing idea he first conceived in El Paso in 1975, while visiting a friend who posed the software problem.
It was at a 1991 gathering of the Dallas-Fort Worth Unix Users Group, which Mr. Brown defined as "a bunch of computer geeks that get together," that he first met Lance Flores -- the man now trying to intervene in DSC's suit.
The two discussed the problems of trying to convert old software. Mr. Flores said he had an approach using artificial intelligence. Mr. Brown said he urged Mr. Flores to bring the idea to DSC, which was struggling with its own need to convert old software. But DSC rejected Mr. Flores's proposal.
DSC representatives said they had not verified that a meeting with Mr. Flores took place.
Mr. Brown said he periodically mentally revisited the problem of finding an algorithm for a software program that could convert old computer code into modern source codes. In March 1996, he said, while coming home from a long weekend, he envisioned the remaining 20 percent of the solution.
He approached DSC to ask for permission to develop his idea independently of DSC. Initially, Mr. Brown said, DSC executives were agreeable. But then a senior executive realized the idea could benefit DSC. In exchange for his developing the idea, the company offered Mr. Brown up to $2 million of any money that DSC and Motorola, a big customer, would save, as well as 50 percent of profits from sale of the software to third parties, according to Mr. Brown.
Mr. Brown said he asked for $5 million and 50 percent. In early 1997, according to Mr. Brown, DSC stopped the discussions, informed Mr. Brown that DSC owned his ideas outright, demanded that he disclose them, and when he refused, dismissed him on the spot. DSC then sued him for breach of contract.
According to Mr. Brunt, the general counsel, discussions about increasing Mr. Brown's compensation fell apart because of a threat by Mr. Brown that he would try to sell his idea to other companies.
Mr. Brunt said, "If a janitor came up with a method of cleaning a hardwood floor suggested to him by his work in cleaning a DSC hardwood floor, technically the idea belongs to DSC."
For Mr. Sayles, Mr. Brown's lawyer, DSC's position is an assault on individual rights. "Does the company own your thoughts 24 hours a day?" he asked. "That's what they're claiming."
Trade-secret scholars say that there are limits to employer ownership of employee inventions, particularly where an agreement signing over inventions is too broad or not related to an employee's work assignment.
But generally speaking, "the deal's the deal," Mr. Milgrim said.
Roger Schechter, a law professor at George Washington University Law School, said: "The larger question is if someone comes up with a really brilliant idea while he's an employee, one that's worth tens of millions of dollars, should that person be entitled to a share in the economic windfall regardless of what the contract says? The traditional answer in the United States has always been 'no.' "
Mr. Brown's lawyer has argued that the contract failed because DSC did not offer anything beyond the salary Mr. Brown was already receiving in exchange for his promise to turn over his inventions.
But so far, county court decisions have not gone Mr. Brown's way. Two judges have ordered him to spend his days at DSC disclosing his ideas to the company -- in an initial May 1997 order for zero pay, and in an order issued last June that he is currently violating, for $45 an hour. Also, Mr. Brown's motion to dismiss DSC's claims was denied.
These early rulings are making Mr. Flores nervous. If it turns out that he, not Mr. Brown, is the owner of the ideas at issue, Mr. Flores is concerned that his ideas could "fall into the hands of DSC through the state courts" and that he would be precluded from using them.
So far there have been no settlement talks, Mr. Sayles said. "Once this lawsuit was filed, it's been an absolute declaration of war," he said.
DSC is continuing its litigation aggressively. "We don't even know if Brown's idea has any value at all," Mr. Brunt said. "That's the ironic thing."
As for Mr. Brown, he is liquidating assets, including his house, to pay expenses. Employers are skittish about hiring someone in violation of a court order, he said, and therefore, until this case is resolved, he does not expect to find employment.
But he says there has been a positive side to the litigation. "I would definitely say that it's very educational," Mr. Brown said. "I learned more about the law than I ever intended."

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton Deserves 'Fast Track'

 BODY:
President Clinton begins an important battle with Congress this week for renewal of "fast track" authority, the right to submit trade agreements to Congress for a speedy vote without amendments. Without fast-track protection, countries will not negotiate trade accords with Washington for fear of endless revision. Not surprisingly, protectionist forces within both parties would be happy to block the no-amendment rule, even though every President over the past 20 years has used the rule to open up foreign markets and also bring down prices for American consumers.
The Administration needs fast track to complete negotiations within the World Trade Organization on opening markets to foreign-provided services, tightening copyright protections and prying open government contracts to bids by foreign companies. Fast track is also needed to negotiate trade agreements with Chile and other South American countries. They are already negotiating deals with Europe, Mexico and Canada that would give exports from those countries favored access. 
 Opponents ranging from isolationists to pro-union liberals indict trade pacts with environmentally lax and low-wage countries. The claim is that these countries steal American jobs and drive down living standards of American workers. But trade itself does not create or destroy jobs. The American economy will operate near full employment as long as Federal Reserve and budgetary policies remain sensible. Trade does shift jobs from apparel and other low-paying industries into high-paying export industries. The transition can be rough, but the long-term benefits are substantial.
Nor are low foreign wages the scourge that the forces led by the House majority leader, Richard Gephardt, proclaim. Low wages largely reflect low productivity, providing no net benefit to foreign manufacturers. Nor would higher foreign wages help American companies. Rising production costs would be offset by a falling exchange rate, leaving the net cost of imports to American buyers largely unchanged.
That said, the Administration goes too far in claiming that trade helps everyone. The influx into the United States of clothing and other goods produced with low-skilled labor has modestly pushed the wages of unskilled workers further behind the wages of skilled workers. But rising inequality should not be confused with falling living standards. After taking account of lower prices for imported goods and the availability of jobs in a fully employed economy, very few Americans actually lose.
Though labor and environmental conditions are rarely related directly to trade, the United States should condition trade pacts on a country's willingness to adopt agreements that provide basic international protections, like prohibitions on child labor and rights for union organizers. As in the trade accord with Mexico, Washington ought to insist that countries, like Chile, strictly enforce their own environmental laws.
Bill Archer, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, proposes a reasonable compromise that would allow the Administration to incorporate into the text of a fast-track accord labor and environmental conditions that directly affect trade in specific products. The details remain to be worked out, but the Archer plan offers an opportunity to fashion a sensible fast-track plan that can be made acceptable to Democrats.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Many Tenants Are Struggling To Pay Rent

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Caught between rising rents and subsistence wages, more renters in New York State are unable to afford their apartments than in any other state in the country, according to a national study.
Mostly because of widespread affordability problems in New York City, the state was ranked worst for the second year in a row in the annual study by the National Low Income Housing Coalition, which represents a wide array of housing groups seeking to help the poor. 
 The study found that roughly half of the state's renters paid 30 percent or more of their income for their apartments, the Federal Government's benchmark for affordability. And many of the poorest paid much more than 30 percent, forcing difficult choices among necessities.
"Housing costs, for most people, represent the largest monthly expense," the report states. "Most families pay their rent first, buying food, clothing and health care with what remains."
The study found that 48 percent of renters in New York State were unable to afford the estimated fair market rent for a one-bedroom apartment, $687, and 54 percent were unable to afford a two-bedroom rent, $796. It calculated that New York renters would need to make at least $13.22 an hour to afford a one-bedroom apartment and $15.32 an hour to afford a two-bedroom. The minimum wage is $5.15 an hour.
Around the country, only Washington, D.C., Rhode Island and Hawaii had affordability problems approaching New York's. But in nearly every other state, more than 30 percent of renters paid more than they could afford for one-bedroom apartments and more than 40 percent did so for two-bedrooms.
The study, which is to be released in Washington tomorrow, theorizes that those numbers reflect the results of new welfare laws, which were intended to move recipients to work but may be moving them from one economic gap to another: workfare programs and jobs with incomes far too small to provide decent housing.
"For us, the most important message in the study is a debunking of the myth that only people on public assistance and not working have a housing problem," said Helen Dunlap, president of the coalition. "You can be working a great number of hours in a steady job and still not be able to afford a place to live."
Renters on welfare continue to be in the most precarious position. The study found that in New York State, the monthly grant provided by the new federally subsidized program known as Temporary Aid to Needy Families falls $219 short of helping a family meet the fair market rent for a two-bedroom apartment.
Leslie Crockett, a mother of three in the South Bronx who lost her data-entry job in January, said her landlord had taken her to court because welfare pays only $143 toward rent, and she had yet to receive rental help under a state program.
"I understand that man needs his money," Ms. Crockett, 32, said of her landlord. "He's got a business to run as well. But this is the situation that I'm in. I don't have anyone to take up the slack for me."
The study used fair market rent levels -- locally adjusted cost estimates for decent but modest shelter -- determined by the Department of Housing and Urban Development for fiscal year 1997 in cities around the country. It compared those rents with median renter incomes.
Advocates for the poor in New York, many of whom contend that the state is in a housing crisis, said the numbers painted only a rudimentary picture of the realities faced by the poor. Especially in New York City, rising rents have forced many people to live doubled and tripled up with other family members, often in dangerous or unhealthy conditions.
"What people fail to understand," said Billy Easton, executive director of the New York State Tenants and Neighbors Coalition, "is that if someone doesn't have a stable home, it has a terrible impact on every other area of their lives -- their ability to work, the ability of their children to stay in school."
Housing analysts said they can find no inherent reason why New York State should have ended up at the bottom of the list for two years. In 1991, New York was tied for eighth place. In 1989, it was 25th.
Michael Schill, director of the Center for Real Estate and Urban Studies at the New York University School of Law, said the numbers might be a result of New York's slow emergence from the recession.
Combined with other factors -- an increase in immigration and low rates of new construction -- the pattern was set, he said: "Rents were increasing faster than normal, and incomes were not catching up."

HEADLINE: ROAD TO CITY HALL;
In Their Own Words

 BODY:

SAL F. ALBANESE
Speaking to reporters yesterday after a broadcast debate by Democratic mayoral candidates:
 
"I am the strongest Democrat against Rudy Giuliani in terms of my strong platform on law and order, my strong platform on education. I was a schoolteacher for 11 years. I teach criminal law at John Jay College of Criminal Justice. I've been an independent member of the City Council. I support political reforms. I think people in New York are looking for someone who can appeal to all New Yorkers and someone who's a strong Democrat, who appeals to working men and women in this city. I believe the city is moving toward a two-tiered city, a small group of very wealthy people and the rest poor and working poor. We need to have a working class and middle class in this city."

If you agree with Rudy Giuliani that this is as good as it gets, then vote for Rudy Giuliani and the status quo. Everybody else, all they had to do was get old enough to vote. Here we're now living in Queens, N.Y. Some of us with nice homes and nice cars. And some of us have to beg you to get up and do what others died to give you the right to do. It's an insult to hang Dr. King's picture on your wall and not use the things he died to make available to you."

HEADLINE: Panel Reviews U.S. 'Life-Support Systems'

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Government research money should be quadrupled by 2004 to prevent cascading failures of the nation's power, water, finance and emergency systems, which are increasingly connected, especially through the Internet, a Presidential commission says.
The panel is reviewing security for eight infrastructures: electric power distribution, telecommunication, banking and finance, water, transportation, oil and gas storage and transportation, emergency services and Government services. 
 "These are the life-support systems of the nation," said Gen. Robert T. Marsh, who is retired from the Air Force and is the chairman of the President's Commission on Critical Infrastructure Protection. "They're vital, not only for day-to-day discourse. They're vital to national security. They're vital to our economic competitiveness world wide. They're vital to our very way of life."
The commission's advisory committee, in its first official meeting, said on Friday that the $250 million budget for research and development to protect against threats to critical infrastructure should be doubled in 1999, and that $100 million should be added each year until the budget totals $1 billion by 2004.
The research and development money is mostly concentrated in the National Security Agency, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency and the Commerce and Energy Departments, General Marsh said on Saturday.
Intentional or accidental damage to one aspect of the nation's infrastructure could spread and bring down other systems.
"We're not trying to alarm," the general said. "In fact, there haven't been any serious attacks on our infrastructures. What we're saying is, let's take prudent actions to forestall this kind of crisis happening to us in the future."
Because much of this infrastructure is in the hands of private business, the commission thinks the Government and private sector should work together to protect the system.
The Internet makes the systems vulnerable, he said.
"The Internet provides an access point into all these infrastructures," either through control systems directly on the Internet or indirectly, he said.
John T. Davis, the commission member representing the National Security Agency, said the Government should develop a secure "Next Generation Internet" for official use. And he said private industry should invest more in research for more secure information systems.
General Marsh said education was also important to Internet security.
"We see the need to make sure our youngsters in their early schooling are taught the rules of the road, there is such a thing as trespassing, it's not proper to break into someone else's system," he said.
Even industry leaders need a better understanding of security design, from fire walls to prevent access to vital systems to better discipline, like not introducing potentially contaminated disks from home.
"It's the first time in my experience the Federal Government has tried to take a major initiative in advance of some kind of problem," General Marsh said. "We're good at reacting, but we're not good at proacting."
The commission is to give its final report to the President on Oct. 13.

HEADLINE: Heavy Hand of Beijing Dampens a Panama Canal Fest

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: PANAMA, Sept. 7

 BODY:
As originally envisioned, the "Universal Congress on the Panama Canal" was to be a grand gathering of world leaders here to discuss the future of the vital waterway. But that was before Panama stumbled into the bitter dispute between China and Taiwan, prompting the incensed authorities in Beijing to undertake a two-year campaign to sabotage the event.
Today, as the conference opened on the 20th anniversary of the signing of the Panama Canal treaties, the magnitude of Beijing's success became clear. Presidents Lee Teng-hui of Taiwan and Ernesto Perez Balladares were in attendance, but nearly all the other heads of state and business leaders who had been invited bowed to the Chinese offensive and stayed away, drastically reducing the scope and importance of the encounter. 
 For Mr. Perez Balladares, this outcome is an embarrassing and politically costly setback. The shipping industry and many foreign governments have been openly skeptical of Panama's ability to run the canal after the United States hands it over on Dec. 31, 1999, and his administration had hoped that the congress would demonstrate that Panama was up to the task.
"This was meant to be an important act of presentation to the international community, in which Panama would tell the world it knows how to manage and modernize a waterway that will soon be ours, and is ready to assume a more serious and responsible global role," said Ricardo Arias Calderon, a former Vice President and a leader of the Christian Democratic Party. "Instead, it is a major lost opportunity."
Although the United States remains the main user of the canal it constructed more than 80 years ago, China and Taiwan have growing commercial and political interests here. Measured by total tonnage shipped through the waterway, China is now the fifth-largest user, while Taiwan, which China regards as a breakaway province and therefore seeks to isolate diplomatically, is the ninth.
The rivalry between China and Taiwan dates back to 1949, when Nationalist Chinese forces retreated to the island after losing a civil war to the Communist army. In 1971, the United Nations seat held by the Republic of China on Taiwan was transferred to Beijing, and now few countries retain formal relations with Taiwan, mostly in Central America and the Caribbean.
Panama's plans for a grandiose global assembly began unraveling, it is now obvious, in 1995, when Taiwan's Embassy here learned of the congress, saw it as a rare chance for Mr. Lee to appear on the world stage and sought an invitation. According to diplomats here, Panama consented after Taiwan agreed to defray $800,000 of the costs of organizing the event.
Given the international importance of the canal's future, Panama had also sought assistance and representation from the United Nations. But once the conference's Taiwan connection became known, all United Nations agencies withdrew their support, and China began to press others who were invited either to stay at home or limit themselves to small, low-level delegations.
As a result, the only presidents attending the conference, other than Mr. Lee, are those of Honduras and Nicaragua, which also have warm relations with Taiwan. The American delegation, which arrived this afternoon, is led by Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and Thomas F. McLarty, President Clinton's special envoy for Latin American and Caribbean affairs.
In remarks to reporters here after disembarking, Mr. McLarty said the United States was "fully confident that canal operations will remain solid after 1999" because "all parties involved are committed to a seamless transition."
He declined to criticize Mr. Perez Balladares' embrace of Taiwan, saying "the Panamanian Government appropriately chose who they would like to invite" to the conference.
Fearful of offending China and being denied business opportunities there, most major international shipping companies have also backed away from sending high-level delegations. Even Chang Yung-fa, who as head of the giant Evergreen Marine Corporation, Taiwan's largest shipping company, was being counted on by Panama to play a conspicuous role, ending up sending his regrets.
In recent years, Evergreen has become one of the most prominent investors in Panama, with projects that include a large container port, an industrial park and an airline. But Mr. Chang and his company also have substantial interests and ambitions on the Chinese mainland, which diplomats here said could be endangered unless he lowers his profile in Panama.
Stripped of its political dimension, the congress, which ends on Wednesday, will now be devoted largely to technical matters of interest only to transportation and shipping specialists. Conference organizers declined to provide reporters with a list of those attending, but have announced panels to discuss issues like "Long-Range Canal Traffic Projections" and "Locks Modernization."
Even after achieving its political objective, though, China has continued to threaten conference participants. On August 28, a Foreign Ministry spokesman in Beijing called on Panama to "change its erroneous decision to invite Lee Teng-hui to attend this meeting" and condemned Taiwan for conducting what he called "activities aimed at splitting the motherland."
A similar warning was also issued to the United States, which granted Mr. Lee a visa to stop over in Hawaii on his way to and from here.
"Don't let Lee Teng-hui use all kinds of opportunities to create two Chinas," the Chinese spokesman, Shen Guofang, cautioned Washington.
In addition, the head of China's new economic and trade mission here, Ju Yijie, has been trying to undermine support for Taiwan in the large and prosperous local Chinese community since arriving here six months ago, leaders of that community say.
Thanks to steady immigration and intermarriage, as much as 5 percent of Panama's population of 2.5 million people is estimated to have some degree of Chinese ancestry. Many of the new arrivals have stronger ties to the mainland than to Taiwan, and have challenged the traditional hostility of Chinese organizations here toward the Communists in Beijing. To prevent further erosion of its support, Taiwan has in recent months made generous donations to educational and other projects that benefit the local Chinese community.
For its part, a grateful Taiwan may seek to soften the blow Panama has suffered with promises of increased investment and aid. According to reports by newspapers in Taipei, Mr. Lee, who is accompanied by a delegation of more than 100 officials and businessmen and about 150 journalists, may announce while he is here that Taiwan is willing to contribute as much as $400 million to help modernize the canal.
But clearly the trip has already enhanced Taiwan's political and diplomatic capital in the region. Using his invitation here as a springboard, Mr. Lee will also visit Paraguay and El Salvador, where he is scheduled to meet with the Presidents of the six Central American nations that recognize his Government.
"Both China and Taiwan are happy, because they have ended up getting what they wanted," a Latin American diplomat here said. "The only real loser in all of this is Panama, which had the most at stake."

HEADLINE: ROAD TO CITY HALL: LONG ISLAND;
Elections Could Threaten Republicans' Control of Nassau County Legislature

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Sept. 7

 BODY:
When the first Nassau County Legislature was elected two years ago, there was a broad field of enthusiastic candidates in a total of 10 Democratic and Republican primaries, all hoping to become a part of history.
This year, there are only three primary contests -- one Democratic and two Republican. Nevertheless, the elections could threaten the Republicans' veto-proof control of the Legislature. 
 In the First District, which Democrats hope to wrench from Republican control, Seretta McKnight, a party rebel in 1995, won the support of Democratic leaders this year. Mrs. McKnight was the only successful primary challenger two years ago, when she defeated the party's choice, Frederick Brewington, a civil rights attorney.
Mr. Brewington stayed in the race as a third-party candidate in 1995, thwarting Democratic efforts to take the district, which was drawn to help elect the county's first minority legislator. The district's population is mostly black.
With the Democrats divided, the seat went to the Republican candidate, Darlene Harris, who is running for re-election this year.
Mrs. McKnight's 1995 campaign was also hurt by the state takeover of the troubled Roosevelt School District, where she was the school board president.
Mrs. McKnight, 39, the general manager of a family-owned home heating oil business, this year edged out Mr. Brewington as the party's choice by 54 votes. But she faces a primary challenge from Patrick Williams Sr., 49, a vice president of the Amerifirst Mortgage Corporation in Hempstead and a newcomer to Nassau politics.
Both candidates promise to fight to address problems that they say have long plagued the economically depressed district, including high property taxes and low economic development. Mr. Williams says he wants to see more affordable housing and a youth center in the district. Mrs. McKnight says she wants to increase health care coverage for poor people in the district.
The Democratic county chairman, Stephen Sabbeth, has staked out the First District as a battleground in his party's efforts to reduce the Republican control of the Legislature. He has long contended that there are more Democrats than Republicans in the district, compared with most of the county, where Republicans outnumber Democrats by a 3-to-2 ratio. With 13 of 19 seats, the Republicans in the Legislature now hold a veto-proof majority, which they would forfeit with the loss of one seat.
 In the two Republican primaries, Patricia Maher, 37, a substitute school teacher, is challenging the party's choice in the 13th Legislative District, Norma Gonsalves, 63, a retired New York City school teacher, and Richard Ahrens, 37, a conservative, is opposing the incumbent in the 15th Legislative District, Dennis Dunne.
Mrs. Gonsalves, a founder and president of the Council of East Meadow Community Organizations, which represents 31 civic, business, education, veterans and religious groups, lost the Republican primary in 1995 by 68 votes to Michael Fiechter, who went on to win the seat that November. He recently resigned, however, to become a Nassau County District Court judge. This time, the party rallied around Mrs. Gonsalves as its choice.
Mrs. Gonsalves and her challenger, Mrs. Maher, both advocate a cut in property taxes but differ on how they would do it. Mrs. Maher would transfer part of the county sales tax to school districts and eliminate most of the automobiles used by county government officials. Mrs. Gonsalves advocates closer scrutiny of county spending to trim costs and taxes. She says a redistribution of sales tax revenues as proposed by Mrs. Maher is not viable.
In the conservative Republican 15th District, Mr. Ahrens, a delegate for Patrick Buchanan in the New York Presidential primary last year, echoes Mr. Buchanan's conservative polices and campaign rhetoric, denouncing the incumbent as "Do Nothing Dunne."
"There are conservative Republican issues that are not being addressed by the current Republican leaders," said Mr. Ahrens, a vehicle maintenance worker at La Guardia Airport. He says the County Legislature should mandate that all county workers speak English on the job, penalize illegal immigrants who send their children to public schools and cut property taxes for older residents.
Mr. Dunne, 47, was the director of the county's Veterans Service Agency for 11 years before being elected to the new County Legislature. In defending his record, he noted that he was a co-sponsor of legislation to expand property tax exemptions for older residents and supported efforts to reduce the size of government.
"I'm a conservative, but I like to stay mainstream," Mr. Dunne said.

HEADLINE: Patents;
Software programs to help buyers make decisions about insurance and health care needs.

BYLINE: By Sabra Chartrand 

 BODY:
AS it has become easier in the last two years to win a patent for software, more computer programs for managing life have emerged with exclusive rights from the Patent and Trademark Office.
Among those are software inventions intended to make financial analyses for consumers and then generate a recommendation of the best product or service to buy. The advantage of having a computer program make the choice is that software can examine competitive data from hundreds or thousands of sources. In the market for a long-distance telephone service? Just try by yourself to uncover all the plans available, get their sales brochures, and then break down the pricing structures to determine which one is the most economical for your needs. 
 Computers can, at least theoretically, analyze the offerings or performance of any industry. Two recent patents were awarded for software programs that are intended to help a buyer get the best deals in insurance and health care.
One patent, awarded to Ryan Evalulife Systems Inc. in Stamford, Conn., covers a software program to help individuals choose a universal life insurance policy. The other patent, assigned to Health Share Technology Inc. in Acton, Mass., covers software that compares the quality and cost of health care at hospitals to determine which are the most competitive.
If the inventors have their way, a lot of middlemen could see their livelihoods disappear.
Evalulife's software is intended to enable consumers to bypass insurance agents and brokers. Already, many banks, dial-up data bases and on-line services offer price quotes for and even sell term life insurance, a basic form of insurance policy that provides a fixed death benefit for an annual premium. Universal life insurance is more like a savings account, with the premiums paid on the policy accumulating value while earning tax-free interest. Owners can borrow from a universal life insurance policy, and sometimes use the accumulated cash to pay premiums.
Evalulife says its patent is for the first and thus far only system that analyzes universal life insurance plans. The inventors, Ronald Ryan, an insurance and financial products developer from Wilton, Conn., and Ronald Gary Marquart, a computer scientist from Oakland, Calif., are negotiating with companies like Intuit and Microsoft to sell their patent.
"Suppose you want to know the best rate of return for triple-A coverage, and you only want to spend a certain amount of money per year," explained Peter K. Trzyna, the intellectual property lawyer who has shepherded the Evalulife patent. "That would produce a listing and ranking of policies. But included are all kinds of investment assumptions -- interest rates and things like that that fluctuate.
"It requires such complicated, intricate mathematical calculations to find the best life insurance investment that it's no surprise this has stumped the industry for a long time," he said. Seeking the information for inclusion in the patent "took a first-rate accounting firm $1.25 million worth of research."
Hardly an approach the average consumer would consider. But the days are over of having access to insurance only through an agent. Today, insurance price-quote services maintain data bases of different policies. Some sell policies; other merely provide information for a fee from the companies that sell the policies.
Customers using Evalulife's software provide traditional underwriting criteria like the applicant's age, gender and health status. They also say how much they are willing to pay in premiums and what size benefit is desired. The software considers factors like rates of return, probability of earning those rates and the reputation of the company offering the insurance.
Mr. Ryan and Mr. Marquart received patent 5,655,085.
The other patent, for the health care software program, was awarded to Richard Siegrist, Jr. and his brother, Donald Siegrist, both from outside Boston, who assigned it to Health Share. Their software is aimed at helping managed care organizations choose which hospitals and doctors to include in their networks and assist hospitals in selecting doctors and health care providers for their rosters.
"What we do is like the way that executives reach conclusions by asking advice from a consultant or specialist," Richard Siegrist explained. "We've automated that process."
Health Share's software considers 33 indicators of health care quality that were determined by a Federal agency, the Agency for Health Care Policy and Research. Some of those are rates of wound infection, obstetrics complications, urinary tract infection and pneumonia.
"It looks for hospitals with high- quality care at the lowest cost," Mr. Siegrist said. "The software then automatically writes a 15-page management report, with an executive summary, conclusion and next steps or solutions, and graphics and charts."
"Most people don't realize that this information is publicly available in about 30 states, with total patient confidentiality," he added. Not to mention that it would be time-consuming for an analyst at a managed care company to track down and evaluate. "That's where we come in," Mr. Siegrist said. "This software means the data is sitting on their PC on their desk,"
He said he and his brother had already sold the software to big teaching hospitals in New York, New York University Medical Center and several New York City hospitals. The brothers received patent 5,652,842.
Patents are available by number for $3 from the Patent and Trademark Office, Washington, D.C. 20231.

HEADLINE: ROAD TO CITY HALL: THE CANDIDATES;
In Primary Debate Slugfest, Democrats Slug Only Giuliani

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
In a mini-marathon of debates that gave them more television exposure in seven hours than they had enjoyed on any other day in this race, the Democratic mayoral candidates repeatedly declined yesterday to draw contrasts between their credentials and ideologies, instead saving their attacks for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
Sal F. Albanese, the Rev. Al Sharpton and Ruth W. Messinger ended their final joint appearance before Tuesday's primary on a deferential -- indeed, docile -- note as they turned away invitations to point out the shortcomings of their opponents. 
 "There's been this obsession in the media about wanting to see the Democratic contenders bloody each other," Mr. Sharpton said on WNBC-TV. "And frankly, I've resisted entertaining them with that. That's entertainment. We're all running based on our own views and saying we offer distinct opportunities to run against an incumbent Mayor. And what the media would like -- and what I think people would like -- are, I think, two different things."
Gabe Pressman, the WNBC host, who spent the first 15 minutes of the debate all but pleading for his guests to talk about one another, leaned toward Mr. Sharpton in exasperation. "I don't want it for entertainment," Mr. Pressman said. "I want to know what the difference is between you guys and gals."
It was to no avail. By the closing moment of the last of three debates that were broadcast yesterday, it was clear that the candidates were using their final moments to ask Democrats to base their selections not on any differences among them, but on the strengths of the cases they made against the Republican Mayor.
The decision by Ms. Messinger to stay essentially above the fray (assuming there had been a fray to stay above) was in keeping with her front-runner strategy of ignoring her primary opponents and focusing only on the general election and Mr. Giuliani. She even held back as Mr. Pressman urged his guests to talk about why they were not talking about each other, joining the conversation only when he insisted that she speak. "What I want the voters to do is to hear, from each of us, Gabe, what we see as the most serious problems and how we would fix them," she said.
But the strategy evidenced by Mr. Albanese and Mr. Sharpton was unusual, since the debates gave both underfinanced candidates an opportunity to try to take down Ms. Messinger, who is widely seen as the front-runner.
Ms. Messinger's political advisers had gone into the debates expecting her to be the center of repeated attacks, and afterward said they were pleasantly surprised -- though slightly mystified -- to learn she was not.
Mr. Giuliani was not so lucky. The Democrats sought throughout the day to one-up each other in their criticisms of Mr. Giuliani's personality and his performance. Mr. Sharpton said the Mayor did not deserve credit for the reduction in crime, saying it reflected national trends and policies put in place before Mr. Giuliani took office. Mr. Albanese, quoting Jim Dwyer, the Daily News columnist, called the Mayor a habitual liar. Ms. Messinger said the Mayor had abused campaign finance laws in paying for his campaign.
"The economy is not up," Mr. Albanese said. "We have the highest unemployment rate of any city across America."
Mr. Sharpton compared New Yorkers who considered the city to be in good shape to tenants who live on the 13th floor but call it the 14th.
"We're pretending we're doing better," Mr. Sharpton said. "The fact is, we're on the 13th floor. Unemployment is record-high. The schools are not working. We have serious problems with how we transfer people from welfare to work that ought to be working, but in real jobs. We have police brutality that's an international embarrassment for the city."
Ms. Messinger had a long list of what she described as the failures of Mr. Giuliani's administration, from a lack of classrooms to the number of hungry and homeless New Yorkers. "If you agree with Rudy Giuliani that this is as good as it gets, then vote for him and the status quo," she said, adding, "To those who say that this is as good as it gets, I say: You ain't seen nothing yet."
"We have a Mayor right now whose middle name is bully," she continued. "That's what has gotten people used to the notion that any political discussion is going to result in someone calling people names."
As the Democrats painted a bleak portrait of the state of New York City, Mr. Giuliani accused the candidates of engaging in "negative and personal campaigning." And then, hinting at his own tactical plans for the general election, the Mayor suggested that the barbs thrown at him by the Democrats had given him the political license to respond in kind against whoever emerges from Tuesday's primary as his opponent.
"I don't think there's anyone that can complain that we started it," the Mayor said.
But the last round of debates for the Democrats was not entirely cordial.
Eric Ruano-Melendez, a civil engineer who works for the city, was allowed to participate in a debate sponsored by the city's Campaign Finance Board because he was eligible for the campaign matching funds.
Mr. Ruano-Melendez repeatedly answered questions by decrying the influence of "corrupt lawyers," and accused Mr. Sharpton of being anti-Hispanic and belonging to organizations that were trying to overthrow the country.
"Like the Democratic Party?" Mr. Sharpton said, lifting his eyebrows. Mr. Sharpton took note of Mr. Ruano-Melendez's central campaign promise, to bring in the National Guard to patrol the city streets: "My only question, Mr. Melendez, is if you promise that on Tuesday night if I win, you will not attempt a military coup."
There were also some slight disagreements among the candidates. Ms. Messinger took issue with Mr. Albanese's proposal to restrict campaign contributions to $10 with the difference made up by the city, an idea that could cost the city $30 million.
"I don't want to say to taxpayers, 'Pay $25 or $30 million for an election,' " said Ms. Messinger, who was one of the authors of the city's current campaign finance law. "We can get 900 teachers for that. What we need is to stop those people who abuse the law, like Rudy Giuliani, who had to return over $400,000 in contributions because his collection of that money violated the principles of the law."
Ms. Messinger was referring to contributions Mr. Giuliani was forced to return this year by the Campaign Finance Board for violating statutory restrictions on who is allowed to contribute.
Both Mr. Albanese and Mr. Sharpton took issue with Ms. Messinger's proposal to cut spending with such measures as requiring employees to work longer hours.
Mr. Albanese, who enjoys extensive support from labor unions, denounced the plan, saying, "The workers of our city are bearing a tremendous burden to make this city viable and they get nothing in return for it."
Mr. Sharpton, alluding to his complaint that Ms. Messinger had moved too far to the political center, also argued that the only way to victory in November was for the party to return to its ideological roots.
"You need a candidate that can energize and excite a new base of voters," Mr. Sharpton said. "Young voters. Disaffected voters. Voters that did not come out in 1993. Clearly I think I'm the best candidate to do that."

HEADLINE: Whitman's Re-election Race Faces Pocketbook Backlash

BYLINE: By JENNIFER PRESTON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 7

 BODY:
Despite a strong economy and a record of cutting taxes, Gov. Christine Todd Whitman is battling for re-election against a little-known Democratic challenger who has put her on the defensive on the issue that is most important to New Jersey voters: auto insurance.
Only a few months ago, Governor Whitman's strategy for re-election was to remind voters that they are better off today than they were four years ago. At the time, her campaign aides said they believed their biggest challenge against State Senator James E. McGreevey, the Democratic nominee, would be exciting a complacent electorate. 
 But Mr. McGreevey, a 40-year-old former assistant prosecutor who has spent much of his career in politics as a legislator and as Mayor of Woodbridge Township, has tapped into voters' anger over paying the highest auto insurance premiums in the nation. Recent independent polls show that even though Mr. McGreevey remains unknown to most voters outside Middlesex County, he is making inroads against the Governor.
The majority of New Jersey voters, the polls show, are frustrated that Governor Whitman has not done more to reduce their auto insurance bills. And even though Governor Whitman kept her promise to cut the state income tax rate by 30 percent, a large number of voters say the tax cut increased their property tax bills.
It was Mrs. Whitman's promise to cut taxes that helped her win election in 1993, and keeping that promise helped make her a rising star in national Republican political circles.
But the pocketbook issue in this campaign is auto insurance. And New Jersey voters are known for deciding races on pocketbook issues. The electorate can be volatile because it does not vote along party lines. More than half the registered voters are unaffiliated with either the Republican or Democratic Party.
"At this point, there is a large enough group looking around for an alternative to the Governor, making it a competitive race," said Janice Ballou, a professor of political science at Rutgers University and director of its Eagleton Poll. "He is unknown, but people are taking a closer look."
Lyn Nofziger, a former aide to President Reagan and a friend of Governor Whitman's who is advising her campaign, said it should be no surprise that New Jersey is going to have a race. He pointed out that President Clinton won by 17 percentage points last November, and that the state's two United States Senators are Democrats.
The last Republican to win by a landslide in a statewide race was Tom Kean, who captured almost 70 percent of the vote during his gubernatorial re-election campaign in 1985.
"I expect her to win, but I don't expect her to win big," said Mr. Nofziger, who also advised Mrs. Whitman in her 1993 gubernatorial campaign and her unsuccessful race for the United States Senate in 1990. "We don't really care. What we want is that one vote to win, and beyond that it is gravy."
Instead of touting her administration's record of cutting taxes 14 times, creating 195,000 new jobs and reducing crime, Governor Whitman has found herself talking mostly about auto insurance.
Some of her own campaign advisers say the Governor's problems with auto insurance might have been avoided if she had not shone a spotlight on the issue earlier this year.
In January, she made auto insurance the centerpiece of her annual address to the Legislature and called it her top priority. She proposed lowering rates by allowing consumers to reduce their coverage, but her own party in the Republican-controlled Legislature rejected the proposal. Lawmakers did agree, however, to parts of her plan, removing unpopular surcharges for drivers who have received moving violations, and automatic annual rate increases for insurance companies.
Over the summer, Mrs. Whitman revived her plan. Only this time, she guaranteed up to a 25 percent reduction in rates. Her decision to refocus on the issue puzzled some of her political analysts, friends and advisers who wondered why she was leading with her opponent's issue.
"We don't have to work so hard to raise the issues, because she is raising them for us," one of Mr. McGreevey's top campaign aides said. "All we have to do is chime in and point the finger."
In an interview, Governor Whitman said she had ignored the advice of her own political consultants, who had urged her to back away from the issue. She said it would be a bigger mistake to ignore the voters. "I'm not going to lie to them," she said of the voters. "I'm not going to tell them it's O.K."
"Remember what almost happened to Bill Bradley," she said, referring to the former United States Senator whom she nearly toppled while making her first statewide election bid in 1990. "And that almost happened because he refused to talk about New Jersey taxes. He kept saying that it is not my problem. It's a state problem. And he ran ads that were feel-good ads, with his feet up on the desk, and said how wonderful everything was. And people were here saying, no, they are not wonderful."
Governor Whitman also said that she was faring better with the voters than recent polls suggested, but was not taking anyone's vote for granted. "All I know is what I see on the streets," she said. "Everything that I see, when I am out talking and walking, taking the people's poll, has been good."
The prospect of a competitive gubernatorial race in New Jersey, the only contest involving an incumbent governor in the nation, has attracted the attention of national Democratic and Republican Party officials who say they will pour money and resources into the state. President Clinton is scheduled to visit New Jersey in the coming weeks, and Hillary Rodham Clinton is to campaign with Mr. McGreevey on Friday. The state Republican Party has already begun broadcasting television commercials, blaming Democrats for the auto insurance problem.
Nonetheless, even Democrats concede that Governor Whitman will be tough to beat. She is a formidable campaigner who has delivered strong performances in televised debates in the past. And although polls show that voters disapprove of how the Governor has handled auto insurance, the same polls show that voters still like Governor Whitman personally.
New Jersey voters have also traditionally re-elected incumbent governors, which is why the discontent among voters during strong economic times in this race confounds veteran state politicians and pollsters. Even Jim Florio, who was strongly disliked by the voters for imposing $2.8 billion in new taxes and the only incumbent New Jersey governor to lose a general election, lost to Mrs. Whitman in 1993 by only 25,000 votes.
Mr. McGreevey, who is making his first statewide election bid, unveiled the details of his plan on auto insurance last week. He said it would guarantee customers a 10 percent cut in premiums without reducing coverage.
"Our campaign is presented with a substantial opportunity by virtue of the Governor's failures," Mr. McGreevey said. "Yet it is incumbent upon us to offer the public a striking contrast to demonstrate how our actions would measurably benefit day-to-day, middle-class life in New Jersey."
He said that in coming weeks he would present proposals on other issues, like lower property taxes, expanded economic development programs to create more jobs in the state's cities, and better schools.
Governor Whitman also said that she would talk more about her record over the next eight weeks, drawing comparisons with her achievements and Mr. McGreevey's. She dismissed his auto insurance proposal, describing it as his "quote, unquote plan, which isn't a plan."
"But the deciding factor when people are in the voting booths, as far as the No. 1 priority, it is not going to be tax cuts," she said. "It's going to be get this auto insurance stuff done. It is not going to go away."

HEADLINE: Retail Customers To Get Intel's New Chips First

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 7

 BODY:
When it introduces its newest generation of microprocessor chips on Monday, the Intel Corporation will be breaking with a long tradition in the computer industry by offering the fruits of its most advanced technology to retail customers shopping at outlets like CompUSA instead of to corporations like General Dynamics or Hewlett-Packard.
The new chip, the latest in the Pentium line, contains the smallest transistors Intel has ever made for commercial sale. As a result, it packs more of these transistors -- the switches that control the flow of electrical impulses in the circuitry -- into a smaller space than ever before. 
 The new technology provides computer users with twin benefits: Their machines can perform more functions faster while using less power. This makes the new chips especially useful in small, battery-powered portable computers -- the fastest-growing segment of the computer industry.
The fastest and most powerful chips are now appearing first in portable and inexpensive systems sold to consumers instead of in the mainframe or minicomputers that typically belong to corporations and research centers. Because the revenues of the consumer markets have outstripped those of the corporate market, tapping into the retail markets is the most effective way for companies like Intel to finance the soaring costs of developing technology.
It is a trend that has already become visible in markets for video games and portable and hand-held computers. "The distinctions between consumer and high-end computer markets are increasingly becoming obsolete," said Michael Borrus, the co-director of the Berkeley Roundtable on International Economics at the University of California at Berkeley.
The new processors, operating at 200 and 233 megahertz with the company's MMX multimedia technology, are the first products made using Intel's most advanced manufacturing technology. The circuit lines on the chip are 0.25 microns wide; more than 300 of them set side by side would barely equal the width of a human hair.
Because the new chips draw far less power than their predecessors, Intel said, they will significantly extend the battery life of portable computers. For example, Intel executives said it would be possible for travelers on a cross-country flight to view full-length movies using only a single battery if their machines played DVD-ROM's, the new disks used for viewing high-resolution video.
For the last three decades, computer engineers have been creating smaller and smaller circuits, as predicted by Gordon Moore, a co-founder of Intel. His statement that the number of transistors that can be put on the same-sized chip would double every 18 months has long been known as Moore's Law.
If the current curve continues, desktop computers will have one billion transistor memory chips and microprocessors that reach speeds of 1,000 MHz -- four times the power of today's machines -- by the beginning of the next century.
The Intel chips being introduced on Monday approach the processing speed of the company's most powerful Pentium II microprocessor -- now used mostly in large computer servers and high-end personal computers -- and will consume up to 50 percent less power than the chip maker's previous generation of portable-computer processors.
At the introduction of the new chips in Santa Clara, Calif., Intel will display portable systems from more than twenty different computer companies that use the faster, lower power chips.
"It's another big step toward the dream machine," said Stephen P. Nachtsheim, vice president and general manager of Intel's mobile and hand-held products division.
Indeed, the personal computer industry has been driven for the last 25 years by the so-called Dynabook, first envisioned by Alan Kay, a computer scientist, and a small group of colleagues at Xerox's Palo Alto Research Center in California.
Although that computer was intended to weigh about two pounds, none of the computers to be introduced at the Monday news conference will achieve that goal.
However, Intel executives said that the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Mitsubishi Corporation would show off an ultralight, ultrathin portable system that will weigh slightly more than three pounds and have a 12.1-inch display screen. Hewlett-Packard officials said on Friday that the machine was only a prototype and that the company had no immediate plans to mass-produce it.
Another company rushing to capitalize on the advances in processing power offered by Intel is the Power Computing Corporation of Austin, Tex., which withdrew from the Macintosh market last week after Apple Computer repurchased its manufacturing license.
Power Computing officials said they would begin shipping their first computers based on Intel's processors in two weeks. The new models, known as Powertrip, will offer only Intel-based systems. The models are expected to cost $3,300 to $5,500 and weigh 7.7 pounds.
