HEADLINE: THE WARMING WORLD: Coping With Climate Change;
Experts on Climate Change Pondering: How Urgent Is It?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
WITH the nations of the world counting down to a Dec. 10 deadline for negotiating cuts in emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases that many scientists say are altering the earth's climate, a fundamental question continues to pervade the debate:
Just how urgent is the problem of climate change? 
 The problem has often been perceived as lying off in the dim future -- a century away, say, since that is the time scale on which most analysis of the question has been based. It can be very hard to get excited about something that seems so remote. "We see the train coming," President Clinton said not long ago, "but most ordinary Americans in their day-to-day lives can't hear the whistle blowing."
Mainstream scientists say that the whistle is getting louder all the time, that many signs of a changing climate are already evident. On the night of Aug. 20 and 21, for instance, a cloudburst poured up to nine inches of rain on New Jersey in three hours. No conclusions about climate change can be drawn from a single downpour. But it provided one more data point in what Government scientists say is a clear trend in the United States: heavy rainstorms have become more common, making damaging floods more likely, and over all it is raining more than it used to.
Other parts of the world have also experienced increases in precipitation in this century. And while the trend's association with global warming is not yet firmly nailed down, mainstream scientists say it is precisely, and unsurprisingly, what would be expected as the earth's atmosphere heats up.
The average surface temperature of the globe has risen by about 1 degree Fahrenheit in the 20th century, and about half a degree in the last 40 years -- with temperatures generally rising more the farther away one gets from the Equator. A warmer atmosphere sucks up more water from the oceans and in general makes more moisture available to developing storms. Observations show that atmospheric water vapor has increased. Therefore, the scientists say, global warming may well be revving up the planet's rainmaking machine.
A rainier world is just one of several climatic changes already observed that are associated with the warming, scientists say. Temperatures have risen more at night than in the day, portending milder winter evenings but also more deadly heat waves. Experts, for instance, attributed the record death toll in Chicago's 1995 heat wave mainly to a combination of unusually high nighttime temperature and humidity.
The area of the Northern Hemisphere covered by snow has generally declined in the last 25 years. Mountain glaciers have receded in many areas. Sea level has risen as warmth has caused the water to expand. Spring comes earlier and fall arrives later in Northern latitudes, which have become about 10 percent greener.
"The climate reality is that if you look out your window, part of what you see in terms of the weather is produced by ourselves," said Thomas R. Karl, senior scientist at the National Climatic Data Center in Asheville, N.C. "If you look out the window 50 years from now, we're going to be responsible for more of it."
Mr. Karl has not been known as a doomsayer on the question of global warming. It was he and his colleagues who analyzed 20th-century climatic data for the United States and southern Canada and found that both overall precipitation and the frequency of intense rainstorms and snowstorms had, on average, increased by about 10 percent over the century. Intense storms were defined as those in the top 10 percent, in terms of the amount of precipitation delivered, at the start of the century.
The trend, said Mr. Karl, is consistent with what would be expected in a world made warmer by greenhouse gases -- principally carbon dioxide, which is produced by the burning of coal, oil and natural gas.
This is only the beginning, if a panel of more than 2,000 scientists advising the world's governments is right. While no one is predicting apocalypse any time soon, the scientists' best estimate is that the world will warm by more than another half degree in the next 20 years if greenhouse emissions are not reduced (although the underlying trend would surely be modified from time to time by natural climatic variations). With another half degree of warming, the average global temperature would approach the highest experienced in the 10,000 years since the last ice age, said Dr. Thomas J. Crowley, a paleoclimatologist at Texas A & M University.
A century from now, according to the scientific panel's best estimate, the earth's surface will be some 3.5 degrees warmer than in 1990. "You have to go back millions of years to find global temperatures like that," said Dr. Crowley. By way of comparison, it was 5 to 9 degrees colder in the depths of the last ice age.
The panel predicted that the warming would bring widespread climatic, environmental and economic dislocation. Some benefits are expected to result, including longer growing seasons in Northern Hemisphere breadbaskets and more robust plant growth stimulated by increased carbon dioxide. But many effects would be adverse, including intensified cycling of water through the ocean-atmosphere system that would result in both more frequent and severe floods and droughts; it would rain harder but things would dry out more and faster between storms. Sea level is expected to rise by about a foot and a half, inundating many low-lying coastlines. Climatic zones would shift away from the Equator, upsetting natural ecosystems. Entire forest types might disappear. Agriculture in some parts of the world, especially Africa, might be devastated. The geographical range of tropical diseases would expand.
Not all scientists agree with Mr. Karl and the international scientific panel, and the disagreement is symptomatic of a more general, nagging uncertainty that plagues all efforts to gauge the urgency of the climate problem. The uncertainty also complicates the task of negotiators from around the world as they struggle to determine how much and how rapidly greenhouse gas emissions should be cut. The negotiators' next session is in Bonn in late October, with a final session in Kyoto, Japan, in the first 10 days in December.
"Yes, there have been these big climate changes, but I think they're all natural," said Dr. William M. Gray, a climatologist at Colorado State University in Fort Collins who has been skeptical that greenhouse gases are altering the climate. "I respect Tom Karl a lot, but I don't agree with his interpretation of his data." Another skeptic, Dr. Richard S. Lindzen of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, says that the natural system has built-in resilience -- "it has to wobble a bit" -- and that the observed changes are an expression of this. Since he believes that global warming is expected to amount to little, Dr. Lindzen believes there is little or no urgency.
The potential Achilles' heel in the mainstream scientists' projections of future climate is that they are based on computerized models of the atmosphere's response to estimates of future greenhouse gas emissions. Everyone agrees that the models are imperfect, and Dr. Lindzen goes so far as to liken them to Ouija boards, but many experts believe they are steadily improving and becoming more realistic. In any case, they say, there is no other way to even begin to cope with the atmosphere's complexities.
The international panel of scientists, which was established by the United Nations and is called the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, relied heavily on the models in rendering its landmark judgment, two years ago, that "the balance of evidence suggests a discernible human influence on global climate." The cautiously phrased statement, a compromise product of intense discussions, was a watershed in the climate debate because until then the panel had always said the observed warming and attendant climate changes could have been a result of natural variability.
Since then, some opponents of action to cut greenhouse gases have seized on an article in the May 16 issue of the journal Science, which dealt with uncertainties surrounding the panel's conclusion that humans are probably altering the climate, to suggest that the uncertainty has grown.
But that is disputed by the chief author of the intergovernmental panel's chapter on detection of human influence on climate. The scientist, Dr. Benjamin D. Santer of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory, who was quoted in the Science article, said in a recent interview that further studies have not only reinforced the original conclusion, but might even strengthen it. And in a recent open letter, he said that despite large uncertainties, "the question is not whether, but rather to what extent" greenhouse gases are influencing the climate. The best evidence, he wrote, "suggests that the human component of climate change is not trivially small."
The size of that component remains, perhaps, the major uncertainty in gauging how urgent the climate change problem is.
But if the intergovernmental panel is right, the average global surface temperature will rise by about a third of a degree Fahrenheit per decade over the next century if greenhouse gases are not reduced.
Many scientists believe that no matter what action is taken in Kyoto, some substantial measure of future warming is already assured.
"We haven't seen the full ramifications" of the greenhouse gases already emitted, said Dr. Kevin Trenberth, a climatologist at the National Center for Atmospheric Research in Boulder, Colo. The reason is that built-in inertia, mainly stemming from a drag on heating exerted by the oceans, prevents the climate system from reacting immediately to the emissions. Only about half the warming potential of greenhouse gases already in the atmosphere has been realized, said Dr. James E. Hansen, a climatologist who directs the NASA Goddard Institute for Space Studies in New York.
What this means, he said, is that even if greenhouse gas emissions suddenly ceased today, "you'd get a few tenths of a degree" of global warming in the next quarter century.
But emissions are not going to cease now, since any policy adopted in Kyoto would require some time to have any appreciable effect. This means that atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases would continue to grow. "You can't turn that off" right away, said Dr. Trenberth. He noted that even if emissions were reduced to 1990 levels -- a target that most industrialized nations are already failing to meet -- atmospheric concentrations would continue to rise indefinitely. This is because the 1990 levels were already so high.
Dr. Hansen says that "what we do now is not going to have much influence on climate change in the next couple of decades; the main impact of changes we make now will be 50 and 100 years downstream." Consequently, he believes, climatic change is going to become "more apparent over the next decade or so." Dr. Hansen has long been a firm adherent of the view that greenhouse gases are the major cause of the observed warming.
Some scientists, while convinced that humans are changing the climate in important ways and that greenhouse warming is a serious issue, believe that taking no action now would have little appreciable climatic effect. One is Dr. Tom Wigley of the National Center for Atmospheric Research, who said, "Just from a pure climate point of view, another 20 years of doing nothing is unlikely to mess things up." He acknowledged that many experts would not agree, and quickly added, "I'm not saying we should do nothing for 20 years." For one thing, he said, "the longer we delay, then the more we have to do later."
How much to do now is the crux of the discussions that will culminate in Kyoto. The decision is complicated by the fact that while the intergovernmental panel estimated a 3.5-degree increase in average global temperature by 2100, it also said the increase could be as low as 2 degrees and as high as 6.
This poses a dilemma, in the view of Dr. Michael E. Schlesinger, a climatologist at the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign: If the warming is on the low end of the panel's estimate and the Kyoto delegates decide to do too much, it will be too costly to the world economy. But if it is on the high end and they decide to do too little, climatic damage will be too high and it will still be too costly.
What should governments do? "We should not do nothing and hope for the best; that's crazy," Dr. Schlesinger said. "On the other hand, we shouldn't do everything, either; we don't want to squander resources on something that might turn out to be a nonproblem." He and others call for an adaptive strategy in which at least some action is taken now, and then both the climatic effects and the economic cost of acting are periodically reassessed. Mid-course corrections would be made as needed. This principle is, in fact, built into the 1992 Rio treaty on climate change, under which the present negotiations are proceeding.
But then a further difficulty arises, in Dr. Schlesinger's view. Since the effects of any emissions reductions undertaken now would not be apparent in the next two decades, it would be impossible to tell for some time whether the right thing was done. And if the reductions did subsequently succeed in mitigating the warming, that very fact would make it harder to know how serious the warming would otherwise have been, and therefore what further action might or might not be needed.
"That," said Dr. Schlesinger, "is what's so difficult about this cockamamie problem."

HEADLINE: A Smart Aleck's Second Chance;
At 18, the 'Squirt TV' Guy Resumes His Pop-Scene Assault

BYLINE: By NEIL STRAUSS 

 BODY:
At 14, Jake Fogelnest started his own public-access television show in Manhattan. At 16, he was the host of his own talk show on MTV. At 17, he was unemployed and in a drug rehabilitation clinic. Now, at 18, he is back, rebuilding his career as a radio host, producer, musician, record executive, comedian and more. In just four years, Jake Fogelnest has completed a career cycle that typically spans a lifetime. And he still lives with his mother.
"My dad has said once again I have the world by the neck," Mr. Fogelnest said over dinner recently at the Coffee Shop in Union Square. 
 Although Mr. Fogelnest is 18, he still looks 14. A scrawny guy in an oversize blue T-shirt with a thin growth of black hair that looks out of place on his baby face, Mr. Fogelnest has made a career out of being a smart aleck.
At a recent star-filled party in SoHo, he walked up to Russell Simmons, the rap mogul, and asked if he could be booked on his black-comic television show "Def Comedy Jam." It was not the first time he had asked Mr. Simmons the question. He later snuck up on the shock-rock star Marilyn Manson, petted his fur coat, grabbed a random male passer-by and announced that they were now engaged. Then, after being introduced to the rapper and executive Sean (Puffy) Combs, he said in deference, "It's a pleasure to meet you, Mr. Puff Daddy, sir." That was just the beginning of a night of flippancy.
Mr. Fogelnest's fearless, wisecracking city-kid demeanor is what made his public-access show, "Squirt TV," so appealing when it first appeared on Manhattan cable television in January 1994. The show's concept was basic: Mr. Fogelnest sitting on his bed talking to a stationary camera about music, the week's tabloid news and whatever else was on his mind. Occasionally he interviewed visiting musicians and passers-by outside, asking them challenging questions like "Have you seen Chris Farley naked?" and "If a kid had a lemon for a head, would it be fair to tease him?"
Before he had taped a dozen episodes of "Squirt TV," Mr. Fogelnest was phoned by a few new fans: Mike D. of the Beastie Boys, Thurston Moore of Sonic Youth, John Flansburgh of They Might Be Giants and Eric Bogosian.
"I've tried to figure out what made my show so successful on public access and what made people like me and want to do stuff with me," Mr. Fogelnest said. "I think it was the fact that here's a 14-year-old kid who's not a big tough guy, talking trash about whatever he wants without fear of offending anyone. I didn't care. I had no friends. Everyone in seventh grade hated me."
Though Mr. Fogelnest had been monkeying around with his parents' video cameras since he was 6, the show was all his own idea and recorded with a camera he bought with money from summer jobs. He also credits his success to the creative background of his mother (a freelance art director who works with DC Comics) and his father (a criminal-defense lawyer who puts out a magazine, The Fogelnest Files, filled with the year's most bizarre news clippings), who separated when he was a toddler.
"After all that Jake has experienced, considering that his age is only 18," said his mother, Murphy Fogelnest, "staying focused on his ongoing desire to build an empire that satisfies his creative wit, financial independence and desire to sleep late in the morning seems to be a challenge he is more than capable of meeting on his own. But that's only Jake's mother's opinion, without prejudice, of course."
In early 1995, MTV, pop culture's quickest star-making machine, offered to pick up "Squirt TV." After making the grade as a host on MTV's spring break shows and creating an hour of "Squirt TV" for Comedy Central, Mr. Fogelnest began "Squirt TV on MTV," though not without a dispute: MTV wanted to record the show in a studio, and Mr. Fogelnest wanted to keep using his bedroom, near Little Italy.
In the end, youth and perseverance paid off, and the bedroom was beamed to millions of homes twice a week, with the Fugees, the Wu-Tang Clan, Adam Sandler, Sean Lennon and others stopping by and subjecting themselves to absurd questions.
In one memorable episode, he challenged the Hong Kong action-movie star Jackie Chan to a video game of Mortal Kombat and won. Though the show lost its homemade charm, it was still a success, and after a three-month trial run MTV renewed it for eight more episodes.
 
'I Didn't See It In Myself'
But trouble was building, from money disputes to Mr. Fogelnest's increasing disappearances. "I became so obsessed at MTV with the idea of making a million dollars and being successful and being independent and being on my own, that I completely lost sight of what I was doing," he now admits.
"I was also probably difficult to deal with because I was in the teen angst rebellion period, which I used to make fun of. But I didn't see it in myself when it happened."
When it came time for MTV to make a second run of "Squirt TV" episodes, Mr. Fogelnest was nowhere to be found. Days passed, weeks passed, a month passed. He had abandoned MTV, so MTV abandoned "Squirt TV." Suddenly, Mr. Fogelnest reappeared in the East Village, performing stand-up comedy at the Luna Lounge, showing old episodes of "Squirt TV" across the street at the Pink Pony cafe and talking about his recent dances with drug abuse.
"He went from being a fresh-faced little kid -- a squirt -- to going down this path I didn't like, where he was hanging out with a bunch of undesirables and dating this older woman," said Shelby Meade, who has handled his publicity, without charge, since 1994. "Then all of a sudden, he checked out. I heard from people he may have been using drugs, then I looked at his behavioral patterns and thought he probably was.
"But now that he's back, he's really becoming an adult. He has a really strong understanding of the entertainment business, and he's much more mature. I'm really proud of what he's done with his life."
Mr. Fogelnest said he did not like to dwell on his monthlong disappearance, during which he put himself back on track at a rehabilitation clinic. "That stuff finds you," he said. "I never got that bad. I could have gotten a lot worse. You're 16 years old, you're on MTV, you're out of your mind, and you lose sight of what's important. I'm glad to have that behind me as early as I did. When you're younger, you bounce back quicker."
Mr. Fogelnest lights a cigarette and attempts to clear up one more misconception: "I never slept with Courtney Love either."
Though the rumor (which Howard Stern asked him about on the air) may seem ludicrous, Mr. Fogelnest does like to befriend musicians 10 and 20 years his elder, he said, "because they know more."
In conversation, Mr. Fogelnest speaks about the goings-on at record labels and MTV like a seasoned industry player. And he constantly talks about such friends as Russell Simins of the Jon Spencer Blues Explosion, the MTV executive Amy Finnerty, the 18-year-old Australian rocker Ben Lee and Mike D., who, as a musician, record executive and magazine publisher, has been one of his idols.
"I relate to Jake in the sense that I was no different," Mike D. said. "I was going to clubs in Manhattan when I was 14. I kind of idolized older punk-rock and hip-hop bands, and I was like 15 when I started the Beastie Boys. And what business did we having doing that at that age? Jake could've been hanging out with us then."
Mr. Fogelnest's propensity for seeking the acceptance of his elders in the music industry has not always succeeded. Marilyn Manson and his group put him in a highchair at the fetish-theme restaurant La Nouvelle Justine in Chelsea and ordered him a spanking; the band Weezer dropped ice cubes down his shirt backstage at Roseland, and the singer Henry Rollins chastised him for 20 minutes during a radio interview, telling him to change his life and get pants that fit. But most of these have been good-humored gibes at one of the entertainment industry's more resilient figures.
He has already moved far beyond his experiences at MTV. He is the host of a radio show on the New York radio station known as K-Rock (WXRK, 92.3 FM) every Sunday at midnight, and he is one of the few disk jockeys with some control over the music he plays. He is producing an album for a rock band from Oklahoma called Epperley. He says he is days away from signing a contract to become a consultant and talent scout for a major record label. He is writing articles for Grand Royal, the magazine run by the Beastie Boys. He is preparing to make his debut as a human beatbox in a rock band. And he recently traveled to Scotland, where he met with television executives interested in discussing future "Squirt TV"-type projects.
 
'A Lot of Doors Open to Me'
Though Mr. Fogelnest has done a little of everything at an age when most teen-agers are worrying about S.A.T. results, he still is not sure what to do next or five years from now.
"There are a lot of doors open to me right now, and I just have to pick the right ones," he said. "I'm 18 years old, and Squirt TV happened really fast. It also ended really fast. So I'm into a slow build now, because I don't have to rush. All my friends keep telling me: 'Just relax. You don't have to hold yourself to the standards you've made for yourself in comparison to us, who are much older and have been doing this for years.' And that part of it has finally sunk in. Maybe I'll surprise everyone and go to college."
For Mr. Fogelnest, there are disadvantages to being a local celebrity so young. After dinner, he called his mother to check his messages and walked to the Beauty Bar on East 14th Street to meet some friends. As he waited in line outside, the bouncer recognized him: "Hey, you're from 'Squirt TV.' "
"Yeah, that's me," Mr. Fogelnest responded with a smile.
The bouncer smiled back and said, "Then you're definitely going to have to show me ID."

HEADLINE: California Is Big Enough

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The notion that population growth is good for California and, for that matter, for the United States, is ridiculous (front page, Sept. 3). Any benefits seen in California are short term and will hurt the state in the long haul. Most of the people who are moving into the state are unskilled, and many are illiterate. 
 In contrast, population growth due to the booming high-tech industry is relatively small. Yet this is responsible for the recent economic growth of the state.
 
V. R. DURVASULA
Cheshire, Conn., Sept. 4, 1997

HEADLINE: Debt Incurred By Consumers Soared in July

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Consumer installment credit climbed in July by $6.5 billion, or at a 6.4 percent annual rate, after a revised $800 million increase in June, or at a rate of eight-tenths of 1 percent, the Federal Reserve said today.
The July increase was well above the forecasts of Wall Street economists for a $4.3 billion rise and reflected a strong bounce in borrowing to buy new cars and in credit-card use. 
 Previously, the Fed said June consumer credit was unchanged from May.
The overall rise in July consumer credit was the strongest in three months, since it gained by $9.6 billion in April.
Total credit outstanding grew by $2.7 billion in May.
In July, auto credit outstanding shot up by $3.6 billion, or at a 10.9 percent annual rate, after a much smaller $900 million increase at a 2.8 percent rate in June.
Revolving, or credit-card, credit was up by $5.4 billion, or at a 12.5 percent annual rate in July -- the strongest monthly rise since last January, when it advanced $7.3 billion, or 13 percent, the Fed said. Credit-card debt had risen $2.4 billion, or at a 5.6 percent rate, in June.
Other credit, which includes consumer bank loans like those for mobile homes and to pay for education, but not real estate mortgages, fell $2.5 billion in July. That was the same as the $2.5 billion reduction in June.
Before seasonal adjustment, total consumer credit outstanding in July was $1.218 trillion, up from $1.158 trillion in July 1996.

HEADLINE: Ms. Albright's Daunting Agenda

 BODY:
Madeleine Albright could hardly have found a dicier time to make her first visit to the Middle East as Secretary of State. Not only has the peace effort between Israel and the Palestinians all but collapsed, but regional powers like Saudi Arabia and Iran are asserting themselves in ways that may undermine America's leadership in the area. As Ms. Albright works her way through the region this week, she will need all her vaunted bluntness and determination to keep instability at bay.
Washington's role in the Middle East has not been as problematic since before the Persian Gulf war in 1991. The war made the political and military landscape more favorable to peace by weakening Iraq and demonstrating the potential benefits of cooperation between the United States, Israel and leading Arab countries like Egypt and Saudi Arabia. But the gulf war coalition, which indirectly opened the way to peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians though Israel itself was not a member, has lost cohesion in recent years. The dynamic works two ways. When the peace talks falter, strains in the coalition increase, and when the informal alliance is divided, as it is today, the pressure for peace diminishes. 
 Ms. Albright can address the first part of the equation by getting Benjamin Netanyahu and Yasir Arafat talking again. It will not be easy. The Israeli Prime Minister justifiably insists that negotiations cannot resume until the Palestinian leader cracks down on terrorists. Ms. Albright properly plans to make plain to Mr. Arafat that his indifference to terrorism has stunted the peace. She need not be tactful in delivering the message. Mr. Arafat must understand that any tolerance for terrorism is unacceptable and that his coy minuet with Palestinian terrorists will sink the peace effort.
Mr. Netanyahu should recognize that Israel, though understandably anxious about its security, can be more selective in its punishment of Palestinians and ought to avoid provocative actions like new construction projects on the West Bank and in Arab neighborhoods in Jerusalem. While there is no equivalency between bombs and bulldozers, as Ms. Albright said earlier this summer, Israeli actions do influence the overall climate for peace.
A resumption of peace talks would help Ms. Albright hold together the American-led coalition. Arab leaders, disturbed by the lack of progress, skeptical of Mr. Netanyahu's intentions and doubtful that the economic benefits of regional cooperation will materialize, are drifting out of the American orbit. Saudi Arabia, for one, has threatened to boycott an annual Mideast economic conference supported by the United States and attended by Israeli representatives and instead may go to a meeting organized by Iran.
Some of this impatience is posturing. No country in the region is more dependent on American military protection than Saudi Arabia or more fearful of a resurgent Iraq. But the breakdown in peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians, coupled with the election of a more moderate President in Iran, has created opportunity for mischief.
Ms. Albright cannot untangle the problems in one visit. But if she fails to budge anyone, the decline of the peace effort and erosion of American leadership in the Mideast could quickly get worse.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
For Asia, Austerity and Exports

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

 BODY:
Now that nearly all the nations of Southeast Asia are reeling under a wave of currency losses, how will they extract themselves from their economic mess?
Probably the same way that Mexico did not so long after it was hit by a devastating currency collapse: exports. 
 Already, the economic crisis in Southeast Asia threatens growth there and raises questions about the sustainability of the success these nations have generally enjoyed over the last decade. And even under the best of circumstances, countries like Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines are going to have to throttle back on their domestic growth to reinforce the advantage that a cheaper currency will provide them in selling goods abroad.
"A decade of boom is ending in a bust," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Primark Decision Economics in Boston. "There is a big question mark over the Asian region and a big risk for the world economy."
Indeed, almost any expected outcome will deliver at least a dose of bitter medicine to the rest of the Asian continent and the world. As austerity takes hold, Japan is expected to suffer the most, since Southeast Asia takes about a quarter of its exports.
But as the other countries adopt Indonesia's announced prescription last week of fostering export-led growth, renewed trade squabbles with the United States and the Europeans are likely to break out in certain industries.
These will probably be manageable, a number of analysts say, in part because the Southeast Asian economies are still not large enough to disrupt prevailing patterns of international trade. Together, Indonesia, Malaysia and Thailand -- three of those hardest hit -- account for only 3.2 percent of world exports. That compares with 2.8 percent for the United States, which has sustained an export boom despite increases in the value of the dollar.
And the United States is not the dominant market for these economies. It absorbs 17 percent of Malaysia's exports, 11 percent of Thailand's and 7 percent of those from Indonesia and the Philippines.
The biggest question facing the fast-growth nations of Southeast Asian is whether they will emerge from this crisis permanently damaged, or will use the opportunity to improve their ability to compete with China's giant economy.
Stock markets in the region, after repeated blows in recent weeks, improved sharply Friday and generally again yesterday. Indonesian stocks rose on hopes that last week's deregulation package might allow interest rates to come down faster than expected. Malaysia's benchmark index soared to a two-week high after Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad ended the stock-trading restrictions that Malaysian officials had imposed late last month. And Thai stocks staged their biggest rally in more than a month.
Many economists argue that the region will recover from the current crisis in a relatively short time. "Experience elsewhere of falling currencies and higher interest rates points to slower growth," said Desmond Lachman, director of emerging-market research at Salomon Brothers. "But this could be beneficial if they take all the steps needed to restore competitiveness, especially against China."
C. Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics in Washington agrees. "In the short run, they face retrenchment and belt-tightening to restore confidence," he said. "But in the longer run, they will see this crisis as a wake-up call for reform. These countries are smart and pragmatic."
At least one economist, Gary Hufbauer of the Council on Foreign Affairs, warns that the tendency of officials in Malaysia and Thailand to blame foreign speculators for their difficulties, and to intervene in their markets, suggests that they may turn their backs on the free-market approach urged by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank if their fortunes do not improve relatively quickly. "A lot is riding on an Asian recovery," he said, "because if these countries don't pull out of the downturn after two years or so, it will raise a huge cloud over the Washington consensus."
What is unclear is just how bad the domestic downturns will be and how low their currencies will have to go for strong growth to resume.
Mexico may provide a model. When it suffered from a 50 percent loss in the value of the peso against the dollar between November 1994 and March 1995, the deficit in Mexico's current account -- the overall balance of trade and investment -- shrank from 7 percent of national output in 1994 to a manageable three-tenths of 1 percent the following year. Mexico's exports to the United States and the rest of the world, by then much cheaper, surged.
But the cost of re-establishing confidence in the peso was recession -- a brutal turnaround in the economy from 4.5 growth in 1994 to a 6.2 percent contraction the following year. Only in 1996 did Mexico start growing again.
Few economists think that the Asian currency problems will wreak such havoc. And many say that Thailand is likely to take the brunt of the blow, with Malaysia, Indonesia and the Philippines emerging relatively unscathed. ING Barings, Merrill Lynch and J. P. Morgan all expect Indonesia and Malaysia to sustain growth rates of 6 to 8 percent this year and next. They forecast growth of 4 to 5 percent for the Philippines.
Still, J. P. Morgan warns in its latest Global Data Watch publication that because of the expected slump in capital investment and the need to increase exports, the region as a whole "will shift from being a net booster of demand in the rest of the world to being a net drag."
And some are even less sanguine. "The emerging nations of Southeast Asia -- not just Thailand -- will suffer longer and more difficult adjustments ahead than those forecast thus far by the major investment houses," said Lisa S. Kaess of Geoffrey Bell & Company, a New York financial adviser.
Even the pessimists agree, though, that investment in the region will pick up again to take advantage of more favorable exchange rates as soon as Southeast Asia takes steps to upgrade its mixture of products and reassure investors that the region can stay ahead of the threat from the vast new export capacity coming on stream in China.
The Chinese, according to the World Bank, received $52 billion of foreign direct investment last year, roughly one-fifth of all private capital flows to developing countries. And since 1994, they devalued their currency 35 percent against the dollar and gave exporters a 17 percent tax rebate. All in all, the price of China's exports has fallen by nearly 25 percent in the last three years. Ultimately, that is what Southeast Asia must respond to.

Dollar Up in Thin Trading
 By The Associated Press
 The dollar rose against leading currencies yesterday, helped by market rumors that August employment data for Germany would show further weakness and help keep interest rates there low.
Further helping the dollar was a modest rally in American financial markets, a Japanese monetary official's endorsement of low interest rates and a drop in the British pound on data that seemed to reduce prospects for higher interest rates there.
But dealings were thin, and traders were reluctant to draw long-term conclusions from the currency market's behavior. Many predicted little significant movement in dollar exchange rates pending release of data on United States producer prices and retail sales on Friday.
In New York late yesterday, the dollar settled at 1.8068 German marks, up from 1.8024 on Friday, and 121.17 Japanese yen, up from 121.06. The British pound cost $1.5820, down from $1.5939.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Prices Rise a Bit After Last Week's Selloff

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities were higher yesterday, with selling on advances limiting the session's gains. Activity was thin, so movement was exaggerated. Many market participants came into the session believing that last week's selloff was a bit overdone.
The 30-year bond rose 11/32, to a price of 97. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 6.61 percent, from 6.64 percent on Friday. Traders largely expect the market to trade in a narrow range most of the week, until Friday, when retail sales and producer price numbers are to be released. 
 Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, describes them as "the two blockbuster statistical economic releases this week, which should reveal that both consumer demand and pricing pressures appear to be accelerating as we proceed into the third quarter of 1997." That outlook was disconcerting to many market participants, he added.
Referring to a speech on Friday night by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who questioned the reliability of key economic statistics, Mr. Chan said, "Some people drew the conclusion that the chairman is concerned that we have had a lot of growth, but with little inflation." He added, "But now if we begin to add more growth and start showing early signs of inflation, the Fed's degree of complacency could change."
Also, market participants are wondering how more than $12 billion of corporate debt that is expected to be priced over the next few days will affect yields. Yesterday, Amresco Residential Capital Markets Inc. priced a multi-part asset-backed issue through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter. Yields ranged from 5.962 percent for securities with an average life of 0.51 year to 7.7945 percent for one with an average life of 6.98 years. There are also a number of securities priced from 19 basis points to 97 basis points over the one-month London interbank offered rate. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In addition, several borrowers from around the world are expected to price issues in the public market this week. Argentina, Venezuela and the Korean Development Bank are each expected to raise $1 billion.
Doug Burtnick, managing analyst for Technical Data in Boston, said, "The investment community has still not shown an interest in buying the market on rallies." These investors, he added, "buy dips and they may even sell rallies to make room for the new corporate issuance." He said, "This can only last as long as the economic data are mixed, and the prospects for a Sept. 30 tightening remains low."
Richard Medley, president of the Medley Investment Group, said that one result of Mr. Greenspan's speech was a squeeze on short positions in the Treasury market. Short- covering occurs when some market participants sell borrowed securities, hoping to buy them back later at lower prices, thereby pocketing the difference. However, if prices begin to rise instead of fall, as they did yesterday, these participants try to cover their short positions: that is, buying back the securities to limit their losses.
Interest rates at the regular weekly bill auction dropped yesterday in what traders said was a better-than-expected auction. The average rate for a three-month maturity was down 6 basis points, to 5.01 percent, from last week, while the six-month bill was awarded at an average rate of 5.14 percent, down 5 basis points.

HEADLINE: Small-Company Stocks Continue to Gain

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
After meandering, major stock market indexes finished higher yesterday in moderate trading as investors looked for underpriced stocks and sectors.
Despite a seemingly tranquil session, the Russell index of 2,000 companies, a major index of small-company stocks, and the Nasdaq composite index again hit record highs, as airlines and technology stocks rose. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.77 points, to close at 7,835.18, while the Standard & Poor's index of 500 companies finished at 931.20, up 2.15 points. Analysts said they expected stock prices to continue moving in a narrow range this week as investors awaited some initial indications of inflation in August. Several economic reports are scheduled for release on Friday.
"You don't have a malaise, but you don't have the makings of everybody having to go out and buy stocks right now," said Charles Pradilla, chief investment strategist at Cowen & Company in New York.
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who questioned the reliability of several economic statistics in a speech in California late Friday, did not roil markets yesterday, but investors are becoming increasingly worried that the Fed may feel it needs to curb economic growth by raising interest rates before the end of the year, Mr. Pradilla and other analysts said.
Investors continued to favor small-cap stocks by pushing the Russell index up 2.95 points, to 435.99, its eight consecutive high.
The Nasdaq composite index increased 9.58 points, to a new high of 1,645.35.
Two airline sector indexes were among the best performing yesterday, in response to a move by the major airlines to raise ticket prices by 5 percent, even though two carriers -- Delta Air Lines and AMR's American Airlines -- backed off the increase yesterday. The American Stock Exchange airline index, which includes the 10 largest airline companies, gained 5.4 percent, while the 12-company Philadelphia airline sector index rose 5.19 percent.
The fare increases, a sign of strong fall bookings and airlines' confidence about meeting third-quarter earnings forecasts "gave a whole bunch of investors a reason to jump" into the stocks, said Thomas S. Schreier, a director of equity research at Credit Suisse First Boston.
AMR climbed 4 3/16, to a new high of 110 7/16. Delta Air Lines gained 5 points, closing at 99 5/16. Northwest Airlines, which initiated the price increase last week, picked up 3 1/8, to 40 1/4.
In contrast to the market's roller-coaster ride in August, September seems to be opening somewhat sedately. In the first five trading sessions this month, the Dow closed more than 100 points higher or lower only once, on Sept. 2, when it advanced 257.36 points. But analysts believe the halt in volatility is just a brief respite.
"I think when you get to the end of this week, the market could be nervous," said Robert Froehlich chief investment strategist at Zurich Kemper Investments. "We've sort of convinced ourselves that the Goldilocks economy is alive and well. That will last until Wednesday."
By tomorrow, investor concerns about the Producer Price Index and retail sales reports, which are scheduled for Friday, should cause an increase in volatility, Mr. Froehlich said.
Meanwhile, announcements of expected third-quarter earnings shortfalls continued to hurt some companies.
Cymer fell almost 13 points yesterday after the company announced that third-quarter earnings might fall below expectations. It closed at 69 1/8, off 12 7/8.
Worldcom was the most actively traded issue yesterday as the company agreed to acquire Compuserve for $1.2 billion. As part of the transaction, Worldcom will also purchase an America Online communications network in exchange for Compuserve's on-line service and $175 million.
Worldcom closed at 33 3/4, up 2 1/4, while Compuserve slipped 3/16, to 13 5/16.
Shares of America Online jumped 6 1/8, to a new high, closing at 76 1/16, after the company announced that it would purchase Compuserve's on-line business.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong's Leader Heads for U.S. to Correct 'Misconceptions'

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Tung Chee-hwa, the man chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong, left today for his first visit to the United States since Britain returned this territory to Chinese control on July 1. He said the visit was intended to correct American "misconceptions" about Hong Kong.
The Hong Kong that Mr. Tung will discuss with President Clinton, members of Congress and interested Americans is flourishing economically. But it has no democratic institutions, has undergone a sharp contraction of civil liberties and apparently has three times the number of people it did 25 years ago who are living in poverty, in part because of an aging population and the large number of immigrants from China who do not have the skills that enable them to work in an increasingly non-manufacturing ecnonomy. 
 "I'm looking forward to going to the U.S.," said Mr. Tung, a shipping tycoon. "Really to tell my friends in America what is happening in Hong Kong, not only about the transition, but what is going on."
Mr. Tung was dissuaded from visiting the United States in the months leading up to Chinese rule, in part because of criticism over his decision to roll back certain rights.
Now, however, with two months of calm behind him, Mr. Tung said he is ready to spread news of Hong Kong's success under Chinese rule to skeptics in the United States, particularly to members of Congress who have been critical of Beijing.
Mr. Tung said he expected to meet with President Clinton, who met last spring with Martin Lee of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, which opposed Beijing's move to disband the elected legislature. He also hopes to meet with other Administration officials and key members of Congress.
"The Government is functioning as normal," said Mr. Tung. "The financial market is moving. Demonstrations are continuing, arguments everywhere. The legislative body is just as assertive as before, challenging everything we want to do."
Still, many people here, including Mr. Tung himself, believe he will face a hostile audience in explaining why Hong Kong is considered not ready for democracy.
Mr. Tung has proposed an electoral system that would give Hong Kong's leading companies and banks a major say in the legislature's composition.
Under his proposal, seats would be distributed to parties according to their proportion of total votes. A third of the seats would be chosen by companies, banks and professional associations. This arrangement is likely to prevent the Democratic Party, which won the largest share of seats in the fully elected legislature of 1995, from winning a large number of seats in elections next May. Because even losers in the elections will gain legislative seats, as permitted under a proportional voting system, and because companies are dominated by conservative business people, the Democratic Party's share of seats is almost certain to fall sharply.
Mr. Tung's view of how things are going is not shared by legislators who were removed from office by China on July 1 and replaced with a body of lawmakers of its choosing.
"It is a step backward -- it's highly undemocratic," said Mr. Lee, describing Mr. Tung's proposal.
The rosy picture painted by Mr. Tung was clouded somewhat today by a report by a group of university academics, the Hong Kong Social Security Society, which found that 856,000 people, 14 percent of the territory's population, are living beneath the poverty line of $358 a month.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Latest Cyberdeal Seems to Have Room for Two Winners

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Follow the money in yesterday's big Internet deal -- an intricate transaction involving Worldcom, Compuserve and America Online -- and it seems that the real value lies in the dull plumbing of cyberspace, not the glamour of new media.
Worldcom Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long-distance phone company, agreed to pay about $1.2 billion in stock for the Compuserve Corporation. It will keep the under-the-hood side of Compuserve's business, managing data networks and providing data services for big corporate clients. 
 In the next step of the deal, Worldcom will sell Compuserve's well-known but struggling on-line service to America Online for the equivalent of $250 million. In short, the plumbing of Compuserve, which is controlled by H & R Block, is worth nearly $1 billion, while its on-line service amounts to pocket change by comparison.
Shares of Worldcom rose sharply yesterday, up $2.25, to $33.75, and were the most actively traded, with nearly 14.6 million changing hands. But if Worldcom jumped, then America Online shares soared, closing up $6.125, to $76.0625.
The enthusiasm was not only because America Online had cut a good deal, but also because the acquisition should help it further a strategy of becoming a genuine media company -- and one able to draw more revenue from advertising and electronic commerce like on-line shopping.
Advertising and commerce now account for about 15 percent of America Online's revenues -- up from next to nothing a couple of years ago -- with the rest coming from monthly subscription fees. The company wants to see the advertising and marketing revenues rise sharply in the coming years, toward the level of 50 percent.
The key to attracting advertising dollars is building an audience on the scale provided by mainstream media. And America Online certainly appears well on its way. Today, it is by far the largest on-line service, with 9 million subscribers. By purchasing Compuserve, the second-largest on-line service, America Online, which is based in Dulles, Va., would add 2.6 million more subscribers worldwide. That would lengthen America Online's already yawning lead over its nearest remaining rival, the Microsoft Network, which has 2.3 million subscribers.
"The next stage of the Internet economy is that the media companies will start to make money, not just the infrastructure suppliers as has been the case until now," said Kate Delhagen, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
"America Online is taking a leading role in that development, and acquiring Compuserve is a big step ahead," Ms. Delhagen said. "You assemble an audience of more than 10 million subscribers, and Madison Avenue has to pay attention."
In the deal, America Online is increasing its focus as a media company not only by adding subscribers, but also by selling its ANS Communications unit to Worldcom.
Less than three years ago, America Online bought ANS, once the Internet's network backbone and run by the National Science Foundation. America Online paid $35 million for ANS, seeking greater vertical integration and less dependence on major telecommunications companies.
Today, the ANS investment seems to have been a particularly shrewd one for America Online, and one that points to the rising value of high-speed digital communications gear that keeps the Internet running. For ANS, Worldcom will give America Online Compuserve's on-line service and a cash payment of $175 million, putting a value on ANS of about $425 million.
To be sure, America Online invested in ANS and Worldcom will assume $150 million in ANS lease obligations, which are the equivalent of debt. Still, the ANS investment has been a big winner for America Online, perhaps providing more profit in the last few years than the company's basic business.
Yet Wall Street is evaluating America Online far less by its near-term profits than by its progress in assembling a working business model for the hybrid media, called interactive services, that combine communication, entertainment, information and on-line shopping. The company's market valuation -- or total market capitalization -- rose sharply yesterday to more than $7.4 billion.
But Stephen M. Case, America Online's chairman, noted yesterday that it would be years before cyberspace was considered a mass medium. In the United States, the on-line population has more than doubled in two years but still represents fewer than 20 percent of all households. "Today's deal really is a step toward the promise of a connected society," he said. "But there is still a lot of work to be done to make interactive services a mass-market media."
The deal, executives said, is expected to take three to six months to be completed. It is subject to approval by the shareholders of the respective companies and will also be subject to review by the Justice Department's antitrust division as well as the European Commission, since both America Online and Compuserve have hundreds of thousands of subscribers in Europe.
Mr. Case said he expected no challenge on antitrust grounds because the Internet business was still so young and relatively easy to enter. The list of current and prospective rivals, he said, includes Microsoft, Walt Disney, Time Warner and AT&T. "It's a pretty daunting list of potential competitors," he said.

HEADLINE: Computer on Mir Fails, Forcing Crew to Shut Down Equipment

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment.
Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The station was able to maintain its orientation toward the Sun, and its power supplies were in much better shape than during the previous breakdowns. 
 Ground controllers said they hoped to repair and restart the computer on Tuesday. In the meantime, they said, the crew was in no danger.
"Why do these malfunctions happen?" asked Vladimir Solovyov, the chief of Russia's Mission Control. "Do you know why your car breaks down? It's hard to say what the reasons might be."
Valery Lyndin, a space agency spokesman, said, "The computer has become capricious again."
Capricious is as good a word as any to describe the Mir's endless, and endlessly vexing, journey around the Earth for the last eight months or so. The space station, which has been aloft for 11 years, has spun from one mishap to the next -- from a fire to oxygen system breakdowns, from a collision with a cargo ship to the repeated computer breakdowns.
Mir's computer became unplugged on July 17 when a crew member accidentally disconnected a cable, then broke down again on Aug. 18 during docking of a cargo ship.
In the latest fumble, the computer shut itself off at about 3 A.M. today, and the crew responded by turning off most systems to economize on power, Mr. Lyndin said.
The crew said later today that they had enough power for normal operations, but had turned off all systems it did not immediately need, including the Elektron oxygen-generating system. The existing oxygen supply is good for several days, and there are also backup oxygen canisters if needed.
The space station's gyroscopes, which keep the station pointed toward the Sun, went down when the computer went off-line. However, the astronaut Pavel Vinogradov said the Mir was maintaining its proper position, the Interfax news agency reported.
In the previous breakdowns, it took hours to bring the computer system back up and several days to fully restore all functions.
There were indications that Mir might bounce back quicker this time. Rob Navias, a NASA spokesman speaking from the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said Mir's solar batteries were filled with juice Monday, in contrast to the previous two breakdowns.
He said he expected the Mir crew to re-boot the computer within a day, and replace a part. Then the crew will spin the gyroscopes back up to resume automatic steering of the station.
Mr. Solovyov, the Mission Control chief, said the computer would be brought back up on Tuesday.
"We will download the necessary information into it to restore it to working order tomorrow," he added.
It has been a trying week for the Mir's crew, which includes two newly arrived Russian astronauts and the American astronaut Michael Foale. On Saturday Mr. Foale and the Mir commander, Anatoly Solovyov, spent six hours on a space walk trying to find holes in the skin of a punctured module, but came up empty. The recent accidents have raised questions about safety aboard the Mir, which was launched in 1986 with an expected life span of five years.

HEADLINE: Chance of Tobacco Deal in '97 Gets Slimmer

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton will not offer an opinion on the proposed tobacco accord until next week at the earliest, aides said today, further diminishing chances that Congress will act on the accord this year.
Senior advisers, including Donna E. Shalala, the Health and Human Services Secretary, and Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy aide, are completing recommendations on the complex proposal. Those recommendations will be presented to the President this week, officials said. 
 The President was originally to have offered his views on the proposal, which was announced on June 20, in late July. But that timetable slipped as aides discovered that the 68-page settlement document negotiated by state attorneys general, plaintiffs' lawyers and tobacco executives raised perplexing questions of law, economics and public health.
In Texas, state officials and tobacco lawyers said today that they were prepared to try that state's suit against the industry, now set to begin on Sept. 29, unless a national accord was reached in the next few weeks.
It has been clear from the beginning that Mr. Clinton would not endorse the settlement plan without demanding significant changes. The White House has signaled that the President will insist that Federal regulatory authority over tobacco be strengthened, that penalities for failing to meet targets for reductions in tobacco use by the young be increased and that the overall cost to the tobacco industry be raised.
Under the proposed settlement, the cigarette manufacturers would pay $368.5 billion over 25 years and agree to stiff Federal tobacco regulation and broad restrictions on marketing and advertising. In return, 40 state lawsuits would be dropped and the industry would get immunity from most other tobacco-related litigation.
There appear to be two principal reasons the proposal has produced little sense of urgency at the White House.
First, critics of the proposal in Congress and among public health experts have objected to it as a bailout of an outlaw industry that does not go far enough toward reducing addiction to nicotine. These critics include many influential Democrats on Capitol Hill as well as powerful health voices, including Dr. David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, and Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General.
The President, aides said, will be loath to endorse a plan that lacks the blessing of these forces.
And second, some political advisers within the White House welcome a delay in debate on the accord. They believe that the tobacco makers' bargaining position weakens by the day and look forward to confronting the manufacturers over teen-age smoking and Government regulation of nicotine next spring as the election season begins.
In a related development, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said today that he expected Congress to repeal a $50 billion credit for the tobacco industry that was slipped into the balanced-budget deal last month. The provision was meant to offset a new 15-cents-a-pack tax on cigarettes to finance health care for children.
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said that Mr. Clinton supported the repeal of the provision.
If Congress does not act to rescind the tax break, Mr. McCurry said, Mr. Clinton will insist that the $50 billion be added to the cost of a tobacco settlement.
In Texas, Attorney General Dan Morales said today that the prospects for an out-of-court settlement of the state's $14 billion case -- which seeks to recoup the state's Medicaid costs for treating ill smokers -- were "essentially zero."
The cigarette makers' lead attorney, Dan Webb, told reporters in Texarkana, Tex., where the case is to be tried in Federal court, that the companies were prepared to try the Texas case and dozens of other state claims one by one unless a national deal was reached to settle them all at once.
"We are going to trial, no question," Mr. Webb said. "Under no circumstances will this case be settled outside of the global resolution."
Mr. Morales and Mr. Webb appeared before Judge David Folsom of Federal District Court, who wanted to assess the prospects for a pretrial settlement.
Florida and Mississippi have already reached multibillion-dollar agreements with the major tobacco companies to settle their Medicaid claims.
Another three dozen states have pending suits against the industry, but most are not likely to go to trial for several years.

HEADLINE: IN PRIMARY TODAY, DEMOCRATS SELECT GIULIANI OPPONENT

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
With a flurry of rallies, advertisements and street-and-subway stumping, three Democratic candidates for New York City mayor brought their campaigns to a close last night, encountering relatively small crowds and often uninterested voters as they struggled to draw attention to today's primary.
"I'm city Councilman Sal Albanese, Democrat candidate for mayor. Give me a chance!" said Mr. Albanese as he sought to buttonhole commuters rushing up the crowded stairway at the 72d Street subway on the Upper West Side. 
 Fifty blocks north, the Rev. Al Sharpton gazed across a rainy and poorly attended primary eve rally on 125th Street and somberly predicted victory today. "We're here on the eve of an upset," he told perhaps 100 people who came to hear him speak.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, who is widely considered the front-runner, spent the day traveling to all five boroughs, dismissing as impossible any chance that she would get less than 40 percent of the vote and be forced into a runoff. Instead, Ms. Messinger presumed victory and moved, before a vote was cast, to set the table for a contest against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"People understand that after I win the primary, I'm going to be the underdog," Ms. Messinger said as she embarked on a walking tour of Harlem. "But this is a city that has a long tradition of listening to underdogs, of paying attention to underdogs, of rallying around them."
With these appearances, a last-minute burst of television advertising by Mr. Albanese and Ms. Messinger, and radio advertising by all three candidates, the mayoral candidates wound down one of the least eventful political contests New York has seen in many years. The candidates found themselves answering questions about how low the turnout would be today, and defending the campaigns they had run.
"I think this is a campaign that people are just beginning to pay attention to," Ms. Messinger said.
Besides the mayoral primary, there is a strongly contested six-way race for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan borough president, primaries for Brooklyn and Bronx borough president and several City Council district primaries. The polls open at 6 A.M. and close at 9 P.M.
There was one last flicker of disagreement among the candidates in the final hours of the race. Mr. Albanese, who has been increasingly irritated over what he sees as the unfair presentation of Ms. Messinger as the front-runner in the primary, used a radio interview yesterday to describe her as a candidate without a philosophy, and doomed to lose to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Albanese's decision to criticize Ms. Messinger in the relatively low-profile radio interview came after he repeatedly declined to assail her while she sat next to him during a series of debates this weekend.
In a gesture with obvious symbolism, Mr. Albanese ended his campaign in the heart of Ms. Messinger's base, the Upper West Side, even paying brief calls to two well-known local food stores, Zabar's and Fairway.
Mr. Giuliani, in City Hall, said the Democrats were facing a low turnout because of what he described as "very, very excessive negative campaigning." The Mayor suggested that voters should consider staying home in protest.
"Each one of them has spent most of their time being exceedingly negative and personal in the way in which they've campaigned," Mr. Giuliani said. "And I think voters don't like that any more. And I think they will record some of that by having at least a fairly low turnout."
In truth, the Democratic candidates have largely refrained from attacks on one another, although they have attacked Mr. Giuliani's performance as Mayor. Mr. Giuliani's remarks may have partly served as a pre-emptive maneuver to head off any criticism of him once he begins what his aides say will be an intense battering of his expected rival, Ms. Messinger.
Another Republican, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, said he would begin a three-week television campaign today that would blame liberals for hurting the public school system. Mr. D'Amato's advertisements would appear to be directed at Ms. Messinger, who has made Mr. Giuliani's education record the central issue of her campaign.
Mr. D'Amato denied that yesterday, saying he was only trying to advertise his own concern with the issue in advance of his own contest next year, though he could not help offering some advice to Mr. Giuliani's expected rival. "If she had half a brain, she would be attacking me," Mr. D'Amato said. "It would rally the liberals around her."
Ms. Messinger did not need the advice. "Al D'Amato is exactly the kind of supporter that Rudy Giuliani deserves," she said when asked about the radio advertising during her stop in Harlem.
In addition to Mr. Albanese, Mr. Sharpton and Ms. Messinger, two other lesser-known candidates appear on the primary ballot today: Roland Rogers, a businessman, and Eric Ruano-Melendez, a civil engineer who works for the city.
Ms. Messinger spent most of her day talking about the Mayor, but Mr. Albanese focused on Ms. Messinger, describing her as "the weakest candidate" the Democrats could put up.
'She is running a campaign without core values," he said. "One week she attacks the rich; the next week she attacks workers. She polls, and basically accommodates positions based on polling. That's why her campaign hasn't taken off. That's why she's going to lose tomorrow."
Mr. Sharpton, at his rally last night, predicted he would win and asserted that he had forced his rivals to work harder and talk about the issues he has stressed this year, police behavior and the economy.
"They thought when we announced this campaign that it was a joke," he said. "But the last two or three days, we've wiped the smile off their faces. Nobody's laughing now. They're all out hustling or working."
Of the three main candidates, Ms. Messinger appeared the least concerned about today's vote, dismissing any hint that she might fall below 40 percent and be forced into a runoff. "I'm going to win tomorrow night, without a runoff," she said.
She described Mr. Giuliani as "a bully" and said: "I'm ready for whatever he's planning to shell out. I'm going to be talking to people in this city about we can make this a better city. I will give as good as I get."
But Ms. Messinger received a hint of her difficulties as she stopped off at the Country Club diner on Staten Island. Two women eating dinner looked up as Ms. Messinger entered with her small entourage.
"Is that Liz Holtzman?" one asked.
