HEADLINE: Hong Kong's Leader Heads for U.S. to Correct 'Misconceptions'

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Tung Chee-hwa, the man chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong, left today for his first visit to the United States since Britain returned this territory to Chinese control on July 1. He said the visit was intended to correct American "misconceptions" about Hong Kong.
The Hong Kong that Mr. Tung will discuss with President Clinton, members of Congress and interested Americans is flourishing economically. But it has no democratic institutions, has undergone a sharp contraction of civil liberties and apparently has three times the number of people it did 25 years ago who are living in poverty, in part because of an aging population and the large number of immigrants from China who do not have the skills that enable them to work in an increasingly non-manufacturing ecnonomy. 
 "I'm looking forward to going to the U.S.," said Mr. Tung, a shipping tycoon. "Really to tell my friends in America what is happening in Hong Kong, not only about the transition, but what is going on."
Mr. Tung was dissuaded from visiting the United States in the months leading up to Chinese rule, in part because of criticism over his decision to roll back certain rights.
Now, however, with two months of calm behind him, Mr. Tung said he is ready to spread news of Hong Kong's success under Chinese rule to skeptics in the United States, particularly to members of Congress who have been critical of Beijing.
Mr. Tung said he expected to meet with President Clinton, who met last spring with Martin Lee of Hong Kong's Democratic Party, which opposed Beijing's move to disband the elected legislature. He also hopes to meet with other Administration officials and key members of Congress.
"The Government is functioning as normal," said Mr. Tung. "The financial market is moving. Demonstrations are continuing, arguments everywhere. The legislative body is just as assertive as before, challenging everything we want to do."
Still, many people here, including Mr. Tung himself, believe he will face a hostile audience in explaining why Hong Kong is considered not ready for democracy.
Mr. Tung has proposed an electoral system that would give Hong Kong's leading companies and banks a major say in the legislature's composition.
Under his proposal, seats would be distributed to parties according to their proportion of total votes. A third of the seats would be chosen by companies, banks and professional associations. This arrangement is likely to prevent the Democratic Party, which won the largest share of seats in the fully elected legislature of 1995, from winning a large number of seats in elections next May. Because even losers in the elections will gain legislative seats, as permitted under a proportional voting system, and because companies are dominated by conservative business people, the Democratic Party's share of seats is almost certain to fall sharply.
Mr. Tung's view of how things are going is not shared by legislators who were removed from office by China on July 1 and replaced with a body of lawmakers of its choosing.
"It is a step backward -- it's highly undemocratic," said Mr. Lee, describing Mr. Tung's proposal.
The rosy picture painted by Mr. Tung was clouded somewhat today by a report by a group of university academics, the Hong Kong Social Security Society, which found that 856,000 people, 14 percent of the territory's population, are living beneath the poverty line of $358 a month.

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Latest Cyberdeal Seems to Have Room for Two Winners

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Follow the money in yesterday's big Internet deal -- an intricate transaction involving Worldcom, Compuserve and America Online -- and it seems that the real value lies in the dull plumbing of cyberspace, not the glamour of new media.
Worldcom Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long-distance phone company, agreed to pay about $1.2 billion in stock for the Compuserve Corporation. It will keep the under-the-hood side of Compuserve's business, managing data networks and providing data services for big corporate clients. 
 In the next step of the deal, Worldcom will sell Compuserve's well-known but struggling on-line service to America Online for the equivalent of $250 million. In short, the plumbing of Compuserve, which is controlled by H & R Block, is worth nearly $1 billion, while its on-line service amounts to pocket change by comparison.
Shares of Worldcom rose sharply yesterday, up $2.25, to $33.75, and were the most actively traded, with nearly 14.6 million changing hands. But if Worldcom jumped, then America Online shares soared, closing up $6.125, to $76.0625.
The enthusiasm was not only because America Online had cut a good deal, but also because the acquisition should help it further a strategy of becoming a genuine media company -- and one able to draw more revenue from advertising and electronic commerce like on-line shopping.
Advertising and commerce now account for about 15 percent of America Online's revenues -- up from next to nothing a couple of years ago -- with the rest coming from monthly subscription fees. The company wants to see the advertising and marketing revenues rise sharply in the coming years, toward the level of 50 percent.
The key to attracting advertising dollars is building an audience on the scale provided by mainstream media. And America Online certainly appears well on its way. Today, it is by far the largest on-line service, with 9 million subscribers. By purchasing Compuserve, the second-largest on-line service, America Online, which is based in Dulles, Va., would add 2.6 million more subscribers worldwide. That would lengthen America Online's already yawning lead over its nearest remaining rival, the Microsoft Network, which has 2.3 million subscribers.
"The next stage of the Internet economy is that the media companies will start to make money, not just the infrastructure suppliers as has been the case until now," said Kate Delhagen, an analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass.
"America Online is taking a leading role in that development, and acquiring Compuserve is a big step ahead," Ms. Delhagen said. "You assemble an audience of more than 10 million subscribers, and Madison Avenue has to pay attention."
In the deal, America Online is increasing its focus as a media company not only by adding subscribers, but also by selling its ANS Communications unit to Worldcom.
Less than three years ago, America Online bought ANS, once the Internet's network backbone and run by the National Science Foundation. America Online paid $35 million for ANS, seeking greater vertical integration and less dependence on major telecommunications companies.
Today, the ANS investment seems to have been a particularly shrewd one for America Online, and one that points to the rising value of high-speed digital communications gear that keeps the Internet running. For ANS, Worldcom will give America Online Compuserve's on-line service and a cash payment of $175 million, putting a value on ANS of about $425 million.
To be sure, America Online invested in ANS and Worldcom will assume $150 million in ANS lease obligations, which are the equivalent of debt. Still, the ANS investment has been a big winner for America Online, perhaps providing more profit in the last few years than the company's basic business.
Yet Wall Street is evaluating America Online far less by its near-term profits than by its progress in assembling a working business model for the hybrid media, called interactive services, that combine communication, entertainment, information and on-line shopping. The company's market valuation -- or total market capitalization -- rose sharply yesterday to more than $7.4 billion.
But Stephen M. Case, America Online's chairman, noted yesterday that it would be years before cyberspace was considered a mass medium. In the United States, the on-line population has more than doubled in two years but still represents fewer than 20 percent of all households. "Today's deal really is a step toward the promise of a connected society," he said. "But there is still a lot of work to be done to make interactive services a mass-market media."
The deal, executives said, is expected to take three to six months to be completed. It is subject to approval by the shareholders of the respective companies and will also be subject to review by the Justice Department's antitrust division as well as the European Commission, since both America Online and Compuserve have hundreds of thousands of subscribers in Europe.
Mr. Case said he expected no challenge on antitrust grounds because the Internet business was still so young and relatively easy to enter. The list of current and prospective rivals, he said, includes Microsoft, Walt Disney, Time Warner and AT&T. "It's a pretty daunting list of potential competitors," he said.

HEADLINE: Computer on Mir Fails, Forcing Crew to Shut Down Equipment

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Sept. 8

 BODY:
The Mir's computer broke down again today and forced the crew to shut down most of the space station's equipment.
Russian and American space officials played down the seriousness of the computer crash, the third aboard Mir since mid-July. The station was able to maintain its orientation toward the Sun, and its power supplies were in much better shape than during the previous breakdowns. 
 Ground controllers said they hoped to repair and restart the computer on Tuesday. In the meantime, they said, the crew was in no danger.
"Why do these malfunctions happen?" asked Vladimir Solovyov, the chief of Russia's Mission Control. "Do you know why your car breaks down? It's hard to say what the reasons might be."
Valery Lyndin, a space agency spokesman, said, "The computer has become capricious again."
Capricious is as good a word as any to describe the Mir's endless, and endlessly vexing, journey around the Earth for the last eight months or so. The space station, which has been aloft for 11 years, has spun from one mishap to the next -- from a fire to oxygen system breakdowns, from a collision with a cargo ship to the repeated computer breakdowns.
Mir's computer became unplugged on July 17 when a crew member accidentally disconnected a cable, then broke down again on Aug. 18 during docking of a cargo ship.
In the latest fumble, the computer shut itself off at about 3 A.M. today, and the crew responded by turning off most systems to economize on power, Mr. Lyndin said.
The crew said later today that they had enough power for normal operations, but had turned off all systems it did not immediately need, including the Elektron oxygen-generating system. The existing oxygen supply is good for several days, and there are also backup oxygen canisters if needed.
The space station's gyroscopes, which keep the station pointed toward the Sun, went down when the computer went off-line. However, the astronaut Pavel Vinogradov said the Mir was maintaining its proper position, the Interfax news agency reported.
In the previous breakdowns, it took hours to bring the computer system back up and several days to fully restore all functions.
There were indications that Mir might bounce back quicker this time. Rob Navias, a NASA spokesman speaking from the Johnson Space Center in Houston, said Mir's solar batteries were filled with juice Monday, in contrast to the previous two breakdowns.
He said he expected the Mir crew to re-boot the computer within a day, and replace a part. Then the crew will spin the gyroscopes back up to resume automatic steering of the station.
Mr. Solovyov, the Mission Control chief, said the computer would be brought back up on Tuesday.
"We will download the necessary information into it to restore it to working order tomorrow," he added.
It has been a trying week for the Mir's crew, which includes two newly arrived Russian astronauts and the American astronaut Michael Foale. On Saturday Mr. Foale and the Mir commander, Anatoly Solovyov, spent six hours on a space walk trying to find holes in the skin of a punctured module, but came up empty. The recent accidents have raised questions about safety aboard the Mir, which was launched in 1986 with an expected life span of five years.

HEADLINE: Chance of Tobacco Deal in '97 Gets Slimmer

BYLINE: By JOHN M. BRODER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton will not offer an opinion on the proposed tobacco accord until next week at the earliest, aides said today, further diminishing chances that Congress will act on the accord this year.
Senior advisers, including Donna E. Shalala, the Health and Human Services Secretary, and Bruce Reed, the President's chief domestic policy aide, are completing recommendations on the complex proposal. Those recommendations will be presented to the President this week, officials said. 
 The President was originally to have offered his views on the proposal, which was announced on June 20, in late July. But that timetable slipped as aides discovered that the 68-page settlement document negotiated by state attorneys general, plaintiffs' lawyers and tobacco executives raised perplexing questions of law, economics and public health.
In Texas, state officials and tobacco lawyers said today that they were prepared to try that state's suit against the industry, now set to begin on Sept. 29, unless a national accord was reached in the next few weeks.
It has been clear from the beginning that Mr. Clinton would not endorse the settlement plan without demanding significant changes. The White House has signaled that the President will insist that Federal regulatory authority over tobacco be strengthened, that penalities for failing to meet targets for reductions in tobacco use by the young be increased and that the overall cost to the tobacco industry be raised.
Under the proposed settlement, the cigarette manufacturers would pay $368.5 billion over 25 years and agree to stiff Federal tobacco regulation and broad restrictions on marketing and advertising. In return, 40 state lawsuits would be dropped and the industry would get immunity from most other tobacco-related litigation.
There appear to be two principal reasons the proposal has produced little sense of urgency at the White House.
First, critics of the proposal in Congress and among public health experts have objected to it as a bailout of an outlaw industry that does not go far enough toward reducing addiction to nicotine. These critics include many influential Democrats on Capitol Hill as well as powerful health voices, including Dr. David A. Kessler, the former Commissioner of Food and Drugs, and Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General.
The President, aides said, will be loath to endorse a plan that lacks the blessing of these forces.
And second, some political advisers within the White House welcome a delay in debate on the accord. They believe that the tobacco makers' bargaining position weakens by the day and look forward to confronting the manufacturers over teen-age smoking and Government regulation of nicotine next spring as the election season begins.
In a related development, Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the minority leader, said today that he expected Congress to repeal a $50 billion credit for the tobacco industry that was slipped into the balanced-budget deal last month. The provision was meant to offset a new 15-cents-a-pack tax on cigarettes to finance health care for children.
The White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said that Mr. Clinton supported the repeal of the provision.
If Congress does not act to rescind the tax break, Mr. McCurry said, Mr. Clinton will insist that the $50 billion be added to the cost of a tobacco settlement.
In Texas, Attorney General Dan Morales said today that the prospects for an out-of-court settlement of the state's $14 billion case -- which seeks to recoup the state's Medicaid costs for treating ill smokers -- were "essentially zero."
The cigarette makers' lead attorney, Dan Webb, told reporters in Texarkana, Tex., where the case is to be tried in Federal court, that the companies were prepared to try the Texas case and dozens of other state claims one by one unless a national deal was reached to settle them all at once.
"We are going to trial, no question," Mr. Webb said. "Under no circumstances will this case be settled outside of the global resolution."
Mr. Morales and Mr. Webb appeared before Judge David Folsom of Federal District Court, who wanted to assess the prospects for a pretrial settlement.
Florida and Mississippi have already reached multibillion-dollar agreements with the major tobacco companies to settle their Medicaid claims.
Another three dozen states have pending suits against the industry, but most are not likely to go to trial for several years.

HEADLINE: IN PRIMARY TODAY, DEMOCRATS SELECT GIULIANI OPPONENT

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY

 BODY:
With a flurry of rallies, advertisements and street-and-subway stumping, three Democratic candidates for New York City mayor brought their campaigns to a close last night, encountering relatively small crowds and often uninterested voters as they struggled to draw attention to today's primary.
"I'm city Councilman Sal Albanese, Democrat candidate for mayor. Give me a chance!" said Mr. Albanese as he sought to buttonhole commuters rushing up the crowded stairway at the 72d Street subway on the Upper West Side. 
 Fifty blocks north, the Rev. Al Sharpton gazed across a rainy and poorly attended primary eve rally on 125th Street and somberly predicted victory today. "We're here on the eve of an upset," he told perhaps 100 people who came to hear him speak.
Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President, who is widely considered the front-runner, spent the day traveling to all five boroughs, dismissing as impossible any chance that she would get less than 40 percent of the vote and be forced into a runoff. Instead, Ms. Messinger presumed victory and moved, before a vote was cast, to set the table for a contest against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
"People understand that after I win the primary, I'm going to be the underdog," Ms. Messinger said as she embarked on a walking tour of Harlem. "But this is a city that has a long tradition of listening to underdogs, of paying attention to underdogs, of rallying around them."
With these appearances, a last-minute burst of television advertising by Mr. Albanese and Ms. Messinger, and radio advertising by all three candidates, the mayoral candidates wound down one of the least eventful political contests New York has seen in many years. The candidates found themselves answering questions about how low the turnout would be today, and defending the campaigns they had run.
"I think this is a campaign that people are just beginning to pay attention to," Ms. Messinger said.
Besides the mayoral primary, there is a strongly contested six-way race for the Democratic nomination for Manhattan borough president, primaries for Brooklyn and Bronx borough president and several City Council district primaries. The polls open at 6 A.M. and close at 9 P.M.
There was one last flicker of disagreement among the candidates in the final hours of the race. Mr. Albanese, who has been increasingly irritated over what he sees as the unfair presentation of Ms. Messinger as the front-runner in the primary, used a radio interview yesterday to describe her as a candidate without a philosophy, and doomed to lose to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Albanese's decision to criticize Ms. Messinger in the relatively low-profile radio interview came after he repeatedly declined to assail her while she sat next to him during a series of debates this weekend.
In a gesture with obvious symbolism, Mr. Albanese ended his campaign in the heart of Ms. Messinger's base, the Upper West Side, even paying brief calls to two well-known local food stores, Zabar's and Fairway.
Mr. Giuliani, in City Hall, said the Democrats were facing a low turnout because of what he described as "very, very excessive negative campaigning." The Mayor suggested that voters should consider staying home in protest.
"Each one of them has spent most of their time being exceedingly negative and personal in the way in which they've campaigned," Mr. Giuliani said. "And I think voters don't like that any more. And I think they will record some of that by having at least a fairly low turnout."
In truth, the Democratic candidates have largely refrained from attacks on one another, although they have attacked Mr. Giuliani's performance as Mayor. Mr. Giuliani's remarks may have partly served as a pre-emptive maneuver to head off any criticism of him once he begins what his aides say will be an intense battering of his expected rival, Ms. Messinger.
Another Republican, Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, said he would begin a three-week television campaign today that would blame liberals for hurting the public school system. Mr. D'Amato's advertisements would appear to be directed at Ms. Messinger, who has made Mr. Giuliani's education record the central issue of her campaign.
Mr. D'Amato denied that yesterday, saying he was only trying to advertise his own concern with the issue in advance of his own contest next year, though he could not help offering some advice to Mr. Giuliani's expected rival. "If she had half a brain, she would be attacking me," Mr. D'Amato said. "It would rally the liberals around her."
Ms. Messinger did not need the advice. "Al D'Amato is exactly the kind of supporter that Rudy Giuliani deserves," she said when asked about the radio advertising during her stop in Harlem.
In addition to Mr. Albanese, Mr. Sharpton and Ms. Messinger, two other lesser-known candidates appear on the primary ballot today: Roland Rogers, a businessman, and Eric Ruano-Melendez, a civil engineer who works for the city.
Ms. Messinger spent most of her day talking about the Mayor, but Mr. Albanese focused on Ms. Messinger, describing her as "the weakest candidate" the Democrats could put up.
'She is running a campaign without core values," he said. "One week she attacks the rich; the next week she attacks workers. She polls, and basically accommodates positions based on polling. That's why her campaign hasn't taken off. That's why she's going to lose tomorrow."
Mr. Sharpton, at his rally last night, predicted he would win and asserted that he had forced his rivals to work harder and talk about the issues he has stressed this year, police behavior and the economy.
"They thought when we announced this campaign that it was a joke," he said. "But the last two or three days, we've wiped the smile off their faces. Nobody's laughing now. They're all out hustling or working."
Of the three main candidates, Ms. Messinger appeared the least concerned about today's vote, dismissing any hint that she might fall below 40 percent and be forced into a runoff. "I'm going to win tomorrow night, without a runoff," she said.
She described Mr. Giuliani as "a bully" and said: "I'm ready for whatever he's planning to shell out. I'm going to be talking to people in this city about we can make this a better city. I will give as good as I get."
But Ms. Messinger received a hint of her difficulties as she stopped off at the Country Club diner on Staten Island. Two women eating dinner looked up as Ms. Messinger entered with her small entourage.
"Is that Liz Holtzman?" one asked.

HEADLINE: Tribes' New Power Over Welfare May Come at Too High a Price

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: ROSEBUD SIOUX RESERVATION, S.D.

 BODY:
On the wind-scarred grassland stretching past Ghost Hawk Lake, Monica Burning Breast, 25, single and pregnant with her third child, has spent her life in a world on welfare.
Government checks have let her bring up her 3- and 5-year-old sons in a beaten-down brown bungalow on this stark, sprawling reservation east of the Badlands. Shoehorned into the same house, her mother, Lorraine Two Elk, is rearing three other children on welfare. 
 Some reservation families are so poor, living in isolated enclaves like Upper Cut Meat and He Dog, that on food-stamp day, they can obtain transportation to the nearest supermarket only by paying for it with some of the milk and bread that they intended to feed to their children.
Though tribal leaders around the country fear that life for Indians like Ms. Burning Breast and thousands of others may become even tougher under the new Federal welfare law's work rules -- daunting requirements in rural, often remote areas with few jobs -- the law may also give those leaders a small chance to soften the blow. In a little-noticed provision in the year-old welfare law, Indian reservations are, for the first time, given the right to run their own programs. The states are the only other entities allowed to set rules on who can receive welfare and for how long.
The same law that gave tribes this new opportunity, which Indian organizations say may be the United States Government's strongest recognition yet of Indian sovereignty, failed to provide enough money for many tribes to take advantage of it.
So tribes like the Rosebud Sioux are caught in a wrenching dilemma. If they choose to run their own programs, they may be able to tailor them to be more sensitive to the people on the reservations, or even more demanding, if necessary. But without sufficient money, the tribes may end up hurting the people they are trying to help, or further squeezing the tribe's resources.
Congress requires states to pay for part of their own welfare-to-work programs, usually at least a third of the cost, and the Federal Government pays the rest. But Congress did not require a state to contribute money for welfare programs run by Indian tribes living within that state, because lawmakers were reluctant to anger state governors. Under the law, the tribes are entitled only to the Federal share. The law also did not provide start-up money for tribes to set up welfare offices by buying computers and hiring caseworkers.
Although states are generally eager to shift the responsibility for reservation welfare to the tribes, most are not eager to shift the resources. Some states say they need the money to shoulder the additional cost of workfare programs; others say that a program not under state control should not be financed by the state.
Many tribes say that without that money, running their programs would be impossible.
"This was something that was anticipated with a great amount of enthusiasm out in Indian country," JoAnn K. Chase, executive director of the National Congress of American Indians, said of the opportunity to design their own welfare rules.
Some tribes had reported that state-run welfare programs were causing some people to leave reservations, Ms. Chase said, because they could not find jobs.
"We looked at this as a true opportunity to make a significant advancement in tribal sovereignty," she said. "But in order for the tribes to do this, they'll just need flat out the money to make it work."
 
Without State Money, A Deal Out of Reach
Of the 557 federally recognized Indian tribes, 11 have applied for approval to run welfare programs. Two have received permission, and the other applications are in the pipeline. Those 11 tribes -- 4 in Wisconsin, 2 each in Oklahoma, Arizona and Oregon and 1 in South Dakota -- are generally smaller and have less poverty than other tribes.
Oregon and Arizona have agreed to give the tribes the money that would have been spent if the tribal members had stayed on state welfare rolls, said Michael Kharfen, a spokesman for the Federal Department of Health and Human Services.
In South Dakota, Indians make up 7.4 percent of the population but account for 53 percent of the welfare recipients. State officials say they can afford to give tribes only a one-time infusion of start-up money. Eight of the nine tribes in South Dakota say that would make tribal-run programs untenable.
"We'd like to run everything on our own," said Jesse Taken Alive, chairman of the Standing Rock Sioux Tribe, which straddles South Dakota and North Dakota. "For us, it is part of what we call a decolonization process. We know that they want to give this responsibility back to the tribes. But they want to do it with no money."
The one South Dakota tribe able to afford its own program has the fewest welfare recipients. That tribe, the Sisseton-Wahpeton Sioux, expects to start its welfare program on Oct. 1, but it has only 80 welfare families out of 5,500 people on its reservation.
The Sisseton-Wahpeton reservation has seen its welfare population shrink in the last few years. A factory that makes plastic garbage bags and three tribal casinos that draw gamblers from North Dakota and Canada have given jobs to dozens of former welfare recipients. Now, tribal leaders say, only a third of the adults who can work are unemployed.
But on the Rosebud reservation, with 20,000 people, a Bureau of Indian Affairs report in 1993 said that only 11 percent of the adults who could work were actually employed.
Sisseton-Wahpeton is prepared to spend up to $200,000 a year to supplement the Federal money it will receive to pay welfare benefits.
"We just felt it was morally right to have our people under our system rather than leave them under the state system," said Gary Johnson, who is not an ethnic Indian but was adopted into the tribe. Kay Bursheim, a member of the tribe who helped draw up its welfare plan, cited another benefit.
"We can be more assertive," Ms. Bursheim said, "and nobody can come back and say we're being biased or racist. Some people are going to need a tough-love approach."
 
Tribe Puts Its Hopes On Flexible Rules
Sisseton-Wahpeton plans to stretch state and Federal rules in its program, which, to pass Federal muster, had to show that it was "really about helping to reduce welfare dependency among tribal members," Mr. Kharfen said.
Under the South Dakota system that began on July 1, the state pays benefits to welfare recipients only if they work or participate in an approved "work activity" like job training or community service. If a recipient goes a month without complying, the family's benefits are cut in half. After two months without working, the family loses all benefits.
The Federal law's intent is to move people to work from welfare, and so it discourages states from reducing their welfare rolls simply by dropping recipients. The law stipulates that after having received welfare for five years over a lifetime -- or, in most cases, for two consecutive years -- a recipient should be dropped and expected to find a job.
The Sisseton-Wahpeton program differs in several ways from the Federal and state requirements. It will allow people to receive welfare for six years over a lifetime, not five. Ten percent of recipients have to be working in the first year of the program, not 25 percent, as Federal law specifies. If people do not fulfill the work requirements, their benefits will be stopped in three months, not two. And the definition of acceptable "work activities" expands.
Lanise Montreal, 22, a welfare mother with a 4-year-old son, Alex, plans to attend a tribal community college to learn to work with computers. Under the state plan, Ms. Montreal would be able to collect welfare for only the first year of college. Then she would have to work. The tribe will allow benefits for at least two years, the time it should take her to receive a degree.
"Now I won't have to worry," Ms. Montreal said in her simple house in Peever Flats, a cluster of houses on the Sisseton-Wahpeton reservation.
Other South Dakota tribes have said that if they could afford it, they would be even more flexible. People would have to work only 16 hours a week, to increase flexibility for needs like child care, not the state and Federal minimum of 20 hours.
Some officials on the Rosebud reservation said they would like to see the definition of work activities include hunting and fishing. Many tribe members stock up on deer and walleye before the bitter winter wind zips people tight inside their homes.
 
In the Meantime, Indians Make Do
The states have incentives to see tribes run their own programs, especially if they do not have to give the tribes money. States would be relieved of responsibility for welfare recipients on reservations, greatly reducing some states' welfare rolls. State caseworkers would no longer have to deal with the cultural and social differences on reservations. And state governments, frequently feuding with tribes over land use or legal authority, would have a chance to offer symbolic support for tribal sovereignty.
But the states have also been given an added burden: making sure that related state-run programs like Medicaid and food stamps are coordinated with the tribal welfare programs.
Deb Bowman, a special assistant to Gov. William J. Janklow of South Dakota, said state officials understood the dire circumstances on many reservations and would help tribes if they did not end up running their own programs. Ms. Bowman said the state was working on ways to offer child care on reservations and to provide transportation from reservations to jobs.
But Ms. Bowman said the state could not afford to give tribes the roughly $5.5 million that the state would spend on welfare if Indians on reservations stayed on state rolls.
"We still have to have our offices on the reservations in order to administer Medicaid and food stamps," she said.
The tribes and Governor Janklow have persuaded Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Senate Democratic leader, to ask Congress for $5 million a year for three years so the South Dakota tribes could run their own programs. The request will be considered in a few weeks.
The program would be a pilot project in South Dakota and would not help tribes in other states.
In the meantime, the Rosebud reservation is trying to comply with the state's new welfare-to-work program.
The reservation's only significant private employer is a casino, which spends much of its profits on water and electricity for destitute families and on $75 clothing vouchers for the tribe's schoolchildren.
Government programs are among the few places providing work for unskilled people. But those are public service jobs, and the programs will be hard-pressed to pay people salaries after welfare benefits expire. So welfare recipients will be back in the position of trying to find a paying job in an area where few exist.
That, of course, would be a problem, even if Rosebud could run the program. But the Rosebud director of child and family services, Rose Chasing Hawk, said a tribal system would give the tribe more time to develop jobs and job-training programs by keeping people on welfare longer and would help more people go to tribal college.
"What jobs there are on the reservation are jobs that require a degree," Ms. Chasing Hawk said. "Even to be a secretary, you have to have some type of training."
Recently, Bevelyn Brave Hawk, 40, a welfare mother who is bringing up 12 of her 13 children in a house with holes pocking the bedroom walls, landed a tribal government job, cleaning a community center.
"First time I had a job," said Ms. Brave Hawk, who left work a bit early one day to join hundreds of people waiting for clothing vouchers.
Ms. Burning Breast and Ms. Two Elk both had their welfare checks reduced last year because they did not meet the state's previous work requirements. Ms. Burning Breast had trouble with child care, she said, and her mother had wanted to spend time making quilts, something that might qualify as a work activity under a tribal program. They will now work in a Head Start program.
"I've been trying to do my best," said Ms. Burning Breast, who needs four months of study to receive a high school diploma. "I'll just try to qualify for benefits for my babies."

$12.5 Billion Offering Set For France Telecom
The French Government said that it would sell up to 38 percent of France Telecom for some $12.5 billion. The Government said it was retaining a majority stake and therefore the sale would not amount to a privatization. The new Socialist Prime Minister, Lionel Jospin, has resolutely opposed privatizing France Telecom and Air France.
One-fifth of France Telecom will be sold on the stock market in one of the world's largest initial public offerings, and up to 13 percent will be swapped with other companies, including a 7.5 percent stake with Deutsche Telekom, its main global partner. Employees can also buy shares. [Page D3.] 

Sunbeam Chief Sues A.M.A.
Sunbeam's chairman, Albert J. Dunlap, sued the American Medical Association on behalf of his company, seeking to force the medical group to honor its agreement to endorse certain Sunbeam products or pay damages "that could exceed $20 million." The A.M.A., under criticism, said last month it was abandoning its alliance with Sunbeam. [D2.]
 
Coca-Cola Chairman Is Hospitalized
Roberto Goizueta, 65, chairman of Coca-Cola, was hospitalized in Atlanta for treatment of a localized malignant lung tumor, the company said. [D2.]
 
I.B.M. Drops Plans for NetPC
I.B.M. has decided not to make a simplified personal computer called a NetPC, although it will offer the enhanced flexibility of the machines across its entire personal computer line by October. [D2.]
 
Motorola and I.B.M. are refocusing the Power PC microprocessor family, which drives Apple Macintosh personal computers, into industrial and consumer electronics markets. [D26.]
 
Small Stocks Pace Market Rise
The Dow Jones industrial average gained 12.77 points to close at 7,835.18. Most of the stock market action came in smaller issues. Both the Russell 2000 index and the Nasdaq composite reached new highs. [D14.]
 
Treasury securities moved higher, with the 30-year bond rising 11/32, to a price of 97, pushing its yield down to 6.61 percent. [D10.]
 
Consumer Credit Rises $6.5 Billion
Consumer installment credit climbed in July by $6.5 billion, or at a 6.4 percent annual rate, well above the forecasts of Wall Street economists for a $4.3 billion rise, as consumers increased borrowing to buy new cars. [D6.]
 
Asian Focus Is Likely to Be Exports
With nearly all of Southeast Asia reeling under a wave of currency losses, the area's hope would appear to be the same road Mexico took after it was hit by a devastating currency collapse: exports. News Analysis. [D3.]
 
New Team in Place At Reader's Digest
George V. Grune, the interim chairman of Reader's Digest Association who was brought back from retirement to revive the ailing company, has rehired some colleagues and promoted others in hopes of bolstering earnings and increasing its stock price. Also, three high-ranking executives are leaving the magazine publisher. [D11.]
 
U.S. Approves Utah Oil Drilling
The Administration approved exploratory oil drilling on Federal land in the red rock country of Utah, despite objections from environmental agencies. President Clinton established a vast national monument there last year to protect the rich wilderness. [A1.]
 
Savannah Picks 2d Suitor
Savannah Foods and Industries, the sugar giant, abandoned plans to merge with Flo-Sun, choosing instead to be taken over by Imperial Holly for nearly $500 million. [D21.]
 
Talk of a Campbell Soup Spinoff
Campbell Soup scheduled a meeting today at which analysts speculated it could announce the spinoff of its $550 million Swanson frozen-food business or its $300 million Vlasic pickle business. It also reported higher-than-expected fourth-quarter earnings. [D10.]

HEADLINE: Clinton Embarking on a New Nafta Quest

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton is about to leap into what promises to be a bruising battle over the expansion of Nafta within Latin America and his powers to negotiate other international trade accords.
Even the hint of a plan to eventually expand America's most famous trade accord is bitterly dividing Democrats and infuriating labor unions. It is also prompting arguments over whether the United States can force other nations into pacts requiring them to raise wages and protect the environment. 
 On Wednesday Mr. Clinton will open a campaign to convince Congress that he desperately needs the authority to negotiate new trade accords if America is to keep up with its economic competitors in Latin America and Asia. His authority to do so expired three years ago.
Mr. Clinton and his aides are marshaling an array of economic and political arguments to make the case that they can wait no longer for that negotiating authority, although Congress is not being asked to vote on any new trade accord and probably will not do so for years.
The Clinton Administration is arguing that the United States has fewer trade barriers than most nations, so negotiations to sweep them away are far more likely to benefit the United States than its competitors. With the economy roaring, the United States is now in a better negotiating position with its trading partners than it has been in decades.
And already, Administration officials warn, Canada and Mexico are striking trade deals with Latin American countries that exclude Washington, a trend that they contend will spill around the globe if Congress does not act fast.
But the reality remains that poll after poll shows Nafta, the North American Free Trade Agreement, as less popular today than the day it passed it 1993. It remains a symbol of the kinds of global accords that, in the minds of millions, make it easier for a good factory job to disappear even in prosperous times.
So even vague talk about its extension has touched off a battle over whether trade pacts simply steal away American jobs, a battle already tinged with the politics of the next Presidential election.
"This has become a matter of America's global leadership, and the trick is for the President to explain it that way," said Commerce Secretary William Daley, who in the first term, as a special liaison with Congress, was put in charge of pushing Nafta through. "But let's face it: the vast majority of Democrats are not comfortable with it."
Technically the debate hinges on a piece of legislation so arcane that when it was first passed by Congress, in the last days of the Nixon Administration, hardly anyone noticed.
It carries a name that sounds more like the lingo of bookmakers than legislators: "fast track." What it means is that the Administration has the power to negotiate trade accords and submit them to Congress for a quick vote, with no amendments. Without that assurance, other nations around the world say, they will not talk trade with Washington. Every agreement would come unglued, they contend, as soon as it hit the floor of Congress and special interest groups began tinkering with the wording.
"This is a mechanism that has been enormously successful for many years," said I. M. Destler, a professor at the University of Maryland and one of the nation's leading historians on trade talks. "It has enabled the United States to shape the terms of globalization to the advantage of American workers." But after years as a noncontroversial mechanism for facilitating negotiations, Mr. Destler said, "fast track has gradually become a stalking horse for all sorts of other issues."
The three-year lapse in authority is the longest that a President has gone since 1974 without the power to negotiate broad trade agreements. An attempted renewal failed in 1995, and in 1996 the Administration determined that the issue was too volatile and divisive before an election.
In the broadest sense, it has become an argument over the wisdom of free trade accords. But most trade agreements are bilateral deals governing trade in specific products or services, from pharmaceuticals to telecommunications. So the debate in Congress is quickly turning into a re-examination of Nafta, which the Administration insisted in 1993 would become a boon for the American economy, and which opponents argued would be a disaster for American workers.
Not surprisingly, voluminous studies conducted since its passage have reached dramatically different conclusions, depending on who paid for the research. The view of many economists who did not have a stake in the original debate is that Nafta has been far less important to American workers than either its advocates or its opponents predicted.
A widely respected study by researchers at the University of California at Los Angeles concluded that the United States had gained just 2,990 jobs since the agreement took effect, though that figure masked considerable job destruction and job creation in some specific industries. It also concluded that in the long term, the United States would gain more jobs than it lost.
But even the Administration now concedes that it wildly oversold the benefits of Nafta in 1993. A study the White House sent to Congress in July suggested that at most, 90,000 to 160,000 American jobs rely on increased exports to Mexico as a result of the pact. In an economy that has created roughly 11 million jobs over the past four years, that is a statistical blip.
But as the Congressional debate begins, there is reason to wonder whether Nafta is the right example to look at. The trade agreements that Mr. Clinton is considering begin with Chile, a nation far from the American border that seems unlikely to suck away many American jobs or to raise many concerns about illegal immigration and drugs.
Beyond Chile's integration into Nafta, there is talk of a "Free Trade Area of the Americas." But at the Latin American summit meeting Mr. Clinton held in Miami in 1994, the date for that hemispheric accord was set at 2005. A similar free trade area among the nations that make up the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation group would only begin in 2010.
"Our biggest problem now is explaining why all this is so urgent," one of Mr. Clinton's economic advisers acknowledged recently.

HEADLINE: Rail Strike Has San Francisco Commuters Creeping Along Alternative Routes

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 8

 BODY:
Traffic around the San Francisco Bay Area crept along for hours at times today as a two-day railway strike left thousands of commuters struggling to get to work and back.
"This was the heaviest traffic I've ever seen," said Scott Johnston, a software company manager who commuted today by car pool to San Francisco from his home in the East Bay town of Lafayette. "It was so bad that I'm thinking of staying home tomorrow." 
 On Sunday morning, workers for Bay Area Rapid Transit, or BART, went on strike, shutting down the commuter rail system here that carries 270,000 riders each weekday.
Mayor Willie L. Brown Jr. of San Francisco warned at a news conference today that the strike could "cripple the city's economy" and offered his services as an unofficial mediator.
"I seriously doubt we'll reach an agreement today," said a BART spokesman, Michael C. Healy. "But we think if anyone can get the unions to look realistically at the issues, the Mayor can, so we welcome his help."
Several union leaders and top BART officials met this afternoon in Mayor Brown's office. The main issues in the dispute are wages and the railroad's two-tier system of employment. New employees work six years to reach journeyman status, and even then, their earnings are limited to 90 percent of the salaries of colleagues who have more seniority.
Without BART, morning commuters turned to buses, ferries and cars in their effort to get to work on time.
"It was an hourlong wait to get on the ferry," said Andrea L. Wright, who normally drives to her job as a hospital manager but chose to travel by boat to avoid the traffic. "Every seat was taken."
The backup was the worst on the Bay Bridge, which connects San Francisco and Oakland. The bridge on normal days is the busiest toll bridge in the nation, and by 4:30 A.M. today, traffic on it was at a crawl, said Jeff A. Weiss, a spokesman for the California Department of Transportation.
"I've never seen such heavy traffic that early before," Mr. Weiss said, estimating that an additional 50,000 cars were on local roads because of the strike. "The problem is the Bay Bridge is already beyond capacity."
Major San Francisco employers like the Bank of America, Levi Strauss & Company and the Pacific Gas and Electric Company said they were encouraging employees to work from home or during off hours to bypass rush-hour traffic.
"There are definitely fewer people in the office today," said Robert C. Wynne, a spokesman for Bank of America, which employs 9,300 people in San Francisco. "Some people are using the strike as an excuse to try telecommuting or take the day off and wait and see if they'll resolve it."
In the afternoon, Officer Ruth O'Brien of the California Highway Patrol described "seriously long lines at the ferries." But, Officer O'Brien added, "traffic on the Bay Bridge looked light."
Traffic was backed up on major highways around the Oakland Alameda County Coliseum, she said, but much of that could probably be attributed to a football game scheduled for tonight.
If the strike does not end soon, its economic impact will become a major concern for Mayor Brown, his press secretary, Kandace Bender, said.
"Common sense tells you that if 270,000 people are unable to get to San Francisco in a timely fashion, that will have an impact on the economy. It just will," Ms. Bender said. "It's a horrendous inconvenience."
Sympathies among more than a dozen commuters interviewed this morning were divided, but the majority sided with BART management.
"I think it's a tragedy, really, that the union is hung up upon squeezing money out of the public," said John M. Smith, a legal consultant who rode his black BMW motorcycle over the Golden Gate Bridge to work today. "The workers are very well paid, and frankly, greedy."
BART maintenance workers, who belong to the Service Employees International Union Local 790, earn a base wage of $48,000 a year. Train operators and station agents, members of the Amalgamated Transit Union Local 1555, make $40,900, placing them among the highest paid transit workers in the country.
Members of both unions rejected an offer from management that would have raised their pay 3 percent a year for three years.
Stacey L. Richman, 27, who works for United Way and who normally commutes by BART, said she supported the union.
"Just because it's inconvenient for us doesn't make it wrong for them to look out for their interests," Ms. Richman said, "and I do think the two-tier system is wrong."

HEADLINE: CLINTON PROMOTES EDUCATION TESTING GINGRICH OPPOSES

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 8

 BODY:
President Clinton and Speaker Newt Gingrich staked out opposing positions today on national educational testing as Congress planned for crucial votes perhaps as early as Tuesday on the program that Mr. Clinton has made a centerpiece of his second-term education agenda.
At an elementary school in Gambrills, Md., on his first day back from vacation, Mr. Clinton said support for his call to develop national tests for fourth-grade reading skills and eighth-grade math abilities should transcend partisanship. 
 "I think every American -- Republicans, Democrats, independents -- should favor high standards," he said. "I think people from all backgrounds should want all of our children to learn at a high level."
Children were clustered around him as he spoke at the school, about 25 miles northeast of Washington, under a banner proclaiming, "Educating Everyone Takes Everyone!"
But with conservative Republicans deeply suspicious of anything that could be seen as a Federal intrusion into local control of schools, Mr. Gingrich said today: "The President is focused on the wrong end. He's focused on Washington bureaucracy, Washington regulations, Washington red tape."
At a news conference in Detroit before a speech to the Economic Club of Detroit, Mr. Gingrich said, "We believe he ought to be focusing on local parents, local students and local teachers."
The battle over Mr. Clinton's plan for developing national tests to measure educational performance is one of many confrontations looming over education, as Republicans and Democrats alike plan to carry competing education agendas into the 1998 midterm Congressional elections to woo suburban swing voters.
Mr. Clinton proposed the national tests to allow parents and local school districts to assess student performance. While several such tests now exist, they are given to samplings of students and are not useful in determining how an individual student or school is performing.
To head off conservative opposition, Mr. Clinton repeated that use of the tests by states and school districts would be voluntary. "No school or school district will be forced to use them if they don't want to," he said. "But they will give us a sense of a national level of achievement in reading for fourth graders and math for eighth graders."
Recently, in an effort to further assuage the Republican Party, he also said the tests would be developed by the National Assessment Governing Board, a bipartisan, independent board created by Congress.
Democrats in the Senate said they thought that Mr. Clinton's pledge to use the independent board would win him support for the testing in the Senate, where a vote could come as early as Tuesday, as part of the spending bill that finances education.
Democratic negotiators said they were close to agreement with Republicans on a compromise under which the G.O.P. would withdraw an amendment to block the Education Department from spending money to develop the tests and would instead require the department to turn development of the tests over to the independent board.
But the situation was fluid. Senator Dan Coats, the Indiana Republican who co-sponsored the amendment, has not agreed to withdraw it, said his spokesman, Erik Hotmire. "Talks are continuing," he said. "There is not an agreement.
Even if the Senate approved the plan, opposition remains strong in the more conservative House, which could vote as early as Tuesday on its own amendment, by Representative William F. Goodling, to block the Education Department from spending money to develop the tests.
Mr. Goodling, the Pennsylvania Republican who leads the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, has argued that in the past decade 46 states have already set higher standards and created new tests. He says that another test will not help students who are performing poorly.
"What they don't need is one more standardized test to tell them and to tell their parents one more time that they are not doing well," Mr. Goodling said. "They know that." He said money should be put into classrooms instead. The Education Department is spending $15 million to develop the tests this year and President Clinton has asked for another $16 million in the next fiscal year.
Mr. Goodling has been drawing support from both ends of the political spectrum and said he thought his amendment would pass.
Conservatives like Gary Bauer, the head of the Family Research Council, have long warned against an expanded Federal role in schools. "It's an attempt by the Education Department to usurp more control from the states and local communities over the education of our children," Mr. Bauer said in a statement about the national testing plan.
Some liberal Democrats like Representative Major R. Owens of Brooklyn have also come out against Mr. Clinton's plan because, they say, not enough Federal money is being spent on schools to make sure that the poorest urban students do well.
A split vote by the Senate and House would mean that the issue would be decided in a conference committee, where Republicans would have to consider a possible veto fight with Mr. Clinton on an education issue.
The President made no veto threat today, with aides saying he did not want to disrupt Senate negotiations. But his spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, said a testing ban "is not going to become law, one way or another."
Mr. Clinton did give a clear display of how he planned to stump for the issue as he asked the children who surrounded him how many books they had read over the summer.
"I want to make sure we give a reading test to every fourth grader in America," he said, "so we'll know if the children need help measuring up to national standards, we'll know if a class needs help, we'll know if a school needs help."

In an effort to head off Republican opposition in Congress, Mr. Clinton stressed that the testing would be voluntary for local schools. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)(pg. A22)

HEADLINE: Bilingual Education Keeps Students in School;
Economics Are a Factor

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Diane Ravitch (Op-Ed, Sept. 5) cites the dropout rates of Hispanic students as proof that bilingual education has failed. That Hispanic students with low English proficiency drop out at higher rates than Hispanic students with high English proficiency has been proved in education studies to result from differences in socioeconomic status. 
 Students with low English proficiency are most often children of immigrant parents who have been in this country for a short period of time. The parents tend to have less education and income than parents of Hispanic students born in the United States.
Ms. Ravitch suggests immersion programs as a preferred alternative to bilingual education. Most studies agree that how students adapt to the school environment has a lasting effect on success. Immersion can only make this adaptation more traumatic for non-English-speaking students, suggesting grave consequences for their future educational success.
 
LISA M. GARCIA
Washington, Sept. 5, 1997
 
The writer is an intern in education policy at the Rand Corporation.

HEADLINE: Youth Study Elevates Family's Role

BYLINE: By SUSAN GILBERT 

 BODY:
THERE is no shortage of efforts in homes, schools and communities to discourage teen-agers from taking drugs, smoking, drinking or having sex. The question is, What really works? One answer, from a major study of adolescents, is that families are more important than previously thought, perhaps as important as peers.
The portion of the study's data that has been analyzed so far did not look at peer pressure, but the findings call into question the idea that peer relationships almost completely eclipse family relationships in their influence over teen-agers' behavior, said Dr. Robert William Blum, one of the study's researchers and the director of the Adolescent Health Program at the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis. The primacy of peer relationships has been a widely held concept among professionals since the 1960's. 
"There's been a pretty significant myth that peer groups are important and parents are not," Dr. Blum said. "We've focused so tremendously on peer pressure and instituted so many things to deal with peer pressure. And what this study is saying is that family environment matters."
The National Longitudinal Study on Adolescent Health, a survey of roughly 90,000 children, some of them 12 but a vast majority teen-agers, is the largest, most comprehensive study ever conducted on adolescent behavior in this country. It will take a decade to analyze all the data, but the first results are being published today in The Journal of the American Medical Association.
"These findings offer the parents of America a blueprint for what works in protecting their kids from harm," said Dr. J. Richard Udry, the principal investigator and a sociologist at the Carolina Population Center of the University of North Carolina in Chapel Hill.
The most significant finding is that the teen-agers who reported feeling close to their families were the least likely to engage in any of the risky behaviors studied, which included smoking marijuana or cigarettes, drinking or having sex. Nearly as important were high expectations from the parents for their teen-agers' school performance. To a lesser degree, having a parent home at important times of day, like after school, at dinner and at bedtime, was also associated with less risky behavior.
In addition, the study identified school characteristics that were protective. Whether the school was public, parochial or private mattered less than whether the students felt that their teachers cared about them and treated them fairly.
In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Jonathan D. Klein, a pediatrician at the University of Rochester School of Medicine and Dentistry who specializes in adolescent medicine, wrote that many of the results confirmed what other research has found, like the benefits of a close ties at school and at home. "The sheer size of the study plus the opportunity to get more data are what make this study special," he said in an interview.
The survey suggests that manypreventive measures used by schools and communities are misdirected, Dr. Blum said. "Most of the rules and regulations that schools institute, like suspending students for smoking on school grounds, don't seem to have a significant impact," he said. "We invest heavily in rule development, but that's not where the action is. The action is in adults' connecting with kids."
The study began in 1995 and was conducted in three phases. In the first phase, about 90,000 students from grades 7 through 12 at 145 schools answered questionnaires about themselves.
In the second phase, interviews were conducted with about 20,000 of those students and their parents in the students' homes. To insure privacy, the students listened to questions with headphones and typed their answers into laptop computers. Students were asked about their experiences with smoking, drinking and other kinds of dangerous behavior. In the third phase, the home interviews with the teen-agers were repeated a year later.
The results published today are based on 12,118 of the initial in-home interviews. This sample was representative of the social and economic make-up of teen-agers around the country.
On one level, the results are a report card on teen-agers' behavior. In the survey, 25 percent of the students said they were current smokers, 11 percent said they had smoked marijuana at least once in the past month, 17 percent reported having had alcohol more than once a month and 3 percent said they had attempted suicide in the past year. In addition, 16 percent of the 7th and 8th graders and 48 percent of those in 9th to 12th grade said they had engaged in sex.
The researchers sought to identify particular characteristics of the families, schools or students that seemed to protect against or promote risky behavior. The results were controlled for demographic characteristics like sex, race and socioeconomic status.
Certain factors correlated with lower risks in specific areas. For example, a teen-ager who had been a crime victim was more likely to be associated with violent behavior. And living in a house without easy access to alcohol, drugs, cigarettes or guns was associated with a lower likelihood of drinking, taking drugs, smoking or using guns.
But the only factor that was linked with a lower risk across the board was a close-knit family, the study found. Emotional closeness proved more significant than the amount of time that parents spent with their teen-agers at home, calling into question a prevalent view among experts that parents can make a big difference by being home at important times of day, like after school, Dr. Blum said. Being home at such times was associated with a lower incidence of some behaviors, like smoking cigarettes or marijuana and, only among those in 9th to 12 grade, less frequent alcohol use.
"What this study showed is that it is emotional availability far more than physical presence that makes the difference," Dr. Blum said. "You need to give your kids the message that when they need to talk to you, you're available, even if it's by phone, and that they matter."

HEADLINE: For Food-Stamp Families, a More Uncertain Future

BYLINE: By DONNA ST. GEORGE 

 BODY:
HER refrigerator is nearly empty. There are 10 cans of food left in the kitchen cabinet. Ruth Acosta looks over her meager spread -- sweet peas, instant potatoes, cling peaches, kidney beans -- and a grimace crosses her face.
She has no money left and no more food stamps. 
 "That's it," she says.
Eight days remain until her food stamps will come again, and in Ms. Acosta's cramped little apartment on the Upper West Side, with its broken appliances and holes in the walls and steamy humid air, that means 24 meals to scrounge up for a family of six -- herself, three sons, ages 5, 7 and 12, a teen-age daughter and a grandson, 3.
Ms. Acosta does not know where the food will come from or how her family will get by. But she tries not to panic. This uncertainty comes every month, a period of nothing, bleak and foreseeable. Always, she finds a way to work it out.
For Ms. Acosta, who came to New York 30 years ago from the Dominican Republic but who never lived the immigrant's dream, never tried, never really imagined it, the hardest part may be knowing her troubles are about to get worse.
This month and next month, 900,000 people across the country will lose their food stamps when a Federal law that abolishes aid to legal immigrants is implemented. In New York City, local and state laws will spare children, the elderly and the disabled from the cuts, but that will leave 30,000 to 40,000 legal immigrants eliminated from the food program.
Ms. Acosta, 37, will be one of them. Her family may lose $65 to $75 a month in food stamps, a big hit for people eating on 87 cents a meal each.
A world away from political debates in Washington, Ms. Acosta may not be an argument for welfare nor one against it. But her experiences over the course of eight months, starting last February, offer a glimpse into the lives of others coping with the same problem: making do with little, anticipating less.
In the world of food stamps, Ms. Acosta's household is larger than most. The average is a family of three. Her history with public aid goes back longer than most do -- she had a baby as a teen-ager and decided to stay home rather than work.
But in many ways, her experience is shared by many families. Like three-quarters of New York's 1.2 million people on food stamps, she receives public assistance. Her monthly income consists of $488 in food stamps and $523 in public assistance.
For Ms. Acosta and others, running out of cash and stamps is a common experience. They make do by stockpiling staples. Collecting free food from pantries. Getting loans from friends. Eating with relatives. Using school lunch programs. Taking jobs off the books.
There is a rhythm to life on food stamps in many families -- a sense of well-being at the start of the month, when cupboards are stocked, and a growing worry as weeks go by and dinner becomes less predictable.
HALF a block from the plush greenery of Central Park, Ruth Acosta leaves her West 92d Street apartment wearing worn blue jeans and a baggy jacket, her pocket stuffed with food stamps.
This is the day of the month when Ms. Acosta feels the most prosperous, when she can walk into the grocery store and fill up a shopping cart, when she has choices.
Her food stamps came today.
They arrived as they always do, paid at a currency exchange on her Government-assigned day of the month. Ms. Acosta collects them in the morning, buys meat at a butcher shop and walks to the supermarket with her oldest son, Jason Rodriguez.
Once inside C Town on Columbus Avenue, Jason is all eyes. He fetches a five-pound bag of bright red apples. Then a 98-cent package of green grapes. The lanky sixth grader looks at his mother. She nods. Into the shopping cart they go.
They buy vinegar (73 cents), plantains (six for $1), cooking oil (2 1/2 gallons for $14.99), white rice (20 pounds for $6.99), dried red beans (99 cents), generic cornflakes ($1.99), Frosted Flakes ($3.69) and three giant cans of Tang ($8.99 each).
The cart fills quickly. "I try to get sales to make it last longer," Ms. Acosta says, poring over the sale flier, "but it doesn't seem to."
They pass up frozen food. They pass up a big display for Cocoa Pebbles. They bypass the candy, the crackers, the potato chips. They buy Vienna sausages, milk, pancake mix, hot-dog buns. In 52 minutes, they collect $108 in groceries, a bounty of staples and a few indulgences: pudding cups, Oreos, grape soda.
Experts say even the wisest shoppers would have trouble living on food stamps, which were not intended to be a family's only source of income for meals. Food stamps are supposed to help, not suffice.
"Food stamps will never supply you with food for a month," said Nilda Tirado, a nutritionist with Cornell University's Cooperative Extension Service in New York City.
As mother and son wind their way toward the cash register, Jason notices a bottle of generic pancake syrup that his mother has placed into their cart. He scans the flier -- and finds that Aunt Jemima is on sale. He races to make an exchange.
BACK in their seven-story apartment building, Ms. Acosta and Jason ride a tiny, halting elevator to their apartment on the sixth floor. As they open the door, they are greeted by a rush of footsteps and a clamor of children's voices. The two younger children, Kenny and Dennis Rodriguez, seize the grocery bags and drag them into the kitchen, squealing, pushing, running with the food.
"Apples!" Kenny announces.
The boys dash into the living room, red-skinned beauties held aloft, and plunk on the raggedy couch. Jason joins them, and they eat with glee.
In a rare moment, this brings quiet to the living room, a place as haphazard as their lives. Here, clothes are drying on the radiator. A mattress is propped against the wall. The walls are bare except for a certificate declaring Jason "Student of the Month" and two photographs of him in a baseball uniform.
As the older boys devour their apples, Ms. Acosta's grandson, Rene Barrientos, is in the kitchen hunting down an apple. "Are the apples here?" he calls out.
A day later, the fruit is gone.
Researchers say that, over all, food stamps are spent on food that is just as nutritious, or more so, than what the general population buys.
Dr. Kathryn Edin, a sociologist who interviewed 214 welfare families for a recent book, "Making Ends Meet," said she found that welfare mothers bought food in bulk, looked for cheaper stores and tended toward staples that are low in cost and high in nutrition.
"I can't remember seeing a frozen pizza on the table," Dr. Edin said.
But that's not to say there wasn't the occasional box of freeze pops in the house. "Every mother wants to give her kids a decent life, a feeling that they're normal," she said.
Eight days after her food stamps arrive, Ms. Acosta is at a food pantry for the poor, run by the West Side Campaign Against Hunger.
Like others who rely on the pantry, in the basement of SS. Paul and Andrew Church, at 86th Street and West End Avenue, Ms. Acosta is allowed to come once a month, on a specially assigned day. Today, she will get three days' worth of groceries for each member of the family.
This morning, she's No. 34 in a line of 50. She has been waiting an hour, since 10 A.M., but she is undeterred, talking quietly with her friend Tita. As the women wait, Ms. Acosta notices a sign on the pantry's bulletin board that says legal immigrants are to lose food stamps.
She reads the notice soberly and tells her friend what it says.
Ms. Acosta was 7 when she and her mother emigrated from the Dominican Republic. She has had a green card since she was a child, and has worked for short periods of time over the years. She has no contact with the father of her oldest child, Lillian Aponte, 18, who is the mother of Rene. The father of her three sons, she said, visits occasionally but is unemployed and has contributed little to the family's support.
Her friend at the pantry cares for eight grandchildren and is frightened by the prospect of losing her food stamps. "But what can I do?" she frets. The women fall silent.
Back at home, dinners are dictated by what is in the cabinet or the refrigerator; often that means rice and beans, oxtail stew, baked chicken, hamburgers or spaghetti.
Lunch is easier, free under the school-lunch program. Today at Public School 84, where Kenny and Dennis are enrolled, the menu is deep-fried meat pies, mixed vegetables and tangerines. It is not a big hit with most of the children. But Dennis, quiet and deliberate, eats one bite of meat pie after another.
On another day, Rene, who is not yet in school, waits for his grandmother to fix lunch. Ms. Acosta baby-sits while Lillian attends a program to complete high school and overcome alcohol problems.
Ms. Acosta is boiling pasta in the kitchen, a tiny room where every appliance is broken and cockroaches dart across the walls. A black-and-white television with a hopelessly fuzzy picture is tuned to the Spanish soap opera "Guadalupe." Rene plunks himself down on the only kitchen chair that has all its legs.
"You want it with cheese, or you want it plain?" Ms. Acosta asks.
"Cheese!" Rene says.
Ms. Acosta spoons his noodles into a small bowl. But she realizes all the cheese is gone. So she roots through her cabinet and finds a last can of spaghetti sauce, which she opens by plunging a knife through the top.
"Sauce!" Rene declares, grinning.
TWENTY-TWO days after the food stamps arrive, they are gone. Ms. Acosta spends the last $5 on bread, salami and cheese.
During the month, she has spent her cash on basics that cannot be bought with food stamps, things like clothing, school supplies, bus fares, dental work, toilet paper, shampoo, detergent, insecticide -- and the subsidized rent of $135 a month.
Her grandson needed new sneakers. Her teen-age daughter wanted eye liner and lipstick. Jason wants his favorite gold jacket dry-cleaned, but he has to wait. "Every check, someone else in the family gets a turn," she says.
Ms. Acosta thinks of herself as a wise shopper, but sometimes money slips through her hands. She spent $45 on Rene's new sneakers. Sometimes, she buys a hot chocolate at McDonald's. At least one night a month, the family eats out. They have no telephone -- but pay $37.50 a month for cable television.
To cut down on impulse buying, she gives her food stamps to Jason for safekeeping -- and doesn't ask where he hides them. "He's the bookkeeper for me," she says. "If you go outside with money, you go broke."
As the month ends, Ms. Acosta relies on rice and beans. She relies on her sister's cooking one night, her sister's money the next. When all else fails, her neighbor lends her $10 for "chicken and stuff." Ms. Acosta is vague about how they get by. They just do.
NOW, the long-feared cut in food stamps is about to take effect -- just as Ms. Acosta and her family have begun to sort out some of their difficulties.
Lillian had a summer job; the three eldest boys took home trophies for summer baseball; the family has a new refrigerator and stove, and Ruth has joined a maintenance crew as part of a welfare work program, which in many ways she enjoys. "I feel like you're earning what you're getting now," she says.
And the work program has increased her food supply: she is paid $3 a day for transportation, but Ms. Acosta often walks the mile to work, using the money for groceries.
But this stability will soon change. "I'm just waiting to see," she says.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls Sharply vs. Yen On U.S. Remarks About Trade

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar suffered its biggest one-day drop against the yen in a month yesterday after comments by a Treasury Department official caused concerns about increased trade tensions with Japan. But the dollar gained against the mark as prospects for higher German interest rates dimmed.
The dollar sharply reversed its recent rally against the yen after Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers was quoted as saying that Washington was worried that Japan would rely too heavily on exports to revive its economy. 
 "Given that there weren't a lot of other things to focus on, this certainly drew the market's attention," said Michael Faust, a foreign-exchange strategist with Bailard, Biehl & Kaiser, a Foster City, Calif., money-management firm.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 118.93 yen, down 2 percent from 121.17 late Monday. It was the biggest drop since a 3 percent slide on Aug. 9, and the lowest level since Aug. 28. The dollar settled at 1.8135 marks, up from 1.8068.
The remarks by Mr. Summers heightened traders' fears that the dollar had exceeded what is considered a comfortable level for United States-Japanese trade relations.
"I continue to be concerned that Japan does what's necessary to achieve the domestic demand-led growth to which it's committed and avoid the export-led growth that has been a hallmark of many past Japanese recoveries," Mr. Summers was quoted as saying in The Financial Times.
While a weaker yen can help Japan's economy by making its goods cheaper overseas, it worries United States exporters because their products are more expensive in Japan.
Against the mark, the dollar was bolstered by a report that German unemployment in August rose sharply. The report was seen as evidence that Germany's economy was not growing fast enough to merit a rate increase by the central bank.
The dollar also benefited from comments from Ernst Welteke, a member of the central bank's policy-setting council, that Germany's economic recovery was being hampered by the weak labor market.
"At the moment, no one expects the Bundesbank to lower rates," Mr. Welteke said.
