HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A small agency creates a campaign for Black & Decker's new line of Kitchen Tools.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
A PRODUCER of prosaic household appliances is undertaking an ambitious effort to carve out a succulent slice of the lucrative market for higher-priced kitchen gadgets.
The Black & Decker Corporation is adding six sleek products with high-tech glosses and user-friendly features to a lineup ranging from waffle makers to irons to toaster ovens. A comprehensive advertising, marketing and promotional campaign, which starts this month and runs through December, promises that the new line will be "simple tools for fine cuisine." 
 To reinforce the separate identity of the new products -- yet also capitalize on the Black & Decker reputation for making sanders, screw drivers and other tools -- they are arriving on shelves of department stores across the country under the moniker Kitchen Tools. The familiar Black & Decker logo is tucked discreetly into corners of packages, advertisements and brochures.
"It taps into the core equity of the Black & Decker brand, which is all about durable, reliable tools," said Becky Bunnell, director for marketing communications and consumer intelligence -- yes, that's her title -- at Black & Decker in Shelton, Conn.
"And it also taps into the 'Martha Stewartization' of the world," she added, "by sending a signal that this line is specifically for people who look at cooking as a creative outlet."
A small New York agency, Nick and Paul, which specializes in projects to identify and exploit the essence, or "DNA," of brands, has developed the introductory campaign for Kitchen Tools. Ms. Bunnell estimated the budget as "north of $2 million to $2.5 million."
Nick and Paul has handled all aspects of Kitchen Tools in what is known as an integrated marketing communications effort: naming the brand, designing the logo and packaging, creating print ads and brochures, even producing instruction manuals and warranty cards.
"It was a 'power tool for the kitchen' approach" developed from consumer research, said Paul Bennett, creative director at Nick and Paul, "a yin and yang between creativity and functionality, stretching the idea of a tool to make it feel upscale."
Indeed, the arrival of Kitchen Tools is indicative of the renewed interest in premium-priced products among giant marketers as the American economy continues to grow and shoppers "trade up" by buying goods with pricier price tags in categories from liquor to autos to apparel.
"People may be feeling their personal-wealth perception is a little higher," Ms. Bunnell said, "and are feathering their nests with Sub-Zero refrigerators and Viking stoves."
That is also noticeable in the realm of less bulky kitchen appliances like food processors, mixers and blenders -- small electrics, in the parlance of Hudson's department stores. Of the estimated 1.3 million to 1.5 million stand mixers sold annually, Ms. Bunnell said, the market share for higher-priced brands has now grown to 56 percent.
"Kitchen Tools is aimed at the more premium end of the market" than products sold under the Black & Decker brand, Ms. Bunnell said.
"It's for people who see a tool they need and are very much willing to pay more for higher quality," she added, particularly if it is perceived as "a tool that allows them to do more." Brands already serving that market include Braun, Cuisinart, DeLonghi, Krups and T-Fal.
So a coffee maker bearing the Kitchen Tools name will sell for $139 to $159, on par with Braun and Krups, compared with its Black & Decker sibling, which may be priced at $69 to $79. Other products that will be sold under the banners of both Black & Decker and Kitchen Tools are can openers, food processors and hand mixers; Kitchen Tools will also offer blenders and stand mixers.
Black & Decker hired Nick and Paul 16 months ago to handle a creative assignment for its household products group that became the Kitchen Tools introduction. The group's agency of record remains the McCann-Erickson New York unit of the Interpublic Group of Companies, which in May was also awarded the company's consumer power tools account.
"Nick and Paul was able to create a voice that goes through every aspect of our communications for Kitchen Tools," Ms. Bunnell said, "and really helped us understand what the relationship should be to Black & Decker and how to leverage that in positive ways."
For example, in the naming process, the agency recommended "that we celebrate our tool name, our tool heritage," she added, rather than coin a name that would scream "high-end, chi-chi, designer apparel" or "down and dirty performance, like a race car."
The brand's identity, according to Mr. Bennett, "was originally much more about creativity, recipes, until consumers told us: 'Get real. Just give me the facts, how this performs, not how to make sushi.' "
"It's important for Black & Decker to have kitchen credibility," he added, "when you're selling a $300 mixer."
That tone is apparent in the ads, which appear in magazines like Food & Wine and Saveur. "It can take years of practice to truly master fine cuisine," the cover of a brochure asserts. "The same shouldn't be true for your kitchen appliances." An ad for the Kitchen Tools coffee maker ends: "Finally, a coffee maker rethought and made simple. Which you can appreciate first thing in the morning."
A label on the carton of the food processor, describing various "quicker assembly" features, declares, "It's a tool, not a puzzle." And warranty cards chattily begin: "So you bought a Kitchen Tools product? Welcome to the family."
Other elements of the introduction include product demonstrations in malls, sponsored by Bon Appetit and Gourmet magazines, and a "Tool Jam" for trainee chefs in cooking schools, sponsored by Food & Wine.
Initial results for Kitchen Tools are, well, yummy.
"We're already starting to see sales that are better than our expectations," Ms. Bunnell said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasuries Dip in Wait-and-See Trading

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities dipped yesterday on weakness in the dollar against the yen and apprehension about a heavy supply of corporate and global debt that will be priced in coming days.
In quiet trading in advance of significant economic reports scheduled for Friday, the 30-year bond slipped 6/32, to a price of 96 26/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 6.62 percent, up one-hundredth of a percentage point from the yield on Monday. 
 Among the issuers of debt coming to the market are Venezuela, Argentina, the Korean Development Bank and the Swiss Bank Corporation. Securities firms that are managing the debt sales often hedge against possible losses by selling government securities before the debt is sold.
Among the first issues to go on sale yesterday was a $300 million offering of 12-year notes by GTE California Inc., a unit of the GTE Corporation, that were priced to yield 6.861 percent through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch & Company. Noncallable by the issuer, the notes were rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
In a two-part offering through Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Company, E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company priced $500 million of five-year noncallable notes to yield 6.576 percent and a similar amount of 10-year notes to yield 6.782 percent.
Bonds were modestly affected yesterday by a report from the Labor Department that said productivity, a measure of time and effort involved in the production of goods and serves, rose to an annual rate of 2.7 percent in the second quarter. It was the largest increase since the fourth quarter of 1993.
The Government also reported that unit labor costs were up an annualized rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, well below the 2.4 percent increase initially reported. This suggested that the Fed might not have to raise short-term interest rates at the next Federal Open Market Committee meeting on Sept. 30.
The Fed has not raised interest rates since March, when it increased the Federal funds rate, the rate banks charge one another for overnight loans, to 5.50 percent from 5.25 percent. Many market participants expect no action this month.
In addition to the increased supply of debt coming to the market, there was also a reluctance by investors to buy bonds before the release of the August retail and producer price reports on Friday. Investors believe these reports may provide more clues about the strength of the economy and the rate of inflation, which are closely monitored by the Federal Reserve.
Robert Pugliese, senior vice president and director of fixed income at J. W. Charles Securities Inc. in Boca Raton, Fla., said the market has not been performing as expected lately on data showing no inflation and little growth -- positive numbers for the market because they would give the Fed little reason to raise rates.
"I think everyone is waiting for bad-good numbers, where inflation and growth show signs of accelerating," he said. The market only offers short-term downside risk, he added, because everyone is waiting for something negative.
Mr. Pugliese is not among those who think the large supply of corporate debt will affect the market significantly.
"I really don't think it's a factor," he said. "Issues get sold 10 minutes after they are priced. Cash has to be put to work, and that area has seen much success. Even the high-yield issues are getting absorbed quickly. I am convinced the market is in a wait-and-see posture for the next few weeks, unless there is something dramatic on the inflation front."
Bill Gamba, senior vice president and head of government bond trading at Cowen & Company, saw yesterday as a typical day when important data are scheduled for late in the week and a huge supply of corporate and global debt issues are looming.
"People are less interested in the Treasury market at this point," he said. "You're not going to see them place any major bets going into Friday's economic data."
While the dollar did play an early role in the market's weakness, Mr. Gamba said, it was only one of many ingredients in a lackluster session.

HEADLINE: Productivity Up; What It Signals Is Still Debated

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
The productivity of American workers -- measuring how much they produce in an hour on the job -- was much higher in the second quarter than originally estimated, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But both sides in a growing debate over the efficiency of the nation's work force saw support for their viewpoints in the new figures.
Productivity for the nonfarm business sector, covering all private business except agriculture, grew in the second quarter at an annual rate of 2.7 percent, far better than the six-tenths of 1 percent estimate issued last month by the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. The new figure represented the fastest quarterly growth since late 1993. But productivity has spurted upward before, only to die away. Lasting trends, up or down, become evident only in hindsight, after several years of accumulated data. 
 "I don't see an argument for saying that the last few quarters are markedly different from the 1980's or 1990's so far," said Edwin Dean, chief of the bureau division that compiles the productivity numbers. "They are just a shade better."
The upward revision reinforces a slight upward trend in the nation's recent productivity growth. That upward trend has encouraged some economists to argue that the United States has turned a corner; that the country is heading back toward a level of efficiency characteristic of the prosperous early post-war decades, but absent for the last 25 years.
"The numbers are beginning to show positive growth," said Barry Bluestone, a labor economist at the University of Massachusetts.
The upward revision for the second quarter was mostly a result of a previously announced upward revision in the gross domestic product. The nation's workers produced much more from April through June than originally estimated, without working many more hours. So their productivity -- in repairing a car, cleaning a hotel room, selling insurance -- was greater. The improvement came outside manufacturing, where the second-quarter number was revised downward, to an annual rate of 2.4 percent from last month's estimate of 3.2 percent.
The upward movement in overall productivity reflected the short term. Viewed over a longer period, a different interpretation emerges. Since the start of the current economic expansion in 1991, the annual productivity growth rate has averaged only 1.2 percent, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported yesterday. That is less than the 1.5 percent average for a similar six years of economic expansion in the 1980's, when there were also periodic spurts in productivity.
The performance in both decades has been well below the most prosperous postwar years, from 1947 to 1973, when the productivity growth rate nationwide averaged 2.8 percent annually, or 1.6 percentage points above the 1990's average. The difference is significant. If a shoemaker, for example, increases in a single hour the sales revenue from his work to $101.60 from $100, then his productivity has grown by 1.6 percent.
The extra money can go into profits or into a raise or both. The shoemaker's boss does not have to increase prices, feeding inflation, to make possible a raise or a higher profit. That higher productivity was at the heart of the prosperity in the early postwar decades. And some economists insist that a similar pattern has re-emerged, though not yet in the official numbers.
The basis of this argument is the coexistence for more than 18 months of low inflation, smartly rising profits and the beginnings of increases in wages. If productivity were not improving, the companies would have to raise prices to fatten profits and give raises, the productivity optimists argue, and they are not raising prices.
"Rising productivity is the only possible explanation," said Edward Yardeni, chief economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, a Wall Street firm.
But the productivity pessimists do offer other explanations. They note, for example, that men and women have been entering the labor force recently in unusually large numbers. The smartly rising profits, they say, might be coming not from the shoemaker's rising hourly output, but from the output of two shoemakers rather than one. Or companies might be feeding profits by holding back on pay.
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, has entered the debate on the side of the optimists, but with caveats. "The still open question is whether productivity growth is in the process of picking up," he said in a speech last Friday.
Like others, Mr. Greenspan has argued that productivity is very difficult to measure in several major sectors of the economy, including financial institutions and noncorporate partnerships and proprietorships. Research by Fed economists, cited by Mr. Greenspan, found productivity to be falling in this latter sector, despite healthy profit margins -- a contradiction that suggests measurement error to Mr. Greenspan.
Seeking a better signal of what may be happening in the economy as a whole, Mr. Greenspan has focused on productivity in the nonfinancial corporate sector. The Bureau of Labor Statistics yesterday issued its first estimate of productivity growth in this sector in the second quarter. It rose 3.2 percent at an annual rate, and has averaged 2.4 percent growth over the last four quarters and about 1.6 percent over a longer period.

D1); "U.S. Productivity" tracks index of output per hour of all people in nonfarm businesses, seasonally adjusted, since 1993. (Source: Bureau of Labor Statistics)(pg. D2)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Columbia/HCA Warns Earnings Will Be Lower
The Government inquiry into Columbia/HCA Healthcare and stagnant business at its 342 hospitals will push third-quarter earnings at the troubled health care provider down. The company said that per-share earnings would drop to 20 cents or 25 cents, compared with 46 cents in the quarter a year earlier.
Analysts were surprised by the company's announcement; they had predicted that earnings would exceed 50 cents a share. Columbia shares fell 9 percent. [Page D5.] 

Xerox Is Selling Another Unit
Xerox is continuing its plan to exit the insurance business. Its latest liquidation is of its Resolution Group, which will be acquired by 14 investors, including top executives, for $612 million. [D5.]
 
Stock Indexes Continue to Inch Up
Stocks moved slightly higher, though investors were concerned about currency fluctuations and earnings disappointments. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 16.73 points to close at 7,851.91. The technology-laden Nasdaq composite index recorded its third consecutive new high, gaining 10.87 points, to 1,656.22. [D8.]
 
Treasury prices fell on weakness in the dollar against the yen and apprehension about a heavy supply of corporate and global debt later this week. The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.62 percent from 6.61. [D6.]
 
Talks on a Tobacco Deal Change
White House officials and tobacco industry representatives are negotiating a possible overhaul of the provisions on youth smoking in the proposed $368.5 billion tobacco settlement that could reduce fines against companies and increase cigarette costs. [A14.]
 
No Credit Cards, Yet
The Government said that it planned to make paying taxes so easy that taxpayers need do nothing more than allow the I.R.S. to dip into their bank accounts. But the Treasury said it had yet to figure out how consumers could pay their taxes with credit cards. Both credit card and debit card payments were approved by the new tax legislation, but the law prohibits the Government from paying fees to card companies. [D2.]
 
Starwood Lodging Buying Westin
As expected, Starwood Lodging Trust is acquiring Westin Hotels for $540 million in cash and stock and assuming more than $1 billion in debt. The new company will own and operate 219 hotels in 38 states and 23 countries and have $4 billion in annual revenue. [D4.]
 
World Bank Sees New Powerhouses
The World Bank forecast that growth in developing countries would accelerate over the next decade, and that the five biggest emerging economies -- China, India, Indonesia, Brazil and Russia -- would become economic powerhouses in the next quarter-century. [D7.]
 
German Woes Appear to Be Growing
Statistics show German unemployment at record levels, inflation increasing and eastern Germany falling further behind the west in economic growth. [A13.]
 
The German economic news helped the dollar against the mark. But the dollar suffered its biggest one-day drop against the yen in a month after comments by a Treasury Department official caused concerns about increased trade tensions with Japan. [D15.]
 
Circuit City in Licensing Pacts
Circuit City Stores has reached licensing agreements with major film studios and makers of digital videodisk players for a technology that would create disposable rental films. The encryption technology, dubbed Divx, is also intended to prevent movie piracy by requiring the use of specially encoded disks and players. [D7.]

Coffee futures prices fell as rainfall in Colombia and Indonesia, two big producers, raised prospects for supplies. [D15.]

HEADLINE: CAMPAIGN FINANCE: THE INTERESTED PARTIES;
Sinking of Casino Plan Makes Tribes Cry Foul

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
When a half-dozen Minnesota and Wisconsin Indian tribes set out two years ago to sink a rival Indian casino proposal, they turned to some influential Washington insiders for help.
The tribes hired Patrick O'Connor, a lobbyist in Minneapolis and Washington who is a former treasurer of the Democratic National Committee. Mr. O'Connor then arranged for tribal leaders to meet with an old friend, Donald L. Fowler, who was then the Democratic Party chairman. 
 The tribes that opposed the project were longtime Democratic supporters who ran their own lucrative gambling operations and wanted to prevent a potential new competitor -- three Chippewa tribes from Wisconsin -- from cutting into their profits. At a meeting here on April 28, 1995, Mr. Fowler promised to get in contact with the Interior Department and Harold M. Ickes, the deputy White House chief of staff, on the tribes' behalf.
What happened next is a bit murky, but the results are not, as Senators investigating campaign-finance abuses heard in testimony today. Less than three months after the meeting, the Interior Department killed the project, overruling the Minneapolis office of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, which had supported the plan.
The tribes that opposed the project, including the Oneida and St. Croix and some other Chippewas, were grateful. Four of the tribes donated $56,000 to the Democratic National Committee in 1995, mainly in the weeks after the decision, and $225,000 in 1996. The tribes also contributed thousands of dollars to the Minnesota Democratic Party. Tribal leaders showed their appreciation.
"On behalf of the Ho-Chunk Nation, I want to thank you for your help in the successful effort to defeat the Hudson casino," JoAnn Jones, president of one of the tribes, in Black River Falls, Wis., said in a note to Mr. Fowler. "You were particularly instrumental in helping the department understand the significance and importance of their decision."
But the tribes that wanted to build a casino on a failing dog-racing track in Hudson, Wis., 20 miles east of Minneapolis, were not amused. They filed a lawsuit in Federal District Court in Madison, Wis., contending that improper political pressure had been used to kill the project.
The Interior Department denied that it had been pressured into the decision, citing the economic effects that a new casino would have had on the gambling operations of the nearby St. Croix tribe.
But in March, Judge Barbara B. Crabb of Federal District Court in Madison ruled that "there is a distinct possibility that improper political influence affected" the decision. The judge may allow the Wisconsin tribes to subpoena Clinton Administration officials to testify.
Senator Susan Collins, a Maine Republican on the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee, said at the hearing today, "It's certainly the case that such actions as were taken undermine public confidence to have officials engaged in fund-raising, in my view to be advocating on behalf of contributors on matters before Government agencies."
The Hudson casino episode was one of several that Republican senators sought to portray as examples of where Mr. Fowler promised favors in exchange for specific donations.
Mr. Fowler acknowledged making calls on behalf of the tribes who opposed the project but said he had not influenced the final decision. "I called Mr. Ickes, explained to him the nature of the situation, and I called someone at the Department of Interior," Mr. Fowler said. "I do not recall the name of the person with whom I talked at the Department of Interior. To my recollection, I did not suggest a result, did not ask for an outcome. I just asked that it be reviewed."
But in a memorandum dated May 5, 1995, Mr. Fowler argued for Mr. Ickes to intervene on behalf of the Oneida and St. Croix, if nothing else than to thwart Republican supporters. "The proposal to convert a dog track to a casino is being pushed by American Indian tribes who are supporters of Governor Thompson," the memorandum said, referring to the state's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican.
Mr. Fowler had a difficult time explaining at least seven telephone conversations that Mr. O'Connor had with David Mercer, a senior fund-raising official at the Democratic National Committee, from April 28, the day of the meeting, to Aug. 21.
"Can you explain to me why a lobbyist for the tribes would have so much contact with the D.N.C. deputy finance director about the same time that the casino application was under consideration?" Senator Collins asked.
Mr. Fowler replied: "One could infer that the casino matter was discussed -- but I don't know that. Mr. O'Connor is also involved in various activities and various affairs of the Democratic Party."
Senator Collins asked again whether Mr. Fowler had championed the cause of the tribes who opposed the project because he knew the Indians would give more money.
"If the implication of that question is did I perform or do something in response to a contribution, or did I do something under the condition of receiving a contribution, I categorically said or answered that, no," Mr. Fowler said. "Whatever they contributed or didn't contribute had nothing to do with my actions in that regard."

HEADLINE: Hong Kong's New Leader Disputes U.S. on Rights

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
In the first of a series of high-level visits over the next two months between American and Chinese leaders, the new Chief Executive of Hong Kong, Tung Chee-hwa, sparred with members of Congress over human rights today and declared that Hong Kong would soon enjoy more democracy "than we ever had in 156 years of colonial rule."
The arrival of Mr. Tung, a shipping magnate chosen by Beijing to run Hong Kong, precedes by a month and a half a long-waited summit meeting here between President Jiang Zemin of China and President Clinton. At times today, it seemed as if Mr. Tung's visit was intended to vent some of the pent-up frustration with China's human rights record in Congress before Mr. Jiang arrives. 
 Mr. Tung clearly decided that the best defense was a good offense, favorably comparing his own proposal for elections in Hong Kong -- which has been widely criticized as benefiting conservative business interests -- with the former British rule.
But in a series of visits today, he skipped lightly over his decision to roll back the electoral reforms pushed through before the handover, which widened the franchise in voting for Hong Kong's legislature.
Mr. Tung also lashed out at American press coverage of the July 1 handover, arguing that it had been slanted to give viewers the impression that the Chinese Army was taking over the city.
"On July 1, after showing the official ceremony, the TV pictures switched to People's Liberation Army soldiers entering Hong Kong," he said, "not emphasis on the peaceful return of a territory taken years ago in an unjust war, not consideration of Hong Kong people being given full responsibility for their government for the first time in their history."
Usually garrulous and relaxed, Mr. Tung seemed a little nervous as he met with members of Congress who have been critical of China and of Mr. Tung's reworking of Hong Kong's electoral system.
This afternoon Mr. Tung met with Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, who is to travel to Hong Kong next week for annual meetings of the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.
At the Treasury today, Mr. Tung emphasized Hong Kong's economic health in the face of a currency crisis that has swept through the rest of Southeast Asia. He reassured Mr. Rubin that Hong Kong would continue to peg its currency to the United States dollar -- one of the city's main claims to financial stability.
But even Mr. Rubin brought up human rights and free speech issues, tying them to Hong Kong's future financial health. Mr. Tung touched on the same theme in his speech, declaring that his city would "continue to uphold academic and media freedom" and would remain "the best place to find out what is going on across Asia."
But much of Mr. Tung's time today was spent defending his proposal for an electoral system under which companies, banks and professional associations will choose the occupants of a third of the seats in the Hong Kong legislature. He argued that these were part of a series of transition rules that would ultimately lead to greater direct participation in elections.

Beijing Ex-Mayor Charged
 BEIJING, Sept. 9 (By The New York Times) -- Just days before the opening of a Communist Party Congress, China's biggest political gathering in five years, the party authorities announced tonight that they were prosecuting a disgraced senior leader and longtime rival to President Jiang Zemin on corruption charges.
Mr. Jiang, who is also General Secretary of the party, is clearly trying to stamp his personal authority on the party congress, which opens on Friday and is to approve China's leaders and policy for the post-Deng era.
By expelling and prosecuting the former official, Chen Xitong, a member of the party's ruling Politburo who dominated the Beijing municipal government for more than 12 years as Mayor and then as local party chief, the authorities led by Mr. Jiang won a big trophy for their campaign against corruption and demonstrated Mr. Jiang's resolve to defeat a rival.
Mr. Chen, 67, the most senior Chinese leader to face criminal charges since the reform program began 20 years ago, was accused of embezzling state funds, accepting bribes and abusing power.
Mr. Chen's exact whereabouts have been kept secret, as has his response to the charges.

HEADLINE: Students Hear Clinton Tell Of Priorities For the Fall

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNETT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 9

 BODY:
Declaring the economic and political drag of budget deficits to be a thing of the past, President Clinton moved on today to a broad agenda for the rest of the year, trying to summon support for a grab bag of causes from expanding trade to tightening pollution controls to passing wide-reaching laws to restrict tobacco.
Speaking to his second audience of students in two days, Mr. Clinton again called on Congress to support his plan for new national tests measured against voluntary standards in reading and math. 
 Mr. Clinton also threatened today to direct "the full glare of public light" toward any senators who try to block legislation to tighten campaign finance laws. But even as he spoke this afternoon about the peril of money in politics and a Senate committee sharply questioned a former top Democratic official about fund-raising, Mr. Clinton planned to attend two dinners tonight to raise $550,000 for the Democratic National Committee.
Addressing the students and faculty of American University here, Mr. Clinton invoked John F. Kennedy's vision of a world free from the cold war, articulated 34 years ago at the same university.
"It is up to you and to me and to our fellow Americans to imagine what the 21st century will be, and then to do what is necessary to make that vision a reality for all our people," he said.
Mr. Clinton addressed topics as open-ended as whether the rush of technology could leave citizens "each with our own Web page, but linked by few human bonds of community." But he also raised more specific matters, urging for the first time in weeks that his nominee for Ambassador to Mexico, William F. Weld, receive a hearing before the Senate Foreign Relations Committee.
Mr. Clinton assured his college audience that Social Security would survive to benefit them, and pledged in the next three months to appoint members of a new commission to study Medicare. He also called on Congress to take this "historic opportunity" to pass "sweeping legislation that focuses first and foremost on reducing smoking among young people."
The President was raucously received by some 4,000 students and faculty members packed into a basketball gymnasium, and flashbulbs pulsed from the bleachers throughout his 41-minute address. Like most of the President's other major addresses this year, the speech today divided into the triad of "opportunity, responsibility, community, " familiar from his 1996 campaign.
One senior aide billed the address, which Mr. Clinton worked on in the last two weeks of his vacation, as a "back to work, back to school, America's back" speech. And Mr. Clinton provided a remarkably upbeat assessment of the nation's health, pointing to low inflation and unemployment as the products of an economy so robust that "many of our poorest urban and rural communities are in a springtime of renewal."
He lavishly praised the recent agreement to balance the budget by 2002.
"Now, after years in which the deficit dominated our politics and dampened our economy, America finally has lifted that burden from the next generation," Mr. Clinton said. "After years in which the two parties seemed often as tired and trapped as punch-drunk fighters in a ring getting smaller and smaller, finally we found a way for Democrats and Republicans to work together for the national interest."
After he turned to foreign policy, however, Mr. Clinton sounded slightly defensive as he described his plans to meet here later this fall with President Jiang Zemin of China. He called the meeting "a chance for us to address candidly and face-to-face our differences on issues like human rights and religious freedom."
He said that "sitting down together across the table is far more likely to produce progress than pointing fingers across the Pacific."
Linking free trade with the growth of democracy, Mr. Clinton called for expanded trade with Asia and other parts of the world. On Wednesday he plans to announce a campaign to persuade Congress to increase his powers to negotiate trade agreements.
For the first time since his address to the United Nations on June 26, Mr. Clinton returned to the subject of global climate change. He is trying to build public support for reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other gases before a summit on climate change in December in Japan.
Mr. Clinton warned that, if it is not checked, climate change could cause flooding in southern Florida and Louisiana over the next 50 years, and he said Americans could take cost-free steps to cut emissions of gases that contribute to climatic warming.
"We could reduce them 20 percent tomorrow with technology that is already available at no cost if we just changed the way we do things," Mr. Clinton said, but offering no specific suggestions.
His aides said today that they could not determine the source of his 20 percent figure, but that he was referring to measures like much more widespread use of refrigerators and light bulbs that require less electricity.
While the Senate Governmental Affairs Committee continued today to investigate the price of access to politicians, including the President, Mr. Clinton turned that subject around, saying the primary cause of the mounting cost of campaigns was "the cost of access to you, the voters." He called for free or reduced advertising time for politicians.
Mr. Clinton repeated his support for campaign finance legislation sponsored by Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, and Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, saying, "Every year I have been President, I have supported a good campaign finance reform bill."
Under the McCain-Feingold bill, much of the money Mr. Clinton planned to raise at the events tonight -- the unlimited donations to parties classified as "soft money" -- would be illegal. Michael D. McCurry, the White House press secretary, wearily repeated today that the Democrats would not "unilaterally disarm" by abandoning soft money.
"We'll continue to try to change the rules even as we try to compete effectively under the rules," Mr. McCurry said.

HEADLINE: RACE FOR CITY HALL: THE OVERVIEW;
MESSINGER FACES SHARPTON IN SEPT. 23 MAYORAL RUNOFF; DEMOCRATIC TURNOUT LIGHT

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Ruth W. Messinger was forced last night into a runoff for the Democratic mayoral nomination with the Rev. Al Sharpton, as a low voter turnout in a three-way race, combined with a strong performance by Mr. Sharpton, dashed her hope for a jubilant primary night sendoff into the fall campaign.
With all 5,627 precincts reporting, Ms. Messinger had 155,913 votes or 39 percent, to 126,799 votes or 32 percent, for Mr. Sharpton. The third major candidate in the race, Councilman Sal F. Albanese, had 83,402 votes, or 21 percent. 
 Under state law, a candidate in a mayoral primary is required to win 40 percent of the vote to capture the nomination. The runoff, to be held on Sept. 23, will be the first Democratic runoff since 1977, when Edward I. Koch defeated Mario M. Cuomo.
Ms. Messinger's aides attributed the result last night to the case of Abner Louima, the Haitian immigrant who prosecutors said was assaulted while in police custody in Brooklyn on Aug. 9. Mr. Sharpton -- who had nowhere near the organization or financial resources of Ms. Messinger or Mr. Albanese -- quickly identified his campaign with the Louima case, and Ms. Messinger's aides pointed to Mr. Sharpton's victory in Brooklyn as proof of the success of that strategy.
But Ms. Messinger was also hurt by Mr. Albanese's healthy showing, which interviews suggested drew support away from Ms. Messinger, and from what may have been the worst voter turnout in a Democratic primary since World War II. Only 395,395 of the 2,246,987 registered Democrats voted, about 18 percent.
Mr. Sharpton, beaming in the brightest spotlight he has enjoyed in a high-profile career as a protest leader and civil-rights advocate, pledged to adhere to the traditional values of his party. In an energetic, televised speech to supporters last night, he also scolded Democrats who he said had sought to abandon those values.
"This is our day. This is our time. I can fly! I can fly! I can fly!" Mr. Sharpton declared exuberantly, repeating the words of the popular song, "I Believe I Can Fly," by R. Kelly, the hip-hop artist, which he plays in his car, in his home and at most campaign stops.
Turning his attention to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani -- who has until now refused to engage Mr. Sharpton in any debate -- the candidate declared: "Whatever skirmish Ms. Messinger and I have, Mr. Giuliani, at the end of the skirmish, we're coming to City Hall and one of us is going to take your seat in 1997."
A few blocks away, Ms. Messinger, standing next to a glum David N. Dinkins in the ballroom of the Grand Hyatt, presented the outcome as just a small setback. "Well, friends, they never said this would be easy," she commented. There was a scattering of boos when she said that there would probably be a runoff. "We're going to have to win this the hard way, but win it we will,' she said.
Still, by any measure, the runoff appears to be a huge setback for Democrats seeking to unseat Mr. Giuliani. It will delay for two weeks the general election assault on Mr. Giuliani, forcing Ms. Messinger and Mr. Sharpton to devote resources against each other instead.
A runoff against Mr. Sharpton is likely to prove particularly uncomfortable for Ms. Messinger. She will now be forced to run head-on against a candidate with a strong following in some parts of the black electorate, but without alienating the black voters who are critical to any hope she has of defeating Mr. Giuliani.
The runoff is also likely to complicate Ms. Messinger's efforts to position herself on the center of the political spectrum in anticipation of a race against Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Sharpton has repeatedly scolded Ms. Messinger for trying to win election by abandoning the liberal wing of the party. Until now, she has been able to ignore him, but that might be difficult starting today.
Ms. Messinger herself seemed unprepared for the outcome yesterday. Right up to the eve of the election, she had been predicting that she would not only avoid a runoff but win easily. She in effect raised expectations for herself, which made her showing last night appear even more damaging. Mr. Sharpton's showing, on the other hand, was almost exactly what he predicted it would be.
There were two other candidates on the ballot: Eric Ruano-Melendez, who received 18,940 votes, or 5 percent, and Roland Rogers, with 11,061 votes, or 3 percent.
Ms. Messinger was almost certainly hurt by the presence of Mr. Albanese on the ballot. Still, her performance was a startling setback for a woman who has been a fixture on New York's political scene since she emerged on the Upper West Side 25 years ago, running first for school board, then for the City Council and then, in 1989, for Manhattan borough president. Her history, base of support and fund-raising ability had led Democratic leaders across the city to view her as the almost certain nominee from the day Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx Borough President, dropped out of the mayoral race in early May.
Even before the polls closed, Democratic leaders across the city were criticizing the campaign Ms. Messinger and her advisers had run as they began seeing signs of her defeat.
In particular, they were critical of one central tactical decision by the Messinger campaign: to forgo the heavy "get out the vote" operation that has always been integral to winning primary elections in this city. The campaign instead devoted its resources to a television advertisement. And that ad spoke only about what Ms. Messinger had presumed would be her contest with Mr. Giuliani -- thereby not even alerting her supporters to yesterday's vote.
Influential Democrats in Ms. Messinger's own neighborhood, reporting during the day on signs of duress in her backyard, said they had been constantly frustrated in their attempts to persuade her staff to turn its attention to what is known as street campaigning. "All we got on the West Side was 150 pieces of literature on Saturday," one Democrat supporting Ms. Messinger said last night. "This has taken a media strategy to a new dimension."
The result last night underscored questions raised by several political analysts over Ms. Messinger's decision to staff her office with political professionals who had little or no experience in New York. Her campaign manager, Jim Andrews, is from Chicago; her media consultant, Mandy Grunwald, is from Washington, though her clients include Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan.
The difficulties of the comparatively well-financed Messinger campaign seem all the more stark when put up against the bare-bones campaign waged by Mr. Sharpton that has forced Ms. Messinger into this position. He broadcast no television advertisements, hired no campaign consultants and did not retain a media adviser. Instead, he adhered to a relentless schedule of campaigning across the city.
And he raised so little money that he could not even meet the $250,000 threshold for qualifying for city campaign finance money.
But Mr. Sharpton's campaign benefited from the Louima case, as evidenced by the vote in Brooklyn. And he also may have been helped by the primary for Manhattan borough president. Democrats said there was a high turnout in black communities for C. Virginia Fields, who won the Democratic nomination yesterday.
Beyond that, Mr. Sharpton offered what many Democrats saw as a far more extensive -- and, from a Democratic perspective, traditional -- view of what he thought the party was about. He repeatedly criticized Democrats who moved to the center, arguing that the party should not abandon its traditional position of helping the poor and oppressed.
Mr. Sharpton discussed that last night, taking full advantage of his suddenly huge platform to present his view of the Democratic Party. But he also took care, at least initially, to frame his challenge as one to Mr. Giuliani, rather than Ms. Messinger.
"Ruth Messinger is not the loser at all tonight," Mr. Sharpton said. "The real loser is Rudy Giuliani." Addressing his remarks to Mr. Giuliani, Mr. Sharpton said: "You will not be able to ignore the issues and the constituency that I've tried to represent. Those days are over. The issues of unemployment and police brutality and schools' not working are on the front burner. And you can run, Rudy, but you can't hide."
Ms. Messinger has framed her campaign around the condition of the schools, which she says have deteriorated under Mr. Giuliani's watch. She visited a public school yesterday, before the polls closed, and spoke of the issue again last night.
But mostly, Ms. Messinger seemed to be trying to reassure her supporters that the results last night were nothing more than a small setback, and not the end of what even her own friends had come to see as a troubled campaign. In doing so, she for perhaps the first time acknowledged the existence of strong opponents for the nomination.
"Tonight, my friends, is just a first step," she said, smiling. "When I decided to run for Mayor, I knew that we would have a fight on my hands. A tough fight against a bully of a Mayor, and yes, a tough fight against my rivals in the Democratic party."
Mr. Albanese, speaking at his early concession speech, declined to say last night whom he would support in a runoff. He could barely disguise his disappointment.
"We campaigned for a year and half," he said after his concession speech. "We shook a lot of hands. But you have 8 million people in this city; you have 2.5 million registered voters. You have to get on the air. But we rallied a lot of people together around the same issues. It was a good campaign. I have no regrets about it."
Interviews with Democrats around the city yesterday suggested that many had decided to skip the primary because they had concluded that the candidates had simply said and done too little to motivate them. Others said they were not at all eager to throw Mayor Giuliani out of office, so why bother voting in the primary?
Sol Sobel, a 73-year-old lawyer, said he had never passed up an opportunity to vote in a Democratic primary. Until now.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
The Dollar Is Mixed as Dealers Await Japanese Trade Figures

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed against other leading currencies yesterday as traders awaited the release of Japanese trade figures amid rising tensions with the United States.
The dollar rose narrowly against the yen, but traders seemed hesitant to make major moves after a plunge on Tuesday caused by concern about growing Japanese exports. 
 Strong German economic data pushed the dollar lower yesterday against the mark.
In late New York trading, the dollar was quoted at 119.31 yen, up from 118.93 late Tuesday. It fetched 1.7990 marks, down from 1.8135. The British pound eased to $1.5850, from $1.5881.
The slight rebound against the yen came after the dollar suffered its biggest one-day drop in a month. The plunge was caused by remarks from Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who said the United States was worried that Japan would rely too heavily on exports for an economic rebound, widening its trade surplus.
The Japanese are to report their current-account balance for July today, and currency traders expected it to show growth in the surplus.
The dollar was also held back by nervousness about a coming meeting of finance officials from the Group of Seven industrial nations, said Christopher Low of HSBC Securities in New York. "There is a fear that the Treasury may resort to intervention to push the dollar down if they're not successful in getting at least some of their trade goals," Mr. Low said.
A higher dollar worsens the trade rift between the United States and Japan by making American exports more expensive and Japanese goods cheaper. The dollar had been rising for the last two weeks amid weak Japanese economic data.
Traders also sold yen yesterday for marks and Swiss francs, which indirectly helped the dollar strengthen against the yen, said Bob Houck of Norwest Bank in Minneapolis.
The mark's strength against the yen contributed to mark gains against the dollar -- something bolstered by German reports of stronger growth in the second-quarter gross domestic product. The prospect of further gains by the mark seemed limited, analysts said, adding that it was not clear the German central bank would raise interest rates despite the stronger growth.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Some say no to a high-powered drive to revamp patent law.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
WITH the blessing of a coalition of large, technology-driven corporations, the Clinton Administration and some senior members of Congress are pressing for a makeover of American patent law. "We're starved for resources and shackled by regulation," argued Bruce A. Lehman, Commissioner of the United States Patent and Trademark Office.
But they will not get far if Franco Modigliani, a Nobel Prize-winning economist at M.I.T. as well as an inventor, has the last word on the subject. Casting himself as David to the establishment Goliath, he has organized an open letter to the Senate signed by 20 American Nobel laureates in chemistry, physics and medicine as well as economics. It decries the rush to judgment against "our time tested patent system" and warns that the proposed changes "would sap the very spirit of that wonderful institution." 
 Whether he's right is an open question. But the publicity is likely to improve the odds of stopping the legislative juggernaut, which has been slowed only by a small lobby of independent inventors and some right-wing Congressmen suspicious of anything the Clinton Administration favors.
From economists' perspective, the key tension is the need to foster innovation without inhibiting the diffusion of new technology. Thus, the "optimal" patent system gives inventors strong incentives to invent -- but not to slow adaptation by charging too much or blocking licensing.
The catch, of course, is that nobody knows how to get from here to there. And much of the controversy over the Senate bill comes from the reality that the actual effect of the proposals can't be predicted with much confidence.
The bill, sponsored by the chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Senator Orrin Hatch, would require all patent applications to be disclosed publicly within 18 months rather than when the patent is issued. It would allow challenges to patents -- the jargon is "re-examination" -- under relatively informal administrative procedures. And it would grant limited "prior use" rights to companies that had developed the technology independently but failed to apply for a patent.
Last but hardly least, it would make the Patent Office an independent Government corporation, a variation on the model of the Post Office.
Mr. Lehman insists that the first two provisions would minimize duplicate research -- and subsequent litigation. But Steven Shore, president of the Alliance for American Innovation, the small-inventors' lobby formed to oppose the bill, sees darker implications. "The changes would expose the little guy to new legal challenges, favoring multinationals with deep pockets," he argued.
The debate over "prior use" rights offers a little more to hold onto, but is still apt to leave all but the most dedicated C-Span devotees scratching their heads. Herbert Wamsley, executive director of Intellectual Property Owners, a lobbying arm for big business, calls the provision a "compromise" that minimizes grounds for litigation between patent holders and those who developed similar technology in tandem but chose to keep it secret.
Mr. Modigliani views it as an invitation to substitute trade secrets -- like the recipe for Coke -- for public patents as a means of protecting intellectual property. Reducing the incentive to patent ideas, he argues, is antithetical to society's interest in their rapid dissemination.
Paul A. Samuelson, a fellow Nobel laureate and economist, agrees. "Prior use exemptions weaken the thrust of patent protection," he said.
Easily lost in this fierce fight is the revolutionary idea of corporatizing the Patent Office. The Clinton Administration has made it the centerpiece of Vice President Al Gore's reinvention-of-government initiative. The idea, simply stated, is to leave the agency under the indirect control of the Secretary of Commerce but grant it broad flexibility in administration and personnel.
According to Commissioner Lehman, this would make it possible to run the agency like the skilled service business it resembles. "We train a patent examiner for years in an area like biotechnology," Mr. Lehman lamented, only to lose him to a higher-paid job in private industry.
By the same token, Mr. Lehman wants the flexibility to short-circuit Government procurement policies, especially in information technology. The sad tale of the Federal Aviation Administration's two-decade odyssey in modernizing the air traffic control system comes to mind.
The fact that change is largely driven by big business doesn't necessarily mean that it is bad for smaller business or the public. On the other hand, there is little doubt that many inventors really are convinced that politicians are selling them out for a mess of campaign contributions.
Probably the most convincing argument Mr. Modigliani and friends make is that the highly technical debate has not been given a proper airing. "Lighting a fire with the public can't be a bad thing," Mr. Samuelson allowed.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Heavy Supply Keeps Bonds On Defensive

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities remained depressed for a second day yesterday, as market sentiment remained negative before tomorrow's reports on retail and manufacturing data for last month.
The volume of corporate and international supply rolling into the market -- $15 billion this week and perhaps a similar amount next week -- helped keep traders on the defensive. Selling was concentrated in securities with long maturities, and there was some buying at the short end. 
 The benchmark 30-year bond dropped 12/32, to a price of 96 13/32, pushing the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, to 6.65 percent, from 6.62 percent on Tuesday.
Dave Shabelman, Treasury market analyst for Standard & Poor's MMS, a market research and analysis unit in San Francisco, said that with little economic data available yesterday, bears seized control of trading in the long bond because of concerns that the retail sales report would be strong, raising the possibility of inflation. "What the market is doing is pricing in the additional risk of a stronger-than-expected number," Mr. Shabelman said.
Mr. Shabelman also said the weakness in the early morning smacked of what he called "stop hunting," in which there are certain technical levels at which investors have given orders to either sell to stop losses or to establish defensive positions.
Prices were supported somewhat by a move by the Federal Reserve to buy coupons. The market had anticipated, but then given up hope of, such a move, in which the Fed buys securities for its own account. The central bank bought coupons dated from March 31, 1998, through Aug. 31, 1999.
But that was not enough to offset the negative effect of the flood of new supply. Among the debt issues priced yesterday was a $1.25 billion deal by ICI Wilmington Inc. that is guaranteed by the parent, Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain. It was offered in three parts, as underwriters led by Goldman. Sachs & Company priced $250 million of 5-year notes to yield 6.755 percent, $750 million of 7-year notes yielding 6.955 percent and $250 million of 10-year notes yielding 7.063 percent.
Also, Petroleos Mexicanos, the Mexican state-owned oil company, started selling $1 billion in bonds. In the first part, the oil concern is selling $600 million in bonds due in about 10 years, at a price to yield 250 to 255 basis points more than a comparable government security. It is also selling $400 million of bonds with a maturity of about 30 years, to yield about 280 to 285 basis points more than a comparable government security. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Jack Ablin, executive vice president at Barnett Capital Advisors, said investor demand allowed the South Korean Development Bank to raise a debt offering through Lehman Brothers and J. P. Morgan to $1.5 billion from $1 billion.
"As little as six months ago Korea was a favorite among fixed-income investors; then, about two months ago, it was suddenly out of favor," Mr. Ablin said. "A lot had to do with problems in the Southeast Asian region. There were some highly visible bankruptcies amid an unstable political climate that also contributed to the Street's negative bias." The demand for the latest offering indicates that South Korea is perhaps back in favor, he said.
The offering consists of $900 million of four-year bonds at a price to yield 98 basis points over a comparable Treasury, and $600 million of seven-year bonds at 115 basis points above Treasury.
